HEADLINE: Finding a Trend Amid the Calm

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
With the Treasury market apparently safely back in its tight trading range after recent reassuring news on inflation, traders and portfolio managers are wondering how to play the market.
Not too many money managers want to bet right now that yields, either long or short, will move sharply lower soon. 
 Short-term rates are expected to be steady or higher because of the belief that the next policy change by the Federal Reserve will be to raise the Federal funds rate, the interest rate the central bank uses to implement monetary policy. The yield on the two-year Treasury note closed at 4.12 percent Friday, up from 4.03 a month ago.
 
Weighing the Variables

 
 Long-term rates are not expected to burst above 7 percent. But if the economy turns out to be growing at a 3 percent annual rate in the second quarter and is holding on to that trend in the summer, it may be difficult to test new lows soon. The yield on the 30-year bond finished at 6.80 percent Friday, down from 7.02 percent a month ago.
All this does not mean that the market lacks a trend that can be played. What many people are betting on now is a flattening of the yield curve.
Flattening occurs when the spread narrows between the yield on the 2-year Treasury note and the 30-year bond. This means that the price performance of the bond is better than that of the note.
The spread -- 2.68 percentage points Friday, down from 2.99 percentage points a month ago -- can narrow in several ways. Short-term yields can rise and long rates hold steady. Long-term rates can fall. Or there can be a combination of both.
 
Devising a Strategy
 Dung Vu, a managing director at Core State Investment Advisers in Philadelphia, believes this is the trend to play. A normal way to do this is to sell two-year notes short and to buy bonds. As the spread narrows, the long-term securities give a better return.
But Mr. Vu recommends another way: buying zero-coupon bonds. These bonds are sold way below face value because no interest is paid. Instead, the investor receives the full face value of the bond when it matures.
The price of zero-coupon bonds is highly volatile, so while they expose the investor to greater risk of loss, they also offer much more gain than regular interest-paying bonds if the yield curve does flatten.
Mr. Vu said the return from zero-coupon bonds could be better than from regular bonds even if the flattening of the yield curve occurs, because short-term rates rise while long rates remain steady. And that kind of flattening from the bottom would be the immediate response if the Federal Reserve raised interest rates.
A rise in short-term rates would give a small upward push to the yields on 10-year notes. Based on an analysis of the relationship of zero-coupon bonds and the spread between 10- and 30-year Treasuries, the value of the zero-coupon bond rises if this happens.
The gain from the zero-coupon strategy is even better if the flattening of the yield curve comes from the top down, with the yield on the 30-year bond falling.
Gerald A. Guild, manager of fixed- income trading at Advest Inc., said a narrowing of the yield curve by half a percentage point, combined with a decline of half a percentage point in the yield on 30-year bonds over the next year, would produce a 31 percent return for the holder of a 20-year zero-coupon bond.
But the return for a holder of a 30-year interest-paying bond, counting the interest and the price rise, would be 12 percent.
This strategy is a mistake if the yield curve steepens with the spread between the 2-year and 30-year widening and if rates across the board move higher without the spread changing. A jump of one percentage point in the yield on the 30-year bond would mean a 9 percent loss.
But the fundamentals in the market and the outlook seem to indicate that the likeliest trend is for a flattening of the yield curve. Legislative approval of President Clinton's deficit-reduction plan would at least steady long-term rates, if not push them lower. The plan would raise hopes for a declining deficit while the tax increases would slow consumer spending and keep the economy from picking up the kind of speed that would raise inflation fears.
The coming cut in the issuance of 30-year bonds by the Treasury, a move that should begin to have an impact after the August auction, should also help. And the leaning of the Fed toward higher interest rates should keep upward pressure on short-term interest rates.
 
Trump Bonds
 Why were money managers rushing to buy Donald J. Trump's junk bonds last week?
Margaret D. Patel, a senior vice president at Boston Security Counselors in Boston and a buyer of some of the bonds, has one explanation.
"Since we haven't felt pain in this type of paper for a couple of years people are ready to play again," she said.
Fears surrounding the junk bond market, which crashed at the end of the 1980's, have been eased by the bonds' good performance over the last two years. And portfolio managers have not failed to notice, she said, that "the best performers have been the most distressed securities."
But she also noted that the scooping up of the Trump bonds might be a warning sign for investors.
"People are willing to take more risk for a higher rate of return and that is a characteristic of a frothy market, a toppy market," she said.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
The Price of Weakness

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
When I asked Cyrus Vance how he was feeling, I meant it as a telephone formality. But his answer was about Bosnia. "Sad," he said.
President Clinton had just signaled that he might accept a three-way partition of Bosnia, allowing Serbs to keep the fruits of their aggression. In light of all that had happened, I asked, was that now the best that could be done? 
 "I wish we hadn't been put in a position," Mr. Vance replied, "where people say this is the best thing that can be done."
Did he mean that it would not have come to this if the United States had provided more forceful leadership?
"Yes, it took leadership," Mr. Vance said, "and I don't think we've demonstrated that."
But can partition at least stop the killing? I asked.
"I'm not at all sure that it can," Mr. Vance said. "I hope and pray that somehow we will get peace. But I don't know that the Muslims will go along with partition. They don't like it, and I understand why they don't."
Mr. Vance and Lord Owen, working together as mediators, tried to preserve Bosnia as a federal state with ethnic cantons. They warned against allowing destruction of a country that was internationally recognized and a member of the United Nations.
"Right from the beginning," Mr. Vance said, "we always said, 'There can be no partition. It's wrong. It's the equivalent of endorsing ethnic cleansing.' "
Coming from Cy Vance, a man of understatement, those were strong words: a cry of pain at the fact that the United States and its European allies have now essentially accepted the result of ethnic cleansing. Cities where Muslims were the majority or lived in peace with Serbs and Croats, often intermarried, will be Muslim-free, their historic mosques reduced to rubble.
Even Lord Owen has given up hope of saving much from the human and political disaster. He advised the Bosnian Government to "look very seriously" at partition, which would mean giving most of the land to Serbs and Croats, leaving a landlocked rump -- or perhaps some uncontiguous bits -- for the Muslims.
At a crucial point this spring, President Clinton failed to support the Vance-Owen plan, apparently believing that the cantonal arrangement would leave Bosnia too weak. He said he wanted to use air power against the Serbs, and lift the arms embargo on the Muslim victims.
But Mr. Clinton did not press his position on the Europeans: did not lead. When they said no, he gave up his proposal and agreed instead to a plan for United Nations forces to protect six Muslim "safe havens" in Bosnia. Having put down Vance-Owen as not strong enough, he opted for something distinctly weaker.
In the week since the safe haven plan was agreed in Washington, it has turned out to be a bitter joke. The Serbs, undeterred, have devastated one of the supposed havens, Gorazde, killing many refugees. They have resumed shelling Sarajevo. The United Nations has had difficulty finding any troops for the supposed protective role.
The safe haven plan is in fact nothing more than a Western cave-in to the aggressors. The havens will be, at best, overcrowded refugee camps with no viable economic life. Serbian forces, not disarmed, will still surround them. And U.N. relief convoys will still have to bargain with Serbian gunmen for permission to go through.
Partition would complete Serbian humiliation of the West, and especially of the United States. The Serbs will have had their way not only in Bosnia but in Croatia, where Serbian militia hold 20 percent of the country. The ugliest elements in Serbian political life, modern-day Fascists, will have been proved right in calling America a paper tiger.
President Clinton inherited an appalling problem because of George Bush's weakness on Yugoslavia. But he made it worse -- dramatized the weakness -- by calling for stronger action and then giving up. The precedent is a terrible one, for other areas of ethnic tension and for American prestige.
His political advisers urge Mr. Clinton to avoid involvement. Americans didn't want it, they said. But the failure to lead on this painful problem -- the failure to act against murderous aggression -- will haunt Bill Clinton for the rest of his political life.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Stop the Roller Coaster

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
We have to cut out the business of pulling Bill Clinton up by the roots every week to see how he's doing.
"Another Failed Presidency"; "Incredible Shrinking President"; "What Went Wrong?" America went to the pollsters and delivered a ringing vote of no confidence; if this were Japan, we'd be holding new elections. 
 But wait -- "What a difference a week makes" gushes a New York Times editorial. Two press conferences in three days; Senate Democrats spare Clinton from ignominious defeat on his tax bill and go along on an Incumbents' Protection Campaign Subsidy; seven days go by without a White House blunder.
Up we go on the roller coaster clinging to the Comeback Kid. Hot after a fresh lead, we flagellate each other for so hastily despising the Only President We've Got; we find a poll showing he's bottomed out; we marvel at the new maturity shown by a President whose message to Congress is now an other-directed "do it your way -- where do I sign?"
The broken-field runner in the Oval Office (mixed metaphors are allowed when the stately pendulum turns into a propeller) encourages this man-to-media coverage. The First Clinton Administration, marked by the surprise leftward lurch, is presumably over; the Second Clinton Administration, or S.C.A., is upon us; centrism is in the saddle, its outriders focus and programmed self-confidence, its lodestar the changeability of change.
Can't we get off this symbiotic roller coaster and try something easier on the stomach, like the old-fashioned, non-interlaced .28 dot pitch merry-go-round? Let others be with-it; this contrarian department will be determinedly without-it, at least until such time as the long view becomes the in thing.
Here are three real-world developments that are more reliable indicators of direction than any barking from the Presidential seal:
1. Dennis ("Strongly Condemn Israel") Ross, James Baker's closest adviser on the Middle East -- supposedly held over for a few months in the transition -- has been appointed Mr. Clinton's man in charge of imposing a settlement in the Arab-Israeli talks. This is called "change."
Mr. Ross's Bakeresque advice this year was to pressure the Saudis to resume their financial support of the P.L.O., suspended after Yasir Arafat's avid backing of Saddam Hussein; as that bribe was extracted, Arafat permitted the Washington talks to resume. If Mr. Ross is the "full partner" in the negotiations, can a P.L.O.-dominated state on the West Bank be far behind -- and has Israel been told that this is the ordained outcome?
2. When the Senate Finance Committee Democrats slipped in a capital gains tax increase as part of their revised economic plan, President Clinton responded with an incredibly passive "let's see what comes out of the conference report."
Reducing rather than raising that tax would encourage investors to take long-held gains, thereby increasing tax revenues; but raising it with a 10 percent surcharge would do the opposite, increasing the deficit while putting a new drag on investment. Bill Clinton has no position on this issue other than supine; could it be he never met a tax he didn't like?
3. The Criminal Division of the Department of Justice -- which should be the heart of U.S. law enforcement -- has gone headless for five months. Why? Primarily because Bruce Lindsey, the Clinton crony in charge of personally-loyal personnel, was unable to resolve a dispute between the First Lady's First Friend, Susan Thomases, and Attorney General de jure Janet Reno.
Ms. Thomases wanted the plum to go to one of her New York law partners; Ms. Reno, already surrounded by Clintonians, wants a less well-connected prosecutor. Meanwhile, Federal law enforcement suffers as embarrassing investigations are shut down; doesn't anybody care?
These are the choices and decision-duckings that get administrations in trouble. Proclaiming a new centrism is fine; bringing in new old hands is useful; compromising is often necessary; postponing health reform by a year is realistic.
But like God and the Devil, governing is in the details. Although items like these do not cause polls to fluctuate or pundits to switch thumbs, they contribute to the voters' cumulative, long-term judgment. They do not power the roller coaster of trend-addicts demanding their weekly fix of fresh angles; all they do is determine whether a Presidency stumbles along or settles down.

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Study on Soviet-Era A-Plants Says Replacement Is Feasible

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, June 21

 BODY:
A confidential report on nuclear energy in the former Soviet bloc says it would be economically feasible to close 25 of the most dangerous nuclear reactors during the next few years and replace them with gas-fired power plants.
But the report says the former Communist countries oppose such a plan and want to keep their nuclear plants going as long as possible, a choice that could prove more dangerous and costlier for the West. 
 The report, drawn up by the World Bank and by the International Energy Agency in Paris, is to be presented to President Clinton and the leaders of six other major industrial democracies at their summit talks in Tokyo.
 
Attractions of Nuclear Power
 Until now, both Eastern and Western specialists have maintained that nuclear reactors, while posing threats, were indispensable because a number of former Communist countries were heavily dependent on nuclear-generated electricity.
Russia, which will require almost half of the West's multibillion-dollar plan to improve nuclear safety, insists on nuclear energy because it wants to reserve its natural gas supplies for export in order to earn hard currency, the report says. Other former Communist countries resist importing natural gas because such imports are more expensive than nuclear energy.
The report was ordered by the Group of Seven at their last summit meeting, in Munich in July 1992, when they called for extensive Western contributions to alleviate the serious threat of nuclear accidents in the former Soviet bloc. The leaders meeting in Tokyo are expected to discuss the strategies laid out in the World Bank report.
 
High and Low Estimates
 The report, which is dated March 1993 and is to be updated in July, estimates that $18 billion will be needed between 1993 and 2000 if the "higher-risk nuclear plants" are shut down as soon as possible and replaced by gas-fired plants; the less dangerous nuclear plants would be refitted with modern safety features. The report says it would be technically feasible to do this "by the mid-1990's."
Alternatively, the report says, it will cost about $24 billion to improve "all the higher-risk and other nuclear plants" to keep them operating "until the end of their planned design life," and to finish those under construction.
For each alternative, the huge investments now estimated are considerably higher than those discussed in Munich, where Germany said such a program would cost about $9 billion and the United States suggested that costs would range between $11 billion and $20 billion.
The study refers to the cost of meeting electricity needs in only six countries -- Russia, Ukraine, Armenia, Lithuania, Bulgaria and Slovakia -- because these six have the reactors that Western experts have repeatedly described as the most dangerous.
The report represents the first time that Western economists and energy experts have officially maintained that the former Soviet bloc could shut a number of nuclear reactors and find quick alternatives without paralyzing their economies.
"This dispels the myth that Eastern Europe would freeze in the dark if their nuclear power is shut down," said Anthony Froggatt, of Greenpeace International, which first made the confidential report available.
 
The Economies of Gas
 Building new gas-fired plants, the report says, can be done much faster than building or outfitting nuclear plants with safety standards acceptable in the West. And, it says, gas-fired plants "can be brought on stream in smaller slices versus the lumpiness of large-scale nuclear plants."
Because future demand is uncertain, enormous investments such as those needed for new nuclear plants thus "present additional investment risks."
But in the six countries concerned, it says, various reasons "lead many decision makers to resist a gas-oriented scenario." Among them, it says, decision makers in the East have "different attitudes" -- meaning less concern -- about the safety risks of various designs.
In addition, the report says, "In Russia, there is a widely held view that gas should be accorded priority for export." In other countries, "reliance on additional gas-fired plants means larger fuel imports."
The World Bank report says former Soviet bloc countries also worry about job losses if nuclear plants are shut down or nuclear investments are cut back. For example, Lithuania fears losing earnings from electricity exports if it shuts down its two Chernobyl-type reactors, which the West regards as highly unsafe.
Moreover, the report says, if the high-risk nuclear reactors are shut down in the next few years, the six countries will have to spend a total of $3 billion more annually on fossil fuel, mainly natural gas. About half of this additional cost would be paid by Russia and about one-fourth by Ukraine.
But even if countries have to spend such large amounts on fuel, the report suggests, this is safer than spending such amounts on fixing up risky nuclear plants.
 
The Plants Involved
 The reactors that have caused most concern make up 7 percent of the region's generating capacity.
They involve two types: one is the large graphite reactor of the kind that exploded in Chernobyl, of which there are 15 operating. The other is the oldest type of the pressurized water reactor known as VVER 440-230. Ten of these early reactors are still in operation. Armenia, citing safety reasons, closed its reactors of this type when it became independent, in December 1991.
In the last two years, the International Atomic Energy Agency has called for the closing of the the reactors that pose the most risk. A number of European countries, led by France and Germany, fear that a nuclear catastrophe would not only affect Europe but also worsen the political climate for the beleaguered nuclear industry.
But the full costs of providing the former Communist countries with safe energy are still unclear and estimates are preliminary, the report says. For example, the current plans do not calculate or include the cost of disposing of the reactors' nuclear fuel.
This month, the first funds from the Group of Seven's pledge to help improve the safety of the nuclear reactors were approved -- a grant of $28 million to improve the reactors at the Kozloduy plant in Bulgaria.
The nuclear-safety account set up by the Group of Seven has received pledges of $120 million, far short of the $700 million that the seven leaders estimated last year were needed for short-term safety measures.

HEADLINE: U.S. MAY LET HANOI GET I.M.F. FUNDING

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 21

 BODY:
President Clinton's senior foreign policy advisers have concluded that the Administration should no longer attempt to block loans to Hanoi from the International Monetary Fund, senior Administration officials said tonight. The recommendation could presage an easing of the relationship between the United States and Vietnam.
In a meeting last week, members of the National Security Council decided to recommend to the President that the United States raise no objections to a plan by France and Japan to pay more than $140 million in arrears that Hanoi owes to the fund. Such an action would free the monetary fund to approve new lending to Vietnam during its next board meeting in July. 
 Officials said tonight that no decision has been made by the President as yet. In addition, it is unclear whether Mr. Clinton's advisers have reached a consensus on whether to recommend that the United States end its 18-year-old trade embargo against Vietnam.
 
Subsidizing Vietnam
 Proponents of a rapprochement between the United States and Hanoi say that once the fund begins lending to Vietnam, it would be harder for the Administration to justify the continuation of a trade embargo. The extension of the fund's loans to Vietnam would mean that United States taxpayers would, in essence, be subsidizing Vietnam's economic development, but at the same time United States companies would be precluded from concluding contracts that are a part of that economic development.
Asked about the proposal, Secretary of State Warren Christopher would only say today that, "It's under intensive review, and hopefully we will be having a decision on that in the near future."
The Clinton Administration, citing Hanoi's increased cooperation in helping to determining the fate of 2,260 American servicemen who are unaccounted for from the war in Southeast Asia, had been strongly considering easing its opposition to new monetary fund loans to Vietnam when the lending agency met in April.
But, just prior to the meeting, a Harvard-based researcher, Stephen J. Morris, brought forward a document he discovered in the Russian archives alleging that Hanoi had many more Americans prisoners than it had acknowledged capturing.
 
Created a Sensation
 Though a number of specialists on the war say the Morris document contained a number of inaccuracies, it created such a sensation in Washington that the Administration was forced to postpone any plans it might have had in moving to allow the lending program.
Meanwhile, a bipartisan group headed by former Secretary of State Edmund Muskie came out today in favor of ending the embargo.
Following a trip to Vietnam in April, a majority of the 10-member delegation concluded that interests would best be served by lifting the embargo, Mr. Muskie said in a statement.
Earlier today, officials in Hanoi announced that Vietnam would apply for observer status, and later for membership, in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a world trade body.

HEADLINE: A Battle Between Cities May Scuttle Navy Base

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: INGLESIDE, Tex.

 BODY:
With its tiny fleet of rusty shrimp boats, screeching sea gulls and wind-blown resort homes, this small community on the muddy tidal flats of the Texas coast seems an unlikely battlefield in the bureaucratic wars over shrinking dollars for the military.
But as a result of voting by the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission beginning this week, the brand-new $440 million Naval Station Ingleside nearby may be ordered closed, victim of a sophisticated lobbying campaign in a tug-of-war whose stakes are thousands of jobs. 
 The lobbying campaign against Naval Station Ingleside focused on environmental concerns and was undertaken by a city half a continent away: Charleston, S.C., which, faced with the Defense Department's plans to shut down virtually all Navy operations there, responded in a way that demonstrates the increasingly effective strategies pursued by communities struggling to protect their economies from Pentagon cutbacks.
It appeared earlier this year that Ingleside had escaped the ax. The Pentagon's "hit list," the first step in a process by which the nation determines the military centers that are expendable in an era of tight budgets, had scheduled 43 major bases and 122 smaller installations for closing but had spared Naval Station Ingleside.
Indeed, the Navy planned for the base to become operational next month as the nation's center for mine warfare. Eventually it was to be home to 12,000 military and civilian workers and 25 mine-sweeping vessels, among them as many as eight ships to be moved from the Charleston ports that the Pentagon recommended be closed.
 
Charleston Fought Back
 But in the meantime Charleston, trying to save 18,000 jobs in its own backyard, had hit upon its strategy. Because operations at sprawling Navy bases like the one at Charleston are often so tightly linked, city officials believed that if they could save one, they might well save the others. And the most effective way to save the mine-warfare operations would be to demonstrate that Ingleside was unfit for them.
"It was a domino effect we were trying for," said Rik Dilgren, a former submarine commander who led the environmental research team that spearheaded Charleston's attack on Ingleside. "If we could save mine warfare for Charleston, we could save the Navy base, which would keep open the hospital there."
The result was a highly polished political and public relations campaign so effective that it may have killed not only Naval Station Ingleside but also two naval centers in the nearby Corpus Christi area.
"It's the classic zero-sum game," said Frank Mankiewicz, who was press secretary to Senator Robert F. Kennedy and who now, as a member of the public relations firm Hill & Knowlton, has Charleston as a client. "In order for someone to get off the base closure list, someone else has to get on it."
Charleston hired public relations specialists and Washington lawyers, and it formed eight technical research teams manned primarily by volunteers. The city was armed with a $1 million war chest and two General Accounting Office studies, ordered by the South Carolina Congressional delegation, that were critical of the Pentagon's base-consolidation process. And it spent $480,000 on consultants to help prepare a presentation that would be made to the base closure commission when the panel was ready to begin public hearings around the country.
By the time the commission met in Charleston on May 1, Barry Steinberg, a former chief environmental litigator for the Army, had carefully rehearsed the city's witnesses on environmental issues and the criteria by which the commission decides which bases should be closed. The witnesses told the commission that the Ingleside base was riddled with environmental hazards, a peril that Ingleside supporters vehemently deny.
In a slide presentation to the commission, Mr. Dilgren said the Ingleside base would threaten nine endangered species, including the sperm whale, the Kemp's Ridley sea turtle, Arctic falcons and the bald eagle. He also said wetlands dredging, required if the Navy's plans to expand the base were to be realized, would harm the Flower Gardens, a coral formation in the Gulf of Mexico.
Within weeks, the commission had added Ingleside and two other bases in the Corpus Christi area to the list of centers being considered for shutdown.
A commission spokesman, Tom Houston, said in a later interview that the panel had felt it only fair to consider Ingleside for closing once the questions about it had been raised, notwithstanding that "it's agonizing to hear these cities plead for their economic lives."
Charleston had spent months preparing for its day and a half of hearings before the commission. By contrast, the Corpus Christi region had to defend its bases in a two-hour session only 14 days after learning that they were threatened.
And the presentation went badly from the start. The commission's chairman, Jim Courter, a former Republican Congressman from New Jersey, stressed in his opening remarks that the panel was "fiercely independent" and "not rubber stamps for the Pentagon." But former Navy Secretary H. Lawrence Garrett 3d, Corpus Christi's prize witness, asked the commissioners to "give additional weight to the experience and judgment of the Navy's uniformed leaders," who, having already invested many millions of dollars in Naval Station Ingleside, clearly wanted it saved.
In other words, after being told that the commissioners were not a rubber stamp for the Pentagon, Mr. Garrett asked them to become precisely that. The commissioners immediately began interrupting witnesses with questions about the Ingleside base's environmental effects. A stormy exchange between one commission member, Hansford T. Johnson, and the Texas Land Commissioner, Garry Mauro, ended abruptly when Mr. Johnson pressed heatedly for answers regarding a required environmental permit and then cut off Mr. Mauro's reply. The assembled crowd gasped, then booed.
Environmental experts here say that none of Charleston's accusations about peril to wildlife are accurate. "There are no sperm whales in our area," said one such expert, Dr. Joe Mosely. "Ridley turtles nest 300 miles from here, not in Corpus Christi Bay. There are no bald eagles here. And, as to a dredging operation damaging the Flower Gardens, they're 200 miles away and wouldn't be affected."
Whether Charleston has been ultimately successful will not be certain until after the commission decides on a final base closure list, in voting that begins Wednesday. By law, President Clinton and Congress must accept all of the commission's list or none of it; no modifications are permitted.
Though he would not be specific about either Charleston or Ingleside, Mr. Courter said in an interview that some communities would necessarily face devastating economic news.
"We want to make sure the suit fits the man," he said of the commission's task. "We need the right size suit to support the force structure. Now, we're looking at a 30 to 40 percent defense function reduction in five years' time, so obviously the man is going on a diet. We need to tailor the suit to fit the man."

HEADLINE: Clinton Looks to Conference Panel to Restore Budget to His Liking

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 21

 BODY:
President Clinton and his top aides spent the day whipping up citizen support for his five-year, $500 billion budget package, but not entirely out of fear about its chances in the Senate.
To the contrary, Democrats are confident that the Senate will pass the plan after it is introduced on Wednesday.
They are less certain about their prospects in the legislative conference that follows, which promises to be a drawn-out effort to fuse the Senate's bill and the more liberal version that the House passed last month. 
 Neither the White House nor its supporters in Congress yet know how, or even whether, they can pull off such perilous surgery. In the House, many liberal Democrats held their noses and voted for Mr. Clinton's budget, even though it included what they considered unacceptable proposals to cut Medicare and to restrict spending on Federal benefits.
 
Areas of Contention
 Senate Democrats are preparing to pass a version that cuts Medicare and benefit programs further and removes the one tax break that liberals actually liked: an incentive for businesses to move into rundown areas.
It is not clear to some Democrats where the twain will ever meet.
"I'm optimistic that something can be worked out -- I don't know how -- that would allow us to support the President and his budget," said Representative Charles B. Rangel, a New York Democrat. "I can tell you right now that we will not be signing off on what we see coming from the Senate."
Mr. Rangel is both a leader of the 38-member Congressional Black Caucus and a likely member of the House-Senate committee that will wrangle over the two versions of the budget once a bill passes the Senate.
A senior Senate aide suggested that the arithmetic was no easier on that side of the Capitol. "Just look at how different these two packages are," he said. "Just look at how different the politics are on each side."
 
Paths Do Not Converge
 In a broad sense, the Senate and House both seem to have given the President pretty much what he asked for: a package that would reduce the growth of Federal debt by $500 billion through 1998, raise taxes on wealthier people and lower them on the poor, and snip mostly around the edges of popular Federal benefits like Social Security and Medicare.
But because the two chambers got there in distinctly different ways, a conference battle looms.
In the House, a bloc of liberal Democrats provided the tissue-thin six-vote margin to pass a budget very much like the one the President submitted last spring.
In the Senate, a bloc of conservative Democrats who hold the balance of power shaped a package with a more pro-business bent. The sticking points in conference bargaining are likely to be these three:
*An energy tax. Mr. Clinton proposed, and the House passed, a tax that fell on virtually all sources of energy, though unevenly, to raise $71.5 billion through 1998. Under pressure from oil and gas interests, among others, the Senate cut that to a $24 billion tax that falls almost totally on gasoline, diesel and kerosene for transportation.
*Social programs. Mr. Clinton proposed, and House liberals swallowed, a plan that would reduce the growth of Medicare spending by $50 billion over five years. The House version also greatly increased the earned-income tax credit for the working poor, by $28.6 billion, and raised spending for food stamps. The Senate cut Medicare by another $19 billion and pared back the earned-income credit by about a third, to $18.2 billion.
*Empowerment zones. Mr. Clinton and the House agreed to a scaled-back version of President George Bush's "enterprise zone" concept, under which businesses would be awarded tax breaks if they located in disadvantaged areas and employed people who lived in them. The Senate omitted the proposal.
 
A Shotgun Wedding
 "There is not a human being alive who can tell you what the outcome of the conference will be," the Senate's majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, said last week.
But the prospective merger of the Senate's pro-business program and the House's social-services agenda is being viewed by both sides with the sort of enthusiasm that might be reserved for a shotgun wedding of Adam Smith and Eleanor Roosevelt.
In radio interviews today in five major cities, Mr. Clinton repeatedly endorsed the House version of the budget plan and suggested that he and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen had worked to soften the flintier version now emerging in the Senate.
At a broadcast news conference last week, Mr. Clinton assailed politicians who he said would balance the budget on the backs of the poor and elderly, and he declared that he was drawing the line at further such changes in his economic proposals.
But in their appearances today, neither he nor Mr. Bentsen was quite ready to say just where that line is being drawn.
"We'll just have to see what comes out of the conference. I don't know what'll happen," Mr. Clinton said when asked whether he could live with the Senate's version of the energy tax.

HEADLINE: From Tumult, New Visions Of Japan Inc.

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 21

 BODY:
For four decades, Japan Inc. has been supported by a triad consisting of a single political party, a powerful bureaucracy and wealthy business organizations.
Now, one leg of the stool, the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, is on the verge of splintering and perhaps losing power, ending a period of political stability widely believed to have been conducive to business growth.
Reflecting the concern about this, the Tokyo stock market today suffered its sharpest drop this year, with the Nikkei average plummeting 592.11 points, or 3 percent, to 19,212.43.
 
Yen Is Also Weaker
 The Japanese yen was also pounded in Tokyo trading today, closing at 110.48 yen to the dollar, about 3 yen weaker than it closed on Friday, before legislators approved a no-confidence vote against Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa that will almost certainly drive him from office. 
 Despite the uncertainty, many executives here welcome what might evolve into a two-party or multiparty system.
"We were very happy that we have had a stable period in Government in the past 20 to 30 years, but it's been too long," said Hiroo Kinoshita, a senior managing director at the Sumitomo Corporation, the large trading company.
In business, there is a feeling that Japan's industrial strategy of control of business by Government and policies aimed at catching up to the West has succeeded as much as it can and that new strategies are needed.
Political reform, some say, could help speed needed business-related reforms like deregulation, lowering of land prices by improving supply, promotion of entrepreneurship and moves toward consumerism.
Business deregulation and consumerism in particular could also be good for America by making it easier for American companies to do business here.
 
'Constrained' Potential
 "The potential of the Japanese economy is obviously constrained by an old system that has lasted from the postwar period," said Haruo Shimada, professor of economics at Keio University. "Inability to reform itself will seriously undermine the flexibility of the Japanese economy."
In the short run, the turmoil sparked by Friday's rebellion will mean confusion in the economic area and a power vacuum. Important decisions, including those involved in trade negotiations with America and next month's Group of Seven meeting in Tokyo are likely to be delayed.
Beyond that, what happens will depend on how the political situation turns out. The Liberal Democratic Party might retain a majority after the July 18 elections for the lower house of Parliament.
But a faction of the party led by the former Finance Minister Tsutomu Hata and the power broker Ichiro Ozawa is planning to break away and start a new party. It is discussing forming a coalition with existing opposition parties, including the Japan Socialist Party. Ultimately, a two-party system or a system with coalition governments might evolve.
 
Socialists and Deficits
 One worry for business is that the Socialist Party, the largest opposition group, will end up gaining power. "In any country, Socialists are bad for business," said Kazuo Nukazawa, a managing director of Keidanren, Japan's most powerful business lobbying group, which will continue to support the Liberal Democrats.
Another potential problem, Mr. Nukazawa said, is that if there is a system of competing parties, each might try to win votes with spending programs that will drive Japan into a national budget deficit.
Still, Mr. Nukuzawa said that on the whole, Japan might be better off with two moderate parties because the one-party system has tended to breed corruption.
The three-legged stool has worked like this: Bureaucrats in powerful agencies like the Finance Ministry and the International Trade and Industry Ministry have had strong control over business. It is the bureaucrats who actually draw up most new laws and submit them to Parliament. The bureaucrats also interpret and enforce the laws.
But the politicians, meaning the leaders of the Liberal Democratic Party, influence the bureaucrats and make some big decisions like whether to send troops abroad or change the tax system. And businesses, particularly through lobbying groups like Keidanren, give contributions to the Liberal Democratic Party in order to gain some influence over the bureaucrats.
 
Builders and Farmers
 Two of the industries that contribute most to the Liberal Democratic Party are the construction industry and agriculture; these are two Japanese industries that are most protected by the Government.
The Liberal Democratic Party draws much of its support from farmers, who have voting power out of proportion to their relatively small number because voting districts were not adjusted as the nation became urbanized. Urban consumers pay high prices for some products, like produce and rice, because of bans on imports to support the farmers.
But if new parties come to the fore, analysts say, more attention will have to be paid to city dwellers, who make up the bulk of the population. That might make it more likely for laws to be passed to allow imports of agricultural products.
That could also speed adoption of policies to make more farmland available for development, easing high prices for land and housing. Lower land prices could also help make it less expensive for foreign companies to set up shop in Japan.
 
Thinning Red Tape
 Another potentially big change could be a weakening of the bureaucracy. Until now, the bureaucrats have gone on their course regardless of who happened to be in the Cabinet.
But the bureaucrats have thrived under a single-party system. If there are two parties that will alternate in power, the bureaucrats might have to repeatedly change course. "I think it will make the agencies weaker," said Taizo Yokoyama, a managing director at the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation and a former official at the International Trade and Industry Ministry.
Whatever happens, however, it is almost certain that change will be slow. "There's real evolution going on, but I don't think we're going to see a revolution," said Gregory W. Noble, assistant professor of political science at the University of California at Berkeley.
One reason for this is the opposition parties are not too different in their policies from the Liberal Democrats. Even the Socialist Party is not really antibusiness and has been drifting toward the center.
 
No Guarantee for U.S.
 Hopes that a Japan run a group other than the Liberal Democratic Party would help the United States could also prove to be wishful thinking.
The Socialist Party, for instance, is as staunchly opposed to opening up Japan's rice market as the Liberal Democratic Party is, if not more so.
Moreover, the political reform will sweep into power more quickly a new generation of leaders that is not as beholden to America as the generation that came of age during and immediately after World War II. That generation, which includes Prime Minister Miyazawa, feels obligated to America for the role it played in Japan's recovery from the war and has been willing at times to bend to meet American demands.
"We've had a credit running with the older generation," said James Abegglen, chairman of Gemini Consulting. "The last of that group just bit the dust. That credit line has just run out."

HEADLINE: New York City Census Profile Shows Stark Changes in Decade

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Even as real income rose in all but three of New York's neighborhoods in the 1980's, one of the city's poorest places -- Hunts Point in the Bronx -- grew poorer by 30 percent. On Staten Island, the most suburban borough, the number of foreign-born people increased four times faster than in the city as a whole. And the number of New Yorkers with college degrees increased more than 44 percent.
Fleshing out a stark profile, a new portrait of New York City drawn from the 1990 census reveals broad demographic changes along with striking contrasts in neighborhoods that have reinvented themselves to accommodate newcomers. 
 Immigration remade much of the city. In 1990, New Yorkers born abroad constituted a majority of the residents in five neighborhoods, compared with only one a decade before. Puerto Ricans, though barely constituting half of the Hispanic population, surpassed people of Italian and Irish heritage as the single largest ethnic group.
The statistical portrait prepared by the City Planning Commission offers a wealth of census data for all of the city's 59 community districts, areas created for purposes of planning and delivery of services.
The commission's data confirmed profound disparities between poor and rich and in educational attainment. Citywide, nearly 7 in 10 people 25 and older had high school degrees, but in 10 of the city's 59 community districts a majority of the adults were not high school graduates.
Over all, nearly 1 in 4 New Yorkers 25 or older -- 1.1 million in all -- had college degrees, compared with about 1 in 6, or 776,000, 10 years before. But the figure varies graphically by district: from nearly 2 in 3 on Manhattan's Upper East Side to fewer than 1 in 25 in the Bronx sections of Melrose, Mott Haven and Port Morris.
Some social and economic indicators showed perceptible improvement, but a portion of those gains may have evaporated since the census measured income four years ago. In three disparate neighborhoods -- Canarsie in Brooklyn, Tottenville on Staten Island and Hunts Point in the South Bronx -- the percentage of women working or looking for work had nearly doubled. Citywide, a majority of women were working or looking for work.
"Economics," Joseph Salvo, director of the Planning Department's Population Division, said of the trend. More families need two-earner couples to survive, he said, and more separated, divorced and unmarried women have to make ends meet on their own. The census also found that nearly half the city's renters spend more than 25 percent of their income on housing.
 
Vivid Differences
 If the overview is largely unsurprising, demographers are reveling in the details, which demonstrate how individual neighborhoods changed during the 1980's and how vividly many of them differ from each other.
In the South Bronx, which includes the only community districts in which inflation-adjusted income declined, 1 in 2 households were receiving public assistance. On the Upper East Side, 1 in 50 were. During the 1980's, the percentage of poor people dropped by 20 percent in Jamaica, Hollis and St. Albans, Queens, where more and more members of minority groups have graduated to the middle class. But in the Longwood and Hunts Point sections of the Bronx, the number of poor people leaped by 30 percent.
In Elmhurst and South Corona, Queens, more than 6 in 10 residents were born abroad and nearly half of the people 5 years old or more have trouble speaking English. In Chinatown and Washington Heights in Manhattan, Hunts Point in the Bronx and Williamsburg and Greenpoint in Brooklyn, 4 in 10 people did not speak English well.
Immigration changed virtually every neighborhood. In the southern half of Staten Island, the number of foreign-born people increased 43 percent, but only to 9 percent of the population. In neighborhoods flanking the Grand Concourse in the Bronx, the percentage of foreign-born people rose during the decade to 29 percent from 17 percent.
In Flatbush in Brooklyn, more than 1 in 3 people are of West Indian ancestry and Italians constitute seven-tenths of 1 percent of the population. In Bensonhurst and Bath Beach, Brooklyn, half the residents are of Italian origin and only three-tenths of 1 percent are West Indian.
Among the residents of Manhattan's Washington Heights section, more than 4 in 10 are Dominican. In Brooklyn's Sunset Park, the largest Hispanic group is Mexicans, who made up 3.5 percent of the population.
 
Dramatic Contrasts
 Contrasts between the South Bronx and the Upper East Side were most dramatic.
In Mott Haven, Melrose and Port Morris in the South Bronx, more than 1 in 4 households reported income of less than $5,000 a year and the median was $9,725 -- down from $11,191 a decade earlier in 1989 constant dollars. Nearly 6 in 10 renters spent more than 25 percent of their household income on rent. More than half lived below the poverty level, including nearly two-thirds of the people younger than age 18. And 63 percent of the people 25 and over had not graduated from high school.
In the South Bronx neighborhoods, more than 1 in 4 teen-agers between the ages of 16 and 19 are neither enrolled in school nor a high school graduate and among those, three-quarters are unemployed or not even looking for work. Nearly 1 in 5 of the employed people work for local government, while 2 in 3 of all workers depend on public transportation and more than 8 in 10 do not own a car.
Among the anomalies found by the census, 18 people, or one-tenth of 1 percent of the population in those Bronx neighborhoods, reported median household income of $150,000 or more a year and 187 said they owned three or more vehicles.
 
More High School Graduates
 On the Upper East Side, 3.2 percent of the households reported annual income of less than $5,000 and the median was $53,000 -- up from $37,383 in 1979. About 4 in 10 renters spent more than 25 percent of household income on rent. Fewer than 6 percent of the people are poor. Under 8 percent of those 25 and older were not high school graduates.
Fewer than 1 in 20 Upper East Side teen-agers between 16 and 19 are neither enrolled in school nor high school graduates. Fewer than 1 in 10 of the employed people work for local government. Urban living creates several common denominators, though: nearly 6 in 10 workers from the Upper East Side use public transportation and 7 in 10 have no car, while in the southern half of Staten Island, only 1 in 10 residents has no car.
Still, 19,705 households, or 16 percent, reported median income of $150,000 or more, and 702 residents reported owning three or more vehicles.
An analysis of the "Socioeconomic Profiles," said Richard L. Schaffer, director of the City Planning Department, shows that "new immigrant communities have emerged in parts of the city where older immigrant groups once resided."

HEADLINE: Blue-Chip Issues Edge Up in Dull Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks rose moderately yesterday in lackluster trading. But the broader market was mixed, displaying pockets of strength, as investors moved cautiously.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 16.05 points, to 3,510.82, with volume on the New York Stock Exchange at 223.7 million shares, down from the 300.5 million shares traded on Friday. 
 The broader Big Board composite index also gained, rising 1.25 points, to 246.19, with gaining issues outnumbering losing issues, 1,119 to 837. And the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks increased 2.54 points, to 446.22.
But the Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter issues fell 0.85 point, to 688.74, while the American Stock Exchange composite slipped 0.18 point, to 436.64, and the Russell 2000, a measure of smaller issues, lost 0.70 point, to 228.32.
Nike and Caterpillar weighed on the blue-chip indicators, keeping them from making major gains. Nike announced late Friday that it expected 1994 earnings to be well below estimates. Its stock fell 4 1/8 yesterday, to 57 7/8. In after-hours trading on Friday, the stock had plunged 5, to 62.
Caterpillar suffered from what traders said were reports that the company had indicated May orders in overseas markets were softer, even though the trend was not unexpected. Its shares were down as much as 3 yesterday, closing at 75 3/4, down 1 1/2.
Ricky Harrington, senior vice president and technical analyst with Interstate/Johnson Lane Inc., Charlotte, N.C., said yesterday's market was reflective of its selloff on Friday, when "triple witching" expirations of options and futures pulled the Dow down better than 27 points.
"Earnings forecast to the negative side by some of the larger companies like Apple and 3M have kept the market in a tight trading range over the past few weeks because interest rates are relatively stable and mutual funds are still with a bit of cash on hand and no alternative investments they can call attractive at this time," Mr. Harrington said.
General Motors increased its projection of 1993 domestic car and truck sales yesterday to 14 million from 13.7 million, based on an "improving market." Its stock jumped 1 1/4, to 43. Traders said the auto maker was also thought to be considering spinning off or selling its Electronic Data Systems unit.
Harry W. Laubscher, senior vice president and market analyst at Tucker Anthony, says his firm's objective is for G.M. stock at 44 or 45.
Pfizer fell 1 3/4, to 70 3/8, after Barbara Ryan, an analyst with Alex. Brown & Sons cut her rating on the stock to hold from buy. Traders said her office had cited Pfizer's growth as already having been discounted.
Shares of American Pacific fell 1 1/2, to 13 1/2. The company said a shareholder complaint had been filed against the chemical company and some of its officials contending that inadequate information was disclosed concering agreements with Thiokol, a major client.
Briggs & Stratton, the lawn mower engine manufacturer, was the subject of a report in Barron's that it may have earnings for the year ending June 30 that are higher than analysts' forecast of $4.40 to $4.50 a share. The stock jumped 2 1/2, to 63 7/8.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Against the Yen And Mark as a Rally Builds

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar surged by nearly a yen yesterday in an extension of Friday's powerful rally touched off by political uncertainty in Japan and economic stagnation in Germany.
The dollar's new bullish tone has put a halt to more than four months of appreciation in the Japanese yen, and traders expect the United States currency to rise even further this week as it breaks above key resistance levels. 
Gold was mostly lower on world markets. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for August delivery, the most active contract, declined $1.40 a troy ounce, to $371.10. The Republic National Bank quoted a late spot bid of $369.60 a troy ounce, off $1.40.
 
No-Confidence Vote
 On Friday, the dollar rose more than two yen and more than two pfennigs after Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan lost the support of members of his own party as many of them joined in a no-confidence vote in Parliament. He dissolved the lower house for early elections, a vote that is expected to be held in July.
The dollar continued to build on that momentum yesterday in Tokyo, where world currency trading starts its day. The dollar closed there at 110.48 yen, up 3.08 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 110.95 yen. By 4 P.M. in New York, the dollar fetched 110.65 yen, up from late Friday's 109.75 yen.
The dollar also gained new ground against the German mark. In European trading, the dollar broke above the key resistance level of 1.6850 marks to close at 1.6855 German marks, up from 1.6805 late Friday.
It continued to rise in New York before slipping somewhat in late trading to close at 1.6875 German marks, up from 1.6805 late Friday. The slight pullback apparently was due to traders cashing in on the dollar's run-up.
 
Interest Rates Favor Dollar
 Global interest rates also favor the dollar's appreciation. The Federal Reserve has indicated its willingness to raise interest rates to combat inflation, if necessary. Higher interest rates would raise demand for dollars by making dollar-denominated investments more attractive.
Conversely, the German Bundesbank has a policy of slow but steady reductions in rates to help its stagnant economy.
The British pound fell to $1.4850 in London, from $1.5000 late Friday. By 4 P.M. in New York, the pound fetched $1.4886, down from late Friday's $1.4970.

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
Justices to Decide if Ash Is a Hazardous Waste

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 21

 BODY:
In a case that could help determine the economics of municipal waste disposal, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the ash left from the burning of municipal solid waste must be treated as hazardous waste, requiring special treatment that could increase the cost of disposal by as much as 10 times.
The issue has been one of the more disputed aspects of Federal environmental policy in recent years. It has split the lower Federal courts and has produced an agonizing series of policy changes within the Environmental Protection Agency, which issued a policy statement last fall stating that the ash should be exempted from hazardous waste regulation. 
 But the Federal appeals court in Chicago later ruled that the ash was hazardous waste after all. The opinion, by Chief Judge William J. Bauer, declared that "the E.P.A. has changed its view so often that it is no longer entitled to the deference normally accorded an agency's interpretation of the statute it administers."
The problem stems from a vaguely worded Federal law, the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976, which governs the disposal of hazardous waste. The law contains an exemption for incinerators designed to recover energy, like steam or electricity, from the burning of municipal solid waste: the incinerator itself is not to be regulated as a hazardous waste facility.
But the law says nothing about the residue of the incineration. If the ash can be buried at low cost as ordinary landfill, the energy-producing incinerators would make economic sense for many cities. If the ash has to be stored under the special conditions required for hazardous waste, the cost would increase dramatically, making it cheaper for cities to bury their waste.
The Court granted an appeal filed by the city of Chicago, which owns and operates a resource-recovery incinerator, the Northwest Waste-to-Energy Facility. The incinerator handles 14 percent of the city's solid waste and produces $1.5 million worth of steam a year, which the city sells to industry and utilities. The ash is buried in an ordinary landfill in Michigan for about $23 a ton; it would cost about $210 a ton to store the ash as hazardous waste.
Chicago was sued by the Environmental Defense Fund, which argued that Federal law required the ash to be treated as hazardous waste. The Federal District Court in Chicago ruled for the city in a decision that was overturned by the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.
In its appeal, Chicago v. Environmental Defense Fund, No. 92-1639, the city said its costs would grow by $20 million a year if the incinerator's ash was treated as hazardous waste. There are 137 municipal energy-recovery incinerators in the country, with dozens more being planned.
There were also these other developments at the Court today:
Belated Evidence
The Court agreed to decide whether an employer can avoid liability under the Civil Rights Act of 1964 for discriminating against an employee if, in the course of the employee's discrimination lawsuit, unrelated evidence emerges that would have provided independent grounds for dismissing the employee.
In this case, a woman who was employed as a security officer for a university sued her employer under the Civil Rights Act for sex discrimination and sexual harassment. During pretrial discovery, the university's lawyers learned that the woman had stated falsely on her employment application that she had never been convicted of a crime; in fact she had pleaded guilty to driving under the influence of alcohol.
There was no dispute that the false statement would have been grounds for dismissal; the question for the Court is whether this "after-acquired evidence" absolves the employer of liability for its discriminatory conduct. The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, found that although the employer violated the Civil Rights Act, it was entitled to win the case because the plaintiff had obtained her job through fraud.
The Clinton Administration urged the Court to hear the woman's appeal, Milligan-Jensen v. Michigan Technological University, No. 92-1214, on the ground that the appeals court's approach to the case had a "vast potential for abuse" that would encourage employers to defend discriminatory conduct with irrelevant evidence. The belatedly discovered evidence "does not negate the discrimination that actually occurred," the Administration's brief argued.
 
Lingering Segregation
 Thirty-nine years after the Court ruled in Brown v. Board of Education that the schools of Topeka, Kan., were unconstitutionally segregated, the Justices let stand a ruling by a Federal appeals court that the school system had still not completely erased the vestiges of segregation.
The old lawsuit was revived in 1979 by Linda Brown, the original plaintiff, on behalf of her two children. It has been in the courts since then, producing several rulings. In the latest decision, the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit ruled last October that the system was still not desegregated in student and faculty assignments. While there are no all-black or all-white schools, several schools are identifiable by race.
The school board's appeal, Unified School District v. Smith, No. 92-1568, argued that the appeals court had ignored recent Supreme Court rulings under which formerly segregated school districts were not to be held accountable for all lingering racial imbalances. The Federal District Court in Kansas must now devise a remedy for the remaining segregation in Topeka.
 
Solicitor General Introduced
 Attorney General Janet Reno went to the Court today to introduce the Clinton Administration's new Solicitor General, Drew S. Days 3d, to the Justices in a brief courtroom ceremony. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist welcomed Mr. Days, who will be in charge of preparing all Government cases in the Court, and also thanked William C. Bryson, a career Justice Department lawyer, who served as acting Solicitor General for the Administration's first five months.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Drew S. Days 3d, the Clinton Administration's new Solicitor General, will be in charge of preparing all Government cases in the Supreme Court. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Minority Firm to Manage Offering

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The New York City Water Finance Authority has selected a minority-owned securities firm, W. R. Lazard, Laidlaw & Mead, to handle today's $375 million offering of notes due next April.
The selection of W. R. Lazard marks the first time that a minority-owned firm has been the lead manager in New York financing of this size since 1987, when city officials began insisting that those firms be made part of the underwriting groups. 
 With interest rates for short-term municipal securities nearly as low as they have ever been, analysts said late yesterday that they expected the notes would be offered with a yield of less than 2.50 percent. The notes, which carry the top short-term rating from various agencies, will be repaid with proceeds of bonds the authority expects to sell next spring. If new bonds are not sold, repayment would come from the water and sewer charges the authority collects from 807,000 businesses and individuals in New York City.
 
Usually a Co-Manager
 W. R. Lazard is no stranger to large municipal financings, but like other minority-owned firms, it has been relegated to a role as one of many co-managers. Because W. R. Lazard was the financial adviser to the Water Finance Authority for many years, it was a leading contender earlier this year when the authority selected three Wall Street firms to handle its securities offerings for the next two years.
Mark Page, executive director of the authority, noted that the authority had very little of its borrowing in the short-term market, and that today's financing was a way to take advantage of the low interest rates and strong demand for short-term securities. Most short-term tax-exempt notes are sold to mutual funds or other institutions, the group of investors which have had prior contacts with W. R. Lazard, he noted. Broader distribution to individuals, if necessary, will be available through Paine Webber and Smith Barney, Harris, Upham & Company, the two co-managers for the deal.
Breaking the hold of large securities firms on the role of lead managing underwriter for such a large prominent issuer as the Water Finance Authority helps win business from other issuers. It is a more profitable position than co-manager since the lead manager generally earns most of the underwriting fees and has the authority to allocate securities among other members of the syndicate.
 
Treasury Market
 In the Treasury securities market yesterday, prices rose as much as 3/8 point for long-term bonds, while shorter maturities were unchanged to slightly higher.
Interest rates at the regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills were little changed at 3.10 percent and 3.19 percent respectively. One-year Treasury bills were traded at around 3.37 percent.
While concerns that the Fed would soon push short-term rates higher have subsided in recent days, Treasury bill rates remain higher than the levels that prevailed from late January to mid-May when the three-month issue traded below 3 percent. The fact that one-year interest rates on Treasury bills and interbank deposits are a quarter to half a percentage point higher than three-month interest rates is a reminder that credit market analysts still expect short-term rates to rise in the coming year.
In advance of today's auction of new two-year Treasury notes, securities dealers traded the issue in the wholesale market with a yield of 4.17 percent, down from 4.18 percent. The five-year issue to be auctioned tomorrow was traded among dealers at 5.19 percent, down from 5.22 percent.
 
Long-Term Benchmark
 The benchmark for the long-term bond market, the Treasury's 7 1/8 percent issue due in 2023 was offered late in the day at 10415/32 , up 3/8 point, or about $3.75 per $1,000 bond, to yield 6.77 percent.
Securities dealers said they were preoccupied during the day with preparing for this week's two note auctions. They said that while the supply of notes was heavy, demand was good, including sales to municipalities that are buying Treasury securities to use as collateral for "defeased" municipal bonds. Such bonds remain outstanding but have been refinanced so they are backed by pools of Treasury securities rather than the issuers' promise to repay.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three- and six-month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: The Unknown Devil

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
The temporary hold on health-care change has been greeted with relief by many health-care professionals who prefer the devil they know to the one they don't. More surprising, perhaps, is that the postponement is also generating relief among some economists who worry that reform would take too big a slice out of the economy at a time when it could ill afford it.
Whatever form the final proposal takes, a fresh start on the way care is delivered and financed is bound to set off wrenching structural changes and job cuts in an economy already reeling from industrial retrenchment. And it is likely to slow the development of technology that generates billions of dollars in exports. 
 But even as the recognition grows of the economic price attached to reform, most economists agree that the cost of delay would be even greater. Unchecked escalation in medical costs is already a serious drag on living standards of the majority of workers who, knowingly or not, pay for their own health insurance.
Equally important, procrastination would foil even the most resolute plans for balancing the Government budget. Since Americans have yet to show that they have the will "to stop and say 'gosh we should raise taxes,' " to cover exploding Federal medical outlays, points out Robert Reischauer, the director of the Congressional Budget Office, the failure to contain costs could send the deficit soaring by the end of the decade.
It is no mystery why the $800 billion industry is worried about the deals Hillary Rodham Clinton and company must have cut in smoke-free rooms. Any reform that Washington deems successful, notes Joseph Newhouse, an economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, is bound to put pressure on both the incomes and job security of health- care providers.
Thus far, the public's attention has been focused on the princely earnings of physician-specialists. But by Mr. Newhouse's calculation, the surplus gleaned by this medical and surgical royalty is a modest fraction of total expenditures. All physicians' earnings after expenses amount to just one-tenth of the national health bill.
Those most vulnerable to cuts, he reckons, will be the hundreds of thousands of semiskilled hospital workers whose services do not seem critical to saving lives. The pressure to perform triage on health-care jobs could hardly come at a more awkward time.
While the employment picture looked less gloomy in May, the Great American Job Machine remains stalled. The 1.1 million health care jobs created over the last four years represent half the jobs created in the economy.
 
Job Picture Not Good
 Although a full-fledged recovery would remove some pressure, the streamlining of the giant defense, construction and financial service industries will no doubt keep unemployment offices busy.
By the same token, successful cost containment might dull the sheen on America's bright successes in key areas of high technology: drugs and medical equipment. While the reformers will no doubt aim at what they see as marginally useful tests and treatments, the introduction of expensive drugs and machines will surely also be slowed. "It is far from clear we would cut the least valuable technologies," Mr. Newhouse said.
The most significant impact would be on the quality of medical care, at least for those who can afford the best. But reforms could also undermine earnings from exports and foreign royalties, at a time when Washington is fixated on regaining world leadership in high technology.
That is hardly the end of the story. Cost containment will be aimed at slowing the growth of medical outlays, says Barry Bosworth of the Brookings Institution, not stopping it. And the effort will be accompanied by an expansion of health-care coverage for the poor. Thus, while there is likely to be a churning of jobs among regions and among institutions providing care, Mr. Bosworth acknowledges, "we are not talking about total cuts in employment."
 
Impatience With Jobs Focus
 In any case, economists who take the long view are impatient with the focus on jobs alone. "You can be a flat-earth person" and mourn labor-saving in health care, Mr. Reischauer says. But from that perspective, replacing telephone operators with automatic switches, was a step backward.
These economists are also quick to point out the doleful consequences of failing to check the growth of medical outlays. The most important of these is the least appreciated: the drag on workers' living standards. While Americans generally receive health insurance as a job benefit, Uwe Reinhardt of Princeton University argues that "costs are mostly shifted back to take-home pay." The premiums generally come out of workers' incomes, whether or not they see an itemized deduction on their pay slips.
The mere fact that Americans are spending more on health care -- and thus have less to spend on other goods and services -- need not mean their living standard is suffering. Nobody, after all, would argue that rapidly escalating outlays for fresh fruit, compact disks and vacation travel are signs of falling personal welfare.
 
Buying Too Much Health Care
 But health care is different, Mr. Newhouse argues, because there is no competitive market in which consumers make informed choices with what they perceive as their own money. As one might expect, health-care buyers tend to buy too much because someone else is footing the bill.
In a famous experiment performed by the RAND Corporation, people with hefty annual insurance deductibles spent one-third less on medical care than those with first-dollar coverage, with no measurable loss in health. Economists thus have reason to believe a substantial portion of the nation's health-care dollar is wasted, and at the expense of the average insured wage earner.
This does not explain why big corporations, notably those providing the most comprehensive health insurance, are chomping at the bit for a financing system that spreads the cost over a broader base. In some cases, they may simply share the misunderstanding that the burden falls largely on profits, not pay. But Mr. Bosworth says there are important exceptions to the rule that workers foot the bill.
The Big Three car makers, for example, have much higher medical insurance bills than their foreign-owned competitors in America because their workers are, on average, much older. Thus the costs cannot be passed on to buyers without the risk of losing market share. What's more, the car companies long ago agreed to cover the insurance costs of retirees, an albatross now attached firmly to the necks of their stockholders.
 
Burden on the Budget
 But the biggest time bomb buried in the health insurance system -- the one driving a reluctant Washington to face the political risks of reform -- is the burden on the Federal budget. If Congress passes something close to the President's proposed budget, the deficit will absorb about half as much of the nation's income in 1996 as it did last year. And since virtually all expenditure categories in the budget are growing less rapidly than revenues, one might expect the deficit to continue to fall thereafter.
There is a multitrillion-dollar catch, however. If costs are not checked, the budget office estimates that Medicaid and Medicare outlays will rise to $672 billion in 2003, from $226 billion in 1993. In fact, projected increases in Medicare and Medicaid outlays plus the increase in interest payments on the accumulating Government debt attributable to medical spending would probably add up to more than 100 percent of the deficit a decade hence.
The country could muddle along with big deficits in the next decade as it did in the last. But it would torpedo the Clinton Administration's hopes for making a difference in the lives of the less privileged. To abandon health-care cost containment, Mr. Reinhardt concludes, is "to say the hell with education, infrastructure, welfare reform and everything else."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Soybeans at 12-Month High; Grain Prices Are Also Up

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Soybean futures shot up yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade to the highest price in more than a year as fears grew that too much Midwestern rain would reduce production.
Grain futures also rose. On other commodity markets, livestock and meat futures ended mixed and oil futures weakened. 
 Soybeans for July delivery surged 15 1/4 cents, to $6.20 1/2 a bushel, the highest settlement for near-term deliveries since June 10 of last year. The contract traded as high as $6.26 during the session.
The November contract, representing the new soybean crop, climbed 15 1/2 cents, to $6.21 1/2 a bushel.
The soybean rally extended last week's 16 1/2-cent gain and followed a weekend of rainy weather in Midwestern states west of the Mississippi River, the region where the excessive moisture problem is most severe.
"You have a unique, bizarre circumstance developing here of a bull market because it's too wet," said Doug Jackson, a grains analyst with the Farmers Commodities Corporation in Des Moines. He said several million soggy acres in Iowa, Minnesota and South Dakota remained unplanted.
A weekly Agriculture Department report released after the close of trading showed that 83 percent of the American soybean crop had been planted as of Sunday, compared with a five-year average of 89 percent. Ninety-two percent of the crop was in the ground at this time last year.
"With weather forecasts calling for heavy rains midweek and this weekend, there is a possibility those acres will not planted until at least July 1," Mr. Jackson said. Soybeans planted in July can lose up to 40 percent of their yield potential, he said.
Light sweet crude oil for July delivery fell 5 cents on the New York Mercantile Exchange, to $18.62 a barrel; July heating oil dropped 0.25 cent, to 51.95 cents a gallon; July unleaded gasoline fell 0.19 cent, to 54.66 cents a gallon, and July natural gas fell 6 cents, to $2.195 for each 1,000 cubic feet.
Cattle futures ended mostly lower and pork futures mostly higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in advance of a monthly Agriculture Department report on frozen meat supplies. The report, released after the markets closed, showed 78.9 million pounds of pork bellies in cold storage as of May 31, compared with 92.7 million pounds a year earlier.
