HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Nike Stock Off on Lower Growth Outlook

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 21

 BODY:
Shares in Nike Inc. took a beating today after the athletic shoe manufacturer's disclosure late Friday that it expects 1994 fiscal year earnings to be well below Wall Street estimates.
Nike's shares fell $4.125 today to close at $57.875 on the New York Stock Exchange. Nike made its announcement late Friday after the stock market close. In after-hours trading on Friday, the stock plunged $5, to $62. 
 Since reaching a 52-week high of $90.25, Nike's shares have lost roughly a third of their value.
Philip H. Knight, Nike's chairman, said in a statement Friday that the continued weakness in several European economies, and a sluggish retail environment in the United States, have prompted the company to scale back its growth projections for the 1994 fiscal year, which ends May 31, 1994.
"We believe the best response to these short-term economic conditions is to continue our relentless strategy of investing heavily in Europe and other developing international markets to strengthen the Nike brand and to gain market share," Mr. Knight said. "When one combines all these factors, it appears our earnings for fiscal 1994 will be significantly below the current mean of Wall Street analysts' expectations of approximately $5.50 per share."
Analysts rapidly readjusted their estimates to $5 a share or lower, and some said further reductions might be necessary. While the long-running trend toward more active life styles remains positive for Nike, discretionary purchases like athletic shoes are very vulnerable to economic weakness, they said. Analysts estimate Nike will post 1993 fiscal year earnings of around $4.78 when it reports final results in July.
"You're looking at a company that was supposed to grow by 13 percent, which will now grow by 5 percent only if things improve," said Alice A. Ruth an analyst with Montgomery Securities in San Francisco.
 
A Weak Retail Environment
 She said Nike was feeling the combined impact of the weak retail environment in the United States; the maturation of the athletic shoe industry, which meant more discounting to maintain market share, and the continued economic weakness in Europe. "Investors really don't have anything to hang their hopes on" with Nike, she said.
Josephine Esquivel, an analyst with Lehman Brothers, said the timing of the announcement by Nike had irritated investors and perhaps prompted a greater decline in its shares.
"There was a meeting a month ago with analysts where they indicated some of the numbers on the Street were high, but not to this degree," she said. "The reality is they don't know to what degree 1994 is going to be bad; it's anybody's guess," she said. "If you're betting on no recovery in any of these pressed economies, they could go below $5," she said.

HEADLINE: The Economics of a Sports Cliche

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR

 BODY:
Pat Riley couldn't coach the New York Knicks past the Chicago Bulls in the National Basketball Association playoffs this year, but in an ironic twist, he will benefit from the Bulls' third straight N.B.A. title.
With their 99-to-98 victory over the Phoenix Suns on Sunday night, the Bulls earned the right to capitalize on a new merchandising wrinkle: the "three-peat" and "3-peat" trademarks. Those phrases were registered by Mr. Riley in 1989 when the Los Angeles Lakers, his former team, were thwarted in their quest for three straight titles. (An optimist, Mr. Riley also registered "four-ward.") 
Retailers expect "three-peat" and "3-peat" merchandise to add extra juice to sales of Bulls' championship merchandise. In 1991 and 1992, an estimated $45 million in licensed merchandise celebrating the Bulls' titles sold within 10 days of each season's final game.
"The Bulls have been our best-selling team for the last few years in licensed merchandise," said Bill Marshall, vice president of licensing for N.B.A. Properties. "I think we'll do significantly more this year."
 
Higher Total Royalties
 Although Mr. Riley was never able to use the trademark for the Lakers, now he and N.B.A. Properties, the licensing arm of the league, will share the royalties, an undisclosed percentage of the wholesale price of "three-peat" merchandise. Mr. Riley's prescience means companies will have to pay higher total royalties.
Forty-five of N.B.A. Properties' 120 licensees are making championship products, but only 15 are licensed to use "3-peat" or "three-peat" on products ranging from T-shirts, caps and pennants to backboards, towels and posters.
The goal has been to rush the merchandise out within hours of the final buzzer to capitalize on fans' euphoria.
At Wincraft Inc. in Winona, Minn., workers started churning out hundreds of thousands of pennants, pins and buttons immediately after the game. "We didn't change to a '3-peat' design until last week when it became apparent that it was a possibility," said Dick Pope, the company president, "and quite a few of our customers increased their pre-sale orders."
But not everyone is happy. The extra cost of licensing caused Huffy Sports to limit its production of "three-peat" backboards, said John Gallun, the Milwaukee-based company's manager of marketing and advance design. "It makes it too expensive," he said, noting that higher royalty payments will cut into his profit margin. "But Pat Riley is going to go home with a nice little piece of change."
Typically, companies are combining "3-peat" or "three-peat" with a variety of traditional championship and team designs and graphics on Bulls goods for the prime selling period -- between five and 10 days after the final game.
Logo 7 Inc. of Indianapolis was prepared to produce as many as 60,000 caps and 400,000 T-shirts, most of them featuring "3-peat" or "three-peat." Production started last night at plants in Chicago, Indianapolis and Massachusetts.
"Three-peat probably has the most sex appeal of any trademark I've been associated with," Matt Mirchin, vice president of sales for Logo 7, said, "because other teams have gone for it recently, but only the Bulls did it."
"If you don't have an item with 'three-peat' on it, why have it?" said Craig Van Orden, product development manager of Peter David Inc. of San Diego, which has initial orders for 10,000 collectible pins.
Some companies waited for the Bulls' final victory before producing goods, but others manufactured a quantity, running the risk of having to destroy items.
Magic Johnson T's, a company owned by the ex-Lakers' star, decided last week to take the gamble. By Thursday, it was producing shirts with four "3-peat" and "three-peat" designs at plants in Chicago and Gardena, Calif., in quantities exceeding several hundred thousand, according to Lon Rosen, Mr. Johnson's business manager.
Although most of the Bulls merchandise will sell in the Chicago area, the national and international renown of the team and its star, Michael Jordan, will probably generate substantially more sales outside the local market than if the Suns had won.
But so far, Mr. Marshall of the N.B.A. said, no one has asked to license "four-ward."

HEADLINE: China Breaks Ground for World's Largest Dam

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

DATELINE: YICHANG, China

 BODY:
THE bulldozers are scooping out the yellow earth along the Yangtze River in preparation for the world's largest hydroelectric project, a dam that will create a lake 350 miles long, fuel China's industrial revolution and save millions of people from the constant threat of flooding.
Or perhaps the project will simply create the world's most colossal mud pie. 
 Critics say that silting behind the dam may result in a $30 billion bog that would inundate China's finest natural scenery and stand as one of the most monumental and vexing legacies of Chinese Communism.
The disagreement is no surprise, for people have been debating the merits of the Three Gorges Dam since the idea was proposed in 1919. But while the debate seems endless, one thing has changed: work on the dam is finally beginning.
"The way things look right now, I don't think it can be delayed any more," said Jiang Xueyuan, the white-haired spokesman for the Three Gorges Project office here in Yichang, the nearest city to the dam site in central China. Mr. Jiang, like many other engineers who have spent their careers designing the dam, is delighted that the supporters finally seem to have won the battle.
Those whose homes, farmland and heritage would be flooded are naturally less enthusiastic. Among the 1.2 million people being forced to move to make way for the project is a furniture vendor in Wanxian, a grimy Yangtze River port.
"None of us want to leave, because our lives depend on this port," said the man, who identified himself only as Mr. Gao, between efforts to interest a foreigner in a $4 wicker chair. "Officially, everyone has to support it, but no one wants to go. What'll happen to us?"
A five-day journey down the Yangtze, through the area that will be flooded, found not everyone so opposed to the project, with some peasants so poor that they seem happy to move. The more optimistic -- or perhaps credulous -- believe the Government's promises of fertile new farmland, prosperous new factories, fancy new homes and lucrative new jobs.
The Three Gorges Dam, sometimes described as the most important construction project in China since the Great Wall, was formally approved last year. It involves a 607-foot-high dam stretching 1.2 miles along the third of the Yangtze River's three famous gorges.
The gorges, which are as famous in China as the Grand Canyon is in the United States, would be partly submerged. The Yangtze in its middle reaches would look more like a lake than a river.
The Three Gorges Dam would not be the highest in the world, nor would its reservoir be the biggest. But its hydroelectric output would be 17,680 megawatts, by far the biggest in the world and nearly three times as much as the output of the Grand Coulee Dam, the biggest in the United States.
The project has a special resonance in part because it would transform the Yangtze, the mightiest river in the nation, known in Chinese simply as the Chang Jiang, "the long river." The Yangtze River basin is home to 35 percent of all Chinese, accounting for nearly 8 percent of all humanity.
Among them is a hefty 60-year-old man with a crew cut who sells dogeared magazines -- mostly with covers of big-breasted women looking either sultry or anguished -- on a patch of ground along the main street in the town of Wanxian.
"We don't want to move," the man said slowly, speaking Mandarin with a thick local peasant accent. "But what can you do? The water's going to come, and then you've got to go."
Still, he accepted the Government's logic that the project was fundamentally good for China. While official propaganda is often regarded with skepticism in the cities, the peasants and workers who will have to make way for the dam seem to accept the official line that it is necessary to control flooding and generate electricity.
"People can't help but feel a bit unsettled in their hearts," said Guo Qinglu, a 60-year-old retiree in Wanxian. "Generations have lived here. Their ancestors are buried here.
"But the dam is a good thing," Mr. Guo added, nodding his head slowly as he stood in a small restaurant. "It'll produce lots of electricity. So while some people here support it and some are against it, most are in favor of the dam."
Apparently only a few hundred people have been evicted so far, although every official seems to have a different estimate. In any case, the bulk of the work in relocating 1.2 million people will not take place until late in this decade.
 
The Dam's Twisted History
 So far the work on the dam is all preparatory. Laborers with heavy equipment are building access roads on each side of the dam site and are beginning construction of a bridge just downstream to facilitate construction. Workers are also digging a new channel to divert a creek.
Housing for the workers and engineers is already in place, and work will begin later this year on a cofferdam, to divert the Yangtze slightly so that work can begin on the main dam.
Still, the history of the project has had more twists and turns than the Yangtze itself, and it could be killed -- or, more likely, postponed indefinitely.
Deng Xiaoping, the 88-year-old senior leader, supports the project, but he is ailing and a growing number of Chinese are beginning to accept that he may be mortal after all. Several other top party elders who were among the dam's strongest backers -- Wang Zhen, Wang Renzhong and Li Xiannian -- have died since the project was approved early last year.
One of the strongest supporters of the dam among China's younger leaders is Prime Minister Li Peng. But Mr. Li apparently suffered a heart attack in late April, and he has appeared in public only once since then. The state of his health, physical and political, remains uncertain.
"If Li Peng remains out of commission, then I don't think the Three Gorges Project will go very far," said a Chinese who circulates among some of the leaders.
For now, the official news media are talking about plans to accelerate the project. It was supposed to take 18 years to complete, but the leaders are now talking about 17 years or fewer.
Progress reports on the dam are regular front-page news in China, partly because of the historical intimacy here between society and water. Few Chinese can name many ancient emperors, but everybody knows of the Great Yu, the ancient hero who conquered a flood and then built the dikes and water projects that nurtured Chinese civilization.
It is difficult to separate myth from history in those ancient times, about 2200 B.C., but some experts believe that Yu, who later founded China's first dynasty, was a real individual. If so, he is one of the first people in human history, outside ancient Egypt, who is known by name.
In the United States, presidents may hope to be remembered for a foreign policy doctrine or a social program. But in China, the best chance for an emperor, past or present, to be remembered is with a huge water project.
And that, say critics of the Three Gorges project, is the problem.
"It's a political project," said Dai Qing, a Chinese writer and environmentalist, as she nibbled on a salad the other day, studiously ignoring a state security agent eavesdropping from the next table. Ms. Dai, who was imprisoned after the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown and lost her job, has emerged as the leading opponent of the Three Gorges project.
 
Fear of Flooding
 Critics like Ms. Dai say that the push to build the dam has less to do with the need for electricity than the desire for a grand monument, which they say, is likely to turn into a white elephant. Gigantic projects have often served a political role in China, as a national show and tell that can unite people in pride, just as construction of the Aswan Dam served a similar role in Egypt and the drive to put a man in space did in the United States.
The main argument in favor of the dam is not the need for electricity, because it would be cheaper and simpler to build several smaller hydroelectric dams. Rather, the primary argument is flood control.
The Yangtze River, like the Yellow River, has gradually filled in much of its channel through silting. Over the centuries, people responded by building dikes on either side, and when silt raised the bottom of the channel they raised the dikes even higher.
As a result, in some places the Yangtze is known as a "hanging" river, because it is higher than the towns on each side. Only the dikes keep the water in place, protecting the millions of people living on lower ground.
One of China's worst nightmares would be a devastating flood like the one of 1870, the worst in the last 1,000 years. If the dikes burst unexpectedly in the middle of the night, hundreds of thousands of people could die.
"If we don't build this dam, then who will take responsibility for the flooding?" asked Cui Zhihao, a senior engineer at the Three Gorges head office in the city of Wuhan. "A single flood would cause far more damage and dislocation than the Three Gorges Dam."
Proponents of the dam say that the existing Jinjiang dike can withstand only a 10-year flood, meaning the worst that can typically be expected in a decade. But it may be in their interest to exaggerate the risk, so as to make the construction of the dam seem more urgent.
The engineers grumblingly acknowledge that no recent flood has burst the Jinjiang dike, not even the 1954 flood, which is believed to be a 100-year flood, meaning the worst that can be expected in a typical century. When pressed, some engineers say that the Jinjiang dike can withstand at least a 20-year flood, or a 40-year flood if several catchment areas are deliberately flooded to ease the pressure.
The major technical debate over the dam is the question of silting. The Yangtze sometimes resembles soup more than water, and it carries 523 million tons of sediment each year. Critics charge that the dam will cause the water to slow down and drop silt on the bottom of the reservoir, gradually turning the lake into an unnavigable mud puddle.
Government engineers say they have licked the silting problem. They say that tests show that the lake will be navigable for as long as the dam lasts.
For all such technical complexities, the major reason why the project might still be postponed is easy to understand: cost. While official estimates are $10 billion or less, inflation and cost overruns could make that much higher. The Gezhouba Dam, built in the 1970's and 80's a bit farther downstream on the Yangtze, ended up costing more than three times the initial projection.
At a time when the Government has a budget deficit and the economy is already overheated, some economic officials apparently think it is mistake to tackle another huge construction project.
Some Western environmental groups are calling on the World Bank not to finance the dam, but China believes that in any case it can attract foreign lenders and investors to help pay for the project. And supporters still express confidence that they will see the Three Gorges Dam built in their lifetimes.
"This has been discussed and debated for decades," said Luo Shixiao, a 56-year-old engineer who helps run the Three Gorges project office in Chongqing. "There've been lots of different opinions, lots of research, lots of discussions. But the consensus is that building the dam is better than not building it, and that building it earlier is better than building it later."
Mr. Luo paused and offered a fleeting and slightly triumphant smile: "I'm confident that construction will go ahead quite smoothly."

HEADLINE: Japan: How Clean a Break?

 BODY:
Politicians continue to defect from Japan's Liberal Democratic Party in the wake of last Friday's no-confidence vote in Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa. Some of these are honest reformers, outraged at the Liberal Democrats' failure to meet the public demand for a cleaner system. Others are opportunists, betting on political realignment as the quickest ticket to the rewards of high office.
It's high drama -- the fracturing of a system of one-party rule that delivered remarkable economic growth and endured for almost 40 years. But beneath the choreographed rituals of Japanese party politics lie even more dramatic changes in public opinion. A new generation of urban Japanese, raised in affluence, is now turning against big-money politics while it seeks a better balance between producer and consumer interests in Japanese life. 
 In the short run, the upheaval could lead to even weaker governments. That could make Japan a still more frustrating ally and trading partner -- and complicate next month's Tokyo economic summit meeting. But if the party realignment now under way gives voice to this new urban constituency, both Japan and its partners could benefit.
The Liberal Democratic debacle has been brewing for a long time. Four years of "money politics" scandals and two years of recession battered the party's popularity. And the end of the cold war removed the original anti-Communist rationale for its existence. Still, as long as the only alternative was the doctrinaire and discredited Socialists, the Liberal Democrats stayed on top.
What changed matters was the revolt launched six months ago by two top Liberal Democrats, Ichiro Ozawa and Tsutomu Hata. Mr. Ozawa, a protege of Shin Kanemaru, the deal maker who now symbolizes political corruption, and Mr. Hata, a former Agriculture Minister who once championed crude protectionism, improbably declared themselves champions of the new Japan.
Suddenly there was a safe, center-right alternative to the Liberal Democrats, especially after the Ozawa-Hata faction started negotiating alliances with reform-minded opposition groups. To build a new majority, this prospective coalition will have to appeal to urban consumers, whose sense of prosperity is undercut by the high land, housing and food prices of a producer-oriented economy.
Besides political reform, Mr. Ozawa stands for a more assertive foreign policy and for building up the power of elected leaders at the expense of Japan's powerful bureaucrats. That might appeal to Americans frustrated by Tokyo's overcautious diplomacy and bureaucratic sabotage of negotiated agreements. For years, Washington preferred dealing with the Liberal Democrats, but changed conditions call for re-examining that preference.
President Clinton will now be attending the Tokyo summit conference in the midst of a hotly contested election campaign. Without any discourtesy to his host, he must take care to demonstrate America's scrupulous political neutrality. By the time Washington's newly named Ambassador, Walter Mondale, takes up his post, Japan's political direction might be clearer. More than any of his predecessors, Mr. Mondale will need to look beyond the rituals of party politics to track the emergence of a new Japan.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Clinton, Iraq And Iran

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
In the winter and spring of 1993, the Clinton Administration quietly worked out an important new policy toward the two countries that could involve the United States again in Mideastern war.
Since Europe was busy boxing Mr. Clinton's ears about not taking over its job on Bosnia, and the American press and public were out getting a haircut, the Administration managed to squeeze in some useful thinking on Iran and Iraq without being belabored for it. 
 But it has to do two things to give reality to the policy it calls "dual containment." It has to keep the U.S. militarily strong and politically steadfast. Second: It has to persuade its allies to show the same sense of purpose, even though it will hurt at the weapons-trade cash register.
For more than a decade, Iraq's power grew under a dictator who never hid his intention to rule the Mideast. Meanwhile Iran's mullahs saw themselves as the crashing wave of Islam, sweeping all, and were developing the military power to match their dreams.
High-devastation weapons, nuclear power, terrorism and religious extremism had changed international equations and dangers. But under Presidents Reagan and Bush, U.S. policy makers reached into the past to come up with the idea of creating a "balance of power" by playing Iran and Iraq against each other.
Iran received missiles through the courtesy of the U.S. and Israel. Iraq was stuffed with American loans and Western arms. The result was that Iraq felt strong enough to risk war with the U.S. while Iran sat back and garaged late-model Iraqi warplanes.
Saddam Hussein lost the war but not his throne or his ambitions. He makes war against millions of his own countrymen, and constantly tests the resolve of the West.
"Dual containment" recognizes the continuing reality of the Iraqi danger without giving in to the temptation to build Iran as a counterbalance.
Because of the failure to oust Saddam, the U.S will be in a state of war with Iraq until he is overthrown. Containment may be the best the U.S. can do meanwhile, but to hold the line against him it must be real.
Right now, it is Saddam's internal enemies who are being contained at least as much as he. In their "safe havens" the Kurds are being squeezed economically by Saddam's blockade and harassed by his nearby armed forces. Throughout the world, his representatives are recognized as speaking for the people he oppresses while the dissident Iraqi National Council hunts for diplomatic crumbs.
Containing Saddam must mean more than responding to his violations of U.N. resolutions. It should mean ordering him to pull back the troops that threaten the Kurds, and ending his blockade. And from the West the Kurds should receive economic aid and basic military equipment to protect themselves when he attacks in strength -- when, not if.
The council of dissident Iraqis should be recognized as the first step in creating a counter-Saddam provisional government.
And for Iran: The Clinton Administration believes containment is impossible without ending the sale to Teheran of weapons and dual-use materiel. This is equipment and technology that are supposed to be for peaceful purposes but can be converted to military use. Washington puts Iranian nuclear power as no more than five years away.
Since there is no U.N. arms embargo against Iran, the Administration will have to be hard and mean with its friends. Does anybody think that Western corporations, including American, that fattened Saddam Hussein militarily are not ready to do the same for Iran if their governments permit? Or the Japanese or Russians?
The Clinton people see "dual containment" and Mideast weapons control as two steps in a three-part Mideast strategy. The third is an Arab-Israeli peace.
But Iraq and Iran will not sit around waiting for containment handcuffs. Iran will call out all fundamental forces in the Mideast to destroy any Israeli-Arab peace. And Iraq and Iran could become nuclear allies, with Iraqi nuclear specialists taking up residence in Teheran.
Dual containment, as the Clinton people know, is not a solution, simply a policy that might restrict two dictatorships to home ground. But it is a lot better than balancing one tyranny against another -- the old recipe for strengthening both.

HEADLINE: Albany, Not City Hall, Holds Purse Strings for Transit Upgrade

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Find Money for the M.T.A." (editorial, June 12) faults the New York City administration for not bearing its share of the cost of improvements on subways and buses. 
 However, you fail to state the already significant contribution Mayor David N. Dinkins has committed to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's capital and operating budgets. Mayor Dinkins committed $1.2 billion to the M.T.A.'s 1992-96 capital plan and $91 million in operating funds to maintain the New York City transit fare at $1.25 in 1993 and 1994.
While the M.T.A. continues to press for $500 million more in capital contribution from the city, it is important to note that the city has maintained virtually the same level of support for the M.T.A. as provided in the 1987-91 plan ($1.2 billion, as opposed to $1.3 billion). The request to increase the city's capital contribution beyond this amount comes at a time when the city's own capital budget is stretched to the limit, as many fiscal monitors have noted.
When the city reviewed its capital program last year, we found that tighter management of commitment schedules and optimizing the opportunities in the construction market allowed us significantly to increase the efficiency of our capital spending. This allowed the city to minimize the impact of the 26 percent reduction in our capital spending plans since 1991.
Based on this experience, and the fact that approximately 4.5 percent of the M.T.A.'s funds from the previous plan were not committed by the end of the five-year period, it is reasonable to estimate that between $400 million and $450 million could be saved in the current plan.
The Mayor presented a plan to the M.T.A and the New York State Legislature that would have increased the city's capital contribution by $65 million annually. The plan depended on action by the Legislature to reallocate subsidies, which would not necessitate the use of the city's $65 million for operating purposes.
Since the State Legislature failed to do the right thing, the city was forced to contribute funds to the Transit Authority's operating deficit to save the fare in 1993 and 1994.
The problem is not the level of the city's commitment, but rather the lack of equity in the distribution of other subsidies to the M.T.A. -- inequities that have resulted in a growing misallocation of toll revenues from the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority and the continued emphasis in capital planning on strict funding ratios over actual need.
The State Legislature can still redress these larger equity issues and return the M.T.A. to the regional authority it was intended to be.
User-friendly subways and buses are an essential component of economic development in New York City. But there are ways to improve the efficiency of the program without disrupting vital service initiatives, including needed station repairs. This will insure that scarce taxpayer dollars are used in the most effective manner.
 
NORMAN STEISEL
First Deputy Mayor
New York, June 14, 1993

HEADLINE: If He Runs, D'Amato Has His Platform

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERICHO, L.I., June 21

 BODY:
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said today that he would decide this fall whether to run for governor next year.
But he told a luncheon meeting here that if he were elected, he would sell the World Trade Center, the New York City airports and the state's Offtrack Betting system. He also said he would support the death penalty and require able-bodied welfare recipients to accept public-service jobs. 
 Mr. D'Amato made his remarks at a luncheon of the Real Estate Practitioners Institute of Long Island University.
Asked when he would decide whether to run for governor, Mr. D'Amato, a Long Island Republican, said, he would first confer with his brother Armand, a lawyer and former assemblyman who was convicted of mail fraud last month in connection with payments he received from a military contractor to lobby the Senator.
"Truthfully," Senator D'Amato said, "I have to talk to my political expert. I have not had the opportunity to talk with Armand D'Amato yet. But it's something we're looking at."
During his speech, he attacked Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and President Clinton for policies that he said were hurting the Long Island economy.
"We hear the kind of proposals that come out of Albany," he said. "And those proposals are not how to cut spending, the proposals are how do you raise more revenue. I'd suggest to you that we got it backward. I'd suggest to you that President Clinton has it backwards. And Governor Cuomo has it backwards."
Senator D'Amato argued that government spending must be cut for Long Island's economy to improve. He outlined his budget plan, which he said would save taxpayers $250 billion and call for freezing Federal spending for two years, eliminating new spending programs, putting the space station and supercollider projects on hold and killing the C-17 cargo plane.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 23, 1993, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato misidentified the person with whom he said he would confer about running for governor. It was his mother, Antoinette, not his brother, Armand.

HEADLINE: SENATORS BRACING FOR FIGHT ON PLAN TO INCREASE TAXES

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
With some of their careers and perhaps the eventual success of Bill Clinton's Presidency on the line, senators prepared today to begin voting on raising taxes and curbing popular programs.
Senators from both parties agree that the budget package will pass by the end of the week on a party-line vote with almost all the Democrats in favor and all the Republicans opposed. 
 But the near certainty of the outcome has not lessened the anxiety that pervades the Capitol and the White House.
Democrats believe they must prove that when their party controls the White House and Congress, they can begin to solve the nation's problems. But some wonder whether they can survive the politically painful votes they will cast this week to raise taxes.
 
Political Calculation
 Republicans have made the political calculation that it is to their advantage to vote against all new taxes. But they will be forced either to vote for deep cuts in popular benefits programs or to show that they are not serious about wanting to lower the deficit. And by always voting no they open themselves to the charge of fomenting gridlock.
Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, reflected the anxiety when he was asked this afternoon whether the main motivation behind the various votes this week would be support or opposition to the President. "It's not the President; it's the class of '94," he replied, referring to the election pressure all senators face, but which will be felt soonest by the 20 Democrats and 14 Republicans up for re-election next year.
At the White House, the main concern is that the bill get through the Senate in one form or another. The budget bill passed by the House last month is more to the President's liking, and he hopes that he can get more of what he wants in the House-Senate conference that will try to resolve the differences.
Leon E. Panetta, the budget director, put the White House position this way at a news conference today, "The key right now, the fundamental point is that we've got to pass this through the Senate to get it to a conference."
 
Feel the Arm Twisting
 The President met with some wavering Democratic senators to administer one final half-nelson. "I could feel my arm being twisted," said Senator Howell Heflin of Alabama.
In a speech to the United States Conference of Mayors this morning, Mr. Clinton challenged his Republican opponents. "If you want to reduce the tax burden on the wealthy, where will you make up the money?" he asked. "What will you do to reduce this deficit? Are you willing to make the same kinds of decisions that I have?"
For the time being, Republicans have no answer. Republican senators met this afternoon and announced afterward that on Wednesday they would offer their own budget plan to lower the deficit by more than Mr. Clinton's plan without raising any taxes. They refused to provide any details of how they would accomplish that.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, conceded that the Republican proposal would be defeated, but he said that would prove the point that the Democrats merely favored higher taxes and more spending.
Democratic Senators met over lunch, and sniped at the budget measure from the right and the left. Some like Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut want more tax breaks for business to stimulate the economy. Others like Paul Wellstone of Minnesota and Tom Harkin of Iowa worry about the limits the legislation would place on the growth in spending for Medicare.
But most said afterward that they would eventually agree and vote for the package.
"It's going to pass in the end," said Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, "but it's going to be a high wire act getting there."
 
Disputes on All Sides
 The only statement about the budget today that went completely unchallenged came from Senator Jim Sasser of Tennessee, the chairman of the Budget Committee. Asked after the Democrats' lunch about all the senators who were speaking out against one part of the package or another. Mr. Sasser said, "I think there's a lot of ventilating going on."
Under the budget rules, the measure cannot be filibustered, and a final vote is expected on Thursday night or Friday.
But the legislation, officially called a reconciliation bill, can be amended. And the Republicans, in addition to offering their overall deficit-reduction plan, are expected to offer individual amendments that would require Democrats to cast votes that can be used against them in their next election campaigns.
One such amendment, for example, would remove the section of the bill that raises the amount of Social Security benefits on which middle- and upper-income retirees must pay income taxes. As might be expected, this provision in the bill, which would raise $26 billion over five years, is unpopular among retirees.
Another amendment the Republicans will probably offer would remove the 4.3-cents a gallon gasoline-tax increase from the bill.
Over five years, the Democrats' bill would raise taxes by about $250 billion and lower spending by about $100 billion.
If the President and the Democrats have their way, another $100 billion in spending cuts over the next five years would be locked in with a freeze in programs that get annual appropriations. And if all this comes to pass, the Democrats have calculated, more than $50 billion will be saved over the five-year period in lower interest costs on the national debt, for a total deficit reduction of about $500 billion.

HEADLINE: Aristide Likely to Meet Army Head This Week

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, June 22

 BODY:
Haiti's deposed President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, is expected to meet with his country's military leaders this week in what diplomats say could set the stage for a settlement of the long political crisis.
Diplomats involved in organizing the talks say Haiti's military commander, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, agreed to the meeting late Monday in response to sharply increased international pressures for a negotiated settlement. 
 Although the site has not yet been determined, the meeting between Father Aristide, who was ousted in 1991, and General Cedras is expected to be held in another Caribbean country by week's end.
Last week the United Nations Security Council ordered a worldwide oil embargo of Haiti, a freeze of assets of top Haitian business executives and officials and a prohibition on arms sales to the country. The sanctions are to take effect on Wednesday.
In a letter to the United Nations special envoy to Haiti, Dante Caputo, published late Monday, General Cedras requested that talks on the "survival and life of the nation" be convened urgently, on "neutral ground."
Apparently hoping for a stay of the new sanctions, General Cedras said "the imposition of these measures is not justified at this precise moment against a country where life is more terrible than death."
Although diplomats said the talks were intended to devise a "definitive solution to the crisis," including the transfer of power to a government to be named by Father Aristide, officials involved in mediation efforts said General Cedras's letter would not bring a postponement of United Nations sanctions. Diplomats said that after repeated shows of bad faith by Haiti's military authorities in nearly two years of negotiations, only an agreement on a settlement and the start of its implementation could halt the sanctions.
The announcement of General Cedras's willingness to meet Father Aristide follows the initially defiant reaction of Haitian authorities to the United Nations sanctions.
As they neared passage, the measures appeared substantially weakened by a last-minute motion led by Brazil for the removal of language authorizing the enforcement of the embargo by American and other ships off Haiti acting under United Nations authority.
Diplomats said that in recent days, however, Haitian military leaders had come to understand that the United States would enforce the sanctions unilaterally, if necessary, to insure their effectiveness.

HEADLINE: U.S. Weighs Easing of Vietnam Trade Sanctions

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is considering allowing American companies to bid on contracts in Vietnam that are financed by loans from international lending agencies like the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank, officials said today.
If accepted by the President, such an action, combined with an Administration decision not to block a plan that would give Hanoi access to loans from multilateral lending institutions, would be the most far-reaching easing of the 18-year-old United States trade embargo against its former wartime enemy. 
 An official familiar with the Administration's deliberations said the idea of allowing American companies to bid for projects financed by international lending institutions is considered a compromise between simply allowing Vietnam to access to loans and completely lifting the embargo.
Senior Administration officials say President Clinton will probably decide on the issue this week. One official stressed that he may not make any change in policy.
Representatives of business groups seeking trade with Vietnam say that permitting American companies to bid on development projects financed by international lending institutions would only allow a narrow range of American companies access to Vietnam's potential market. For example, American petroleum companies, seeking to exploit Vietnam's offshore oil fields would not be permitted to execute contracts with Hanoi. Nor would trading companies seeking to import rice or textiles from Vietnam.
Mr. Clinton has come under increasing pressure by groups on all sides of the question of whether the United States should ease tensions with Vietnam. All sides agree that the main issue is Hanoi's cooperation in determining the fate of 2,260 American servicemen who are listed as unaccounted for from the Southeast Asia wars.
Some veterans groups such as the American Legion, and their allies in Congress, argue that no improvement of relations between the United States and Vietnam should be undertaken.
"We've urged him not to approve the loan by the I.M.F. because of the fact that Vietnam has not cooperated with respect to the P.O.W./M.I.A issue.," said John Sommer, executive director of the American Legion. "They continue to dribble out a document or two relating to missing Americans when it suits their purpose or when they are seriously criticized for not cooperating."
Others, such as Senator John Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat who headed the Select Committee on P.O.W./M.I.A. Affairs, say some reciprocal action is needed to insure Hanoi's continued help in the search for unaccounted for Americans.
Maj. Gen. Thomas G. Needham, the Pentagon official in charge of the search for unaccounted for Americans, has told Administration officials and lawmakers that Hanoi's cooperation in the search "is at its highest level."
With Hanoi's help, 104 of the 196 American servicemen who were considered to have had the best chance of survival after being captured or shot down over Vietnam have officially been determined to have died, Department of Defense officials said. Investigators have also checked 66 cases of Americans whom defectors or other individuals have reported seeing alive in the years since the war. According to Mr. Kerry, no evidence has been discovered that the Americans were alive.
Hanoi has also produced new documents that have been demanded by American investigators and allowed interrogation of top military leaders.
Administration officials also say that pressure is building on them from allies such as Japan and France to at least not stand in the way of new lending by the monetary fund.
In April, the two countries asked the United States how it would view a plan to lend Vietnam $140 million to pay off debts incurred when Hanoi conquered the South and as a result assumed loans that had been granted to the old South Vietnamese Government. Once Hanoi becomes current in its loans to the monetary fund, it would be eligible for new World Bank and Asian Development Bank loans.

HEADLINE: Punitive Tariffs Raised Against Foreign Steel

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
In a move angering European and Asian steelmakers, the Clinton Administration announced steep penalties today on steel from 19 countries that the Commerce Department said had been sold at less than fair value.
The ruling would more than double the price of some imported steel -- and, for many foreign companies, significantly increase punitive duties beyond the levels of the preliminary penalties announced in January. 
 American manufacturers hailed the ruling. They have been hurt by a worldwide glut of steelmaking capacity and by foreign makers' efforts to maintain their share of the market by selling steel here for less than what they charge at home. "Today's decision confirms an egregious distortion of the international marketplace by foreign steel producers," said Curtis H. Barnette, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation. "We applaud the Commerce Department for enforcing the trade laws."
 
Negative Views Abroad
 Trade officials from other countries assailed the action while American officials denied their assertions that it was protectionist.
According to American industry experts, the average punitive duty under today's ruling will be 36.45 percent, up from 27.04 percent in January. They range from 1.47 percent to 109 percent, with Brazil and Britain facing the highest punitive tariffs.
Argentine producers of cold-rolled steel saw their penalties jump to 51 percent from 20 percent in the preliminary ruling on Jan. 27. For a Belgian company, Cockerill Sambre, the penalty on hot-rolled steel soared to 62 percent from 5 percent.
The penalties could be eliminated if the United States International Trade Commission concludes within 45 days that the American industry has not been hurt by the foreign steel companies' practices.
Besides Britain, Brazil and Argentina, steelmakers were found in violation in Australia, Austria, Belgium, Canada, Finland, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, South Korea, Mexico, the Netherlands, Poland, Romania, Spain and Sweden.
 
Subsidy Penalties
 The Commerce Department also ordered duties, ranging from five-tenths of 1 percent to 73 percent, on steel from 12 countries that, it said, received improper subsidies from their governments.
Nations cited here were Austria, Belgium, Brazil, France, Germany, Italy, South Korea, Mexico, New Zealand, Spain, Sweden and Britain.
Foreign officials soon deplored the action taken in Washington. Among the voices from overseas condemning the American decision was that of Sir Leon Brittan, Commissioner for External Economic Affairs of the European Community. Sir Leon said that the American industry's woes come not from overseas but from excessive production capacity at home.
"It is unacceptable that steel imports from the European Community and 13 other countries should be used as a whipping boy for problems arising largely from domestic competition within the United States," he said.
Charles H. Blum, an adviser to European steel companies, saw another set of consequences. "These results clearly mean at least a temporary end to shipments to the U.S. for a lot of foreign suppliers, including some big ones," Mr. Blum said.
Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, trying to deflect charges that the Clinton Administration was being protectionist, said that the decision today was a technical, legal one, rather than a political judgment.
"The Administration," Mr. Brown said, "fully supports the rights of the domestic industry to obtain relief from unfair trade practices under U.S. law, and will make certain that these laws are enforced in fair and effective manner."
Since the preliminary penalties were announced, the Commerce Department has gathered detailed information on foreign-made steel, including selling prices, production costs and subsidy levels.
Some foreign steelmakers got moderately good news today. For the South Koreans, penalties declined, with the punitive duties on plate steel and hot-rolled steel now about 8 percent.
Thomas J. Usher, president of the U.S. Steel Group, said the dumping showed that foreign manufacturers were "exporting unemployment to the United States."
To buttress their arguments, American manufacturers filed papers with the International Trade Commission on Monday, asserting that Japanese and European steelmakers had set up a cartel, restricting steel trade.
They contended that the Europeans and Japanese had signed an agreement assigning specific spheres of influence in the Eastern Hemisphere to European and Japanese producers, with the line of demarcation running through Myanmar, the country formerly known as Burma. This agreement, they said, distorted the flow of trade and imposed a handicap on American steelmakers.
Industry officials in European countries and South Korea issued statements in response today, saying that instead of resorting to penalties, the United States should help push for an international steel agreement that address the industry's complex problems, including overcapacity.
Alan Wolff, a lawyer representing the American industry, maintained that it had done more than its competitors to reduce excess capacity.
"The U.S. industry has rationalized," Mr. Wolff said. "We are now the most competitive in man-hours per ton. It's utter nonsense to say we are trying to pass the burden of adjustment onto others."
The case was filed a year ago by nearly a dozen American producers. In addition to USX, the parent company of U.S. Steel, and Bethlehem, those bringing the action were Armco Inc., Geneva Steel, Gulf States Steel, Inland Steel, LTV Steel, Lukens Inc., National Steel, Sharon Steel and WCI Steel.

HEADLINE: Congressional Roundup;
Senate Passes a Smaller Stimulus Bill

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
The Senate today approved by voice vote a far smaller version of President Clinton's ill-fated economic stimulus package, with fresh financing for summer jobs and child immunization and an unexpected last-minute Republican addition on welfare.
The supplemental appropriations bill is a diminutive orphan of the original $16 billion stimulus package, which was killed on April 21 after a Republican filibuster. The new $1.9 billion bill is not proposed as an economic stimulus because it includes a few million dollars more in cuts than added expenditures, but it will bring some relief to hard-pressed cities. 
 Reflecting growing support for imposing restrictions on welfare aid, the Senate also approved by voice vote an amendment proposed by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, requiring that state and local governments institute workfare programs for able-bodied welfare recipients without dependents or risk losing their Federal share of welfare funds.
Under the amendment, states would be required to enlist 10 percent of qualifying welfare recipients in workfare programs after a year. About 20 states already have such programs.
 
Moynihan Motion Defeated
 The proposal by Mr. D'Amato passed after a motion to kill it, offered by his Democratic colleague from New York, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, was defeated by a vote of 64 to 34. A similar amendment was approved last year but did not survive a Senate-House conference committee, and a similar fate is expected for this year's version.
Mr. D'Amato said the measure would simply put into effect the President's own ideas on welfare changes. But Administration officials have said they are in only the early stages of what is bound to be a broad and complicated effort to translate those ideas into legislation.
The appropriations measure provides $200 million in Justice Department grants to local governments to expand law-enforcement programs, $360 million in financial aid to students, $175 million in loan guarantees for small businesses and $200 million in summer jobs. But most of the money will go to the military, with $750 million for the Somalia operation.
The measure is expected to create 160,000 summer jobs nationwide, 12,500 of which will be filled in New York State, roughly half of which will go to New York City. New Jersey will be allotted 6,500 summer jobs, and Connecticut 1,600 more.
 
Democrats Disappointed
 While support for the measure was bipartisan, Democrats largely expressed disappointment with the bill while Republicans praised it.
"It's better than nothing, but it's not the son of stimulus," said Senator Harry Reid, a Nevada Democrat. He complained that cities would receive funds too late in the summer to plan an adequate summer jobs program.
Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, said the Senate's decision to reject more deficit spending and pass a more modest measure showed that "Congress has gotten the message: We have to make cuts first."
The bill must still be reconciled with a House version that includes $120 million more for summer jobs and $290 million for construction of waste-water treatment plants.
 
Gain for Abortion Rights
 Abortion-rights advocates won a modest victory today when the House passed the $22.7 billion Treasury-Postal Service appropriations bill without language barring Federal employees' health-care benefits from covering abortion.
The prohibition had been included in the spending bill every year since 1983.
The bill, which passed by a party-line vote of 241 to 171, largely followed President Clinton's spending objectives for the Treasury Department, the Postal Service and the President's executive offices.
Abortion opponents chose to fight another day. They plan to make their stand in the House Appropriations Committee on Thursday when they try to reinstate a provision prohibiting Medicaid from covering abortions. An appropriations subcommittee dropped the ban on Government payments for elective abortions for poor women, reversing a policy that has been in effect since 1977.
 
Loss for Ex-Presidents
 An amendment to the spending bill passed today would be unpleasant news for the five living former Presidents.
Pushed mainly by deficit-hawk freshmen in the House, the amendment limits the former Presidents to five more years of Government financing for clerical staff, mail services, office rentals and travel. Mr. Clinton would be limited to five years of such services once he leaves office.
Such clerical and office expenditures now cost the Treasury $2 million a year. That is a small fraction of the amount it costs for the Secret Service to protect former Presidents, a service that will not be touched by the measure.
Representative Karen Shepherd of Utah, a Democratic sponsor of the amendment, said the amendment was symbolically important because "this is simply a case of saying that the Federal budget deficit is forcing us to take a tough new look at all Federal spending." Lifetime financing for these offices, she added, "is something we just cannot afford."

HEADLINE: Finding Strong Allies for Foreign Aid

SERIES: SPECIAL PLEADERS -- A Periodic Look At Lobbying

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
Back in May, when political analysts and even the White House budget director were making dire predictions about the fate of President Clinton's Russian aid package, David Nagle, a former Iowa Congressman, figured about 40 people would come to a meeting to put together a lobbying strategy for the program.
About 90 showed up. 
 There were Jewish groups and Ukrainian groups, labor groups and manufacturers, farmers, arms-control advocates and environmentalists, as well as businessmen and foreign trade organizations.
Mr. Nagle, a Democrat and a nervous, chain-smoking lawyer who likes to joke that he works out of a "shack" off Main Street in downtown Waterloo, knew that foreign aid bills could win support, having once put together a similar group to help President George Bush move his aid proposals for Russia through Congress. But the turnout exceeded even his wildest expectations.
"We were astounded," said Mr. Nagle, adding that the attendance at his meeting suggested what subsequent events were later to prove: Contrary to the conventional wisdom that foreign aid has no natural constituency, the Administration's Russian aid package would not have a bit of trouble in the House.
 
Victory by Wide Margin
 Indeed, last week, when the votes were taken, the bills providing $13 billion in foreign aid, including $2.5 billion in assistance to the republics of the former Soviet Union were approved by a surprisingly wide margin. The bill authorizing the Administration to spend money on foreign aid passed by a voice vote, while the appropriations bill was approved 309 to 111.
One major reason for that vote is that while American people generally view foreign aid as a giveaway, such bills are in the political, and, more important, economic self-interests of a large assortment of interest groups.
Among the 58 groups that lobbied members of the House for the foreign aid bill were farmers who would benefit from increased agricultural credit for grain sales to Russia. Manufacturers saw a potential market for their products overseas; Jewish organizations were concerned that political instability in Russia would foster anti-Semitism there, and peace groups worried that a return of a bellicose Russia would lead to a new arms race. Ethnic groups like Ukrainian-Americans were worried that chaos in the former Soviet Union would worsen ethnic tensions.
"At one meeting we had pork producers sitting next to the Jewish groups, which I thought was kind of ironic," Mr. Nagle said. "At another meeting we had the Armenian-Americans sitting next to Azerbaijanis" even though their cousins in the former Soviet Union are warring with one another over territory.
 
Using Pledge of Support
 Under what were called Nagle's rules, members of the coalition were free to pursue their own narrow interest in the foreign aid bill. But each had to pledge to support the final version. The idea was that once support was mustered for foreign aid in general, and aid to Russia in particular, it could last for years. So if a group did not win what it wanted this year, it could return to the issue next time around.
The group also decided to steal a page from the Pentagon's past lobbying efforts and used the argument that aid to Russia would produce jobs for Americans.
"Historically, the former Soviet Union was the third-largest importer of pork in the world," said Alan Tank, vice president for public policy and trade for the American Pork Producers Council. "Knowing that our competition, most notably the European Community, are very aggressively pursuing that market, raises the interest in our minds of trying to provide impetus for Russia to deal with the United States over the long run, rather than dealing with someone else."
But backers of the foreign aid bills did not rely solely on the economic advantages of helping Russia. The committees that wrote the bills produced lean pieces of legislation that actually reduced foreign aid both from the Administration's request and from last year's levels. The House leadership was able to persuade their counterparts on the Republican side, including the minority leader, Robert H. Michel of Illinois, and the minority whip, Newt Gingrich of Georgia, to support the measure.
Business organizations like the United States Chamber of Commerce and the National Association of Manufacturers were attracted by a transfer of $300 million from the Agency for International Development to a pilot program run by the Trade Development Agency that would guarantee loans for overseas capital projects. Jewish groups were kept on board by insuring that aid to Israel was not cut.
 
Different Groups, Same Result
 Because of the defeat in the Senate of the Administration's $16.3 billion package to stimulate the economy and President Clinton's withdrawal of Lani Guinier to head the Justice Department's civil rights division, the chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus had threatened retribution by defeating the foreign aid bill. But a $100 million increase in aid to Africa helped mollify the caucus.
In the end, members of the black caucus voted 31 to 6 to defeat an amendment in the authorization bill that would have drastically slashed Russian aid and voted 20 to 17 against a similar, less drastic amendment in the appropriations bill.
"This was the most smooth-running expeditious treatment of this issue that I've seen," said Representative Howard L. Berman, a California Democrat who was in charge of lining up votes on the Democratic side before the vote on the floor. "Certainly this year, with all the fights on a partisan basis, this was a stellar exception."
But in the end, supporters said the day was won by the economic argument, coupled with a coalition of interest groups that would hold representatives accountable for a rejection of foreign aid. That was especially the case, they said, among the freshmen, many of whom ran on platforms arguing that the nation needs to pay more attention to domestic needs, and not be responsible for curing the world's ills.
"We really leaned on the freshmen," said one Congressional aide involved in the lobbying effort. "We made it clear that if they thought this was going to be an easy no vote, they were mistaken. They had to understand that this is the reason you come to Washington, bud. If you just want to vote to fix potholes, you could have stayed home. Now you can vote no to foreign aid, but with all these groups, we can assure you that there will be somebody in your district who will remember and will call you on this."
In the final vote on the appropriations bill, freshman from both parties voted 89 to 23 in favor of foreign aid.

HEADLINE: Tired After 2 Decades at City Hall, Young Will Retire as Detroit Mayor

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 22

 BODY:
After dominating Detroit politics and government for two decades, Coleman A. Young, the first black Mayor of the nation's eighth-largest city, said today that he no longer had the vitality to campaign for office or run a big city and would not seek re-election this fall.
Mr. Young, who is 75 and suffers from emphysema, had kept everyone guessing about his intentions until a news conference this afternoon. For weeks he had told reporters and confidants that he had not decided whether to run for a sixth four-year term. 
 On Monday night he made his decision, he said at the news conference, which began a few minutes after the 4 P.M. filing deadline for the mayoral primary on Sept. 14.
"I have had many people tell me that they would help me campaign, should I decide to run," he said. "But I don't campaign like that. I campaign all out."
 
'It Would Be a Disservice'
 During his last year in office, he said, "I have not been able to put out the effort."
"Should I win another term," he went on, "I do not think I could put as much into the job as I believe it deserves or demands. It would be a disservice to my own standards to be able to deliver anything less than 100 percent."
Mr. Young becomes the latest recent political retiree among a group of blacks whose election and longevity as big-city mayors brought a new era of black urban enfranchisement beginning in the 1960's. Tom Bradley, who decided last year against a re-election campaign, will leave office on July 1 after 20 years as Mayor of Los Angeles, and Maynard Jackson announced only two weeks ago that he would not seek election to a fourth term as Mayor of Atlanta.
Here in Detroit, Mr. Young's decision provides an opportunity for fresh leadership and political initiatives in a city that suffers from a high rate of crime, extensive blight and vast unemployment. More than a dozen candidates have filed for the primary, a nonpartisan election whose two top vote-getters will meet in a runoff on Nov. 2 if no one wins a majority.
 
Conyers Files to Run
 Among the candidates is United States Representative John Conyers Jr., a leading member of the Congressional Black Caucus who was routed by Mr. Young in the mayoral primary four years ago and who filed at the last minute today to run again.
At least four of the candidates are Young supporters or former proteges: Dennis Archer, a former Chief Justice of the Michigan Supreme Court; Sharon McPhail, a former prosecutor; Arthur Blackwell, chairman of the Wayne County Commission, and Paul Hubbard, onetime head of an urban coalition.
But the Mayor did not immediately anoint a political heir today, saying that "I have to review the situation after the smoke clears."
 
A Battling Chief Executive
 Mr. Young, a onetime union organizer and State Senator who first won election as Mayor in 1973, became a feisty, frequently contentious chief executive who was also a symbol of black enfranchisement and opportunity. With the onset of the Young administration, the Police Department, which during that first campaign he had called "an army of occupation," began to diversify, offering an increasing number of jobs to blacks and women.
Extolling his record today, Mr. Young told reporters that in the year before his election Detroit "issued fewer than $20,000 worth of contracts to minority-owned businesses" and that since 1988 "we have averaged more than $125 million a year" to minority-owned concerns.
He also pointed to development efforts along the city's riverfront, to an expanded convention center and to industrial policies that had resulted in construction of two automobile assembly plants within the city's limits.
But it was also during his administration that this city of 1.2 million people, 70 percent of whom are black, declined by many standard measures of economy, education, public safety and public health. Drug abuse is rampant here, and much of the housing is substandard. Abandoned buildings dot the city.
Mr. Young often blamed racism and outsiders for Detroit's problems. He pointed to whites' flight to the suburbs, a Federal Government unwilling to channel enough money to projects that would improve the city and an auto industry whose declining job base had depressed the income of Detroiters. His relationship with the City Council was rocky, marked by repeated fighting over budget deficits.
Further, his administration was not without taint of corruption among his appointees. Just 13 months ago, for instance, a jury convicted William Hart, whom Mr. Young had appointed Police Chief, of embezzling $2.6 million.
And the Police Department that the Mayor had tried to make reflective of the city's people suffered a further blow last year when three police officers were charged in the fatal beating of a black motorist. The officers are now on trial.
For much of his administration, Mr. Young was a target of criticism by news organizations here, lampooned in editorial cartoons and faulted in investigative articles. He, in turn, was often reclusive. During infrequent meetings with reporters, he lashed back at critical questions with attacks of his own, often laced with profanity.
The acrimony has not been without the press's appreciation for his impact on the city's political life. Last weekend Thomas J. Bray, editorial-page editor of The Detroit News and a critic of the Mayor, wrote that he hoped Mr. Young would run again, for in that case "the winner would not be mayor by default, but mayor in his or her own right."
"The new mayor would have bested not just another candidate," Mr. Bray said, "but a foe with a formidable political reputation and record."

HEADLINE: Japan Scorns Fund for Russia

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 22

 BODY:
Japan's Foreign Minister, Kabun Muto, said today that a Clinton Administration proposal to create a $4 billion fund to help turn Russia's state-owned enterprises into private companies was "preposterous," and added that an agreement had been reached to scale the fund back to about $500 million.
The proposal was made in April during a meeting here of the finance and foreign ministers of the Group of Seven industrial democracies. The meeting produced an agreement to provide $28 billion in aid to support Russia's transition to a capitalist economy, but the $4 billion fund was not part of that total. 
 Clinton Administration officials said they wanted the fund to finance the purchase of state-owned enterprises by private interests. But the other countries failed to support the proposal.
Today, Mr. Muto called the fund "a preposterous suggestion" and said it was too early to finance privatization, arguing that Russia still did not have the basic ingredients of a capitalist system, such as entrepreneurs, office workers and other employees trained in the basics of a market economy and willing to work hard.
Mr. Muto made his remarks at the monthly meeting of a study group on international affairs, which was attended by businessmen and journalists. The comments were quoted by the Kyodo News Service and the general content was confirmed by Foreign Ministry officials.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen acknowledged today that it "would be very difficult to achieve" the goal of $4 billion for the privatization fund. But Administration officials disputed Mr. Muto's assertion that the Group of Seven had agreed to scale back the fund to $500 million, saying that exact funding levels have not yet been set.
Mr. Muto said today that Japan would divert money already promised for Russia to the privatization fund, not provide new money.

HEADLINE: Budget in California Shuffles Taxes to Close a Gap

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 22

 BODY:
California appears to have avoided a state budget crisis this year. But the price will be steep, in health care, parks, libraries, welfare and still higher college fees -- and the possible outright defiance of county governments at what they consider the illegal expropriation of their property taxes by the strapped state government.
Under enormous public pressure to avoid the kind of stalemate that forced the state to pay its bills with i.o.u.'s for more than two months last summer, the State Senate early this morning narrowly passed a Rube Goldberg-type of budget meant to get the recession-racked state government through another year. 
 The State Assembly had fallen into line a day earlier, dragged kicking and screaming by Speaker Willie L. Brown Jr., a Democrat, and Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican, who both said there was no other choice for the state. California faces a $9 billion gap between spending and expected revenue in the $52.1 billion budget that starts July 1.
In essence, the budget robs Peter to pay Paul, but then allows Peter to rob somebody else.
 
$2.6 Billion Tax Transfer
 The plan would balance the state budget, as required by law, in part by transferring $2.6 billion in property taxes raised by counties, cities and other local governments to pay the state's obligation to support public schools. But to offset the loss to the local governments, the plan then extends a "temporary" half-cent increase in the state sales tax. The increase, which was to expire next week, will remain for half a year until the taxpayers vote in November on making it permanent.
If they do -- a big if -- that would replace about $1.4 billion a year of the lost local taxes, but it is all earmarked for law enforcement and fire protection. In addition, the plan would relieve local governments of about $500 million a year in spending mandated by state laws for health, welfare and transportation, among other programs.
 
'It's a Shell Game'
 The property tax transfer is the biggest part of the Governor's plan to make up the $9 billion shortage. The rest of the gap will be filled by methods ranging from raising fees at community colleges by 50 percent to cutting grants to the aged, blind and disabled by 3 percent.
"It's a shell game," said an angry Ed Edelman, chairman of the Board of Supervisors of Los Angeles County, which will suffer half the losses faced by the state's 58 counties. "It is an assault on local governments' home rule." Lifting the state-imposed mandates on counties to feed and house the indigent, he said, was illusory.
Mr. Edelman said he expected Los Angeles County, the state's largest county, to lead the fight against the property-tax transfer. In an interview after returning from lobbying the Legislature, he said: "We are going to refuse to send our property taxes to the state. Let them solve the state budget but not on our backs."
But all over California, local leaders were preparing for the worst. In Northern California, Alameda County, which includes Oakland, expects to lay off 1,200 workers next week. The property tax transfer would sap $96 million from the county's $1 billion budget.
Governor Wilson, facing a tough re-election fight next year, is expected to sign the budget after the Legislature passes 19 separate bills that carry out the various taxing and spending changes. While the details of the bills will be hard fought, legislators and their aides said there was little doubt that they would pass by July 1, given the unusual alliance between Governor Wilson and the two legislative Democratic leaders, Speaker Brown and Senator David A. Roberti, president pro tem of the Senate.
Last year, a standoff between Mr. Brown and Mr. Wilson led to a 63-day crisis in which the state had no budget and ran out of cash, leaving many businesses unpaid for goods they had supplied. Politicians at the Capitol were saying today that Mr. Brown was willing to back most of Mr. Wilson's budget, hoping the voters would blame the Governor for the pain.
 
Trying to Avoid Gridlock
 A spokeswoman for Mr. Brown, Darolyn Davis, said he simply wanted to avoid the "gridlock" of last year. "The Speaker realizes we are in the worst shape California has been for years," she said. "This is the best we are going to come up with."
Recession-scarred Los Angeles County alone stood to lose $273 million in property taxes, which would force a 16 percent budget cut across all departments except for law enforcement. The county would face the loss of another $150 million if voters turn down the sales-tax extension. Overall, the cut from the current year would be 11 percent, to $12.3 billion.
Harry L. Hufford, the county's chief administrative officer, said the budget would mean closing one or more of the county hospitals and health centers, curtailing residential care and outpatient programs for the mentally ill, closing 10 libraries and reducing hours by half at other libraries and ending the purchase of new books, magazines and newspapers. In addition, he said, lifeguard service at eight state beaches would be terminated and three-fourths of all swimming pools at 23 parks would be closed.
But according to District Attorney Gil Garcetti, police and sheriff departments and prosecutors came out "safe" in the budget, assuming voters approve the sales tax in November. "No doubt law-enforcement appears to have come out O.K.," he said, speaking of statewide enforcement.
In Alameda County, Supervisor Don Perata described an atmosphere of "community depression."
"All our pleading, all of our cajoling, all of our protests got us nowhere," he said. "We didn't expect miracles, but the legislators absolved themselves of public responsibility."
 
Court Challenge Is Seen
 Governor Wilson had originally proposed to have each county vote on whether to extend the sales tax locally, but the final budget plan calls for a uniform statewide vote this November in which a majority vote will be sufficient. This is likely to be challenged in court by anti-tax groups.
As for the property-tax transfer, Governor Wilson has argued that the state was only reclaiming money it had given to bail out local governments after their ability to raise taxes was limited by the passage of Proposition 13 in 1978.
There were few people defending the budget agreement vigorously, least of all Assemblyman John Vasconcellos of San Jose, the lone Assembly Democrat to vote against it. As the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, he had proposed using the sales taxes to pay off state debts rather than financing local services.
The budget does little to solve underlying fiscal problems of the largest state, problems brought on by a combination of the recession and years of limits on taxing and spending voted by Californians.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Canada Rate at 20-Year Low

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TORONTO, June 22

 BODY:
Canada's official interest rate fell today to a 20-year low, paving the way for prime lending rates to dip below those of the United States for the first time since 1984.
The Bank of Canada rate, which sets the trend for short-term interest rates, dropped to 4.88 percent from 4.94 percent at its weekly setting. 
 Andrew Pyle, chief economist for MMS International, said that Canada's leading banks could follow sometime this week with a cut in prime lending rates from 6 percent to their lowest levels since the mid-1960's.
United States prime rates are currently at 6 percent as well.
But unlike the United States, where interest rates have bottomed, Canada's sluggish recovery and negligible inflation give interest rates further room to ease, economists said. The recession hit Canada twice as hard as the United States, they added.
Inflation is practically nonexistent in Canada. The country's consumer price index fell by two-tenths of 1 percent in May after rising by the same rate in April.
Mr. Pyle said the Bank of Canada rate could fall another 25 to 50 basis points, or a quarter to half a percentage point, during the summer.
The central bank's anti-inflation policy, worldwide deflationary pressures and the recession have caused the Bank of Canada rate and prime rates to fall sharply from the spring of 1990.
The Bank of Canada has exceeded its tough inflation targets of 3 percent at the end of 1992 and 2.5 percent by mid-1994.
