HEADLINE: Beyond 'Jurassic Park': Few Jobs in Old Bones

 BODY:
Michael Kass forges through intensive courses in geology, mathematics and chemistry. He spends summer vacations searching for ancient bones in hot, dusty quarries. Words like "Mesozoic" and "velociraptor" roll easily off his tongue.
But Mr. Kass, a graduate student in paleontology at Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah, worries that he will not find a job once he leaves school. After all, few paleontologists have the luxury of hunting dinosaur fossils for a living, like the adventure-seeking duo in the movie "Jurassic Park." Other opportunities, including museum work, teaching and research, are almost as scarce. 
 "You can be very interested, motivated and qualified and still have a hard time finding work," said Mr. Kass, who hopes to teach at a university.
Thanks in part to the dinosaur mania that has swept the nation in recent years, more college students than ever are studying prehistoric life. Last fall, almost 600 students took an introductory dinosaur class at the University of California in Berkeley. And at the University of Michigan, 300 students take a survey course on dinosaurs each semester.
 
Who Will Pay?
 But intimidating course requirements and bleak employment prospects limit the number of students who actually major in paleontology, said Daniel C. Fisher, a professor of geological sciences at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor.
"There is great intellectual interest in the history of life," said Dr. Fisher, who advises 12 graduate students in paleontology. "But who is going to pay for people to study it?"
Only 30 undergraduates listed paleontology as their major in a nationwide survey of geology department heads conducted last year by the American Geological Institute in Alexandria, Va. There were 182 candidates for graduate degrees in paleontology.
But in the wake of "Jurassic Park," paleontology departments across the country are bracing for an influx of new students, said Robert S. Cox, an adjunct lecturer at the University of Michigan who has taught a survey course titled "Dinosaurs" since 1985.
"I haven't seen the enrollment figures yet, but I'm sure they'll be through the roof," Mr. Cox said.
"A lot of these kids have loved dinosaurs since they were little," he said. "Virtually everyone I've known in this field grew up exploring the natural world."
Mr. Kass, who loved dinosaurs as a child, forgot about them for years and studied business administration in college. But one day, he bought a toy dinosaur in a gift shop. "After that, I was totally hooked again," he said.
In a telephone interview from the paleontology laboratory at Brigham Young, where the bones of a giant Ultrasaurus tower overhead, Mr. Kass was eager to discuss Mososaur, the dinosaur he is studying for his master's thesis.
"I tend to like carnivorous animals, and Mososaur was the swimming version of Tyrannosaurus rex," he said. "Take the lions on the African plain and picture something 10 times bigger, faster and meaner."
 
More Need for Protection
 Although some paleontologists grumble about the flood of publicity "Jurassic Park" has brought their field, students hope it will expand their career opportunities. Several paleontologists helped design the mechanized dinosaurs for "Jurassic Park," and theme parks and traveling exhibits featuring life-size dinosaur models are in the works.
If the movie promotes a national interest in dinosaur hunting, there will also be an increased need to protect fossils, said Peter Robinson, a professor of natural sciences at the University of Colorado in Boulder. The Federal Bureau of Land Management hired several paleontologists this year to help analyze and preserve fossils in Western states.
"There are an awful lot of amateur fossil collectors out there, and someone needs to regulate them," Dr. Robinson said.
Even so, many paleontology students make sure they have backup plans. David Varricchio, a graduate student at Montana State University in Bozeman, will receive a Ph.D. in biology next year and teach anatomy. "I figure I can get a job teaching premedical students and do dinosaur research on the side," he said.
Since the Western states have some of the best fossil reserves in the world, many paleontology students apply to graduate schools there. In the summer, they work "in the field," extracting delicate bones from quarries. Field projects, some say, are the best part of their studies.
"Dozens of students want to go on the digs, but we can only take a limited number," said Wade E. Miller, a professor of geology and paleontology at Brigham Young. "With so few opportunities, we need to be very selective and weed out talent."
Mr. Varricchio said he is looking forward to July and August, which he will spend unearthing fossils in northwestern Montana. "Compiling the data back in the lab can be frustrating," he said. "But digging up bones is never boring."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The recent interest in dinosaurs is expected to result in an increase in college students studying paleontology, but employment prospects in the field are few. Wade E. Miller, a professor of geology and paleontology at Brigham Young, displayed the leg bones of an Ultrasaurus. (George Frey for The New York Times)

TITLE: JURASSIC PARK (MOVIE); EDUCATION PAGE (NYT)

HEADLINE: Health-Care Chiefs' Pay Rises at Issue

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
The pay of the chief executives of 26 top health-care corporations is rising rapidly and is unrelated to the size or success of their companies, according to testimony scheduled to be delivered before a Congressional subcommittee Wednesday.
Graef Crystal, an expert on executive compensation at the University of California at Berkeley, will say in his prepared testimony, which was released today to certain news organizations, that compensation for health- care executives ranged widely in 1992 at the 26 companies he studied. 
 According to Mr. Crystal, these salaries ranged from $696,000 for the chief of Beverly Enterprises, David R. Banks, to $8.8 million for the chief of Merck, Dr. Roy P. Vagelos. If the value of cashed-in stock options is included, the highest pay was $127 million to the chief executive of the Hospital Corporation of America, Thomas F. Frist Jr.
The median pay for the chief executives of the 26 companies Mr. Crystal studied was $2.9 million. In 1985, the median pay of the chief executives of the 26 companies was 97 times higher than that of a janitor. By 1992, the pay was 192 times higher, Mr. Crystal asserts. In 1985, the ratio of chief executive pay to a nurse was 54 to 1, and in 1992 it had risen to 85 to 1.
 
Similar to Other Industries
 Mr. Crystal said the scale of pay at American health-care companies was similar to that of executives at companies in other American industries, but far higher than companies in nations such as France, Germany, Japan and Britain. He said that the ratio of executive pay to that of other workers in those countries was in the range of 20 to 1 to perhaps 33 to 1.
Michael D. Bromberg, executive director of the Federation of American Health Systems, a trade association of some 1,400 investor-owned hospitals, said today in a telephone interview that he could not dispute Mr. Crystal's economic analysis. But, he said, "there are two values here that are important: the value to the stockholders, and to the customers."
He said that health-care stockholders have done well by their investments, adding that executive compensation goes unnoticed by consumers because, spread over all the products and prices, the compensation costs consumers "pennies."
"I just don't know where the problem is here. No one is getting ripped off in this," he said. "The rhetoric Mr. Crystal is using is old populist rhetoric. The compensation sounds exorbitant to anyone. But Americans are getting good value."
Mr. Crystal is expected to testify Wednesday before the House Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations of the Energy and Commerce Committee, which is looking into Federal health-care costs.
In a telephone interview today, he disagreed with Mr. Bromberg. He said that the difference between other companies and health-care companies was that the main customers of the health companies were the taxpayers in the form of Medicare and Medicaid expenditures. "It is the taxpayers who are getting ripped off," he said.
To compare compensation with performance, Mr. Crystal measured a chief executive's direct salary, bonuses and the present value of stock options against stock appreciation plus dividends of a company.
He said that while some companies reported they linked bonuses and stock options to company performance, there were too many loopholes in compensation packages for those links to be effective.
Also at Wednesday's hearing, the General Accounting Office will offer testimony about the Hospital Corporation of America. The corporation, which includes some 500 hospitals worldwide, was audited by the G.A.O. in an attempt to discover how much of its cost would be disallowed or found questionable under Federal rules of health-care cost reimbursement.
Most of the $2.6 million in administrative expenses reviewed by the accounting office in its audit of the company's fiscal year that ended September 1991 had not been charged to Medicare programs, but rather was distributed widely among costs to be paid by private insurance.
Only about $10,000 of that found to be unallowable by the G.A.O. was actually charged to the Government, corporation officials said.
 
Amount Is Unallowable
 However, in looking at questionable expenses in general, whether they were charged to patients or Medicare, the G.A.O. found about $1.1 million of the $2.6 million reviewed to be unallowable or questionable. This included everything from $51,000 for trips, tickets to performances and other entertainment to $26,000 to counteract negative publicity from an investigation by Texas authorities into the practices of some psychiatric hospitals.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Little Movement in Treasury Rates

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Interest rates were little changed yesterday as securities dealers concentrated on digesting a large supply of new Treasury issues while awaiting more economic data to provide clues to future rate moves.
At the regular monthly auction of new two-year notes, the Treasury sold $16 billion of 4 1/8 percent notes with an average yield of 4.14 percent. The average rate was little changed from 4.17 percent a month earlier and closer to the bottom than the top of its range for the last six months. Since late 1992 the two-year issue has ranged from a high of 4.72 percent on Dec. 22 to a low of 3.88 percent on April 27. 
 In advance of today's auction of $11 billion of new five-year Treasury notes, dealers traded the issue at about 5.18 percent, down from 5.19 percent. The bellwether of the long- term bond market, the 7 1/8 percent Treasury issue due in 2023, was offered late in the day at 10416/32 , up 1/32 , to yield 6.77 percent, unchanged from Monday.
After repaying maturing securities, the Treasury would raise a total of $5.4 billion of new cash through the sale of new two-year and five-year issues. Although the Treasury's plan to sharply reduce sales of long-term bonds requires larger offerings of shorter maturities, the size of the two-year and five-year issues have not prevented those issues from rising in price and declining in yield so far this week.
In the short-term market, Treasury bill rates were unchanged from Monday's auctions at 3.10 percent and 3.19 percent for three-month and six-month issues, respectively. In advance of tomorrow's $15.25 billion auction of new one-year bills, the issue was traded by dealers at 3.38 percent.
The overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market, a closely watched barometer of the Federal Reserve policy, traded between 215/16 percent and 3 percent during the day. That rate was little changed from recent days, an indication that the Fed was not in the midst of any adjustments to monetary policy.
 
Tax-Exempt Bonds
 Demand remains brisk for tax-exempt issues as securities dealers tap a large reservoir of individuals who are buying directly or through mutual funds. Investor appetite is large, both because higher income tax rates proposed by President Clinton make tax-exempt bonds more attractive, and because the heavy volume of refunding by local governments has put billions of cash in the hands of investors who are now looking for new investments.
John F. Lahive, the head of municipal bond trading for T. Rowe Price, the mutual fund company in Baltimore, noted that prices of new and recent issues have benefited by a noticeable decline in the supply of new issues expected over the next month. The expected supply for the next 30 days, compiled by the Bond Buyer, was about $6 billion yesterday, down from $8 billion two weeks ago, and a peak for the year of $9.9 billion on March 24.
Because offerings of new issues usually become scarcer in late June and early July, Mr. Lahive said there was a good chance that prices of tax-exempt bonds would stay strong, and possibly improve in relation to the Treasury market in coming weeks. Investors who receive large sums from the early retirement of bonds should buy new issues now, he said, rather than wait until mid-July when they will receive their checks.
 
Short- Term Issues Offered
 Among short-term issues, the New York City Water Finance Authority's $375 million of notes due in April 1994, were offered at 2.40 percent through underwriters led by W. R. Lazard Laidlaw, Mead. A $1.5 billion issue of Los Angeles County one-year notes was offered at 2.55 percent through Lehman Brothers.
Among long-term issues, demand was good enough that underwriters raised prices slightly to reduce the interest rates by five-hundredths of a percentage point to as much as 20-hundredths for various offerings. Even at lower yields, underwriters said large new offerings of revenue bonds for Seattle Light and Power and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey were sold out.
After prices were increased and rates cut, a $452 million issue of Seattle Light and Power revenue bonds was offered through Lehman Brothers with yields ranging from 2.55 percent for bonds due in 1994 to 4.35 percent in 1998, 5 percent in 2003 and a maximum yield of 5.70 percent for 2018. The Port Authority bonds were offered through Prudential Securities with yields ranging from 2.40 percent in 1994 to 4.10 percent in 1998, 4.80 percent in 2003 and 5.30 percent in 2011 and 2012.
Though the Port Authority bonds were rated A-1 Moody's Investors Service, or slightly lower than the Aa rating for the Seattle bonds, the Port Authority issue was offered with lower yields because it was a smaller issue and it appealed to New York investors seeking bonds exempt from state, city and Federal income taxes.

HEADLINE: A Nudging Up of Rates Is Considered by the Fed

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
After rising unexpectedly in the beginning of the year, inflation seemed to have abated in May, but the Federal Reserve remains haunted by its specter.
Another inflationary spike this year strikes most economists as unlikely in an economy that remains subdued. But the Fed's policy makers say they are toying with the notion of nudging up interest rates anyway to make doubly sure that inflation does not return. 
 "The logic is impeccable that inflation should not be a problem," said David W. Mullins Jr., the Federal Reserve's vice chairman. "But it has risen in recent months anyway, when it should not have. If inflation were to become re-established in the minds of the markets, with no timely response from the Fed, that could be damaging to the economy."
For the Fed, a "timely response" means an increase in rates before the end of the summer -- a possibility that Mr. Mullins and other Fed policy makers are for the first time discussing openly, in effect calling the strategy a pre-emptive strike against resurgent inflation. At least one high Administration official, declining to be named, said the Administration was prepared to accept a mild rate increase.
"At this point, a one-quarter of a percentage point rise in interest rates would have more of a psychological impact than an economic one," the Treasury Department official said.
The surge in inflation early this year led many economists to speculate that the Fed would respond by raising interest rates. At a policy meeting in May, Fed officials reportedly passed a resolution that in effect expressed a greater willingness to raise rates than to lower them, but the minutes from the meeting will not be made public until next month. Only now are Fed officials beginning to speak openly of raising rates soon -- as if preparing the American public for the change after nearly four years of pushing rates down.
Part of what makes the focus of the Fed on raising rates significant is its belief, shared by the Treasury Department, that the economy is growing at a 2.5 percent to 3 percent annual rate, or strongly enough to withstand a mild blow, such as a small interest rate increase. "There is good, solid economic growth," Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said, noting that job creation has risen in recent months.
Federal Reserve policy makers talk of pushing up interest rates on short-term loans as a way of getting people, particularly bond traders and businessmen, to stop expecting inflation at a time when labor is plentiful and inexpensive, and the nation is oversupplied with goods, conditions that make it difficult to raise prices. When people stop counting on inflation, the Federal Reserve argues, then interest rates fall on their own, which helps the economy, mainly by making mortgages less expensive and reducing the cost of the bonds that companies sell to modernize or expand their operations.
That sort of talk elicits various reactions. One is that the Federal Reserve and the Treasury are right: a small rate increase -- less than half a percentage point -- while sending the central bank's anti-inflation message, "won't make any difference at all in the slow upward drift of the economy," said Albert T. Sommers, a senior economist at the Conference Board, a research organization supported by corporations.
Then there is the view that a window of opportunity has opened, one that will close by early fall, and this window is the Fed's last chance for a while to deal with what it considers the inflationary potential. Once the budget bill now before Congress takes effect, bringing the nation higher taxes and less Government spending, the impact of these actions is likely to weaken the economy, at least temporarily. The Fed might even be forced to resume lowering rates again.
"You in the media are getting this spiel about higher rates because it is one of the Fed's potential strategies," said Henry Kaufman, the Wall Street economic consultant. "They are looking for an opportunity to raise rates, but they have to have the right economic support, and if they don't get it, at least they have made their point in the press." He suggested that another jump in inflation or strong employment growth would help give the Fed the opportunity to raise rates.
The justification for a rate increase originally developed when inflation, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, jumped to an annual rate of more than 4 percent from January through April.
The Fed's policy-making committee -- composed of Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, the six other Fed governors, and five of the 12 presidents of Federal Reserve regional banks -- voted in May in favor of a resolution that in the Fed's formulaic language predisposed the policy makers to raising interest rates.
But then the Consumer Price Index rose only slightly in May, the Government announced last week, and with that announcement, the inflation scare seemed to have passed.
Fed officials, however, are troubled that they still cannot adequately explain the inflation surge. Mostly they blame inflationary expectations, which they say are still embedded in public thinking as a holdover from the double-digit inflation of the late 1970's and early 1980's.
"If the reason for this inflationary spurt were judged to be a function of this psychology, then you would want to send a signal that you are not going to let it get out of hand," said John P. LaWare, a Fed governor. "But who knows at this stage of the game."
Administration officials express similar puzzlement. "The Treasury, the Council of Economic Advisers and the Fed, everyone is trying to find out what is going on with these price numbers," said Alicia Munnell, the Treasury's Assistant Secretary for Economic Policy.
But Mr. Greenspan and Mr. Mullins, if not Mr. LaWare, appear to be convinced that inflationary expectations play an important role. Anticipating a stronger economy and rising inflation, Mr. Mullins said, many executives may have tried earlier this year for price increases they had not been able to get in 1992.
The strong yen may also have played a role in the inflation surge, Mr. Mullins said, forcing Japanese auto makers to raise car prices, for example, and allowing the Big Three to follow suit -- again in the expectation that higher inflation might allow the price increases to stick.
Then there is the Labor Department's seasonal-adjustment formula for determining the Consumer Price Index. It may artificially overstate price increases in the early months of the year, Mr. Mullins said. Many Government officials agree, noting that inflation also surged early last year and then petered out, leaving the 1992 inflation rate at a mild 2.9 percent. "The seasonal adjustment factor may have added almost half a percentage point to inflation earlier this year," Mr. Mullins said.
Finally, some companies may be pushing for price increases in anticipation of Clinton Administration programs, Mr. Mullins said. Pharmaceutical companies, for example, may be acting before a health bill limits price increases for prescription drugs.
 
'Capital Markets Will React'
 "Whatever the reasons, if inflation should persist, unchallenged by the Federal Reserve, then the capital markets will react and they determine the level of long-term interest rates on which the economy depends for stimulus," Mr. Mullins said.
The links between interest rates, inflation and economic growth are convoluted. The Fed, for example, has the power to raise or lower short-term interest rates. A quarter-point rise in short-term rates would mean that the tens of thousands of Americans who buy 30-day Treasury bills might earn 3.25 percent interest instead of 3 percent. That would put a bit more income in their pockets, which is good for the economy.
But the rates that banks pay to borrow money for short periods would also rise to 3.25 percent. Banks constantly borrow big chunks of short-term money that they then relend to the public, at higher rates. To maintain this profit margin, the banks may feel compelled to raise their prime rate to 6.25 percent from the present 6 percent. All sorts of other loan rates rise and fall with the prime rate, among them home equity loans and most loans to companies. So a higher prime rate might discourage this vast borrowing, hurting the economy.
But Mr. Greenspan and Mr. Mullins, along with other Fed policy makers, look beyond what they consider this temporary damage to a different goal. Raising short-term rates, they argue, will help convince people that the Fed will be vigilant, and that inflation will be held down over the long run. So the really important people -- the bondholders and others who lend money for 15 to 30 years -- are more willing to accept lower interest rates, satisfied that the income from their bonds won't be destroyed by inflation.
 
Tonic for Economy
 And it is low long-term interest rates, the Federal Reserve argues, that really keep an economy growing. They influence mortgage rates in the all-important housing market, and also the rates companies pay to finance investments in new machinery that make Corporate America more efficient and profitable. The 30-year Treasury bond, a guidepost of long-term rates, is currently at 6.8 percent, down from more than 7 percent in January. Some Fed officials, however, say it should be still lower. The key is to keep downward pressure on long-term rates, Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Fed governor, suggested in a speech last week.
The Federal Reserve's great concern over long-term interest rates is partly shared by Treasury Secretary Bentson. "At the present time, low long-term rates are the main source of stimulus," he said. "But they are not the only operating force; sales and demand play a major role."
To stimulate sales and demand, President Clinton had asked Congress to approve a fiscal stimulus, nearly $20 billion in Government spending intended to spread new wages through the economy, mostly through public works jobs.
"Congress did not give us the stimulus and everyone is now resigned to this fact, so we need to go on from there," a senior Administration official said, adding: "Long-term rates have come down and in this sense, the 'gamble on interest rates,' as this policy is now being called, has so far been won. But I want to emphasize the 'so far.' The low rates are what is to make a contractionary budget next year less contractionary."

HEADLINE: Arthur H. Kunz Is Dead at 59; Guided Long Island Development

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Arthur H. Kunz, a government planner who helped guide Long Island's development as one of the nation's largest suburban areas, died on Saturday at a hospital in Smithtown, L.I., where he lived. He was 59.
His family said he died of a heart attack after making a good recovery from a transplant of a kidney donated by his daughter six weeks ago. 
 Mr. Kunz was Suffolk County's Planning Commissioner and the planning coordinator of the Long Island Regional Planning Board. In his 35-year career, he also served as the chief planner for neighboring Nassau County.
 
Sought a Balance
 As the region's population grew to nearly three million, Mr. Kunz sought to balance the pressures for development with the need for preservation. He analyzed economic, demographic, environmental, transportation and housing trends and helped formulate government responses.
He became an expert on such diverse topics as duck farms, property taxes, birth rates, North Shore estates, multiplex movie theaters, water supply, golf courses, real-estate prices, sewers, hurricane patterns, car ownership and shopping malls.
Serving under Republican and Democratic administrations in both counties, he gained a reputation as a nonpartisan professional. Politicians did not always follow his advice. He made unpopular recommendations, for example, for more apartment zoning and public housing.
Assessing last winter's severe beach erosion, he said, "My guess is a lot more houses are going to fall, and we can't stop that." He opposed proposals to spend public money to save "houses that shouldn't be there."
 
Long Island Native
 Mr. Kunz was born in Floral Park, L.I., and grew up in Hempstead, L.I. At Virginia Polytechnic Institute, he earned a bachelor's degree and a master's in architecture, with a specialization in planning.
Early in his career he met Lee E. Koppelman, who became his mentor. Mr. Koppelman preceded Mr. Kunz as Suffolk County Planning Commissioner and is now executive director of the regional planning board.
Survivivors include his mother, Lydia Juckes of Boynton Beach, Fla.; his wife of nearly 35 years, the former Sharon White; a son, Scott of Lake Grove, L.I.; a daughter, Tracey Femminella of Coram, L.I., and a sister, Linda Ann Kunz of Manhattan.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Soars Against Mark But Advance Slows vs. Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar surged to a 20-month high against the German mark yesterday and rose against other leading currencies.
But the dollar posted only slight gains against the Japanese yen, indicating that the American currency's recent rally against the yen may be faltering, some traders said. 
 In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6958 marks, up from 1.6875, its highest close since October 1991. The dollar also rose to 110.90 yen, up from 110.65 on Monday.
 
Gold Off in New York
 Meanwhile, gold prices fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the actively traded gold for August delivery closed at $369.70 an ounce, down $1.40. The Republic National Bank quoted a late spot bid of $368.30 an ounce, off $1.30.
Traders continued to buy dollars on political unrest in Japan and economic uncertainty in Germany, which have sent the dollar soaring more than 5 percent against the yen and nearly 4 percent against the mark in the last week.
"The dollar is rallying more by default, more by what is going on in Germany and Japan, than what is happening in the U.S.," said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the consulting firm IDEA. "But there is more room for the story to play out."
After flirting with the key resistance level of 1.7000 marks in New York trading yesterday, the dollar retreated a bit after negative comments from an official of Germany's central bank.
Hans Tietmeyer, vice president of the Bundesbank, said that the bank would "do everything to preserve" the mark's long-term stability and that German officials must show better fiscal restraint to bring inflation below its current 4 percent annual rate.
Jay Wertheimer, a senior trader at the New York branch of Banco di Sicilia, said he had sold marks around the 1.7000 level after he heard Mr. Tietmeyer's comments. "If anything, I was surprised it didn't trigger more of a wave of buying," he said.
Many traders expect the Bundesbank to lower its discount rate, an important short-term interest rate, by 0.25 percentage point at one of its policy-making meetings next month.
The speculation has driven the dollar sharply higher because lower rates in Germany would hurt the value of mark-denominated investments.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
Incumbents in the top leadership positions of the National Organization for Women are routinely challenged in elections, and this year, when 3,000 delegates to the annual convention are expected to cast ballots in Boston on July 3, will be no exception.
Contending that the administration of PATRICIA IRELAND has lost touch with the grass roots, a team headed by EFIA NWANGAZA, a lawyer from Greenville, S.C., is seeking office. 
 The other challengers on her Everywoman NOW slate are PATRICIA LASSITER, an abortion-clinic director from Gainesville, Fla.; LINDA OSTEN, a restaurant manager from Norwich, Conn., and KATHLEEN WILSON, a member of the Pennsylvania Human Relations Commission.
Lauding her group as diverse -- Ms. Nwangaza, Ms. Lassiter, Ms. Wilson are black; Ms. Lassiter and Ms. Osten are lesbian -- Ms. Nwangaza said that NOW "must attract a broader cross section of women."
"Our slate grew out of the administration's insensitivity to its membership," she continued, "and its inability to deal in a substantive way with racism, homophobia, class bias, economic injustice, religious intolerance and environmental destruction."
Ms. Ireland, who became president when Molly Yard stepped down in 1991, said, "There is not one of us who doesn't want to end oppression of race, ethnicity, class, sexual orientation, but where are their concrete proposals?" She added, "More than one-third of our national board are women of color," and she noted that one of her running mates, ROSEMARY DEMPSEY, is a lesbian. Ms. Ireland herself has both a husband and a female companion.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: ANALYSIS;
Harazin Victim of a Brave New World

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
As a man whose baseball upbringing was on the business side, Al Harazin knows the significance of the bottom line. Simply but economically painfully put, if the Mets had been the contender and perhaps division champion Harazin and many others thought they would be last season and this, as many as 3 million fans who haven't gone and won't go to Shea Stadium would have bought tickets.
That converts to $36 million lost, which could have paid for nearly all of the Mets' $39 million payroll this season. That is why Harazin is the latest victim in the increasingly volatile world of general managers. 
 Dallas Green, the Mets' manager, who previously served as general manager of the Chicago Cubs, called the job "the worst" in baseball. "The g.m.," he said yesterday, "now gets fired as quickly as the manager does, and with the complexity of baseball you'll see more and more of it."
Harazin is not a victim in the sense that he was fired, because he was not. He quit because his pride would not allow him to accept half the job he has had the past 21 months. But he was a victim nonetheless.
"In the nature of baseball today," Nelson Doubleday, one of the Mets' co-owners, said at Shea yesterday, "it is so big and so complicated one man can't handle everything."
If Doubleday and his partner, Fred Wilpon, can be faulted for anything, it is for not following through on their original plan in the post-Frank Cashen era. They planned three years ago to have Harazin run the business and administrative end and Joe McIlvaine the baseball part, but McIlvaine defected to the San Diego Padres in October 1990, before the plan could be implemented.
If Wilpon and Doubleday believed in two-headed leadership, they should not have abandoned their view just because the heir apparent flew west. A diligent search in 1991, before Harazin replaced Cashen in September of that year, could have uncovered a capable successor to McIlvaine.
General managers, after all, move more often these days than they ever have. (The title itself is used less often; clubs have created a variety of titles to describe what a general manager traditionally has done.) Three have left their jobs in the past two weeks: McIlvaine resigned in San Diego June 9, Ted Simmons walked away from the Pittsburgh Pirates' position last Saturday and now Harazin is gone.
Harazin and Simmons were part of the large class of 1991-92. Ten clubs named general managers between the last month of the 1991 season and the start of spring training in 1992 -- seven in September '91 alone. McIlvaine was one of five general managers named a year earlier.
When McIlvaine says yes to the Mets' offer to return -- he gave strong indication yesterday that he will -- 17 of the 28 clubs will have named general managers within the last three years.
Money is at the root of the general managers' plight. With player payrolls and other expenses so huge today, they face as much pressure as their managers to win, or at least to contend, so fans will flock to the ball park and television ratings will rise. Owners are impatient when their money is at stake and they are unforgiving when they feel it is being squandered.
Jim Bowden, the Cincinnati Reds' rookie general manager, was criticized last month for firing Tony Perez after only 44 games as manager, but he knows that he himself will be subject to dismissal once the club owner, Marge Schott, returns from suspension if the players earning a total of $43 million don't make a serious run at the division championship. Like George Steinbrenner of the Yankees, Schott has left a trail of general managers with heads lopped off.
 
'Had to Be Done Now'
 If the Mets had contended last season and this, Wilpon and Doubleday most likely would not have decided now to take away Harazin's player personnel hat and ask him to focus on the business side alone. "Things were at a point where we felt it had to be done now," Wilpon said at the Mets' news conference yesterday.
McIlvaine could have remained as the Padres' general manager, but he felt he couldn't continue under the Padre owners' decision to decimate their club so they can severely reduce their player payroll.
The owners might not have liked McIlvaine's outspoken reaction to their plan while he was still their general manager, but he felt betrayed by their changed fiscal approach from when they hired him.
 
The Ultimate Imperative
 Discussing the influence of money on both player decisions and the fate of general managers, McIlvaine said yesterday by telephone from San Diego: "That's where your owners come into it, what they're willing to do, how long they're willing to take. In my mind, Doubleday and Wilpon are as good as any owners, if not the best owners, in baseball today from that standpoint. Their primary interest is winning. That's music to my ears. In a g.m.'s position, that's what your interest is."
Simmons gave up the Pirates' job because he had suffered a heart attack. His heavy smoking obviously could have contributed to his heart problems. But working under the pressure of letting Barry Bonds, Bobby Bonilla and Doug Drabek, among others, leave and still being expected to compete also could have been a contributing factor.
Yes, like smoking, being a general manager can be dangerous to your health.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Men and Women and Sex and Power

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
Fans of talk shows and news programs will have noticed that sexual harassment has replaced date rape as television's offense of the season. Both subjects enjoy that good old man-woman appeal, but, as tonight's edition of CBS's "48 Hours" demonstrates, charges of harassment have more reach and variety.
"When does a word, a look or a touch become a slur, a leer or a grope?" asks Dan Rather at the start of the program, titled "Indecent Proposals." On the show is a Hollywood talent agent who was charged by 11 women (10 aspiring actresses and one undercover police officer) with giving talent tryouts a special meaning; female police officers in Newport Beach, Calif., who sued after what they asserted were years of being manhandled by superiors, and Minnesota women who say they were emotionally scarred by having to endure dirty cracks from boys in their school hallways. 
 The emphasis here is on men using their power to obtain sexual favors. The talent agent, whose fate at the hands of a jury you can learn tonight, says self-flatteringly, "I thought all these women were coming on to me." He and his wife blame his troubles on the actresses' quest for publicity. But the descriptions of his encounters with the pretty plaintiffs suggest strongly that this fellow was asking for it. The Screen Actors Guild evidently ignored its members' complaints, perhaps in deference to the grand old tradition of the casting couch.
In the Newport Beach case, the police chief -- who was only accused of looking the other way -- denies the charge. After the National Organization for Women took over the campaign, the chief and a captain were dismissed by the city. But when they fought back, with some community support, they were reinstated. The impression left is that despite an investigation of sorts, city officials were unable to figure out whether anyone had done much of anything to anyone else, and were simply hoping to quiet matters by bowing to the heaviest pressure of the moment.
In the Minnesota school these days, some girls seem to feel put upon while some boys seem to feel beleaguered. Perplexed administrators have naturally called in a consultant. One woman, seen lecturing, travels the nation talking to fourth, fifth and sixth graders about sexual harassment and exhorting everybody to step in if they see something disrespectful or hurtful. With unemployment still high, the issue of sexual harassment, however defined, at least deserves credit for creating a new, undemanding career opportunity.

HEADLINE: A Budget Too Much Like Perot's

 BODY:
Ross Perot told voters he would reduce the deficit. So did Bill Clinton. But Mr. Clinton added a more profound promise: to tilt Federal spending toward investments in education, training, technology and research. In his February budget message President Clinton lived up to his promises, proposing to cut the deficit by $500 billion over five years, yet add $200 billion in programs to raise public and private investment.
Now Congress is about to dispose of Mr. Clinton's investment plans. Unless the Administration lobbies effectively, Congress will pass a budget that focuses on deficit reduction and virtually ignores economic growth. 
 The President's five-year budget plan included several tax subsidies for corporate investment and about $150 billion in public investment in, for example, technological research and training for displaced workers. But soon after the President presented his plan in February, the political mood turned nasty toward anything that sounded like Government spending. Congress rejected the President's stimulus package, which included some investment initiatives, and his proposed $30 billion tax credit for corporations, which increased their investment spending above past levels.
But these blows were light compared with Congress's decision to knock more than $50 billion over five years out of the President's proposed non-defense discretionary spending. And Congress refused to consider raising caps set for discretionary spending in 1994 and 1995. Those caps are tight -- requiring non-defense spending to fall, after accounting for inflation, by a few billion.
So unless Congress cuts defense spending more than Mr. Clinton proposes, which isn't likely, it will have to cut non-defense spending by a whopping 10 percent for 1995. Say goodbye to most of Mr. Clinton's initiatives. And hello to Ross Perot's crimped vision, which puts deficit reduction above all else.
Appropriations committees are already busy with their budget shears; tentative agreements would cut Mr. Clinton's request for Head Start, the program of early education for children, and the Job Corps, which trains disadvantaged workers, by about one-third. Expect the fraction one-third to keep popping up; that might be what Mr. Clinton is able to preserve of his $150 billion, five-year investment program.
The Administration didn't help its cause by including in its investment plan programs of suspicious worth. The Senate rightly excised a set of corporate tax breaks that would have done little to increase productive investment. The Administration's plan to subsidize investors in small companies and real estate would be wasteful giveaways.
What's needed is for the Administration to set priorities and fight hard for what's most dear. That probably means training programs for displaced workers, the national service initiative, early childhood education and preventive health care, scientific research, technological development and, later, welfare and health-care reform. These are programs that can throw off huge social benefits and are, therefore, a proper function of the Federal Government.
Congress seems intent on giving Mr. Clinton a third of his loaf. That's too close to Mr. Perot's myopia, and two-thirds away from what Mr. Clinton wisely promised.

HEADLINE: Where Is The Old Bob Dole?

BYLINE: By Alice M. Rivlin; Alice M. Rivlin is deputy budget director.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
I have such a longstanding respect for Senator Bob Dole that I fantasize that the old Bob Dole -- the responsible statesman -- will weigh back into the budget debate.
He was one of the first Republicans to recognize that the towering Reagan deficits endangered the health of the economy. Ignoring the political risk, he stood up to his own President, who offered supply-side nostrums, blithely talking about "growing out of the deficits" and minimizing their size by basing projections on rosy scenarios. 
 The old Bob Dole cut through the malarkey. He knew the Government was living beyond its means, borrowing the nation's savings, punishing farmers, home buyers and investors with high real interest rates. He knew there were no easy answers, that deficit reduction required tough political compromises involving spending cuts and tax increases.
The old Bob Dole, as Finance Committee chairman, then majority leader and finally minority leader, took on two Presidents of his own party, in 1982, 1985 and 1990, to try to tame the deficit. He got precious little White House support but kept fighting for saner fiscal policy.
Now, finally, we have a President who is leading the fight for fiscal responsibility. Bill Clinton did not have to be urged or cajoled. His first priority was an economic plan to reduce the deficit by $500 billion over five years. His plan included unpopular tough spending cuts: Well over 100 domestic programs would be cut by $100 million, including reductions in Medicare and agricultural subsidies and deep cuts in Government administrative costs and personnel. It called for tax increases on those most able to pay and a broad tax on energy. It showed the reductions in Federal interest costs that would result from the lower deficits.
The plan was balanced and fair: roughly half the deficit reduction would result from spending cuts, half from tax increases that would fall overwhelmingly on the most well-off Americans. And the numbers were real: The estimates rest not on a rosy scenario but on the Congressional Budget Office's conservative assumptions, also used by the Congress.
Congress passed a resolution reflecting the main features of the plan. In working with it, we agreed to cut the deficit even more than our original proposal would have by putting a "hard freeze" -- no adjustment even for inflation -- on discretionary spending programs. A reconciliation bill passed the House with only slight modifications in the Administration's basic design. The Senate Finance Committee reached the same deficit reduction target, with differences in some tax and spending cut components; passage of its bill this week would move action to a conference. Next, appropriation action consistent with the budget resolution would lock in spending cuts, so that half of all deficit reduction would come from those cuts. Indeed, under the Clinton plan, all discretionary spending would be frozen for five years. No other President has been so courageous. The old Bob Dole would have lead the cheering.
Instead of pitching in to help solve the deficit problem, Mr. Dole is sabotaging the effort with misleading rhetoric. He says the Democrats' plans are mostly tax increases because some of their spending cuts do not count. He claims the appropriation cuts should not count because the budget resolution caps might not hold. (Why not? Those in the 1990 agreement held, and Congress is more serious about deficit reduction now than it was then. So is the electorate.) He says cuts in interest costs should not count. (Why not? It's real money and he was happy to count it in the 1990 agreement.) He says cutting Federal subsidies by charging higher user fees is really raising taxes, although longstanding budgetary practice and common sense say otherwise. He talks vaguely about controlling entitlement spending, but offers no specific proposals.
The old Bob Dole would have had little patience with such nitpicking. He knew deficit reduction is tough, requiring not only tax increases and spending cuts but user fees and interest cost cuts. He would have recognized the Administration's plan, in the House or Senate versions, as a balanced package of politically difficult changes, pleasing no one but designed to get the job done. I still respect him, but I sure miss the old Bob Dole.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
What Will Mets Rebuild With?

BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON

 BODY:
AT last, the Mets' co-owners have used the dreaded word that is baseball's synonym for surrender. The word is rebuild.
"We're here," Fred Wilpon was saying yesterday as Nelson Doubleday stood next to him, "to rebuild a championship team." 
 It's a start. In their best sincere suits, the co-owners were behind a microphone in the Diamond Club at Shea Stadium, announcing Al Harazin's resignation as chief operating officer, executive vice president and general manager, while acknowledging that Joe McIlvaine is their choice to take over the reconstruction of this fallen franchise.
"If Joe came back to us and wanted to run the team," Wilpon said, "we would be very pleased."
McIlvaine helped assemble the Mets who won the 1986 World Series; he also helped to disassemble the Mets in the seasons that followed. Even so, he's the best general manager available to assemble a new Mets team with Dallas Green, thankfully, preferring to remain as manager. Green's commanding personality is more important in the dugout than behind a desk.
McIlvaine recently resigned as the San Diego Padres' general manager after orders to slice his player payroll. If he returns to the Mets, his problem would not be salaries.
"No one has accused us of cheaping out," Wilpon said, alluding to the club's $39 million player payroll. "We haven't cheaped out in any area. Nor will we in the future."
Doubleday talked of how quickly the Phillies suddenly emerged as a runaway first-place team this season, as if the Mets might do the same. But what will the Mets rebuild with? They need virtually an entirely new roster, position by position.
Of all the Mets players, only Bobby Bonilla is good enough, healthy enough and young enough to be considered a cornerstone for a National League East contender. Dwight Gooden, Bret Saberhagen and John Franco have pitched well when healthy, but their arms keep creating unanswered questions. Sid Fernandez will be a free agent.
Looking to next season, the Mets might need an entirely new infield. Eddie Murray won't be back at first base. Jeff Kent has not been convincing at second base. Tim Bogar is merely holding the fort at shortstop following Tony Fernandez's departure. Howard Johnson, unable to play third base now because of a mysterious virus, will be a free agent.
In center field, Darrin Jackson has yet to justify the Tony Fernandez trade. If left fielder Vince Coleman doesn't pull a hamstring muscle, maybe the Mets will be able to deal him.
More than any other position, the Mets need an all-star catcher who can hit home runs and get the most out of the pitchers. When the Mets were either winning or challenging for the National League East title, Gary Carter was as important as Gooden, Keith Hernandez or Darryl Strawberry. Without him, the Mets' batting order and pitching staff haven't been the same.
But the essence of the Mets' problem is the absence of immediate blue-chip help from their farm system. There's no Gooden there, no Strawberry there. If anything, the Mets' best prospects are still several years away. McIlvaine would need to use free agency and trades to retool the Mets for next season. And there's no guarantee that the Mets' best prospects will ever develop into impact players. Most of their recent prospects have been overrated.
McIlvaine has been fingered as one reason for the Mets' liberation or disposal of Strawberry, Lenny Dykstra, Kevin Mitchell and Wally Backman.
"You want to tell me how many games Mr. Dykstra has played since he left; you want to tell me how many games Mr. Strawberry has played since he left," Doubleday asked, his voice rising in defense of those moves. "We go after talent. We don't go after citizens."
As much as anything else, the Mets will be going after a team good enough to attract the political and financial support for a domed stadium to be built around the turn of the century as part of an entertainment center not far from Shea Stadium. "Constructive entertainment," Wilpon said. "No thrill rides."
The only thrill ride would be a rebuilt Mets team good enough to win a World Series and good enough, eventually, to attract a buyer. Asked if the co-owners were considering selling the franchise now, Wilpon replied, "Absolutely not."
That's understandable. The Mets aren't worth much now. But in the nation's inflated economy, if the Mets were rebuilt into a World Series winner, the franchise will be worth $200 million. Ask the co-owners then if they might sell.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 24, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A picture with the Sports of The Times column yesterday, about the Mets and Joe McIlvaine, the leading choice to be their next general manager, was published in error. It showed Jerry Hunsicker, the team's assistant vice president of baseball operations.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Design vs. the Environment: A Debate Among Architects

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 21

 BODY:
You can walk to McCormick Place, but not without dodging cars. Though it is just minutes away by foot from the Loop, the cavernous convention center is so isolated from the rest of Chicago by the traffic streaming past that most visitors arrive and depart by taxi or bus. Intentionally or not, the building is a perfect example of the problem addressed over the weekend by the more than 6,000 architects who gathered at McCormick Place: the extent to which architecture has contributed to the global environmental crisis.
Automobile traffic is only part of the problem. Roughly half the world's energy consumption goes into the construction, maintenance and operation of buildings. Architects don't initiate this gross consumption, but some of them have begun to recognize that design can help curtail it. The choice of building materials, use of renewable resources like natural light and ventilation, and controlled patterns of suburban growth are some of the strategies architects can adopt toward what is called sustainable development: design that provides shelter without environmental or human exploitation. 
 Last weekend's World Congress of Architects, which brought together members of the American Institute of Architects and the International Union of Architects, was organized with the goal of enlarging the number of converts to "green design." "Architecture at the Crossroads: Designing for a Sustainable Future," as the conference was called, also served to commemorate the World's Columbian Exposition, the fabled Chicago world's fair of 1893, an event that gave birth to the City Beautiful Movement and symbolized the emergence of American architecture as an organized profession.
Several exhibitions throughout the city are also celebrating the tradition of design excellence that came out of the fair. The most notable is "Chicago Architecture and Design 1923-1993: Reconfiguration of an American Metropolis," on view at the Art Institute of Chicago through Aug. 29.
Organized by John Zukowsky and brilliantly installed by eight young Chicago architects under the supervision of Stanley Tigerman, the show traces the legacy of the Chicago School up through the bumper crop of post-modern skyscrapers that transformed the skyline in the 1980's. Concurrently, Culture in Action, a program of conceptually oriented public artworks sponsored by Sculpture Chicago, updates the City Beautiful tradition of integrating fine art into the urban fabric.
There was some historical irony in observing the fair's centennial with a conference on ecologically correct design, for the fair helped pave the way for many of the environmental problems addressed by this year's conference. Though the fair gave rise to a great tradition of civic building, it also helped to forge an unholy alliance between the architectural profession and America's emerging industrial civilization.
As Lewis Mumford observed, the classical style of the fair symbolized all too aptly the imperial style of modern industry, which exploited the "life and resources of separate regions" for the benefit of a privileged few. While some of the benefits -- like the magnificent city that Chicago remains today -- were indeed spectacular, architecture's pact with industry has had devastating consequences for the global environment. A local catastrophe, the Chicago Fire, provided impetus for Chicago's emergence as the great city of American architecture. Now, a century later, a global crisis is prodding architects toward a reappraisal of their values.
Leadership has its perils, and the World Congress faced a major obstacle in devoting a four-day conference to the theme of sustainable growth. It became painfully clear that there weren't many architects around who could speak with any authority about this subject. Most of those who spoke at the conference, including such celebrated designers as Helmut Jahn, Michael Graves, Peter Eisenman, Denise Scott Brown and Jean Nouvel, seemed more disposed to talk around or even discount environmental issues than to explore them. As a result, the conference threatened to become an exercise in deceptive green packaging rather than an occasion for fundamental change.
At times, the discussion seemed to revolve in aimless circles around a dubious polarity between esthetics and social responsibility. There was a heated exchange on Sunday morning between Mr. Jahn, the designer of some of the snazzier skyscrapers of the 1980's, and William McDonough, one of the best-known advocates of sustainable design. Mr. Jahn said he was disturbed by the applause that greeted Mr. McDonough's remarks because it suggested that "architects are trying once again to play the saint." Mr. McDonough got another round of applause when he accused Mr. Jahn of designing obsolete "steamships."
Still, on the second morning, when Jaime Lerner began to speak, all the noise suddenly seemed worth it. Mr. Lerner, an architect who until recently was Mayor of Curitiba, a medium-size city in Brazil, held the audience spellbound, partly because he has realized a fantasy architects often harbor: acquiring enough political muscle to carry out their ideals.
"It's important to have success scenarios," Mr. Lerner told the audience, and then proceeded to present one, describing innovations in mass transit, waste management, city planning and urban design that have helped to narrow the gap in quality of life between Curitiba's rich and poor. A man who radiates the dignity of common sense, Mr. Lerner brought the theme of sustainability down to earth.
Mr. Lerner's message was at least as urbanistic as it was environmental. With devastating confidence, he predicted that the 21st century would be a century of cities, because governments have a more direct connection with the environment at the local level. But what about those who lack even local political power? That was the question addressed by Culture in Action, a citywide program of public artworks organized by Mary Jane Jacob of Sculpture Chicago. One of the projects, a "street level" video installation on a street in West Chicago, promises to be one of the most memorable events of this centennial year.
Television is a medium that has helped to corrode communities by displacing the need for public space. "Tele-Vecindario," a project conceived by the video artist Inigo Manglano-Ovalle, is using television to strengthen a sense of community on Chicago's West Side.
Come August, Mr. Manglano-Ovalle and his 15-member collective, the Westtown Vecinos Video Channel, will be holding a video block party. Sixty monitors will be set up along a one-block stretch of Erie Street, in a largely Hispanic neighborhood in west Chicago. Placed in apartment windows, front yards and parked cars, the monitors will be displaying a video portrait of the community, based largely on taped interviews with local residents.
Mr. Manglano-Ovalle calls the project a "video mapping." It explores the overlapping territories of individual memories, the political structure of urban development, and turf struggles between street gangs, some of whose members have assisted Mr. Manglano-Ovalle in the project.
Like Mr. Lerner, Mr. Manglano-Ovalle has embraced a philosophy of "Think globally, act locally." His videos will depict a community that has been hurt by the shipment of jobs abroad, but that is home to people who have moved here in search of a better life. And it employs the electronic technology that links today's global economy. Though Erie Street is visually and geographically far from the City Beautiful monuments of downtown Chicago, Mr. Manglano-Ovalle's project recalls the City Beautiful ideal in using art and urbanism to reinforce each other. It is not a work of architecture, yet it is a project from which architects could learn about the spatial dynamics of the contemporary urban street.
And while street-level video may not qualify as sustainable design, it takes things down to the scale where individual actions are linked to global effects. In his closing remarks, Jaime Lerner told the audience that people often ask him what they can do to protect the planet. "Just do two simple things," he tells them. "Drive less the car. Separate the garbage."

HEADLINE: U.S. Warns Russia on Missile-Fuel Sales

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 22

 BODY:
The United States is trying to block the shipment of rocket-fuel ingredients from Russia to Libya, officials said today. The shipment is the latest in a string of exports that have caused major worry in the Clinton Administration.
With a deteriorating economy, Russia has been increasingly dependent on military sales to earn hard currency. 
 The Administration says stopping the spread of weapons is a high priority, but Washington also wants to prop up Boris N. Yeltsin and is trying to win Congressional support for $2.5 billion in aid to Russia.
 
A Political Balancing Act
 Thus President Clinton has sent a letter to President Yeltsin, warning that Russian companies face economic sanctions unless they halt such exports, United States officials said.
As an inducement, Mr. Clinton indicated, Russian companies could share the work on the multibillion-dollar space station and launch United States satellites for profit.
Administration officials met today at the State Department with Deputy Prime Minister Aleksandr N. Shokhin of Russia to discuss curbs on missile-technology exports. The State Department did not publicize the meeting, and officials declined to say whether they had made any progress.
Moscow's arms sales have been an increasing worry for Washington. Russia has sold Flanker MIG-27 planes and SA-10 surface-to-air missiles to China and three diesel submarines to Iran.
"Russia and Ukraine increasingly are authorizing export of sensitive, dual-use space-launch, chemical and biological technologies as they attempt to save their weapons facilities and prevent unemployment," William Grundmann, a senior official at the Defense Intelligence Agency, told the Joint Economic Committee last week.
Russia has not joined the Missile Technology Control Regime, an international agreement that restricts the technology sales. But Moscow insists it is observing the controls.
Despite these assurances, the Bush Administration imposed santions in 1992 on Glavkosmos, the Russian space organization, after it determined that Moscow's sale of rocket technology to India violated the controls.
Under United States law, trade sanctions must be applied against companies that violate the missile accord. In addition, an amendment to the Freedom Support Act providing aid to Russia calls for development assistance to be cut off if Moscow ignores the controls. Under the law, President Clinton can issue a waiver, but such a move would indicate that helping Russia is a higher priority than controlling arms.
 
The Serbian Connection
 United States officials familiar with the shipment to Libya say the episode began when Pavoks, a Moscow company, exported 80 tons of ammonium perchlorate, which can be used to make solid rocket fuel.
According to United States intelligence, the deal was brokered by Serbian middlemen, who are playing a greater role in military sales to earn hard currency and circumvent the United Nations embargo on Serbia.
"Middlemen like political turmoil and loose controls," an Administration official said. "For them, Serbia is a nice place to try to operate out of."
Administration officials said customs documents were prepared to disguise the destination of the shipment, but Washington learned that the chemical was destined for Libya by way of Ukraine. After a tip from Washington, Ukraine seized the shipment.
According to American and Russian officials, Russia missile technology exports have been discussed in several high-level forums in recent months.
Mr. Shokhin, the Deputy Prime Minister, told a recent news conference in Moscow that President Yeltsin had sought compensation during the Vancover summit for canceling the sale of missile technology to India, a deal that he said was worth $400 million to Glavkosmos. Washington said participation in the construction of the Freedom space station and in launching American commercial satellites could be worth more.
 
Trying for a Compromise
 Earlier this month Robert Einhorn, a Deputy Assistant Secrtary of State, went to Moscow to try to resolve the differences. He reportedly offered a compromise under which at least part of the sale of missile technology to India would be tolerated. But the Russians would have to assure Washington that they would strictly observe the Missile Technology Control Regime.
That effort at a compromise failed, and Mr. Clinton sent his warning letter to Mr. Yeltsin.
Even if Moscow agrees to more strictly observe the controls on arms sales, United States intelligence experts say there will be problems in guaranteeing adherence.
"The concern is that organizations and individuals facing enormous pressure to survive financially will try to evade government controls," said Mr. Grundmann of the Defense Intelligence Agency.

HEADLINE: SENATORS TAKE UP CLINTON'S BUDGET WITH ACID DEBATE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
The grand debate over President Clinton's package of tax increases and spending cuts opened at last in the Senate today, and Democrats and Republicans, well aware that the outcome is predetermined, seized the occasion to paint the economic differences between them in the starkest political terms.
The two sides suspended the invective long enough for the Republicans' alternative to the Democratic plan to be rejected. The Republican proposal would have capped spending on Federal benefit programs, frozen most other Federal spending and kept taxes at current levels. Republicans cast it as a tax-free way to reduce the Federal deficit; Democrats called it a sham because it simply decreed a halt to the explosive growth in benefits spending, without specifying how to halt it.
 
A Turncoat in Each Camp
 The vote against the Republican plan was 55 to 43. One Democrat, Richard Shelby of Alabama, voted for it, and one Republican, James Jeffords of Vermont, joined the Democrats to vote against it. 
 Earlier, a handful of Democrats joined the Republicans to reject an attempt by the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, to add to the bill $3.6 billion in tax breaks for small businesses.
No one appeared to question that the Democratic version of the Clinton budget -- a version with $50 billion less in taxes and $50 billion more in cuts than its House companion -- would pass the Senate, probably Thursday night. In large part, today's debate was moot court, played out in a mostly empty chamber for the primary benefit of cable-television cameras.
 
In High Dudgeon Indeed
 Democrats took to the floor to assail Republicans as gutless protectors of the fat-cat rich, hypocrites who preach the gospel of small Government but shrink from any politically risky effort to actually attain it.
Senator Jim Sasser, a Tennessee Democrat, on the Republicans' opposition: "What's it all about? It's about protecting the tax breaks -- of those who got those lucrative tax breaks in the 1980's, during the Reagan-Bush years."
Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, mocking the Republican argument in a bottomless Southern drawl: " 'There's a difference in philosophy, I've heard. We Republicans don't believe in raising taxes; we believe in cutting spending and paying the bill.' " Then, abandoning his mocking tone and comfortably back in his Democratic skin, Mr. Hollings declared that the Republican approach would "wreck the Government economy."
Republicans lashed back by accusing Mr. Clinton in the most sarcastic terms of selling the voters a bill of goods. They repeatedly turned the President's own words against him, wielding excerpts from his campaign speeches and his political manifesto, "Putting People First," to contrast his early pledges of tax cuts and small government with what they said was the reality of his duplicitous budget.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, mocking Mr. Clinton's words in "Putting People First": " 'A Clinton-Gore Administration will encourage small businesses and enterprises to take risks,' " he read. " 'My plan will not add new taxes on small business.' "
Instead, Mr. Dole argued, "they now face a tax increase not from 31 to 35 percent, but from 31 percent to 45 percent, or maybe even more."
 
D'Amato Is Indignant
 Senator Alfonse D'Amato, Republican of New York: "Almost one half -- 49.8 percent -- of the tax increases come on small business. Promises made, promises broken."
Senator Phil Gramm, the deeply conservative Texan: "I oppose this bill because you cannot create more investment by taxing investors. You cannot create more savings by taxing savers. You cannot create more jobs by taxing the job creators.
"Hundreds of thousands of Americans will lose their jobs because of this bill; Bill Clinton will be one of those Americans," he said, adding slyly, "but he will deserve to lose his job."
The genuinely tough fight will come next week, behind closed doors, when House and Senate lawmakers try to meld the two packages into a bill that can pass both chambers of Congress.
Still, today there was an oratorical food fight in which multibillion-dollar figures were tossed about like tomatoes, and pie charts and bar graphs, purporting to prove both sides' arguments, abounded. But to non-economists, there often was not much clarity. So far apart were the two sides that they could not even agree on how much Mr. Clinton proposes to raise taxes or cut spending.
The Democrats say the measure will slow the growth of the Federal debt by more than $500 billion through 1998 by raising taxes a total of $250 billion and reducing spending another $250 billion. More than three-quarters of the tax increases will fall on people with incomes exceeding $200,000, but all Americans making more than about $20,000 would owe some extra money to the Government because of a new tax on gasoline and some other fuels. (For those making less than about $20,000, the gasoline tax would be offset by a tax credit and increased Federal benefits.)
 
Where Cuts Will Come
 Only about $100 billion of the proposed spending cuts are in this bill, and most of those cuts will come from limiting the explosive rise in Medicare spending. The remaining cuts will largely be made in military spending and in other bills for individual Federal programs to be passed this fall and in the next four years.
The Republicans took issue with all those numbers, saying the bill had more taxes and fewer spending cuts than the Democrats maintained. But mostly they hammered away at the tax increases.
Their alternative, which Mr. Dole labeled "Tax-Free for '93 -- and '94, '95, '96 and '97," was secretly prepared and sprung on the Senate hours after the debate began. It claimed to reduce the Federal deficit to $197 billion in 1998, $5 billion lower than the Senate Democrats' proposal, but without any of the tax increases or increases in Federal fees that Mr. Clinton and the Senate Democrats contemplate.
In place of tax increases, the Republicans proposed to adopt all the spending cuts in Mr. Clinton's budget and to extend existing caps on total spending for discretionary programs for five years, saving $164 billion. Those caps, part of the 1990 budget agreement between Democrats and President George Bush, are to expire in 1995.
Starting in 1996, the plan would further limit spending on Federal benefit programs like Medicare and Medicaid to an amount that includes inflation, the growth in program rolls and 1 percent extra for growth.
Republicans said the two-year delay in lifting the caps on benefit programs would allow Congress time to enact a bill to cut health-care spending, but their proposal gave no indication of how that might be done. Their plan also exempted Social Security.
The Senate would have been allowed to override the caps, and further increase spending, whenever it could muster 60 votes.
Mr. Dole wielded a huge "big spending cuts" pencil as a television prop as he pointed to charts showing the Federal deficit plummeting under his plan and rising drastically in 1998 under the Democratic proposal. In truth, the chart would have been accurate only if Congress enacted health-care legislation under the Republican plan and did not do so under Mr. Clinton's.
"There is a Republican alternative," he boasted. "We don't have any taxes. We don't tax small business. We don't tax small-business men, we don't tax small-business women in Idaho or California or Illinois or New York or anywhere else in America."
 
Packwood Weighs In
 Senator Bob Packwood, an Oregon Republican who ran the Senate Finance Committee during the last major tax debate in 1986, said that long-term caps on Federal spending were the only way to keep Democratic hands out of the Treasury's till. Otherwise, he said, America would end up like Sweden, taxing not 30 percent but 60 percent of all income to pay for expensive social programs.
"The pressure to take the money we're raising in this bill in taxes, which the President says is to reduce the deficit -- the pressure to take that money, and spend it on education, environment, highways, defense -- will be inexorable," he said. "Maybe Republicans are on the wrong side of this issue. Maybe the public wants this money spent and is willing to pay taxes for it. But we're willing to take that gamble."
Democrats were simply and openly contemptuous. "Over the course of their program, in three years, you've got $108 billion in reductions in Medicare and Medicaid," Mr. Sasser said. "Now, if that's not going to adversely and dramatically affect millions of senior citizens and sick senior citizens of this country, I don't know what will."
The Republican plan, Mr. Mitchell said, was just a plot to preserve the tax breaks of the 1980's for the Republican political constituency.
"Who bears the burden?" he asked. "When my Republican colleagues come here and say there should be no taxes, their intent -- their clear purpose -- is to protect those who earn more than $200,000 a year."
 
Simpson Smells 'Rubbish'
 But Senator Alan K. Simpson, a Wyoming Republican -- said the contention that cutting spending and opposing taxes is protecting the rich was "the truest form of posturing."
"What rubbish," he spat. "What absolute rubbish."
Earlier in the afternoon, four Democrats joined the Republicans to defeat an attempt by Mr. Mitchell and another Democrat, Dale Bumpers of Arkansas, to add to the Senate package an array of small-business tax breaks that are already in the House bill, and which Mr. Clinton favors.
The clauses would raise from the current $10,000 to $18,000 the amount of equipment that small businesses could write off immediately as business expenses rather than having to depreciate over a number of years. It also would have reduced the capital-gain tax from the current 28 percent to 14 percent for a select number of investments in small businesses, mainly high-technology firms worth less than $50 million.
Mr. Bumpers argued that the breaks were an effort to help the sector of the economy that is responsible for most innovation and most new jobs. But the capital-gains proposal was savaged by another Democrat, Bill Bradley of New Jersey, who argued that it was just another special-interest tax break.
Mr. Bradley predicted that it would lead big businesses to spin off profitable units into new firms, partly owned by corporate executives, who would would then sell their interests. In effect, he said, the reduced capital-gains tax would become a benefit for rich officials of big, established companies.
And he railed at the idea of inserting a new tax break in the Senate bill merely because, at the end of its deliberations last week, the Finance Committee discovered that it had some money left over.
Mr. Bradley and three other Democrats -- Howard Metzenbaum of Ohio, Russell Feingold of Wisconson and Paul Wellstone of Minnesota -- voted with Republicans and against a Democratic effort to rule that the amendment was germane to the budget bill. The amendment needed 60 votes under Senate rules to pass; it received only 54.
