HEADLINE: Budget Debate: A Primer;
Cutting Through Claims and Counterclaims As Senate Ponders Ways to Curb the Deficit

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
Those watching the budget debate in the Senate on television today must have been numbed by the claims and counterclaims.
There were the Democrats, with their four-color charts, arguing that their budget would turn around the nation's economy by slashing Government spending, taxing the rich and lowering the deficit by more than $500 billion over the next five years. 
 There were the Republicans, with their own charts and graphs, calling the Democrats' plan little but a huge tax increase, especially on small businesses, and saying they could reduce the deficit as much just by lowering spending.
In name of cutting through the fog, here are the facts about some of the main matters in dispute.
 
Amount of Deficit Reduction
 The Democrats contend that the legislation before the Senate would lower the deficit by $516 billion over five years. The Republicans say the correct figure is $347 billion.
The legislation, officially called a reconciliation bill, deals only with taxes and spending for benefit programs like Medicare and Social Security that are not subject to annual appropriations. It is projected to raise taxes by $249 billion and cut spending by $98 billion. That is where the $347 billion comes from.
But the Democrats plan to offer an amendment, backed by the White House, that would freeze total spending for all other Government programs -- the military, education, the salaries of Government workers and everything else in the Federal budget. In the language of the budget, this is called discretionary spending, for which money is appropriated each year.
The freeze would save more than $100 billion, and the lower interest payments that would result from smaller deficits would amount to nearly $60 billion. Adding those figures to the $347 billion gives the Democrats their total deficit reduction of $516 billion.
Regardless of how precise the figures offered by the politicians seem, budget specialists say no one can predict accurately what the deficit will be five years from now.
Tax increases often raise less revenue than anticipated. For example, the large increase in revenue predicted from the higher taxes on business in the Tax Reform Act of 1986 never materialized. That was in part because businesses found ways around the new law. But the most important reason was that the economy since 1986 has been worse than expected, and business profits have been much lower.
Spending reductions also depend heavily on the turn of events. Who knows whether the state of the world in a few years will require greater military spending, or whether a slow economy will require more to be spent on social programs like unemployment compensation? This legislation has no contingency fund for emergencies or for unforeseen circumstances.
Still, no one argues that politicians should give up the cause of deficit reduction because the precise amount achieved from various steps cannot be accurately predicted.
 
Taxes vs. Spending Cuts
 The Democrats say their package is evenly divided between the two. Republicans say the Democrats are most interested in raising taxes, and contend that the spending reductions may never come to pass.
In fact, the higher income taxes would go into effect this year, and most of the other taxes would become effective in January. But most of the spending cuts would come much later.
No spending would be lowered in this fiscal year, and only 7 percent of the total spending reductions proposed by the Democrats would take place in the next fiscal year, beginning Oct. 1. More than three-fifths of the spending cuts, $165 billion out of $267 billion, would be made in the fiscal years 1997 and 1998, after the end of this Presidential term.
Each year, the President and Congress could reverse these cuts, and the temptation would become greater as their effective dates draw nearer. Recent history has shown that when deficit reduction legislation begins to bite, the politicians change the rules rather than bear the pain.
 
Entitlement Caps
 The basis of the Republican plan to lower the deficit without increasing taxes would be to cap spending for entitlement programs beginning in the fiscal year 1996 so they could not rise faster than the growth in the eligible population, inflation and, in 1996 and 1997 only, an additional 1 percent. These are programs like Medicare, Medicaid, pensions, unemployment compensation, farm price supports, food stamps and welfare under which benefits are paid automatically to everyone who is eligible.
The Republicans would exempt Social Security from the caps. But that is a meaningless exception because Social Security is not rising faster than inflation and the growth in the eligible population. The only programs expected to rise faster are Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly and the disabled, and Medicaid, the health program for the poor. The Republicans offered no clue how they hope to limit costs for those programs.
Would they pay doctors and hospitals less? Would they charge retired people higher premiums? Would they stop making medical insurance payments in midyear if the spending ceiling was reached?
And what if the economy turned sour, putting more people out of work? Would the Government break its promise to pay unemployment benefits?
The Republicans never say. And without such specifics, the promise is an empty one. It is like saying that the best way to avert a flood is to hold back the tide. Everyone agrees that if the tide could be stopped, the flood could be avoided. But no one knows how to keep a high tide from occurring.
 
Taxing Small Business
 The Republicans maintain that a large portion of the higher tax rates the Democratic plan would impose on taxpayers with taxable income above $140,000 would fall on small businesses and would inhibit the owners from pouring money back into the business so they could expand and hire new workers.
This proposition is grounded on the fact that many businesses are not themselves taxed. Rather, the proprietors, partners or shareholders pay taxes on the profits at their tax rate, which is lower than the corporate rate.
One problem with the argument is that many of these businesses are actually doctors, lawyers and other professionals -- not the sort of entrepreneurs normally associated with job creation.
Another problem is that these businesses pay taxes only on their profits, after deductions are taken for expenses like paying wages to employees or making new investments to expand.
The Republicans never quite explained why surgeons, or even the owners of hardware stores or canneries, should be taxed less on their income than someone who draws a salary from, say, the United States Treasury.

HEADLINE: Goodbye, Adirondacks?

BYLINE: By John B. Oakes; John B. Oakes is former editor of the Editorial Page of The New York Times.

 BODY:
This is the moment of truth for the Adirondacks. The future of New York's greatest public natural resource is at stake.
In the next few days, the Republican majority of the State Senate will decide whether one man's zealotry to kill the Adirondack Park will prevail. 
For the first time in at least 30 years, the state has no funds to purchase privately owned, environmentally endangered land that is urgently needed for park purposes. To meet this emergency, Gov. Mario Cuomo and Assembly Speaker Sol Weprin, a Democrat, have each proposed setting up an environmental trust fund to enable the state to buy some of the most immediately threatened areas.
Here is where the man who would like to kill the park -- and may yet succeed -- comes in. Senator Ronald B. Stafford of Plattsburgh, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, is an implacable enemy of the park, which lies partly in his district. A foe of zoning controls above the local level, he panders to the illusory short-term interests of his constituents. Last year, he tried and failed to kill the park altogether. Now he has hit upon a clever, divisive scheme to strangle it. Under the names of Owen Johnson and other Republican colleagues, he proposes his own version of an environmental trust fund to buy high-priority natural areas throughout the state. What makes the scheme unacceptable is its frankly discriminatory twist.
With only two specifically named exceptions in the park, he would exclude the entire Adirondack area from all future state purchase of privately owned land -- no matter how willing the seller, how low the price and how vitally necessary to protect the park from further degradation.
The park's nearly six million acres cover one-fifth of the total area of the state. Within its boundaries (it is about 60 percent privately owned) lie some of the state's most environmentally sensitive properties. If they are lost in the next few months or years -- as they surely will be under the Stafford proposal -- the unique qualities of the park's great open spaces are certain to be rapidly nibbled away. The park's pathetically weak zoning rules are already unable to curtail accelerating development pressures.
How is it conceivable that a lone legislator could succeed in a scheme that would offer public protection to the rest of the state at the expense only of the Adirondacks?
The answer lies with one Ralph J. Marino of Oyster Bay, the Senate Republican majority leader. Mr. Marino is politically in debt to Mr. Stafford, largely owing his position to him. Mr. Stafford, in turn, sits on a favor-dispensing throne among his fellow Republicans as Senate Finance Committee chairman.
Mr. Marino long ago gave Mr. Stafford the Adirondacks as his political fiefdom. He has rationalized the gift on the transparently false theory that whatever concerns the Adirondacks, the largest park in the U.S. outside Alaska -- it attracts 10 million visitors a year -- is only a local matter. Of course, the park is not merely of statewide interest: It is of national concern.
In addition, the permanent economic health of the park and its 130,000 residents depends not on lawyers' fees, temporary construction jobs along the lakefronts and speculative real estate values but on a thriving tourist, woodworking and timber industry. If the best of the private land holdings are thrown open to speculative development, the jobs that matter will disappear along with the park's still matchless beauty.
Senator Stafford's proposal is no compromise, as it is purported to be; it is a shrewd scheme to entice legislators with the prospect of more funds for the rest of the state by taking the Adirondacks virtually out of the competition.
It deserves to be flatly rejected in favor of a genuine and statewide environmental trust fund in which the needs of each area, including the Adirondacks, would be fairly weighed. The Stafford plan will fail if the Republicans of the Senate face up to their responsibilities -- and not to their political debts to Mr. Stafford.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: House Retains Space Station In a Close Vote

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
Putting space research and jobs ahead of cutting the budget deficit, the House today endorsed the troubled space station by a hairline margin, probably insuring at least one more year of construction.
The station is several years behind its original construction schedule and has run several billion dollars over its original budget, set by the Reagan Administration a decade ago. And with the cold war over and the deficit growing as an economic and political issue, the construction of a permanently staffed orbital laboratory has steadily lost Congressional support in the last three years. 
 But a last-minute Administration lobbying blitz, including letters to lawmakers from President Clinton and a visit to the House floor today by Vice President Al Gore, saved the program from probable defeat.
 
Move to Kill Project
 An amendment to the space-agency authorization bill that was intended to kill the program was defeated 216 to 215, with 104 Democrats joining 112 Republicans in support of the project. Voting against the project were 153 Democrats, 61 Republicans and one independent.
The space station, which would have the capacity to hold five astronauts for up to 30 days in space, would help scientists determine the long-term effects of space travel on human beings. It would also provide opportunities for advanced research in biotechnology and metallurgy in the lack of gravity.
Concerned about cost overruns, President Clinton last week endorsed a slightly smaller, less expensive version of the station, which would cost $2.1 billion annually for the next five years.
Although the redesign and orbit plans have not yet been fully developed, the station is to include solar power units and pressurized laboratory modules stretching from a girderlike truss.
The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has already spent $9 billion on the station, $1 billion more than it originally said a more advanced space station would cost. Opponents predict that the final cost could eventually reach $40 billion or more, with billions more needed for maintenance and operation.
The margin of victory in today's vote was a bit larger than it appeared, since four of the votes opposed to the space station were cast by delegates from the Virgin Islands, District of Columbia, Puerto Rico and Guam. The House cancels votes and votes again when delegates provide the margin of victory.
 
Second Chance for Opponents
 House opponents will have another opportunity to kill the project next week by denying financing for the space station, but very few lawmakers are likely to change their votes.
Last year, an identical amendment also failed, but by a vote of 237 to 181, demonstrating that Congress has become more skeptical about big science and other expensive projects. Much of this year's opposition came from the 114 House freshmen who had never voted on the issue.
The vote also appeared to insure that the superconducting supercollider, another big science project whose political support has been shakier than the station's, will go down to a decisive defeat in an appropriations vote by the full House on Thursday.
After today's vote, Representative George E. Brown Jr., a California Democrat who is the leading proponent of the space station in Congress, conceded, "I was surprised it wasn't a little wider margin." But he noted that supporters of the space station would dominate the House-Senate conference committee that will probably make the ultimate decision on financing for the space station this summer.
The Senate, which has historically been more supportive of the project, is expected to provide the space station with stronger backing.
Support and opposition in the House today cut across party and ideological lines. Lawmakers from California, Florida and Texas, representing states that depend on the space and aerospace industries for hundreds of thousands of jobs, provided the core of support. Supporters promised that experiments aboard the space station would lead to far-reaching scientific spinoffs, from cures to cancer to creation of new industrial alloys.
"History has shown that the great nations have been those that had a spark of risk-taking, of adventure, of being willing to operate at the frontiers of knowledge and exploration," said Representative Jack Brooks, Democrat of Texas,
Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip, predicted that 50 years from now people would see the vote today as the most important one cast in the House this year. "Imagine," he added, "if Isabel had said to Columbus, 'We just can't afford it this year.' "
Those opposing the space station were a coalition of big city liberals and rural conservatives who characterized the project as high-flying pork. Representative Fred Upton, Republican of Michigan, likened the space station to "pork in a can." Representative Dick Zimmer, Republican of New Jersey, called it a "fiscal black hole."
The bill that passed today authorizes the building of a space station by the year 2000. But the authorization is meaningless if the funds are not appropriated.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative George E. Brown Jr., right, a California Democrat who is the leading proponent of the space station in Congress, said, "I was surprised it wasn't a little wider margin," after the project survived by a single vote. With him were Representatives Norman Y. Mineta, left, a Democrat, and Dana Rohrabacher, a Republican. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times) (pg. A20)

HEADLINE: FUND FOR BUSINESS IN RUSSIA TO BE CUT

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration said today that a $4 billion international fund it proposed to help Russian state enterprises convert to private businesses would have to be shrunk because Japan and the Western European allies are too squeezed for cash to join.
"We are doing some serious arm-twisting on the Japanese and Europeans to try to salvage as much as possible," a senior Administration official said. "People understand that the idea is not a bad idea, but they keep saying to us: Where are we going to come up with this dough?" 
The $4 billion fund, which was supposed to help Moscow sell unprofitable state industries to the private sector and to fund new entrepreneurs, was proposed by Washington during an April meeting of foreign and finance ministers of the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations in Tokyo.
The fund was separate from the pledge by the ministers and international lending institutions in April to provide $28 billion in loans and grants to Russia for currency stabilization, economic restructuring and imports. The first $2.5 billion of this pledge is about to be distributed by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
 
Group to Meet in Two Weeks
 The $4 billion fund for conversion to private enterprise was pushed by the Clinton Administration as something that could be formally established at the Tokyo conference of the Group of Seven set to take place in two weeks. The group includes the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Italy, Britain and Canada. But the White House spokeswoman, Dee Dee Myers, said today that "there are some problems" with the fund proposal.
A State Department spokesman, Michael McCurry, said: "Many Governments are under serious financial constraints. It's going to be difficult to achieve a $4 billion figure."
One reason the $4 billion package is facing problems is that it would require a more immediate infusion of grants, whereas the $28 billion package agreed to in Tokyo consists mostly of loans and credits that the donor countries and agencies would supply by borrowing money.
Administration officials said that while the $4 billion target cannot be met now, they still believe the project is viable. They hope that a version of the plan, calling for roughly half or a quarter of the $4 billion target, can be agreed to at the Tokyo meeting, and that the fund could then grow.
 
Effect of Economic Slowdown
 The fact that the the Group of Seven has not been willing to contribute as much as it originally indicated appears to reflect the general economic slowdown in Europe and Japan. President Boris N. Yeltsin's consolidation of his political position has also removed some of the sense of urgency on the part of Western officials to provide aid to Moscow. Another factor is Japan's conviction that the Russian economy is not ready to spend the aid efficiently.
"We came up with an ambitious proposal, the allies couldn't swallow it and now we are trying a phased approach," a senior Administration official said.
The Administration, however, still intends to proceed with its own plan to provide $1.8 billion in bilateral assistance to Russia. This consists of grain aid, housing projects, and various technical advisory programs. The aid was promised to Mr. Yeltsin at his meeting with President Clinton in Vancouver in April.
As originally outlined, the $4 billion privatization fund was supposed to be made up of $2 billion in contributions from the Group of Seven countries and $2 billion from international lending institutions, with Washington kicking in $500 million of the $2 billion as a "challenge grant" to the other allies. Germany and Japan were supposed to have been major contributors, but on Tuesday the Japanese Foreign Minister, Kabun Muto, scornfully dismissed the fund proposal as "preposterous."
 
Confused by Japan's Stance
 Mr. McCurry said the Administration was "somewhat mystified" by Mr. Muto's statement and was seeking clarification from Tokyo.
"That characterization certainly doesn't square with the conversations we've had with the Japanese Government," Mr. McCurry said, adding that in previous talks with American officials, Japan had supported the concept of the fund.
A senior Administration official said the American goal now is to establish a smaller privatization fund of $500 million from the United States, Japan and the European Community. He said the United States would contribute $125 million, and the allies are being pressed to come up with the rest. In addition, they would try to get the World Bank and other international lending institutions to contribute another $1 billion, but that remained "iffy," the official said.
Nevertheless, the reduction of the proposed fund was something of an embarrassment for the Clinton Administration, which has stressed that its efforts to aid Russia will be distinguished from those of the Bush Administration because all the money it promises will be delivered.
President Clinton and Secretary of State Warren Christopher have sought considerably higher levels of aid to support Russian democracy, and appear to be winning Congressional backing for it, despite a political climate that is anti-foreign aid. But it is unclear whether this Administration will be any more successful than its predecessors in getting Japan and the other allies to deliver on their commitments.

HEADLINE: Pratt & Whitney Unions Approve Concessions Pact

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON

 BODY:
Putting the final piece of a major economic puzzle for the Northeast in place, union workers at Pratt & Whitney agreed last night to a package of concessions that are aimed at keeping the company from moving a large portion of its operations out of Connecticut. The vote is expected to save more than 2,000 jobs in the state.
The agreement gives Pratt & Whitney what it demanded -- tying wages to productivity and freezing raises until late 1995 -- in exchange for a promise not to use sub-contractors and to keep open its five plants in Connecticut open. After the state Government offered a package of tax cuts and grants worth $32 million, Pratt, a jet-engine manufacturer that is Connecticut's largest private employer, agreed not to move on the condition that the union accept the concessions package.
 
Sacrifice for Security
 Economists and politicians warned before the vote that a departure by Pratt would have been disastrous for Connecticut's fragile economy, endangering Pratt subcontrators and costing millions of dollars in lost taxes. The company's employment in the state has already fallen to 17,200 from 28,800 in 1986. 
 The vote, 4,210 to 3,496, was neither close nor overwhelming. The final count was tallied at 10:30 P.M. With about 82 percent an estimated 9,200 rank and file workers appearing to vote at one of four sites in the state, the decision appeared to reflect a clear desire to make sacrifices in exchange for job security.
Andrew Romegialli, directing labor representative for District 91 of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, said he thought the agreement represented the only viable alternative. But he added that the vote also reflected dissatisfaction among Pratt workers with their employer.
"It means that the workers have little faith in the company, and that Pratt & Whitney has a long way to go to earn their trust," said Mr. Romegialli.
Mr. Romegialli declined to provide a breakdown of the vote at the separate sites in East Hartford, Middletown, Southington and North Haven, but said it was relatively close at each. The votes were tallied in East Hartford.
Pratt & Whitney, a division of United Technologies Corporation, offered no response to the vote last night. Al Pollard, a human resources representative at the company's headquarters in Harford, said it would respond later today.
 
Wages Tied to Goals
 Under the agreement, wages could drop by up to $2 an hour if productivity goals are not met. The agreement also calls for a freeze on raises and cost-of-living increases until December 1995, as part of a one-year extension of the current contract.
Mr. Romegialli said that the package meant that there would be no room for subcontractors in the next union contract, which is due to start in 1995.
"We now have a fighting chance to build our productivity over the next two years," he said.
In January, Pratt & Whitney said it would eliminate 6,700 jobs from its Connecticut plants within two years. It also said it would cut 1,500 jobs in Florida.
"Last year, Pratt & Whitney lost approximately $500 million," wrote Karl J. Krapek, the company's president, in a letter to employees. "These losses cannot continue. Our goal is to make ourselves recession proof."
The layoffs and job eliminations -- with similar ones at Boeing and McDonnell Douglass -- are part of an industry-wide shrinking in aircraft manufacturing.
In April, Pratt threatened to close two plants and to eliminate 2,300 more jobs unless it received tax breaks from Connecticut and concessions from its unions.
 
Comparisons to Other States
 In seeking the concessions, company officials argued that building jet engines in Connecticut costs 30 percent more than in states like Georgia and Maine, where Pratt maintains other plants. The plants in Georgia and Maine are non-union shops, which rely on robotics for much of their labor.
Operating in Connecticut cost $6 to $8 an hour more than in other states, the company said, including fringe benefits, taxes and energy costs. The figure was based on how much more the company said it cost to pay a hypothetical middle-level manufacturing worker.
The announcement shocked employees and legislators. It quickly opened a debate on Connecticut's fiscal condition, and Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and the state's lawmakers vowed to try to meet the requests.
Pratt has been particularly hurt by the loss of Pentagon contracts, because under military procurement rules called cost-plus, local expenses became essentially irrelevant as the price of a product, whether a jet engine or a transistor, was determined by taking local production costs and adding the profit margin.
 
Huge Outlays
 Property taxes also cost the company $22 million in five communities, while it spent hundreds of millions of dollars a year on research and development, a powerful incentive for legislators in a state hit hard by the recession.
In early June, Pratt & Whitney company announced that it had tentatively agreed not to move 2,300 jobs to plants out of state in return for a package of tax cuts and other incentives. It said its decision would become final when the state legislature approved the tax plan, worth $32 million a year, and when unions agreed to concessions equally that amount.
The legislature approved the tax plan shortly after the announcement. The plan consists mainly of a system of tax credits to to encourage research and development by Pratt & Whitney, as well as other Connecticut companies, in return for their continued presence in the state. Last night's vote appeared to satisfy the company's other condition.
Pratt & Whitney has made aircraft engines since 1925.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Does the American trade deficit reflect U.S. success or failure?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
THE American trade deficit in April, the largest in four years, is:
(a) Evidence of Japanese perfidy.
(b) Proof the American economy is in decline.
(c) A $10.5 billion misunderstanding. 
 O.K., O.K. The multiple-choice teaser may be a little hoary as a column opener. But don't turn to the crossword puzzle just yet.
The message -- that the trade deficit is as much a reflection of the strengths of the American economy as it is of its weaknesses -- seems to have eluded President Clinton. And what Bill Clinton does not know could prove costly to the nation.
First things first: Merchandise trade is hardly an adequate benchmark for American competitiveness in world markets since it does not include such big-ticket items as trade in services and earnings from foreign investments. But even the broader gauge commonly used by economists, the balance on the "current account," offers small comfort to doom-and-gloomers. In 12 months ended in March, Americans spent $81 billion more abroad than they earned -- and that figure is apparently on the rise.
What is going on? Van Doorn Ooms, the research director of the Committee for Economic Development, points out that the American economy has managed to pull out of recession while Japan and Europe have not. Hence foreign demand for American goods and services is stagnant, even as American demand for imports has picked up.
Richard Cooper, an economist at Harvard University, notes, moreover, that America's trade balance is particularly sensitive to ups and downs in foreign economies because a disproportionate share of American exports consists of capital goods -- aircraft, computers, earth-moving equipment and the like. And cycles in investment are generally far more pronounced than cycles in the demand for consumer goods.
This is no small matter: If the other industrial economies were growing at a reasonable pace, Fred Bergsten of the Institute for International Economics estimates that the kick would add some $30 billion to Americans' incomes.
But with Germany determined to fend off inflation and the Japanese Government paralyzed by political crisis, exhortations to stimulate by the Clinton Administration are not likely to make much difference. More to the point, the ballooning trade deficit is a consequence of America's success, not its failure.
That is not the end of the story, however. Experts agree a return to healthy growth rates around the globe would still leave the American economy with a substantial foreign deficit. What they do not agree about is whether this remaining "structural" deficit is worth fussing over.
By Mr. Bergsten's reckoning, $9 billion to $18 billion of the American trade deficit with Japan is the result of Japanese trade barriers -- barriers that reduce American business profits. And even if these lost profits amount to petty cash in a $6 trillion economy, they are no joke to the companies that lose them. The resulting tensions, Mr. Ooms argues, "are putting great stress on the industrial world's open trade regime."
It is not clear, though, whether a more open Japanese market would take the heat off. One rough-and-ready predictor of protectionist sentiment in Congress seems to be the overall size of the trade deficit. And Robert Lawrence, an economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, points out that a reduction in the deficit with Japan would not necessarily reduce that overall figure. Indeed, John Makin, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, thinks the burden of the argument is on those who think it would.
Mr. Makin notes that the current-account balance is the consequence of thousands of private market transactions between consenting adults: every dollar of deficit created by an American purchase abroad is mirrored by an extra dollar's worth of assets bought voluntarily by a foreigner.
It thus makes just as much sense to argue that the rest of the world has a problem finding places to invest at home, Mr. Makin reasons, as it does to argue that America has a problem living within its means. He concludes that foreign investors -- everyone from insurance companies that pay too much for real estate to conglomerates that hold the working capital in Treasury bills at interest lower than the rate of inflation -- are "making us an offer we can't refuse."
Confused? Mr. Cooper, who was a senior economist in the Carter Administration, adds a clarifying middle ground. The core concern, he believes, ought to be the long-term growth of American living standards, and current account deficits are thus no cause for alarm. Indeed, they are cause for satisfaction as long as they are financing productive investment rather than current consumption.
The real worry, then, is that Federal budget deficits are sucking savings from private investment, forcing America to rely on foreign savings to finance growth. By this reckoning President Clinton, who worries about both budget deficits and trade deficits, has got it half right.

HEADLINE: U.S. Won't Send Troops To Seek Croats' Bodies

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
The United States has rejected a request by the United Nations to send military engineers to help dig up evidence of possible war crimes in Croatia because Washington does not want to put American soldiers at risk, State and Defense Department officials said today.
Instead, the Administration will donate $180,000 in medical supplies and equipment, including body bags, surgical instruments, hand tools and cleaning solvents, to Physicians for Human Rights. The group, based in Boston, is aiding an investigation into what is believed to be one of the worst massacres in the Balkan war. 
 Administration officials have not yet informed the United Nations that it will not join in the exhumation of bodies from a mass grave on a farm near Vukovar.
The farm, in a Serbian-held area on the Danube River in eastern Croatia, is suspected of having been an execution site for as many as 200 people.
 
175 Croats Are Missing
 The United Nations is trying to determine whether the grave holds the remains of about 175 Croat men who vanished from a hospital after Serbian forces captured Vukovar in 1991.
State and Defense Department officials said the decision to support Physicians for Human Rights was an attempt to fulfill the Administration's pledge to bring suspected war criminals to justice.
"We were happy to respond to the request for military equipment," said Vernon A. Guidry Jr., the chief Pentagon spokesman. "But it was determined that civilians could do the job as well or better than we could. Also, if we sent troops, it would have raised questions about sending additional troops for security, which would have involved a significant commitment of equipment."
President Clinton has refused to deploy American soldiers as part of United Nations peacekeeping teams in Bosnia because their lives might be put at risk.
Diplomats said the United Nations was likely to ask Norway for the engineering help that the United States has declined to supply.
 
Fear of Serbian Attacks
 Some Pentagon officials said their main concern was that even in a humanitarian role, American troops would be a target for Serbian attacks. The Pentagon estimated that the operation would require 150 to 200 engineers, plus logistical support troops to construct shelters and secure the area.
"It wasn't as simple as putting in engineers," one Pentagon official said. "You would be digging in Serbian-held territory to investigate Serbian war crimes. We would have had to provide an extensive security force in case trouble erupted and our troops were attacked or taken hostage."
Informed of the decision, Eric Stover, executive director of Physicians for Human Rights, said, "We're disappointed that there is not a combat engineering unit and we hope that another country will step forward. But the assistance given for the equipment costs is very much appreciated."
Mr. Stover added that his organization had requested combat engineers because the peacekeeping mission in Croatia had said it was unable to secure the area and take the bodies out through checkpoints for laboratory tests elsewhere.
 
A Court Awaits
 Last month, at the request of the United States, the Security Council set up a court to sit in The Hague and try people accused of murder, rape, torture and other atrocities in the former Yugoslavia.
The United States has taken the lead in gathering evidence for the court, and last week submitted its eighth report to the United Nations with details of suspected war crimes.
Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali made the request for the American combat engineers in March, after Physicians for Human Rights, which conducted the initial inspection of the Vukovar site, informed United Nations investigators that it needed significant help in exhuming the bodies.
The request remained stuck in the Pentagon's bureaucracy, largely because of resistance to committing troops, Administration officials said.
 
Pleas to Aspin
 Last month, Madeleine K. Albright, the United States representative to the United Nations, pressed Defense Secretary Les Aspin in a letter for a quick response. Although she asked for substantial cooperation, she did not specifically ask him to send a military team.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher also pushed the idea -- without specifically asking for troops -- in a recent lunch with Mr. Aspin, telling him, "We should do something to help this project," a senior State Department official said.
But the Pentagon strongly objected to the involvement of any American soldiers. In a letter to Ms. Albright on June 11, Walter B. Slocombe, the principal Deputy Undersecretary of Defense for Policy, stated three objections: the engineers would require a substantial number of additional troops to protect them; the operation could be carried out by civilians; deployment of military personnel would be expensive.
 
Balkan Update
 In GENEVA, the two international mediators for the Balkans expressed concern yesterday over initial Serbian and Croatian plans for dividing BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA into three loosely federated ethnic states.
After talks with leaders of the warring factions, Lord Owen, representing the European Community, said that he and the United Nations representative, Thorvald Stoltenberg, had been "rather disappointed" by plans' vagueness.
The United States has rejected a request by the United Nations to send military engineers to investigate war crimes in CROATIA because Washington does not want to put American soldiers at risk. Instead, the Administration will donate $180,000 in medical supplies.
Washington's first Ambassador to Bosnia, Victor Jackovich, presented his credentials and tried to lift the morale of the country's beleaguered President, Alija Izetbegovic.
FRANCE announced that it would send 800 more soldiers to Bosnia to help defend declared safe zones, including the capital, SARAJEVO.
In BELGRADE, Prime Minister Radoje Kontic warned that the trade embargo could cause economic collapse and social unpheaval.

HEADLINE: How House Panel Is Persuaded to Retreat

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
The House subcommittee that helps to support the District of Columbia's government thought it had found a painless way to funnel money to the District: it would force a giant federally sponsored mortgage corporation to pay local income taxes.
Not surprisingly, the corporation, known as Fannie Mae, fought back. The federally chartered concern, which is the nation's biggest underwriter of home mortgages, lobbied vigorously to defeat the proposal, which was withdrawn today. 
 The defeat was a good illustration of the lobbying influence of an organization that sometimes behaves like a branch of the Government and sometimes like a private company.
Fannie Mae, which maintains a team of prominent lobbyists for such occasions, mobilized the real estate industry and the chairman of a friendly House committee in its successful defense against the tax increase.
Among the Fannie Mae executives who worked against the proposal, said Mimi Mager, the District of Columbia's deputy director of Congressional affairs, was Franklin B. Raines, its vice chairman, who was formerly a top economic adviser to Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly. For its part, the financially strapped city government itself never warmed to the idea of taxing Fannie Mae, which is considered a very good corporate citizen with 2,000 jobs.
To Congress, Fannie Mae argued that the tax exemption lowered the cost of mortgages for low- and middle-income home buyers. "This proposal would be nothing less than a housing tax," said James A. Johnson, Fannie Mae's chairman.
The fight erupted after the Appropriations Committee's Subcommittee on the District of Columbia had approved the measure unanimously in its draft of the bill providing next year's Federal aid to the city. Today, a chastened subcommittee chairman, Representative Julian C. Dixon, Democrat of California, withdrew the offending provision.
Fannie Mae, formally the Federal National Mortgage Association, is a profit-making, Government-sponsored enterprise whose stock is publicly traded. By law the hybrid concern cannot move its headquarters from Washington.
The company raises money from investors, uses the cash to buy mortgages from banks and savings and loans, and then either holds the mortgages or sells them in packages to investors.
It earned $2.2 billion last year, on which it paid $773 million in Federal tax, but no local tax. The subcommittee estimated that Fannie Mae would owe the District as much as $260 million if it did not have a local tax exemption. The measure would also have removed the local tax exemption of Sallie Mae, the Student Loan Marketing Association.
To persuade Republicans that the amendment was a mistake, Fannie Mae used one of its frequent lobbyists, Kenneth M. Duberstein, a former chief of staff to President Ronald Reagan.
The company also enlisted the help of Democrats on the House Banking Committee, whose chairman, Representative Henry B. Gonzalez of Texas, wrote the Appropriations Committee to say that his panel had jurisdiction over Fannie Mae's charter.
And Mr. Dixon himself was lobbied by a powerful home-state organization, the California Association of Realtors.

HEADLINE: Panel Takes First Steps, Modestly, in Closing Bases

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
In the first of a set of decisions that will cause economic disruption in scores of communities nationwide, a Presidential commission voted today to close one small Army installation and shrink another Army base but spared two big bases in New Jersey and Alabama.
Beginning today through Sunday, the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission is deciding to close, shrink or spare 88 major military bases and 150 smaller installations that in most cases are the economic engines in their regions. 
 Today's actions were relatively modest, as the seven-member panel voted to close Vint Hill Farms, a small intelligence post in Virginia, and to shrink Fort Belvoir, Va. It rejected the Pentagon's recommendation to close most of Fort McClellan, Ala., and to reduce Fort Monmouth, N.J.
New Jersey's Senators, Bill Bradley and Frank R. Lautenberg, both Democrats, said Fort Monmouth would actually gain about 500 civilian jobs from the closing of Vint Hill Farms.
As expected, the commission decided to keep open Fort Lee and Fort Monroe, both in Virginia; Fort McPherson and Fort Gillem, both in Georgia, and the Marcus Hook Army Reserve Center in Pennsylvania. It had added those installations to the list of Pentagon recommendations mainly for comparison.
The panel also voted to save Rock Island Arsenal in Illinois.
 
A Lengthy Process
 The commission's final recommendations will go to President Clinton, who has until July 15 to approve or reject the package. If he approves, he then forwards the package to Congress for approval or rejection. Given the pressure to cut military spending, approval appears almost certain.
Congress established the commission in 1990 to insulate lawmakers from having to vote individually on the politically sensitive issue of closing bases.
Commissioners face the delicate task of balancing the economic necessity of closing costly bases in light of shrinking military budgets and troop levels and maintaining the proper number and types of installations to insure combat readiness.
In rejecting the Pentagon's recommendation to close Fort McClellan, for example, commissioners criticized the Army's plan to move the fort's school that trains soldiers against chemical weapons but keep its live-agent chemical training center. The panel had rejected a similar Army proposal in the last round of base closings in 1991.
"I'm convinced that the school and the live-agent training center must be kept together," said Hansford T. Johnson, a commissioner who is a former four-star Air Force general.
Defense Secretary Les Aspin recommended in March the closing or shrinking of 43 major installations and 122 smaller ones. The commission later added 47 other major bases and 26 smaller ones for consideration. Commissioners have suggested in interviews that they might substitute some bases for Mr. Aspin's choices, but they are unlikely to close many more than the Pentagon has proposed.
Mr. Aspin and Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told the commission last week that closing more bases than the Pentagon advised could hurt military readiness and overload fledgling efforts to help communities find new uses for the closed sites.
The Pentagon is eager to reduce its costs, which have remained high as the military makes cuts in other areas. From 1985 to 1997, the Defense Department budget is expected to shrink by 42 percent and the number of troops by 30 percent. If Mr. Aspin's recommendations are accepted, the number of bases will decline only 15 percent.
 
Lobbying for Livelihoods
 Today's deliberations marked the beginning of the end of a process that started three months ago and has required commissioners to crisscross the country to visit bases on the hit list and listen to a parade of angry and sometimes desperate local politicians, civic leaders and ordinary citizens fearful of losing jobs in their communities.
Many of those lawmakers and community leaders packed a Senate hearing room today, consoling each other when their base lost or celebrating when their installation was spared.
Gerald Powell, chairman of a community task force in Anniston, Ala., that had argued to keep Fort McClellan open, could barely contain his glee after the vote. "The Army didn't do its homework," he said.
California, which has several bases under consideration for closing, got a bit of good news today. Commissioners postponed until Thursday a final vote on the Defense Language Institute in Monterey. They generally agreed, however, that it was a bad idea to move the center, which trains military linguists, to Fort Huachuca, Ariz., where university language instructors would be hired to teach military students.
 
Good News for New Jersey
 In addition, the commissioners voted unanimously to keep the Army's last remnant at the Presidio in San Francisco. The base itself has been turned over to the National Park Service, but the Sixth Army will now retain its headquarters buildings there.
The commission rejected a Pentagon plan to move the Army's Communications Electronic Command from Fort Monmouth, near Red Bank, N.J., to Illinois. Instead, it decided to move the unit from leased property off the base to buildings on post that are being vacated by a military intelligence command and the Army Chaplain School, which is moving to Fort Jackson, S.C.
The panel will consider Air Force bases on Thursday and Navy installations on Friday, Saturday and Sunday. The strongest opposition to closing bases has come from Charleston, S.C., and the San Francisco Bay area, both of which stand to lose tens of thousands of jobs and millions of dollars in revenues if the Pentagon's proposals win approval.
If Mr. Aspin's recommendations are accepted, the Defense Department will spend $1.7 billion to clean up and close those installations, and then anticipates saving $3.1 billion annually beginning in the year 2000.
In its last round of base closings, in 1991, the commission closed 34 bases and reduced or consolidated 48 other sites, decisions that were expected to save $1.5 billion a year after 1997. In the 1988 round, 16 major bases and 70 smaller ones were closed to save $693 million a year. But only 5 of the 50 large bases on those lists have actually closed: Pease Air Force Base, N.H.; George Air Force Base, Calif.; Eaker Air Force Base, Ark.; England Air Force Base, La., and Myrtle Beach Air Force Base, S.C.
The Pentagon operates 470 installations around the country. It has closed scores of bases overseas in the last five years; closings overseas do not need commission approval.
Mr. Clinton plans to offer $15 billion to $20 billion over the next five years to help communities hurt by base closings.

HEADLINE: Fed Finds Slow Pace For Growth

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
The prospect of higher taxes and costly health-care changes is helping to limit economic growth to a "slow to moderate pace" in most sections of the country, the Federal Reserve's latest survey of business conditions said today.
The Fed's anecdotal assessment of business conditions through mid-June came as the Commerce Department published statistics showing that new orders for big-ticket manufactured goods fell for the third straight month in May and that the economy grew at an even slower pace in the first three months of the year than had previously been thought. 
 "They're ugly, there's no two ways about it," Kenneth T. Mayland, chief economist for the Society National Bank in Cleveland, said of today's results. "The goods side of the economy is doing nothing."
 
Auto Sales Mixed
 Sales reports today from the auto makers provided mixed news. Car sales for mid-June showed no improvement over last year, but sales of pickup trucks, mini-vans and sport utility vehicles were up 13.4 percent, giving overall vehicle sales a 5.5 percent increase. Among the major auto makers, only the General Motors Corporation reported a dip. [Page D4.]
Although business activity as a whole continues to forge ahead, today's characterization as "slow to moderate" was disappointingly similar to the "generally modest improvement" the central bank found in its preceding survey in early May.
President Clinton's top economic adviser, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, viewed the latest soundings with equanimity. "The bottom line to all of this is slow growth -- but continued growth," she declared, predicting that the economy would pick up in the second half once the President's package was approved and uncertainties removed.
It is widely expected that the Administration's budget package purporting to cut the deficit by $500 billion over five years will be enacted in midsummer. Congressional leaders expect to begin consideration of a health plan in the fall.
The glum report today by the Fed also portrayed an economic climate in which the central bank would be less likely to raise interest rates any time soon, various analysts said. In recent days, some officials of the Federal Reserve had said that it might be wise to raise rates to reassure the world of its commitment to keep inflation at relatively low levels.
 
Summarizing Is Blunt
 The central bank's survey, compiled this time by its regional unit in Philadelphia, bluntly summarized private-sector reservations about Clinton Administration policy proposals.
"Businesses commented that investment and hiring were being delayed because of uncertainties about Federal tax increases and national health-care reform," the Fed said in its summary. "Retailers also said that such concerns might be preventing a more vigorous increase in consumer spending."
A Fed spokesman, Joseph R. Coyne, said it was not unusual for policy matters to be discussed in the survey and there was no attempt by the Fed to influence the debate on taxes or health care. "This is just what the reserve banks pick up in their discussions with people," Mr. Coyne said.
For several months Federal Reserve officials have said in private that the tax increases in the President's plan and the uncertainties it creates will hurt economic growth. Indeed, Administration officials concede that the uncertainty will hamper growth.
But some Administration officials say in private that some of business'sgrumbling that all the uncertainty is discouraging them from hiring and investing is a not-so-subtle form of politicking against any tax increases.
The report on orders for durable goods -- items from clothes dryers to jet planes designed to last at least three years -- showed a May decline of 1.6 percent. While this slump was not particularly large for a series subject to big swings, most analysts had expected an advance of this magnitude.
They were also discouraged by a second straight, although modest, four-tenths of 1 percent decline in shipments of durable goods and by a nine-tenths of 1 percent decline in unfilled orders. Backlog is one of the Commerce Department's official predictive indicators of the economy and this was the 12th decline in 13 months.
 
Orders 'Pretty Slow'
 "Our order books are pretty slow these days," said William Curtis, manufacturing manager for Hill-Loma Inc., a Gorham, Me., custom producer of machine tools for the metals processing industry.
He attributed much of the order decline, which he estimated at 50 percent from levels a year ago, to recession in Europe, where most of the company's output has gone in recent years.
When asked whether domestic customers, who he said were currently active quote-seekers but wary order-placers, were holding back because of policy uncertainties in Washington, Mr. Curtis said, "That could be part of it."
The 1.6 percent orders decline, to $128.3 billion in May, followed a two-tenths of 1 percent April decline that had originally been reported as a gain of three-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department data showed. The drop in March was 3.4 percent.
The decline, moreover, was widespread. Orders for transportation equipment fell 2.4 percent while electronic machinery was down 2.2 percent and primary metals down 1.9 percent. Industrial machinery posted a 1.7 percent advance, regaining most of April's decline.
Nonmilitary capital goods, a widely watched but volatile category, eased eight-tenths of 1 percent, the report also showed.
 
Revised Growth Rate
 The report on gross domestic product put the growth rate for the January-March period at a scant seven-tenths of 1 percent, compared with a nine-tenths of 1 percent rate a month ago and a 1.8 percent pace when initially estimated in late April.
The biggest downward revisions were for personal consumption spending and for business inventories, $3.4 billion and $3.3 billion, respectively. The main upward revision was $2.1 billion for business investment.
The Fed's survey, which is known as its beige book, showed the Minneapolis district among the strongest areas of the country and San Francisco, where business sentiment has "deteriorated" since the first quarter, probably the weakest.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Security Prices End Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities ended mixed yesterday as the market reacted to negative economic reports and renewed concern that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates as a pre-emptive measure against inflation.
Increases in Treasury prices were confined to long-term bonds, which benefited from a double dose of bad economic news: the nation's first-quarter growth was more sluggish than originally reported, and orders for "big ticket" factory goods plunged again in May. 
 The slow pace of economic growth, considered a damper on inflation, spurred buying of long-term bonds, which are most vulnerable to erosion in value when inflation heats up.
The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond rose 3/16 point, or $1.88 per $1,000 in face value. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, slipped to 6.76 percent from late Tuesday's 6.77 percent.
Short-term Treasuries, meanwhile, were unchanged to 3/32 point lower. Intermediate maturities were 3/32point lower to 1/16 point higher, the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported.
 
Short-Term Notes Sold
 Traders sold short-term securities yesterday morning after an article in The New York Times said the Federal Reserve was considering nudging up interest rates before the end of the summer to shield the economy from rising inflation.
The Times quoted the Federal Reserve vice chairman, David W. Mullins Jr., as saying that a failure by the central bank to respond to inflationary pressures "could be damaging to the economy."
Higher interest rates would hurt the value of all existing fixed-income securities. But the report depressed short-term securities the most because the Fed aims at short-term maturities to carry out its monetary policy. The report also dampened demand for new five-year notes sold by the Treasury at its monthly auction.
The Treasury sold $11 billion in notes at a high yield of 5.23 percent. The notes carried a coupon interest rate of 5 1/8 percent, with each $10,000 in face value selling for $9,954.30.
The bid-to-over ratio, a measure of Treasury auction demand that compares the number of bids offered to those accepted, was 2.70 to 1, up from an average of 2.56 to 1 in the last six five-year auctions. However, the ratio trailed last month's ratio of more than 3.1 to 1.
"The auction dynamics were so muddled by these other events, it left marginal players uninterested," said Dana Johnson, head of market analysis at First Chicago Capital Markets in Chicago.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 3.18 percent as the discount advanced 0.03 percentage point, to 3.12 percent. Six-month yields rose to 3.31 percent as the discount advanced 0.04 point, to 3.22 percent. One-year yields rose to 3.51 percent as the discount gained 0.04 point, to 3.39 percent.
Yields are the interest bonds pay by maturity, while the discount is the interest at which they are sold.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, fell 0.14, to 1,299.16.
The Federal funds rate, the interest on overnight loans between banks, was 3 percent, up from 215/16 percent late Tuesday.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 1025/32 , up 1/8 from late Wednesday. The average yield to maturity fell to 5.78 percent from 5.79 percent.

HEADLINE: Cutback in U.S. Funds to Reduce Summer Jobs for New York Youths

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
With a belated package of Federal financing about to be approved by Congress, government agencies and community groups in New York City are gearing up for a summer jobs program for teen-agers that promises fewer jobs and shorter periods of employment than in recent years.
The Federal program, a cornerstone of the nation's efforts to give poor young people their first exposure to the workaday world, is more critical than usual this year in New York, where unemployment among young people has recently soared. 
 Those responsible for matching teen-agers with jobs say that even when they do get the new Federal funds, their troubles will not be over -- they will have less money for salaries, far fewer jobs than teen-age applicants and fewer hours of work in the jobs that do exist.
 
Contrast to Last Summer
 Across the state, the State Labor Department said there would be at least 30 percent fewer federally financed jobs than there were last summer, when most big cities received an unexpected, last-minute injection of Federal money for jobs. Federal funds enabled New York City to create 52,400 summer jobs last year.
In New Jersey and Connecticut, state officials said yesterday that they should be able to provide as many or more jobs this summer than last.
"The kids are waiting, and a lot of them are going to be dissappointed," said Josephine Nieves, the New York City Commissioner of Employment. She said that more than 100,000 young people had applied for summer jobs in the government-sponsored program and that fewer than half that number of jobs would be created.
One applicant still hopeful of finding work is Sarah Mercado, 15, of Manhattan, who applied for the jobs program a month ago. In her only job interview so far, "they told me there were so many other kids, they had run out of numbers," she said yesterday.
The jobs aid that Congress is working on now is in addition to a larger package of Federal summer-jobs money that has been directed to cities and states for years. New York City has already received money to create 27,000 jobs this summer.
In Washington, the House and the Senate have approved different jobs bills; now members of Congress must work out a compromise that will have to go back to both houses for a final vote over the next week.
On Tuesday, the Senate appropriated $200 million to pay for 160,000 summer jobs. Of that number, it said about 12,500 jobs would be in New York State, with half of those in New York City. New Jersey would be allotted 6,500 summer jobs, and Connecticut would get 1,600. The House has passed a bill appropriating $340 million for summer jobs.
At City Hall, Ms. Nieves said she expected that summer jobs that lasted 8 or 10 weeks last summer might be shortened to 6 weeks this year. Young workers might also have their workweek shortened to 20 hours from the 28-hour week that has been common in recent years.
 
Minimum Wage
 Under the city's program, all participants are employed at the minimum wage of $4.25 an hour and assigned to jobs at government agencies or nonprofit organizations. Many jobs involve clerical work at hospitals and government offices, child care, maintenance of streets and parks, and work in summer recreation programs.
The federally financed program is separate from another large summer-jobs program sponsored by the New York City Partnership, a business group, in which young people are offered summer work at private companies, often at pay higher than the minimum wage.
The program created 42,000 jobs last summer. Although a final count is not yet available, officials of the business group said there would be fewer jobs in the program this year because New York City companies have been hurt by the recession and are trying to protect their existing employees.
The cutbacks come at a time when unemployment among New York City teen-agers, always worse than in most of the nation, has soared. The city said this month that the unemployment rate among young people 16 to 19 years old was 40 percent in the first three months of the year, compared with 20 percent two years ago.
 
A Need for Hope
 "We have to give our kids hope, and nothing is more hopeful for them than having a job," said Richard E. Green, executive director of the Crown Heights Youth Collective in central Brooklyn, a neighborhood group that works with the city to match young people with federally financed summer jobs.
Like other experts, he said he feared that the cuts in the jobs program might aggravate social problems in some of the city's poor neighborhoods. Among those who had applied for summer jobs this year through his group, and were still waiting, were two of the four young Brooklyn men who were arrested last week in the killing of a man in Prospect Heights in an attempt to steal his bicycle.
"What that incident should tell us is that there a lot of kids out there with noble intentions who can easilly get into serious trouble if they don't see a light at the end of the tunnel," Mr. Green said.

HEADLINE: Blazing a Power Trail in the Adirondacks;
When Senator Ronald Stafford Says Not in My District, a Whole State Goes Without

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 23

 BODY:
Now and then, an issue arises that spotlights the way things really work in the New York State Legislature. There is, for instance, the current tale of how the fate of arguably the most important environmental legislation of the year has come to rest largely with one man: Senator Ronald B. Stafford, Republican from Plattsburgh.
At stake is the creation of an environmental trust fund, legislation that would set aside at least $100 million for the state to purchase and preserve undeveloped land, including in Adirondack Park and in Long Island's Pine Barrens and along barrier beaches. 
 But most of Adirondack Park is in Mr. Stafford's district. A critic of big government and environmentalists alike, the Senator has opposed the fund, saying state land purchases will hurt the economy of his rural, largely poor region by stifling development.
In other places, Mr. Stafford's concerns might be viewed as one opinion among many in a Legislature with 211 members. But in the Republican-controlled Senate, he is the deputy majority leader, chairman of the Finance Committee and widely considered the second most powerful man after the majority leader Ralph J. Marino, of Oyster Bay.
 
Control at Home and Far Afield
 Furthermore, Mr. Marino is the type of leader who cedes considerable influence to those he is ostensibly leading. Among the Republicans, senior senators have great control over issues dear to them.
At times, Mr. Marino's leadership style gives his inner circle vast power over issues outside their districts. For example, Senator Norman J. Levy, Republican from Suffern, maintains a virtual stranglehold over legislation relating to the New York City subway system because he is chairman of the Transportation Committee and a trusted associate of Mr. Marino.
The power Mr. Stafford wields is over the Adirondacks, with virtual veto power over anything the Senate, and thus the entire Legislature, does in the six million acres of craggy mountains, frigid lakes and dense forests that sweep across the state's northern reaches.
If the trust fund did not include the Pine Barrens and the barrier beaches, and Mr. Stafford's opposition therefore only affected the Adirondacks, the issue might not have gained much attention in Albany. But by blocking the trust fund, Mr. Stafford has also prevented money from flowing to other parts of the state.
This year, that has caused grumbling not only among Democrats, but also among downstate Republicans who want the state to purchase land in their districts. Mr. Marino himself has made promises to pass a bill this year.
 
'One Man, and One Man Only'
 For those reasons, Mr. Stafford's power over the park is being severely tested. Thus far, he has held his own. The Senate trust fund bill, drafted with Mr. Stafford's help, bars the use of a trust fund for purchasing any land in Adirondack Park.
But under pressure from environmental groups, Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, a Queens Democrat, and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo have said they will oppose any legislation that does not include the Adirondacks.
"It's a very bad public policy precedent to give one man, and one man only, veto power over a sixth of the state, the sixth with a majority of the state's natural resources," said Neil F. Woodworth, conservation director of the Adirondack Mountain Club. "It's a policy without precedent in the nation."
Mr. Stafford is not the only official raising concerns about a trust fund. Mr. Cuomo has said he will support a fund only if money is raised primarily through new taxes or fees, a position opposed by Republicans and some Democrats who say the fund can mostly come from the state's operating budget.
But Mr. Stafford's longstanding opposition to the land purchases has been so effective that it has become the stuff of lore upstate, where he has been called, sometimes derisively, sometimes reverently, King Ronald.
It is a role Mr. Stafford, 57, seems to enjoy. In his office in the Capitol are framed cartoons of him from local papers. One shows him dressed in royal robes and wearing a crown; another has him lighting fireworks from a box labeled "abolish the A.P.A. bill," environmental legislation Mr. Stafford helped kill last year.
A broad-shouldered man with flowing white hair, Mr. Stafford conveys anything but the image of a power broker. Avuncular and soft-spoken, his sentences tend to ramble and he often gropes for words, sometimes looking to aides for help.
"I don't think I'm close to the developers, I don't think I help any one group," he said in a recent interview. "All I'm trying to do is keep our way of life. To give our people the opportunity to make a living."
 
Longtime Ties
 To a large extent, his singular power over his region exemplifies the highly decentralized way Mr. Marino runs the Senate. But it also reflects the closeness of the two men: Mr. Stafford was an early supporter of Mr. Marino when he first ran for majority leader in 1988, and his support was considered instrumental to Mr. Marino's victory.
But Mr. Stafford, who has been in the Senate for 27 years, has also built a reputation for near invincibility in his district, where he has been unopposed 8 times in 15 races. Underlying his success, friends and foes say, is a back-country populism that mixes attacks on big government with an uncanny knack for obtaining big government money.
In this year's budget, for instance, Mr. Stafford is responsible for about $10 million in appropriations for public works projects in his district, ranging from a $350,000 sewer project in Warrensburg to a $6 million low-interest loan to a paper company in financial straits. Mr. Stafford is widely thought to have obtained more members items, as they are called, than any senator other than Mr. Marino.
Mr. Stafford says his members items have provided an important economic boost to a poor area. But his critics say he has used them to buy political support from local officials and business interests, particularly the logging industry.
"This is a poor area and there are things we cannot do without money from the state," said Dick Purdue, town supervisor of Indian Lake and a frequent critic of Mr. Stafford. "It is a not so subtle form of corruption in the Adirondacks."
His critics also say that Mr. Stafford has exploited local anxiety with the weak economy, portraying environmentalists as wealthy downstaters and blaming the Adirondack Park Agency, which has far-reaching authority to restrict development in the park, for stifling local enterprise.
"He runs year in and year out as the defender of the little guy, yet he's done nothing for them," said Melody Mackenzie, a Democrat who ran against Mr. Stafford last year. She was outspent by a 10-to-1 margin but won 38 percent of the vote.
During her campaign, Ms. MacKenzie repeatedly accused Mr. Stafford of using his political clout to direct state jobs to his associates. A similar charge has been made in a Federal lawsuit brought by a Saranac Lake developer who claims he was pressured by a bank to use Mr. Stafford as his bond counsel. Mr. Stafford, who is a director of the bank, denies the charges.
Friends say Mr. Stafford's conservatism is grounded in his humble roots. "He's a populist," said Harold A. Jerry Jr., a member of the state Public Service Commission who advocates trust-fund purchases in the Adirondacks. "He's not adopting false positions to please constituents."
 
Humility and Hard Work
 Orphaned as an infant, Mr. Stafford was adopted by a Plattsburgh couple when he was 3. His father, a guard at Dannemora State Prison, liked taking him ice fishing; his mother, a school teacher, cajoled him to study. She usually prevailed, imparting lessons in humility, personal responsibility and hard work, he said.
"She always reminded you you're not as good as you thought," he said.
After graduating from Columbia Law School, he worked on the 1964 campaign of United States Senator Kenneth Keating, who lost to Robert Kennedy. The following year, he returned to Plattsburgh, challenged the local Democratic Senator and won. The margin, 8,600 votes, stands as his narrowest victory yet.
As an example of Mr. Stafford's independence, his defenders point to his early support for legislation allowing people sickened by toxic chemicals to sue companies long after being exposed. Republican leaders adamantly opposed the toxic torts bill, as it was known. But Mr. Stafford shepherded the bill to passage in 1986, winning respect from some of the same liberal lobbyists who now battle him on environmental issues.
"When they write the New York version of 'Profiles in Courage,' Ron Stafford will get an entire chapter for the toxic-tort fight," said Arthur N. Malkin, a lobbyist who worked with Mr. Stafford on the legislation.
During that fight, Mr. Stafford was stricken with lung cancer and received chemotherapy that left him bald, weak and almost unrecognizable. "We were once at a breakfast," said H. Douglas Barclay, a former state Senator, "and a Legislator came in and said, 'Too bad Senator Stafford couldn't make it.' And he was right next to me. It took a lot of guts to get through that."
Mr. Stafford says he has completely recovered from the cancer.
Now, amid a daily barrage of criticism from environmental groups, he faces his biggest political battle in years.
"The environmentalists are paid to do their job," he said. "But if people really knew how these laws affect people, they'd have a different attitude."

HEADLINE: Hartford Predicts 2d Consecutive Budget Surplus

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HARTFORD, June 23

 BODY:
A jump in corporation tax receipts will help Connecticut finish the 1992-93 budget year with a small surplus for the second consecutive year after four years of deficits, the latest forecast shows.
By law, the expected $10 million surplus must be applied toward the $966 million deficit from the 1990-91 fiscal year. The state still owes $706 million to investors who bought five-year notes. 
 William J. Cibes Jr., the state budg et director, said that the state appears to have achieved stability in its revenue system despite the problems afflicting the Connecticut economy.
"The main sources are very strong," he said, pointing to the corporation, sales and personal income taxes.
A $45 million rise in receipts from corporation taxes, which are assessed on profits, suggests that many companies are turning the corner, Mr. Cibes said. "That ultimately means, I believe, that there will be job creation," he said.
The jump in corporation-tax receipts will offset a $32 million Medicaid penalty that was assessed in February, but was not recognized as a revenue loss in the state's official budget forecasts until this week.
State Comptroller William E. Curry Jr. has been warning since March that the state would fail to get the $32 million by June 30.
Mr. Cibes said today that the previous decision to overlook the penalty had been justified because the state had earlier been optimistic about winning its appeal.
Mr. Cibes's new forecast differed in several ways from the one he issued last month.
The differences include a $14 million reduction in spending and a $5 million increase in tax refunds. The $10 million surplus represents the net result of all changes, as last month's report projected a zero balance on June 30.
All changes are comparatively small, given the size of the overall budget: $8.1 billion.
The sales tax, which usually falls off drastically in an economic downturn, has held steady for the last two years.
The income tax exceeded projections made last fall by more than $100 million when final returns, and first estimated payments for 1993, were opened in mid-April.
Mr. Cibes speculated that one factor may be the reduced rates on capital gains, dividends and interest that were introduced in 1991 when the income tax was extended to wages.

HEADLINE: Blue Chips Lead Retreat as Dow Falls 30.72

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks retreated broadly yesterday led by a sharp drop in blue-chip issues that pulled the Dow Jones industrial average down 30.72 points, to 3,466.81. Investor concern over corporate profits was again a factor, traders said.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy, with 278.3 million shares changing hands, up from 260 million on Tuesday. Losing stocks were narrowly ahead of gainers, 1,073 to 845, as the Big Board composite slipped 1.17 points, to 244.92. 
 Heavy selling in oil stocks and losses in a number of bank issues supplied the downside impetus for blue chips in a session dominated by programmed trading. Oil stocks fell on concern over supply, compounded by rating downgrades and lower earnings estimates from several analysts on a number of oil companies.
 
Investors' Fears Heightened
 Declining oil prices amid bickering by OPEC members over production levels and an industry report late Tuesday showing a sharp rise in crude oil and gasoline inventories in the United States heightened investor fears over oil company profits. Texaco, fell 1 5/8, to 62 1/2; Mobil was down 1 3/4, to 73 1/8, and Atlantic Richfield dropped 4 3/4, to 114 5/8.
However, transportation issues, grounded for weeks, did well yesterday on propects of lower fuel prices. The Dow transport index rose 7.98 points, to 1,493.41 and was led by UAL, up 2 5/8, to 120 5/8.
Other negative news came from a Government report that May durable goods fell 1.6 percent and that first- quarter gross domestic product was revised downward to a gain of only seven-tenths of 1 pecent.
Among the issues leading the market lower were Caterpillar, down 1 3/8, to 72 7/8, after Tuesday's Commerce Department decision to impose punitive duties on imported steel. Traders said the move could lead to higher steel prices and hurt the construction industry, where Caterpillar has a major presence.
Frank Calta, managing director and head of institutional trading at Josepthal, Lyon & Ross, said the cancellation of the RJR Nabisco stock offering yesterday hurt the market.
 
Nabisco Offering Halted
 RJR Nabisco Holding's decision not to go ahead with a previously announced public offering of 93 million a special stock in its food business was based on the decline over the last four months of the market value of comparable food companies. The decline would have made it difficult for Nabisco to fetch the price for the food stock of $17 to $19 a share. One trader called the move a warning sign for the market, since it was the first of 290 initial public offerings this year that was not done.
The Costar Corporation, a manufacturer of disposable plastic lab ware, rose 5 7/8, to 23 5/8, after saying it had agreed to be acquired by Corning for $25 in Corning common stock for each Costar share. Corning fell 1/4, to 34 3/8.
