HEADLINE: Small Business Wants More In Clinton Economic Plan

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
Convinced they have been outlobbied by big business, the nation's small businesses began pressing today for changes in President Clinton's economic plan, complaining that the Senate Finance Committee wiped out most provisions that would help them.
Representatives of the nation's 20 million small businesses, once optimistic about the President's original package, have soured on the plan because the Finance Committee dropped a capital-gains tax cut for small business and other investment incentives. 
 "We were done in on Capitol Hill," said Bennie Thayer, chairman of the 350,000-member National Association for the Self-Employed, "Big business once again got its way. Now we see small business being hurt more than we anticipated in the beginning."
Mr. Clinton's original plan included numerous goodies for small business that were eliminated in Congress -- like a permanent investment tax credit, the capital-gains tax cut for investments in small companies and tax breaks for hiring workers in poor urban areas.
In addition, the House of Representatives inserted a provision enabling small businesses to quickly write off the first $25,000 -- up from the first $10,000 -- of each year's investment in equipment, but the Senate Finance Committee scaled that back, too.
"We would like to go back closer to what the original package included," said John Galles, executive vice president of National Small Business United, a group with 60,000 business members. "At this point, we're incredibly upset with what the Senate did. It will show a real absence of leadership on President Clinton's part if he doesn't work to get some of these small-business incentives back in."
As the full Senate took up the deficit reduction package today, small-business lobbyists peppered the nation's capital with faxes and held numerous news conferences as they urged small-business owners to shower the White House and Congress with phone calls and letters.
Several lobbyists questioned why the Senate Finance Committee favored big business over small companies because, in their view, small business packs a far more powerful electoral punch.
The small businesses at first praised the President's plan, showing a willingness to put up with some higher taxes because the plan was serious about reducing the budget deficit. Many wealthy small-business owners complained about the increases in personal income taxes, but the general sense was the President's plan was positive because it contained special provisions for small business. President Clinton had also stressed that small businesses needed special incentives because they were the main engine of job creation.
But when the Senate Finance Committee replaced a broad-based energy tax approved by the House with a smaller tax on gasoline and other transportation fuels, it also dropped most of the tax breaks for small business as it struggled to offset the money lost from the energy tax.
 
Effort in Congress Pledged
 Hearing small business's pleas, Administration officials said they would seek to insure that some of the small-business incentives remain in the final package after negotiations between the House and Senate.
"The President's plan has always had a commitment to target incentives for small business because we believe they are a major engine of job creation," said Gene Sperling, an assistant to the President for economic policy. "I suspect in one form or another we will work to make sure the final bill has incentives that help small business."
Many lawmakers were heeding the wrath of small business. The Senate majority leader, George Mitchell, introduced an amendment to give back part of the small-business incentives that the Finance Committee removed, but it was defeated on the Senate floor.
His amendment would have increased the amount of an investment that small businesses could write off in the first year to $18,500 from the current level of $10,000. The House had approved a $25,000 ceiling in such deductions, but the Senate Finance Committee cut it back to $15,000. This provision aims to encourage small businesses to invest more by allowing them to deduct a sizable chunk of each year's investment that same year.
Mr. Mitchell's proposal also called for cutting a capital gains tax on investments in businesses with less than $50 million in capital. The Senate Finance Committee deleted this provision.
One Senate aide said the package was still favorable to small businesses, arguing that eliminating the broad-based energy tax was good for them. The aide asserted that the capital gains tax break would have helped only the rich, and added, "Expensing has been raised by 50 percent. How can anyone complain about having a deduction enlarged by 50 percent."
 
 
Income Tax Plan
 Much of small business's fury was aimed at the Administration's proposal to raise the personal income tax rate from 31 percent to 36 percent for households with taxable incomes of more than $140,000 and to 40 percent for households with taxable incomes of more than $250,000.
This provision would hit many wealthy small-business owners, whose corporate profits are taxed at the personal rate.
The National Federation of Independent Business, which has 600,000 members, called the personal income tax increase its No. 1 problem.
"Small businesses have accounted for 65 percent of the new jobs created in the past five years," said Ronald Bullock, president of the Bison Gear and Engineering Corporation in Downer's Grove, Ill. "Do we, as a country, really want to derail this job express by imposing an unfair tax on family-owned businesses?"

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS: Canada's Tobacco-Tube Test;
New Cigarettes Save Butts From Ashtrays

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TORONTO, June 23

 BODY:
Smokers who cannot finish whole cigarettes will have a way to extinguish them neatly and smoke them again later with a new brand that is being introduced by Rothmans, Benson & Hedges Inc., the Canadian tobacco company.
Packs of new Oxford Long-Lasting Cigarettes will come with special storage tubes to save partly smoked cigarettes. The packaging was a response to research that showed 50 percent of Canadian smokers put out unfinished cigarettes and later resmoked them. 
 The reason for Canada's smoke-and-snuff habit is attributed to high tobacco prices and tough smoking restrictions.
Oxford cigarette packs also contain "snippers" to cut off the ends of butts as well as a tube to extinguish and store a half-smoked cigarette.
"It responds to the changing trends of today's smokers," said a company spokesman, John McDonald, "mainly public and workplace smoking restrictions whereby people have to go down elevators, into stairwells and outside to enjoy a cigarette."
Canada's tobacco consumption has been declining by about 3 percent a year, Mr. McDonald noted.
"Quite often as well, people want to reduce their smoking and do not want to smoke a whole cigarette at once," he said.
Canada has some of the world's strictest anti-smoking laws. Smoking is prohibited in public places like shopping malls, railroad stations and office buildings. Tobacco is also heavily taxed, which has led to a thriving black market in cigarettes smuggled across the border from the United States.
Smokers will pay extra for the Oxford brand, which has a suggested retail price of 2.99 Canadian dollars, or about $2.35 (United States), for a pack of 10, compared with about $3.50 for a typical 20-pack.
The product is being sold initially in Quebec City and London, Ontario and is expected to be introduced throughout Canada.
Mr. McDonald said his company had the exclusive license in Canada for the special filter on the cigarettes and international patents on the product.
Sixty percent of Rothmans, Benson & Hedges is owned by a unit of Britain's Rothmans International P.L.C., and 40 percent is owned by the Philip Morris Companies.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
New York Gold Prices Jump As Inflation Concern Rises

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold futures prices jumped to a two-week high on the Commodity Exchange in New York yesterday, as the rapidly rising soybean market fanned inflation fears and the dollar fell versus the yen.
In other commodities markets, silver futures rose sharply, grain advanced, orange juice cooled down, oil rose and livestock and meat were mostly higher. 
 Gold for August delivery climbed $5.80, to $375.50 an ounce, the contract's highest settlement since June 8. July silver surged 13.5 cents, to $4.395 an ounce, also a two-week high.
The metals market had been calm this month as inflation jitters that prompted a spring rally quieted. But the strength in commodity prices this week, especially in the weather-driven soybean market, revived investors' interest in gold, said William O'Neill, senior futures strategist at Merrill Lynch Futures in New York.
"You don't have to look too much farther than the soybean pit," Mr. O'Neill said. "When there is something that threatens to have some inflationary implications, gold is quick to respond to it." Many investors consider gold a hedge against inflation and currency fluctuations.
Soybeans reached a 12-month high this week as planting delays caused by excessive rain in the Midwest caused analysts to lower their acreage and production expectations.
The strength in soybeans contributed to a rise yesterday in the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 agricultural and industrial commodities. The index, which is considered a significant indicator of inflation, closed at 206.76, up 114 points.
Buying in precious metals was also prompted by gold's ability to hold above $367.50 an ounce and silver's ability to remain above $4.25, when sellers tested the markets, said Peter Cardillo, research director with Westfalia Investments in New York.
In energy trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for delivery in August rose 4 cents, to $18.86 a barrel; July heating oil rose 0.19 cent, to 52.07 a gallon; July unleaded gasoline rose 0.19 cent, to 54.09 cents a gallon, and July natural gas skidded 22.1 cents, to $1.865 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: Administration May Cut Growth Forecast to 2.5%

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is likely to cut its forecast for this year's economic growth to around 2.5 percent from the 3.1 percent prediction it made in January, the Administration's chief economist said today.
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, head of the Council of Economic Advisers, said the Administration was contemplating a downward revision in the forecast because of the defeat of President Clinton's $16 billion jobs program and slower-than-anticipated growth in the first quarter. 
 "We're talking somewhere between 2.5 percent and 3 percent, and probably on the soft side of 3," she said at a lunch with reporters, suggesting that numerous factors were pushing the forecast toward 2.5 percent.
Many economists say that growth needs to be at least 2.5 percent to make an appreciable dent in the nation's unemployment rate, now running at 6.9 percent.
 
Smaller Debt Service
 Ms. Tyson predicted that notwithstanding the slower-than-anticipated growth, this year's budget deficit would not be larger than the $322 billion the Administration forecast in January. The reason: interest rates have fallen more than the Administration had forecast, causing large savings in servicing the Federal debt.
Ms. Tyson said that in light of the strong rise in business inventories in the first quarter, growth in the second quarter would probably remain moderate. She said she agreed with private forecasters who suggested growth of 2.3 to 2.4 percent.
But she predicted faster growth in the second half, saying that once the President's economic package was approved and many uncertainties removed, businesses would feel more willing to expand, invest and hire new workers.
She added that "the lagged effects" of low interest rates would also help speed growth later this year. For example, homeowners who paid $1,000 to refinance their mortages may take several extra months to feel the effects of their lower mortgage payments.
Other factors that suggested faster growth, she said, were interest-rate cuts in Germany and an expected economic rebound in slumping Japan. Stronger growth abroad would help increase American exports, which have been weak in recent months.
Ms. Tyson said the Senate's defeat of the President's stimulus program would subtract three-tenths of 1 percent from this year's growth rate.

HEADLINE: Why Not Take a Gander at This Piece?

BYLINE: By ENID NEMY

 BODY:
THE nicest people do it, the most intelligent people do it, the "letting it all hang out, telling it like it is" people do it. It's unconscious, subconscious, automatic. It's highly unlikely that there's anyone around who hasn't, at one time or another, used a euphemism.
"They're probably just as old as language," said Dr. Frederick C. Mish, editor in chief of Merriam-Webster Inc., dictionary publishers in Springfield, Mass. He noted that the actual word was Greek in origin, loosely meaning something that sounds better, and that it was generally related to "getting around the taboos and certain sacred words." 
 He said, for example, that "gosh" and "golly" were first used instead of "God," and that "jeepers" was used for "Jesus."
"Euphemisms also turn up anywhere they're needed to put a better face on things," Dr. Mish said. "The military may say 'incursion,' politicians use 'negative growth' and 'retrenchment.' What do they really mean? 'Invasion,' 'downturn' and 'cutting back on spending.' "
He also pointed out that there was a new tendency to use an initial in front of "word" as a euphemism -- "L-word" instead of liberal, for example, although this one was generally said tongue in cheek.
One of Dr. Mish's favorite euphemism-related phrases is "Pardon my French," which is generally said before profanity.
"It's amusing because there's an unspoken assumption that English wouldn't have any bad words," he said.
Back to politics. "Politically correct" is a euphemism, but for what?
Joseph J. Esposito, president of the Encyclopaedia Britannica Publishing Group, thinks the phrase is both curious and amusing because, he said, "It refers to the rigid ideologues of the left but is used exclusively by rigid ideologues of the right."
The British have some rather wonderful euphemisms. Try "one sandwich short of a picnic" for "crazy" or "NQOCD" instead of "not quite our class dear." And how about "sugar on your strawberries," meaning that senility may be just around the corner?
In various parts of the United States, to "send someone to the woodshed" is to give them a tongue-lashing or even a spanking. To "bless out" is to curse someone, and to use the phrase "horse hockey" is to get around saying "excrement."
Once in a while, the more thoughtful will catch themselves using a euphemism. They'll say "remains" and then ask themselves what makes that word any better, any more acceptable or pleasant than "corpse" or "body." They'll ask themselves why they say "odor" instead of "smell" and "perspiration" instead of "sweat" and, in short, why they are shilly-shallying around.
They may ask themselves but, for the most part, they'll still do it, a holdover perhaps from the past when it was considered impolite to be direct, or when certain words conjured images that were apparently too embarrassing to be spoken aloud, especially by ladies.
Most women of a certain age (another euphemism, usually used instead of "old" but in this case meaning anyone past the first blush of youth) can remember when "menstrual period" was a phrase used almost exclusively by doctors. Its most common euphemism, for some reason considered less distasteful, was and often still is "the curse."
A marginally more pleasant but infinitely less honest euphemism is remembered by Judy Licht, a television reporter. For years, she recalled, she referred to that time of month (another euphemism) as "having a friend." She and many in her age group also used a phrase -- "falling off the roof" -- that made even less sense but was an accepted part of their vocabulary.
Death has many euphemisms but one of the strangest -- "he bought the farm" -- may have an unusual provenance. According to Jerry Della Femina, who is married to Ms. Licht and is chairman of Jerry Inc., an advertising agency, it was first used in World War II by pilots and soldiers when a colleague was killed. "He bought the farm" meant that the insurance policy left behind would pay off any mortgage.
"Passed away" is probably the most ubiquitous euphemism for death, but more elaborate and genteel are "departed this life," "called home" and "gone to eternal sleep." And when it comes to the next step, burial, who hasn't heard the expression "laid to rest"?
All of these and more are a thorn in the side (is that a euphemism for irritation?) of Louis Ufland, a partner in Ufland-Jannes, a public relations and special-events firm in Manhattan. As for Mr. Ufland, he says he doesn't equivocate -- he comes right out with "died" and "buried."
It's true that "at liberty" and "resting" sound better than "unemployed," but the end result is the same. Everyone knows what is meant. And once in a while, "considering offers" actually means just that -- once in a while.
Once in a while, too, there is an euphemism that makes sense. "Eyewear" started as a fashionable and better-sounding word for "eyeglasses." Now that glasses are most often made of plastic, eyewear is more accurate.
There's nothing unpleasant about the word "wife" -- one hopes. So why "the little woman," a patronizing and infinitely less preferable euphemism? And why, too, "my better half," which is patronizing in another way? It's usually used by men who mean the exact opposite.
Let's not forget "sleeping with," "going to bed with," and "having an affair." All, in most cases, to avoid -- and what's wrong with it? -- the word sex.
Going to the "powder room," the "little boys room," or "little girls room"? Where's the "bathroom" or even, dare we say it, the "toilet," which is after all, just a small room fitted for a specific purpose?
For Dr. Maria New, chairman of the department of pediatrics at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, some euphemisms are essential -- but she deals with children. When she says "We're going to have 'a little stick' or 'a little pinch,' " it's accepted more quietly and readily than "Now we're going to stick a needle in you and draw some blood."
One of the more sublime euphemisms is attributed to Winston Churchill. It's "terminalogical inexactitude," and in less polite terms it means "a lie." Another owes its birth to royalty. It's called "a gracious message" and translated for mere mortals, it means a royal request to Parliament for money. Try that one on your boss.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Fernandez's Statistics Change With the Scenery

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, June 23

 BODY:
Twelve days ago, Tony Fernandez escaped from baseball's version of hell, the place where a team cannot win two straight games, where a pitcher has lost 23 straight and where both the manager and general manager who started the season are now unemployed. No longer muddling along with the last-place Mets in Flushing, Fernandez returned to the defending World Series champion Blue Jays in Toronto in a trade for outfielder Darrin Jackson.
But the improvement in scenery has not improved his demeanor, at least not today. There was no smile emanating from Fernandez when he was asked about being back in the city where he began his major league career at shortstop 10 years ago. There were no wonderful stories from him about playing before a sellout crowd every night at the Skydome and no theories about why he is playing remarkably better for the Jays then he did for the Mets. There was mostly gruffness as a player reputed as aloof was exactly that. 
 "I'm happy to play wherever God sends me," said Fernandez, who spent two seasons in San Diego before playing two months with the Mets. "I'll be ready to play anywhere. It just didn't work out in New York."
 
Injuries Took Toll
 Why not? After claiming that everyone knew why he faltered in New York, and then being told that was untrue, Fernandez grudgingly mentioned how a bout with kidney stones and then fatigue from the ordeal had detracted from his game.
But he remained very guarded. Asked how much happier he was to be in Toronto, Fernandez snapped, "What makes you think I wasn't happy in New York?"
Well, if Fernandez is not happier in Toronto, his statistics surely have made the Blue Jays happier. After scraping bottom by hitting .225 with one homer, 14 runs batted in and making 6 errors in 48 games for the Mets, Fernandez has soared here.
While the Blue Jays were losing, 4-3, to the Yankees tonight, Fernandez was going 2 for 3 with a double, triple and a walk. He extended his hitting streak to seven games and raised his batting average to .356 for his 11 games with Toronto. He has 1 home run and 12 runs batted in. And he has not made an error.
"I'm just doing my job," Fernandez said before the game, never lifting his head to make eye contact.
 
A Savior For the Jays
 Although Fernandez has a bizarre sidearm throwing style that will not be taught at any baseball clinics, he is a savvy veteran who usually positions himself adequately and makes the plays his limited range allows. A four-time All-Star with a career .284 average who turns 31 next week, Fernandez has been a savior for the Jays because Dick Schofield, their regular shortstop, is on the disabled list with a broken arm and will be sidelined until at least August.
A deeply religious man who has sometimes been described as peculiar, Fernandez is the eighth player to serve two stints with the Blue Jays and is the club's career leader in games played at shortstop, 1,020. Although it seems as if it would be easy for him to speak about leaving the out-of-the-running Mets for a team that has a chance for its second straight World Series title, Fernandez is reluctant to elaborate on the blessing.
"I feel good," he said. "God works in mysterious ways."

HEADLINE: Cornwall Village Gets a Tate Gallery Branch

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. IVES, England, June 20

 BODY:
Nestled into the cliffs overlooking Porthmeor Beach in this tiny fishing village in the farthest corner of Cornwall is the brand new Tate St. Ives, a pristine white structure that politely defers to the sea. Within, there is a selection of art from the English artists who belong to the St. Ives School, selected from the holdings of the Tate Gallery in London.
The opening of the $4.95 million museum has not been without considerable fanfare, in the hope of improving the fortunes of St. Ives, an economically depressed area with an artistically rich history. 
 [Prince Charles arrived on Wednesday to add further luster to the inauguration ceremonies. About 2,500 members of the art world are expected in St. Ives before the week's festivities are over.]
For more than a century artists beginning with J. M. W. Turner and Whistler have come here to capture the views of the sea, the wild landscape and the soft, even light. So have scores of late-19th-century plein-air realist painters. The first of the so-called St. Ives School -- Ben Nicholson; his wife, Barbara Hepworth, and Naum Gabo -- moved here in 1939. Bernard Leach established his pottery here in the 1920's, and in the 1930's and 40's Peter Lanyon, Terry Frost and Roger Hilton joined the growing artists' colony.
"A number of these artists had international recognition in the 50's," said Nicholas Serota, the director of the Tate. "The museum can't help but provoke a renewed interest and a reappraisal of their work."
 
Long Ruminations
 The idea for the museum has been brewing since the mid-1970's, but in 1985, when the Tate held a major exhibition of St. Ives artists, community officials got serious. "They asked us if we would be willing to run a museum if they could ever have the means to build it," Mr. Serota said.
The Tate's growing number of satellite operations is similar to that of the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York, an institution that operates several branches in the United States. Yet it is still less ambitious than the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, which is running museums on both sides of the Atlantic. This is the Tate's second branch; the first, the Tate Liverpool, opened five years ago. While the Liverpool museum has had its share of economic difficulties, Mr. Serota said it was averaging about 600,000 visitors a year and that he hoped St. Ives would have the same appeal. Art for the Tate's latest venture has come from the museum's holdings of about 100 paintings and sculptures by artists of the St. Ives School. About 30 to 40 percent of the art in the new museum's galleries will change each year. "We'll also borrow works from time to time," Mr. Serota said.
Mike Tooby, the curator in charge of the Tate St. Ives, explained that he didn't want to "draw a line around a body of work and say it is strictly St. Ives." He added: "Mark Rothko came here on holiday in 1958. You wouldn't put him in the list of St. Ives artists; nevertheless there is a connection. We want to blur the edges."
Seventy-five artworks are currently on view. So are about 70 pieces of ceramics, many by Bernard Leach. There are also several new commissions. The entrance to the museum, for example, is dominated by a large colored-glass window -- part gift, part commission -- in rich hues of pinks and turquoise, created by Patrick Heron. Terry Frost, another contemporary St. Ives artist, created a long hanging especially for the main stairwell inside the museum.
 
Local Vernacular
 The main glazed rotunda echoes the shape of the gasworks that were built in 1835 where the museum now stands. The building's architects, Eldred Evans and David Shalev, were selected through a national competition. Their design reflects the vernacular architecture of St. Ives. The building's exterior, fashioned from a material known as marble dash (actually cement with pebbles mixed in) is common to the area. Natural light bathes the building, and the galleries are plain white modern spaces. Nautical references like portholes give the feeling of a ship; visitors are never supposed to lose sight of the water.
The core of the museum is centered around five small galleries. Two are devoted to a chronological overview of the St. Ives School from 1925 to 1975, two are for special exhibitions, and a fifth is for an in-depth show on a particular artist's work or period. The current installation includes a show of paintings and drawings by Barbara Hepworth from 1948 to '49 when she worked in a local hospital. In another gallery, there are two paintings by Brian Winter, one done in St. Ives, the other in London. "No doubt Winter is a St. Ives painter," said Mr. Tooby. "But I wouldn't want to take only the St. Ives pictures."
Mr. Tooby said there were about 200 professional artists living and working in St. Ives and three serious art galleries there; a lot, given that the total population is 11,000. In the last few years the village has had its share of economic troubles, and the new museum is seen as a way of creating more local jobs as well as increasing tourism. According to a market research survey conducted by the Tate, some 75,000 people will visit the museum each year, many of whom would not make the five-hour train ride from London just for a visit to the sea. And unlike the stately homes in the area that are open only from Easter through October, the Tate St. Ives is planning to stay open all year.
 
Cooperative Effort
 The museum has been as much a community effort as a Tate production. The 16,000-square-foot building is owned by the County Council of St. Ives and leased to the Tate. Local authorities raised more than $1 million; $1.8 million in grants came from the Rural Development Commission and the European Community Regional Development Fund, and more than $1.5 million has been raised from private sources, including the Henry Moore Foundation, the Sainsbury Family Charitable Trusts and the John S. Cohen Foundation. The museum's annual operating costs will be covered by the $3.75 admissions charge and by private donations.
Mr. Serota said the time was right for such a small, specialized museum. While the institution is looking for a site in London where it will run a contemporary-art branch of the Tate, the director stressed the need for museums in more remote settings. "Culture in Britain has always been rather centralized," he said. "But patterns of communication are changing as people are beginning to travel to art centers like Liverpool and St. Ives."

HEADLINE: Green for a Greeting, Red for Rape

 BODY:
At first it seems almost funny, that the Navy has produced a one-page guide on sexual harassment that reads like a 6-year-old's reading primer. On second thought, it's no laughing matter. Maybe this equivalent of the 1992 Presidential campaign's "It's the economy, stupid" is precisely what a service so deeply steeped in sexism needs to reform its ways.
The guide, which has been sent to all commanding officers for posting on military bulletin boards, defines harassment in terms of traffic lights. "Sexual assault and rape" gets a red light. "Expressing concern or encouragement" gets a green. Behavior that falls somewhere between a casual hello and a determined grope gets a yellow. Many women would agree that "unwanted letters or poems" is properly yellow. But "sexually suggestive touching"? Surely that qualifies for red. 
 Still, the Navy deserves some credit for an earnest if awkward attempt to clarify the do's and don'ts of sexual behavior for people who seem never to have learned them -- people like some of the aviators who attended the debauch that was the Tailhook Association's 1991 convention. Such people are hardly exclusive to the Navy. They reflect the American culture out of which they come -- a culture in which sexual harassment is common and sexual braggarts like California's Spur Posse become the guests-most-wanted by the nation's talk shows.
It may be hard to believe that servicemen must be told that asking "Did you have a nice weekend?" is O.K., and "grabbing, forced kissing, fondling" is not. But experience suggests that a clear code of conduct is needed. The Navy's guide may be simplistic, but like a reading primer, it's a start.

HEADLINE: Mr. Clinton Beats the Haitians

 BODY:
The Supreme Court has upheld the Bush-Clinton policy of taking to the high seas to force fleeing Haitians to return home. In doing so, it has given the executive branch a legal victory and a moral black eye.
Revolted by episodes of forced repatriation of political refugees, the United Nations and Congress prohibited the practice -- but not, says the Court, on the high seas. Why didn't the law mention the high seas? Probably because the lawmakers "may not have contemplated that any nation would gather fleeing refugees and return them to the one country they had desperately sought to escape." 
 That reasoning is strikingly reminiscent of the Court's ruling a year ago that U.S. agents might kidnap a suspect in Mexico for trial north of the border because the extradition treaty didn't expressly forbid that evasive tactic.
These are costly victories, sustaining executive power only because the fine print hasn't covered every weaseling evasion. The moral: When dealing with the United States, don't shake hands; get it in writing. That's just what Mexico is doing now in negotiations for a respectable extradition treaty.
As a candidate, Bill Clinton denounced the Bush Administration's ocean blockade of Haitians as cruel, and agreed with lower court decisions that it was illegal as well. But as President he adopted Mr. Bush's policy, calling it a humane interim response to mass migration from Haiti's dictatorship. Then his lawyers echoed the Bush Administration's legal arguments, including the complaint that the lower courts were bothering the President in matters of foreign policy.
Justice John Paul Stevens, writing for an 8-to-1 majority, needed all the agility at his command to construe the law the President's way. The law provides plainly that aliens may not be returned to a country where the Attorney General has found a threat to their lives or freedom based on politics, as opposed to economic deprivation.
Before President Bush announced the interdiction policy, thousands of boat people had been found to be political refugees. By blocking all boat people without an asylum hearing, the Coast Guard returned them knowing that many deserved asylum.
Despite what Justice Stevens called "the moral weight" of the Haitians' argument, he found that Congress did not intend to apply the asylum law beyond the water's edge. Justice Harry Blackmun, in a lone but cogent dissent, called on the Court to apply the law's plain language to carry out its broad humanitarian purpose.
Often in history the high court has cut the President some extra slack when he must deal with an intractable international problem. The Court has done so again, but in a way that awards power without honor to the President.

HEADLINE: How Mexican Jobs Ease U.S. Burden

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Reaganomics, With a Mexican Accent," (Op-Ed, June 11), Michael Lind accuses President Clinton of confusion because he supports revitalizing the economy and the North America Free Trade Agreement, but Mr. Lind's arguments are confused. 
 "For Mr. Clinton to try to raise middle-class incomes and taxes while Mexican and other third world immigrants are depressing wages and raising the costs of law enforcement, education and welfare would be like bailing water from a leaking canoe," he says correctly.
Yet we share a huge border with Mexico and have been unsuccessful in preventing illegal immigration for decades. Surely, the best way to cut Mexican immigration is to help Mexico provide jobs at home, and the trade agreement can only help.
It may be true that under the agreement we will lose jobs to Mexico, but we will lose those jobs anyway, to China, Malaysia and Thailand. The job loss will only accelerate, whether to Mexico or Asia, if we raise the minimum wage. We will almost certainly lose fewer jobs if the trade agreement passes. It will make much more sense for a Mexican factory to get bulky raw and intermediate materials from the United States than it would for a factory in distant Thailand. Also, new jobs will be created.
Remember, there was never anything to keep American companies from building factories in Mexico to export to the United States and elsewhere. The barriers were against American companies making goods for Mexicans on either side of the border. Since the Salinas Government changed policies, United States-Mexican trade has increased, and the United States has developed a significant and growing trade surplus with Mexico, preserving some United States jobs and creating new jobs on both sides of the border. The Mexican standard of living has increased in the process.
I share Mr. Lind's concern for American workers, but surely we must care for the conditions of Mexicans as well.
 
FRANKLIN PIUCK
Bay Shore, L.I., June 16, 1993

HEADLINE: House Passes a Bill to Encourage Strikes

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"House Passes Bill to Ban Replacement of Strikers" (news article, June 16) incorrectly reports of H.R. 5: "The measure would apply only to companies where a labor group is recognized by the employer or the National Labor Relations Board as the exclusive representative of the workers in negotiations." 
 The "strike bill" continues to apply to both union and nonunion companies. In the June 15 House vote, an amendment by Representative Chet Edwards of Texas would have clarified this issue by restricting application only to union members who are
part of a "recognized or certified" bargaining unit. The Edwards amendment would have addressed business concerns about increased "recognitional strikes" by nonunion workers. Mr. Edwards's amendment was defeated, led principally by the House Democratic leadership and organized labor.
Under the House-passed bill, union members striking to press economic demands, or nonunion employees striking to force union recognition, would be permitted to shut down their employers and be guaranteed automatic reinstatement whenever they decide to return to work. Employers would be prohibited from hiring permanent replacement workers to keep the company afloat during the strike.
The bill would have an adverse effect on nonunion employers in other ways. Union strikes are not isolated events affecting only striking workers and their company. Under H.R. 5, nonunion employers would be subject to devastating economic consequences and small-business failures from increased union strikes.
The bill also creates an ideal, though unfair, union organizing tool for use against nonunion companies by guaranteeing the jobs of union members following strikes for economic demands, no matter how unreasonable. The certain result will be increased strikes, inflationary wage settlements and a chill on economic recovery.
 
HAROLD P. COXSON
Washington, June 16, 1993
The writer, a lawyer, is a spokesman for the Alliance to Keep Americans Working, the business coalition opposed to H.R. 5 and S. 55.

HEADLINE: Nurturing Technology in Ohio

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio

 BODY:
This city in the heart of the Mahoning Valley may be better known for defunct steel mills than high technology and international competitiveness. But Youngstown is home to a technology outreach office that may be the prototype for a nationwide system, if the Clinton Administration's technology policy proceeds as planned.
The Technology Development Corporation is a strange beast, organizationally. Legally, it is part of Youngstown State University and is in a Victorian-era house on its campus. But it is also one of five outreach offices across the state sponsored by the Great Lakes Manufacturing Technology Center in Cleveland. The other four are in Akron, Canton, Elyria and Toledo. 
 Officials in the outreach office, which receives funds from a variety of Federal, state and private sources, have been actively coaching a group of 10 small and midsize manufacturing companies on such matters as making sure their products will meet the European Community's stringent new quality standards.
 
Thinking Globally, Acting Locally
 And so it came to be that Henry E. Bertolini Jr. has been spending roughly equal amounts of time lately thinking about his Youngstown company's aluminum extrusion business and about the intricacies of an arcane-sounding set of international quality-control specifications known as ISO 9000. So far, only a few hundred American companies -- most of them corporate giants like Du Pont and Union Carbide -- have been certified as meeting the standards.
But working with the outreach office has persuaded Mr. Bertolini, his colleagues at General Extrusions and indeed much of the Youngstown manufacturing community that the future lies in being globally competitive.
"We did not have a quality system in place that would make us a preferred supplier in the year 2000," said Mr. Bertolini, who is engineering manager for General Extrusions, a company that uses computer-controlled heavy machinery to squeeze thick, heat-softened aluminum bars into shaped parts. "We are going to use the ISO 9000 standards as the vehicle to build that system."
The principal agent of change was Michael J. Coast, a technology transfer specialist with the four-person, nonprofit Technology Development Corporation. "We looked at plants around here and found that most of them had no quality operators and no written procedures," Mr. Coast said. "So we held meetings to explain what ISO is and why they need it."
The ISO standards, originally devised to promote trade within Europe, are a set of rules governing such things as quality standards and management procedures. ISO certification is a sort of Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval for manufacturers. In Youngstown, representatives of the 10 companies meet twice a month for workshops on how to interpret the standards and write the manuals and procedures that will be audited by the outside examiners that can confer ISO certification.
"I can draw on the expertise of the other companies and T.D.C.," Mr. Bertolini said. "They help keep us on track, which is useful because it is easy to get sidetracked on this kind of thing."
 
Technical Assistance
 The Great Lakes Manufacturing Technology Center receives Federal support through the National Institute of Standards and Technology, or NIST. The Cleveland center employs more than 60 people who operate a technology demonstration facility, where executives can test computers, software and advanced machinery before deciding what to buy.
The center also operates a teaching factory on the campus of Cleveland State University, where the next generation of manufacturing managers is being trained by making real products. And the center offers a variety of consulting services, like the outreach program in Youngstown.
Though Great Lakes is one of seven similar, federally financed regional centers around the nation, it is by most accounts the most fully developed. And NIST officials consider it a model of what the Clinton Administration's technology program should be doing throughout the country. The other regional centers are in Albany; Columbia, S.C.; Ann Arbor, Mich.; Overland Park, Kan.; Torrance, Calif, and Minneapolis.
Institutionally, NIST has a lot riding on the program's success. Currently, the agency has a budget of just $18 million a year for its seven centers. But the Administration is backing legislation that would earmark $186 million in the next fiscal year for such manufacturing technological assistance. Beyond that money, NIST is also hoping to administer another $100 million or so in Defense Department funds intended to help military contractors convert their operations to civilian products.
The House of Representatives passed legislation on May 19 authorizing the NIST spending as part of a two-year, $1.5 billion effort to improve the competitivness of American companies. Action by the Senate is expected this summer.
If passed by Congress, the spending for technological assistance would begin to help American manufacturers match their competitors in Japan and Europe, where help from the Government is a way of life. According to Philip Shapira, an associate professor at the Georgia Institute of Technology who has studied technology programs, the Japanese spend about $745 million annually supporting 170 public technology centers.
While the United States has excelled in developing new technology, he said, "U.S. companies have been rather less successful in applying and commercializing those technologies."
 
Plans for Nationwide System
 Philip Nanzetta, a mathematician who heads NIST's efforts to assist manufacturers, said a fully developed nationwide system would include about 30 large manufacturing technology centers, like the one in Cleveland, and about 100 outreach centers, like the one in Youngstown.
"I think it can be done over a four-year period," he said. "We can open four to six M.T.C.'s a year and 20 to 25 outreach centers."
This vision for a national network to systematically transfer such expertise as the ISO quality standards and other technology and management methods to small and medium-size manufacturers comes after a decade of study and experimentation, largely at the state level. In the early 1980's, as it became clear that American manufacturers were losing to overseas competitors because of higher costs and lower-quality products and services, states like Ohio, Pennsylvania and Michigan established assistance programs.
In general, the approach was to tap the technical expertise available at state universities and community colleges and find a way to apply it to smaller companies lacking the time or money to send people back to school or hire private consultants. Great Lakes was supported by Ohio's Thomas Edison technology-assistance program and private financing before adding NIST support in 1989.
Because of this local orientation, each center has adapted to the economy of its area, rather than impose a uniform model. Youngstown, for example, lays claim to being the aluminum extrusion capital of the country. Thus the outreach office here has formed an organization of extrusion companies and the tool and die makers that are their parts suppliers.
 
Simple Additions, Big Benefits
 The goal is to meet manufacturing challenges they face in common, such as predicting how dies will perform. The center also hired an engineer, Yean-Jenq Huang, to build a computer model of what actually happens in an extrusion press.
This simple addition proved beneficial.General Extrusions was making a part by ramming aluminum through a die at 24 inches a minute, which company executives believed was about the right speed. But after Dr. Huang ran some calculations through his computer model, officials realized they could increase the feed rate to 48 inches a minute, doubling the machine's capacity.
"That is what we are here to do -- take current technology and transfer it to the people who need it," Mr. Coast said. "It is no good sitting there. We have to get it out on the shop floor."
Mr. Nanzetta said the system in Ohio -- a manufacturing technology center in a major city, with satellite outreach offices in smaller cities and towns -- was the model NIST would develop throughout the nation. NIST hopes eventually to link all of the regional and satellite centers over the proposed national data highway of optical fibers that is also part of the Administration's technology vision.
Mr. Nanzetta also said that the Government's national laboratories, traditionally the province of the Defense and Energy Departments, would be pulled into the system, so equipment and technology developed for military purposes could be made available for the civilian economy.

HEADLINE: Senate Democrats Block Efforts To Alter Clinton's Budget Plan

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Friday, June 25

 BODY:
Democrats held ranks in the Senate Thursday and early today in the face of solid Republican opposition and defeated all Republican efforts to change a five-year budget package that follows President Clinton's approach in most important respects.
The measure, the subject of one of the most belligerently partisan debates of any major legislation in years, is the most crucial bill of the year to the President. 
 The next step after the Senate is a conference with the House, which passed its deficit-reduction bill last month. The final version is expected to be voted on late next month or in early August.
 
Tax on Affluent Retained
 Unlike the House, which diverged from the Clinton prescription only on the margins, the Senate version replaces the President's proposal for a broad tax on all forms of energy with a 4.3-cent-a-gallon tax on gasoline and diesel fuel. The Senate version also includes somewhat stricter limits on Medicare spending and does not have some tax breaks for small business that the President and the House favor.
But the central feature of the President's plan, a steep tax increase for the most affluent Americans, remains in the Senate proposal.
The White House strategy was to take a hands-off approach to the Senate bill, hoping to get it through the Senate bottleneck to the conference committee, where the Administration plans to participate actively in writing the final legislation.
 
Party-Line Votes
 All day Thursday and into the early morning hours today, Senators trooped into the Capitol to cast one party-line vote after another. Senators Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington, and Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, are ill and did not participate. Of the 98 remaining Senators, Democrats hold a majority of 55 to 43. They were able to win the tough votes but not by much.
First thing Thursday morning, the Senate rejected, 50 to 48, a Republican effort to block the increased gasoline tax. Five Democrats defected. Vice President Al Gore came to preside lest his vote be needed to break a tie.
In another cliffhanger, the Senate voted, 51 to 46, to kill a Republican amendment to prevent an increase in taxes on the Social Security benefits of middle- and upper-income retirees.
During the debate, the Democrats accused the Republicans of partisan tunnel vision. "If President Clinton tomorrow sent a bill up here to praise apple pie and motherhood," declared George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader, "I predict to you that the Republicans would offer an amendment that says apple pie is evil and motherhood is insidious."
But Republicans maintained that the Democrats had excluded them from drafting the bill and asserted that the Democrats should not be surprised if they voted against it.
"We were just plain left out," said John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, a senior Republican on the Finance Committee. Over the years, Senator Chafee has often found common ground with the Democrats, but not now.
At a photo session at the White House on Thursday afternoon, President Clinton said he hoped the go-it-alone partisanship would come to an end. "It's just rare in these first tough budget votes to get any votes from the other party," he said. "I hope this will never happen again."
Over all, the measure is expected to cut the deficit by nearly $350 billion over five years. An additional $100 billion is expected to be eliminated from the deficit by appropriations bills to be enacted later this year. Counting more than $50 billion in lower interest payments resulting from the smaller deficit, the total five-year deficit reduction should be slightly more than $500 billion.
This would be more or less evenly divided between tax increases and spending reductions. But most of the tax increases would be put into effect this year and next, while most of the spending cuts would not come until 1997 and 1998.
 
Tax on Wealth
 The Administration calculates that two-thirds of the tax increases in the legislation would be borne by taxpayers with annual incomes above $200,000 and that more than three-quarters would come from those with incomes above $100,000.
Families with incomes below $20,000 would end up with a tax cut. The tax increase to middle-class families would typically be no more than a few hundred dollars a year. But the additional tax to a family making $350,000 a year would average about $25,000.
As was the case in the House last month, every single Republican was against the legislation.
Most of the Democratic defectors are up for re-election next year. Among those who went with the Republicans on one vote or another, were Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey, Herb Kohl of Wisconsin, Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, Jeff Bingaman of New Mexico and Richard H. Bryan of Nevada.
"This bill is a bad deal for New Jersey," Senator Lautenberg said. "Every study I've seen indicates that New Jersey will get the short end of the stick, paying a relatively large share of the taxes collected and getting very little in return."
 
Vote at Last Moment

 The defectors tended to vary on different votes, leaving the impression that the Democratic leaders had arranged ahead of time to allow certain Senators to stray on certain votes, always retaining enough support for a majority.
Senator Lieberman, for example, joined the Republicans on the gasoline tax vote, but he did not cast his vote until the last moment when a Democratic victory was certain.
A Democratic majority for the legislation was clinched Thursday morning, when a group agreed to a compromise that would restrict the growth in Medicare spending by about $60 billion instead of the $69 billion the Finance Committee approved.
Although they lost on the crucial votes, the Republicans still had mischief up their sleeves. On the one hand, they attacked the Democrats as big spenders. On the other, the Republicans, taking advantage of arcane Senate budget rules requiring 60 votes to approve certain items, blocked Democratic measures that were intended to make it more difficult to increase spending in later years. The White House supports and the House approved the measures that were defeated.
Democrats maintained that the maneuver showed the Republicans were not genuinely concerned about lowering spending. But Senator Phil Gramm of Texas called these budget discipline measures "a teeny little fig leaf" aimed at "convincing the public that we're doing something we're just not doing."
 
Unidentified Targets
 On Wednesday night, the Senate rejected their proposal for deep but generally unspecified spending cuts without tax increases.
The opportunity to block the spending discipline measures will be available to Republicans again if the conference agreement with the House includes those provisions, and this could threaten the whole bill's prospects. Without the provision, the final bill could face trouble in the House, where the complete legislation passed by only a six-vote margin.
The debate reflected age-old differences in the philosophies of the two parties. Democrats generally favor the Government's active involvement in solving the nation's problems, a position that requires the Government to spend money raised by taxes.
Republicans would rely on the marketplace and believe higher taxes and more Government involvement merely worsens the problems.
 
Reflects 90's Politics
 But the debate also reflected the politics of the 1990's. Democrats feel they must stick together behind President Clinton to prove that when their party controls both the White House and Congress, they can get the economy and the country moving.
Republicans hope their low-taxes, small-Government approach is their passport back to the White House and to control of the Senate.
It was this partisan divide that led to the bitter debate this week.
Senator David Pryor, an Arkansas Democrat, declared: "Republicans don't really oppose taxes. They just oppose rich people paying taxes."
Senator Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming, said he was "deeply offended" by such assertions. The Democratic approach, he asserted, is "premised on the politics of envy."
"What is wrong with the people who create jobs in America?" he asked. "Why should they be singled out."

GRAPHIC: Charts: "Major Differences"
 
ENERGY TAXES
 
Senate bill increases gasoline and diesel fuel taxes. House bill has a broad tax based on energy content of fuels.
 
EARNED INCOME TAX CREDIT
 
House bill has higher increases in benefits for families with children and adds coverage for workers without children.
 
MEDICARE
 
The Senate bill cuts $17 billion more in payments to providers.
 
(pg. A1)
 
"Highlights of the House and Senate Budget Bills"
 
Both the House and Senate versions of the budget packages reduce the deficit by an estimated $500 billion over five years. Many of the provisions in the two bills are identical and cannot be altered by the conference committee. Other provisions differ sharply in the two bills and will have to be negotiated. The committee is not bound by either version on contested provisions.
 
REVENUES AND TAX PROVISIONS
 
INDIVIDUAL TAX RATES
 
House Version: Raises $115 billion byincreasing the top rates to 36 percent for couples earning more than $140,000 and singles earning more then $115,000; a 10 percent surcharge on those earning more than $250,000 would raise their top rates to 39.7 percent. The changes take effect Jan. 1.
 
Senate version: raises $107 billion by increasing the tax rates, but making only half the increase apply in 1993, with the full increase taking effect in 1994.
 
CAPITAL GAINS
 
House version: Retains top capital gains tax rate of 28 percent, and does not applysurtax for wealthy taxpayers.
 
Senate version: Aplies 10 percent surtax to capital gains tax paid by those earning more than $250,000, raising $600 million.
 
SOCIAL SECURITY
 
House version: Taxes 85 percent of Social Security benefits for couples earning more then $32,000 and singles making more than $25,000 (up from 50 percent now), raising $32 billion.
 
Senate version: Creates two tiers of taxation for Social Security benefits. Those earning mroe than $32,000 ($25,000 for singles) would continue to pay tax on 50 percent of benefits, while those making mroe than $40,000 ($32,000 for singles) would pay tax on up to 85 percent of the benefits, raising $26 billion.
 
ENERGY TAXES
 
House version: Imposes broad based energy tax (B.T.U. tax) and inland waterway tax increase, raising $72 billion.
 
Senate version: Increases gasoline and diesel fuel taxes by 4.3 cents a gallon; does not increase waterway tax. Raises $22.7 billion.
 
EARNED INCOME TAX CREDIT
 
House version: Increased benefits for families with children, and adds coverage for workers without children, costing $28 billion.
 
Senate version: Increases benefits, but not as much as the House bill. Does not cover workers without children. Costs $18 billion.
 
CORPORATE TAX RATE
 
House version: Raises $16 billion by raising tax rate from 34 percent to 35 percent for corporations earning more than $10 million.
 
Senate version: Same as House.
 
SMALL BUSINESSES
 
House version: Raises the amount of capital spending that a company can write off in a single eyar to $25,000, costing $8 billion. Provided a 50-percent exclusion from tax for capital gains earned by stockholders in certain new small businesses, costing $900 million.
 
Senate version: Raises the limit on capital spending write off froom $10,000 to $20,500 costing $6.5 billion; does not provide the tax break for capital gains.
 
URBAN AID
 
House version: Creates empowerment zones and enterprise communites in which businesses would get special tax incentives to spur job creation in poorer neighborhoods, costing $5.3 billion.
 
Senate version: No provision.
 
SPENDING
 
MEDICARE
 
House version: rEduces payments to hosptials, doctors and others, saving $50 billion.
 
Senate version: Makes deeper cuts in payments to providers, saving $67 billion.
 
MEDICAID
 
House version: Reduces Medicaid, but increases child immunization by $2.1 billion, and adds money for tuberculosis, undocumented workers and other purposes. Net savings of $6 billion.
 
Senate version: reduces Medicaid, but excludes most increases provided by House, whild providing $1.5 billion for child immunization. Net savings of $8 billion.
 
FOOD STAMPS
 
House version: Eases eligibility rules for low-income high school students, the working poor, homeless families and others, and raises the basid benefit levels, costing $7 billion.
 
Senate version: No provision.
 
FAMILY PRESERVATION
 
House version: Provides new assistance for families at risk of having children removed from the home, costing $1 billion.
 
Senate version: No provision.
 
FEDERAL PRESERVATION
 
House version: Ends lump-sum retirement distributions, reduces cost of living increases for military and civilian retirees, saving $12 bilion.
 
Senate version: Same as House.
 
FEDERAL PAY
 
House version: Includes changes to reduce civilian and military payrolls, accounting for $50 billion of spending cuts.
 
Senate version: Does not include changes in pay and personnel levels in the package.
 
(pg. A18)

HEADLINE: SPECTER OF TERROR: The Links;
Suspect in Bomb Plot Linked To World Trade Center Blast

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

 BODY:
Siddig Ibrahim Siddig Ali, the 32-year-old Sudanese immigrant whom Federal authorities have placed at the center of a conspiracy to bomb the United Nations and other targets in New York City, confided to an F.B.I. informer that he had helped test the bomb for the World Trade Center blast in February, according to Federal officials.
That explosion, Mr. Siddig Ali was quoted in a Federal complaint as saying, was a message that "we can get you anytime." 
 Another suspect, Clement Rodney Hampton-El, described by the authorities as the leader of a violent faction of militant Muslims in Brooklyn, also told the informer that he too had participated in the preparations for the trade center explosion.
The statements were some of the many links that emerged yesterday between the latest eight suspects, the trade center defendants, the man charged with the 1990 killing of Rabbi Meir Kahane and Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, the Islamic fundamentalist cleric. Mr. Abdel Rahman, whose Jersey City apartment was searched for several hours yesterday, said last night that Mr. Siddig Ali had been his interpreter for the last six months.
 
'Beyond a Single Terror Cell'
 How close and substantive the links between the two bomb plots and the many Islamic figures would turn out to be remained unclear last night. But senior officials in the Clinton Administration said the latest arrests gave a new and broader dimension to what had until now been regarded as a narrow plot aimed at the World Trade Center.
"What this certainly shows is that the conspiracy in New York went beyond a single terror cell," said one Administration official.
Both the group of men arrested yesterday and the trade center suspects were assembling similar bombs, mainly composed of fertilizer, Federal officials said. The two groups also had a shared world of common associates, religious beliefs and causes.
A senior law-enforcement official said the conspirators were apparently planning to carry out the bombings on or near the Fourth of July as revenge for the upcoming trial of the trade center suspects.
Law-enforcement officials said several of the latest suspects were close to Mr. Abdel Rahman, a blind, self-exiled Egyptian who calls for the overthrow of that country's secular government.
Mr. Abdel Rahman had emerged before as a tantalizing figure to law-enforcement authorities. His militant preachings attracted some of the trade center defendants as well as El-Sayyid A. Nosair, an Egyptian who was convicted on lesser charges related to the Kahane killing. But the authorities had never called him a suspect or even questioned him.
 
Apartment Searched
 For the first time yesterday, however, Federal agents searched his spare Jersey City apartment on Fairview Avenue, using the sheik's connection to Mr. Siddig Ali and other reported conspirators to obtain a search warrant. "I know that some of these individuals know him and they've allegedly met in various functions in the past," said James Esposito, the head of the F.B.I. in Newark. "The depth of that relationship I wouldn't comment on any further."
At a news conference announcing the arrests of the eight men, James M. Fox, the head of the New York office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said that "at this time, we have no plans to arrest the sheik." But hours later, after the search of the sheik's apartment, a senior law-enforcement official said that "significant documents" were found and that Attorney General Janet Reno would have to make the decision about how agents would proceed with the cleric. The official did not elaborate.
 
Forced Their Way In
 Mr. Abdel Rahman said at a news conference last night that the agents broke down his door, and later told him they had seized papers, books and tapes. "I did not do anything to break American law," the Egyptian insisted, speaking through a new interprter who kept a cloth over his head to hide his features. "I have absolutely nothing to do with what happened," Mr. Abdel Rahman said.
Of Mr. Siddig Ali, Mr. Abdel Rahman said, "I don't know anything about him, but he's a fine young man."
Religion appeared to be one of the closest ties between the eight men -- five of them from the Sudan -- who were arrested in the raids.
A senior law-enforcement official said the group was essentially made up of two factions: five of the men who were arrested in Queens, headed by Mr. Siddig Ali, and three others headed by Mr. Hampton-El. The official said that Mr. Hampton-El, who was said to have been planning assassination attempts, was believed to be the leader of a particularly violent Muslim faction in Brooklyn that is suspected of several killings over the last year.
Six of the men, including Mr. Siddig Ali, worshiped at the Al-Salam mosque in Jersey City, where Mr. Abdel Rahman preached his incendiary brand of Islamic fundamentalism. Several of the Middle Eastern immigrants charged in the trade center explosion had also worshiped there.
 
'Religious Activist'
 "Most of the time they come here," said a member of the walk-up mosque who refused to give his name. "They sit together once a week in one of the houses belonging to one of them and they recite the Koran. But there's never any political involvement."
But he singled out Mr. Siddig Ali, an unemployed immigrant, as a "religious acitivist who's outspoken." It was Mr. Siddig Ali, fluent in both English and Arabic, who had acted as a translator for Ronald L. Kuby, a lawyer who had visited the Al-Salam mosque in April to lecture the Muslims on their rights and responsibilities when approached by the F.B.I. "He introduced himself and said he would be translating for me," said Mr. Kuby, a law partner of William M. Kunstler.
Mr. Kunstler, who represented Mr. Siddig Ali at a hearing yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan, said the Sudanese immigrant had also been a constant presence at the trial of Mr. Nosair. And law-enforcement officials said that several of the men arrested had connections to Mr. Nosair.
Most recently, the six men who attended the al-Salam mosque had taken up the cause of the World Trade Center suspects, trying to collect money for them, according to the member of the mosque. And a senior law-enforcement official said the motive behind the other bombing scheme was revenge for the trial of the trade center suspects, now scheduled for September.

HEADLINE: Yale Professor Is Injured by Blast; Mail Bomb Tied to Terror in 70's

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON

 BODY:
A prominent computer science professor at Yale University was critically injured yesterday by a mail bomb that Federal officials said marked the re-emergence of a mysterious bomber who terrorized campuses and high- technology companies around the country in the 1970's and 80's.
The package exploded shortly after 8 A.M. at the computer science center at Yale in New Haven. The authorities said they believed it had come from the same person who sent a bomb to a professor at the University of California at San Francisco on Tuesday and who has sent 12 other similar packages since 1978.
 
A Group Called 'FC'
 Scores of law-enforcement officials have tried for years to track down the bomber, whom they called Unibom, for University Bomber. The authorities have never been able to establish a motive or precise pattern to the bombings, but officials said yesterday that the bomber's distinct signature was clear from the material used to make the bombs. They also made the connection to the earlier incidents from a letter received yesterday by The New York Times. 
 The letter, which was postmarked June 21 from Sacramento, Calif., warns of "a newsworthy event" and identifies its author as "a group calling ourselves FC." It promises to "give information about our goal at some future time." The authorities said the bomber had previously identified himself as FC.
William S. Sessions, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said this evening that the agency had sent a message by computer network to most universities to be on the alert for suspicious packages. At a news conference in San Francisco, Mr. Sessions said professors should be particularly cautious about any packages with excessive postage, incorrect titles, misspellings of common words or no return address.
The bomb yesterday went off in the hands of David Gelernter, the 38-year-old director of undergraduate studies in computer science at Yale. Moments after the bomb exploded, ripping off his shirt, he ran from his fifth-floor office at Yale's computer science center building to a health clinic a block away, leaving a trail of blood. Witnesses said they could hear the explosion throughout the building.
 
Professor Undergoes Surgery
 Professor Gelernter's condition was upgraded from critical to serious yesterday afternoon after surgery at the Yale-New Haven Hospital. He suffered severe wounds to his abdomen, chest, face and hands.
Mr. Gelernter, who had studied to become a rabbi, is best known for inventing an innovative computer programming language he named Linda, after the pornography star Linda Lovelace. It has attracted a wide following in both the scientific world and for its commercial applications in publishing and computer animation. He has also expressed a strong commitment to applying computer technology to a wide array of social and economic problems.
Officials said that after the bombing, the switchboard at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center in West Haven received a call from someone who said, "You are next."
Professor Gelernter's brother, Joel, an assistant professor of psychiatry at the Yale Medical School, works at the medical center, but Assistant Chief Dean Eserman of the New Haven police said the authorities did not know if the bombing and the phone threat were related.
Joel Gelernter is also a specialist in genetics, and last night the authorities said they did not know if threats to him were also connected to Tuesday's bombing in California, whose victim was a geneticist.
That victim was Charles Epstein, who lost several fingers and suffered a broken arm and severe abdominal injures when he opened a padded brown envelope at his home in Tiburon, near San Francisco. Dr. Epstein, 59, continued recuperating yesterday. He is widely known for his research into Down syndrome and other genetic conditions and heads the university' division of medical genetics.
 
String Dating to 1978
 Law-enforcement officials said yesterday that they believed the mail bombs were the latest in a series of deadly parcels that have been mailed or placed by the bomber since May 26, 1978. The bombs have injured 21 people and killed one, Campbell Scrutton, the owner of a Sacramento computer shop, on Dec. 11, 1985.
While the bombs apparently have been sent mostly to people who workedextensively with computers and in high-tech fields, investigators have been at a loss to establish a more concrete pattern and motive. Some of the packages were addressed to a particular person, but others were left in parking lots or on doorsteps. The bomber has occasionally sent letters advising intended victims that packages would soon be arriving.
Three Federal agencies and scores of local law-enforcement officials have spent years trying to track down the bomber, who is also believed to have been behind bombings at universities in California, Illinois, Michigan, Tennessee and Utah. In 1980, he sent a bomb to the Lake Forest, Ill., home of Percy A. Wood, president of United Airlines, cutting and burning his hands and face. The bomb was planted inside a novel, "Ice Breakers."
 
Wide-Ranging Inquiry
 The bomber also mailed an explosive device in 1985 to the Boeing Aircraft Company plant in Auburn, Wash. It did not injure anyone.
The authorities say the bombs have become progressively more complex over the years and they tend to be meticulously constructed of common materials like fishing line, string, nails and wrapping paper. The shards in each explosion have been similar enough to lead investigators to conclude that they came from the same person.
In an attempt to crack the case, the authorities have held conferences over the years about the bomber and have combed through thousands of names supplied by victims. The case has been jointly handled by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms; the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and the United States Postal Service.
Officials say the biggest break in the long-running investigation came on Feb. 20, 1987, when the bomber placed his 12th bomb, the last once before this week. It was in a burlap bag in a parking lot of CAAMS Inc., a computer sales and service company in Salt Lake City. When Gary Wright, an employee of CAAMS, tried to move it, it exploded and he received fragmentation wounds to his leg, hand, arms, throat and face.
But before the bomb went off, the authorities say a witness observed a white man putting the device between two parked cars. He was described at the time as between 25 and 30 years old, around 5 feet 10 inches to 6 feet tall, and weighing 165 pounds, with reddish-blond hair, a thin mustache and a ruddy complexion.
The authorities say the bomber's first attack, in 1978, was in a technology building at Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill. A security guard was injured in that incident. A year later, a graduate student at Northwestern's Chicago campus was burned when he opened a cigar box containing an explosive device.
On Nov. 15, 1985, a bomb exploded at the Ann Arbor home of James McConnell, a psychology professor at the University of Michigan. The blast injured a research assistant who opened the textbook-sized package. The parcel was addressed to Professor McConnell and was postmarked in Salt Lake City.
Altogether, 12 of 14 bombs that the authorities say were sent by the bomber have exploded and in all but one of those instances someone has been hurt. The most damaging explosion occurred on an American Airlines flight from Chicago to Washington in November 1979, when a bomb exploded in the airplane's cargo section. The plane made an emergency landing and 12 passengers suffered smoke inhalation.
The letter sent to The Times, which investigators say came from the bomber, said:
"We are an anarchist group calling ourselves FC. Notice that the postmark on this envelope precedes a newsworthy event that will happen about the time you receive this letter, if nothing goes wrong. This will prove that we knew about the event in advance, so our claim of responsibility is truthful. Ask the FBI about FC. They have heard of us. We will give information about our goals at some future time. Right now we only want to establish our identity and provide an identifying number that will ensure the authenticity of any future communications from us. Keep this number secret so that no one else can pretend to speak in our name."
It then gives a nine-digit number.
There was a feeling of nervousness at Yale yesterday as postal workers on the campus and in New Haven checked for suspicious packages. The newly named president of the university, Richard C. Levin, met with faculty members to reassure them about security.
"There is concern on campus," said Sheila Wellington, secretary of Yale University. "But there does not appear to be fear. There is nothing approaching a crisis circumstance."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Senate Democrats held ranks in the face of solid Republican opposition and defeated all efforts to change a five-year budget package that closely follows President Clinton's plan. [Page A1.]
A day after the House decided to continue the space station, it voted overwhelmingly to halt construction on the $11 billion Superconducting Supercollider. [A18.] 
 A Presidential commission voted to create a major staging base at McGuire Air Force Base in New Jersey and close Plattsburgh Air Force Base in New York. McGuire will gain more than 2,500 jobs at Plattsburgh's expense. [A12.]
 
International
Ministers from the leading industrial nations meeting in Tokyo failed to agree on liberalizing trade, setting back hopes for a comprehensive global accord this year. [D1.]
The Administration and many economists are confident that the yen's recent advances will successfully cut Japan's bulging trade surplus. Economic Analysis. [D1.]
Germany canceled a major meeting with the French after Paris's Economy Minister suggested that it might lead to lower European interest rates. [D2.]
Facing the most bitterly contested elections in decades, Japan's Liberal Democratic Party is apparently turning to banks and businesses for financing. [A6.]
 
Companies
The parent of Northwest Airlines will consider filing for bankruptcy if the Air Line Pilots Association rejects the terms of a final proposal. [D1.]
Hoping to bolster its Smith Barney Shearson brokerage with strength in investment banking, Primerica hired the former president of Morgan Stanley to run the firm. [D1.]
Procter & Gamble is expected to act on a strategy that could eliminate thousands of jobs, but the exact number is unclear. [D1.]

Markets
The major stock indexes were swept higher, helped by program buying and gains in bond prices. The Dow industrials gained 23.80 points, to 3,490.61. [D4.]
Bond yields declined, putting the 30-year Treasury issue's yield within striking distance of a 20-year low. [D12.]
The dollar resumed its rally against the German mark. [D14.] Gold futures prices edged higher. [D14.]

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Jump by 8,000

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing first-time claims for unemployment benefits jumped by 8,000 last week, to the highest level in nine weeks, the Government said today.
The Labor Department said new applications for unemployment insurance totaled 353,000, up from a revised 345,000 for the week that ended on June 12. Claims for the previous week were originally estimated to be 344,000. 
 It was the largest increase since 9,000 new claims were filed for the week that ended on May 29. It raised the total to the highest level since 356,000 claims were filed in the week ended April 17.
Many economists had predicted before the report that claims would edge up by just 1,000.
The less-volatile four-week moving average of jobless claims, which analysts prefer to track because it more accurately reflects the labor situation, rose 3,750, to the highest level in two months.
