HEADLINE: Economic Analysis;
Yen Strategy: What the U.S. Is Expecting

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- When the Japanese yen soared against the dollar in the mid-1980's, it put only a minor dent in Japan's huge trade surplus with the United States.
But the Clinton Administration -- and many economists -- are confident that this time the yen's recent rise will prove far more successful in cutting Japan's bulging trade surplus. 
 To chop away at Japan's surplus, the Administration has embraced a three-part approach that includes not only a strong yen but also wiping away trade barriers and pushing Japan to stimulate its economy and consumption. Administration officials say it is important for all three parts to work together, although they acknowledge that Japan's political crisis could weaken the yen and might make it harder to persuade Tokyo to take further steps to reduce the surplus.
Although the Administration denies that it has deliberately sought to push up the Japanese currency, the yen, egged on by comments from Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and others, has soared almost 14 percent against the dollar, from 126 yen to the dollar early this year to 108.70 yen in New York today. [Page D14.]
Administration officials and many economists point to several reasons why the strong yen should push the America's $50 billion trade deficit with Japan down more rapidly than in the past.
Japanese companies, plagued by recession at home, now often have razor-thin profit margins, so when the yen rises, they feel immense pressure to pass that on quickly by raising their prices. An example: Japanese car makers have raised the sticker price on their exports to America by about 10 percent in slightly more than a year.
By contrast, in 1985, Japanese companies, helped by thriving sales at home, swallowed -- and were able to swallow -- much of the currency swing in order to hold on to market share.
"The effects of the exchange-rate changes will be quicker than before because Japanese companies are not in a position to absorb the exchange-rate change," said Barry P. Bosworth, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.
 
Other Reasons Cited
 Another reason why a faster reaction is expected this time is that American companies are more competitive now, giving American consumers less incentive to buy Japanese, no matter what the price. Probably the best evidence of this is the resurgence of American auto makers, chip manufacturers, and laptop computer makers -- all of whom have gobbled up some Japanese market share this year.
And Japan is in a slump, so when its economy snaps back, Japanese consumers and companies will have more money to spend, and as a result will buy more imported goods. Thus Japan's recovery should naturally make a dent in the trade surplus.
C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington, argues that the stronger yen will cut Japan's surplus in another way: Since a mighty yen will slow Japan's economic growth by hurting its exports, "the stronger yen substantially increases pressure on the Japanese Government to do a large, new economic stimulus package."
Under intense pressure from Washington, Japan has announced a $116 billion stimulus package, its second since last summer, to help end its worst slump in two decades. But Mr. Bergsten says the stronger yen keeps the heat on Tokyo to offer yet another stimulus program. That would certainly further the Clinton Administration's goal of getting Japan's economy to grow through domestic consumption rather than exports.
 
Cutting Japan's Surplus
 William R. Cline, an economist at the Institute for International Economics, estimates that every 1 percentage point increase in the yen against all currencies will reduce Japan's surplus with the rest of the world -- expected to be $150 billion this year -- by $3 billion to $4 billion, but with a two-year lag.
Several economists estimate theat the yen's rise against most major currencies this year should ultimately cut Japan's worldwide trade surplus by at least $40 billion. Mr. Bergsten says the yen needs to rise to about 100 yen to the dollar to achieve the Clinton Administration's goal of cutting Japan's worldwide surplus in half as a percentage of gross domestic product.
After the yen soared against the dollar and many other currencies between 1985 and 1988, its global surplus dropped to 1.2 percent of its gross domestic product in 1990 from 4 percent in 1986. But Japan's surplus has soared back to 3.5 percent of gross domestic product because the yen weakened considerably against most major currencies from 1988 to 1991, helping make Japanese goods more attractive. Not surprisingly, Japanese exports rose so that by last month Japan's trade surplus with the United States reached its highest level in five-and-a-half years.
According to Mr. Cline's calculations, every 1 percent increase in the yen against the dollar should, within two years, cut Japan's trade surplus with the United States by about $1 billion from what it would otherwise be. Japan's stimulus program and President Clinton's campaign to topple Japanese trade barriers are expected to reduce it even more. In a new book, Mr. Bergsten and Marcus Noland, a Johns Hopkins economist, estimate that American companies would export $9 billion to $18 billion more a year to Japan if Tokyo removed all trade barriers.
Still, a minority of economists say all this talk about a sharp drop in America's trade deficit is wishful thinking. Some economists and Federal Reserve officials are dubious that the stronger yen will push down Japan's surplus, when the dollar's 50 percent plunge against the yen from 1985 to 1988 cut Japan's annual surplus with the United States by just $15 billion, leaving it well above $40 billion. And they worry that the stronger yen, by making Japanese goods more expensive for Americans, will push up inflation.
"If Detroit wasn't able to sell autos at 240 or 125 yen to the dollar, then 110 yen to the dollar isn't going to make a difference," said Scott Pardee, a former Federal Reserve official and chairman of Yamaichi International America, a Japanese brokerage house.
And David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International in New York, said, "The rise of the yen will reduce Japan's surplus probably a lot less than many economic models would predict,"
One hurdle to a lower deficit, he said, is that the mix of products that American companies make is not so attractive to the Japanese, while the goods Japanese companies make are highly attractive to Americans.
Then, there is another problem. The yen's rise makes it cheaper for Japanese companies to move production to low-wage locales, like Taiwan or Thailand, whose currencies are closely tied to the dollar. Thus, while America's trade deficit with Japan may fall, its deficit with the smaller Asian tigers may soar, fueled by Japanese investment there. The upshot: the jobs the United States loses to Japan today may be lost to other Asian countries tomorrow.
If the Japanese are unhappy with the strong yen, then they have an easy way to push it back down, says Stanley Fischer, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. All they have to do is reduce their trade barriers, making it easier for American companies to export. Then, Mr. Fischer said, financial markets would feel less need to push up the yen to chop away at Japan's trade surplus.
This gives the Japanese a choice that Clinton Administration officials love: accept a strong yen or sweep away some trade barriers.

HEADLINE: In Sarajevo, Silence Turns to Despair

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzego vina, June 24

 BODY:
While the Serbian guns that have blasted this city for more than a year have quieted, news reports about a peace plan that would partition Bosnia and Herzegovina have plunged many here into despair.
"Bosnia's partition is only a matter of days away," said Mustafa Spahic, a Muslim cleric, referring to the proposal by the Serbian and Croatian presidents, Slobodan Milosevic and Franjo Tudjman, to divide this country into Serbian, Croatian and Muslim territories. 
 Many of the Muslims in Sarajevo are convinced that the partition plan will lead to the annexation of the Serbian and Croatian states in Bosnia by Belgrade and Zagreb, leaving a landlocked Muslim state overflowing with refugees.
The plan, advanced last week at peace talks in Geneva, was received positively by Lord Owen, co-author of the international peace plan for Bosnia. He said that the Bosnian Muslims could expect no better deal, and President Clinton said he would welcome the plan if all sides agreed to it.
 
Consistently Opposed
 Bosnia's Muslim President, Alija Izetbegovic, has consistently opposed partition, arguing that it rewards Serbian and Croatian aggression against an internationally recognized republic and the forcible uprooting of minority populations.
But Mr. Izetbegovic and Bosnia's Vice President, Ejup Ganic, the two most influential Muslims in the Government, were outvoted by the rest of Bosnia's ten-member collective leadership. As a result, a Serbian- and Croatian-dominated delegation is in Geneva, discussing the partition plan on behalf of a Government whose supporters are mostly Muslim.
After a year of hardship and military setbacks, the split in the collective leadership has further strained the Bosnian Government ideal of a multi-ethnic Bosnian state and has raised Muslim concerns that their interests may be trampled by their own representatives in Geneva.
"We are not deciding our own fate, and those who have taken it upon themselves to decide it are biased against us," said Sheik Mustafa Ceric, the top Islamic official in Sarajevo.
"If Christians were being massacred in any Islamic country like the Muslims are being killed here," Sheik Ceric said, "the world community would have quickly found the means to condemn the Muslims as fundamentalists, and fighters of a holy war, and things would be taken care of overnight. A Muslim's life is now worth the least on the world market."
"Bosnia's Muslims are the new Jews of Europe," said Mr. Spahic, the Muslim cleric. "But we have no America to lean on. We have no one to lean on."
Mr. Spahic said that the small Muslim country foreshadowed by the partition would lack any economic prospects. "Bosnia's Muslims will be scattered like fallen leaves in autumn," he said. "Everyone will eventually leave except the few who will survive in a kind of reservation, chopping wood and working in gardens.
"This is the first genocide to be committed under the protection of the United Nations," Mr. Spahic said. "This is the first world-class crime to be carried out like a football game before the eyes of the entire world on television. And it has not helped at all.
"The Serbs are doing the dirty work of dealing with Bosnia's Muslims for all of Europe," he said.
 
Editor Speaks Out
 Kemal Kurspahic, the editor of Oslobodjenje, Sarajevo's daily newspaper, said the West's failure to intervene had disappointed Muslims.
"Right when we thought the West was thinking seriously about taking decisive action, our hopes have been dashed," he said. "Nothing has taken its place except the concept of safe areas, which is not only recognition of Serbian conquest but also capitulation by the West.
"As a consequence," the editor said, "there will be a new cycle of violence and ethnic cleansing, because exclusively Croatian and Muslim states in Bosnia and Herzegovina cannot be created without ethnic cleansing like that which we have seen in Serb areas so far.
"The international community had three reasons to intervene in Bosnia," Mr. Kurspahic said. "First, there was a moral imperative raised by the genocide, the concentration camps, the rape, the mass murder. Second came the 'new world order.' If a new world order exists, then the West had to act. If not, then the West must stop claiming to act as a defender of human rights. Third, a failure to intervene has given a signal to other potential aggressors."
"By all measures of human suffering, there were more reasons to intervene in Bosnia in '92 than in Kuwait in '91," he said.
"We've never asked anyone to come here and fight for us," Sheik Ceric said. "We will fight to the last drop of our blood, but we do not want our hands to be tied."
 
Balkan Update
 In GENEVA, 7 members of the Bosnian Government's 10-member collective leadership declared yesterday that they constituted the country's legitimate Government.
In VIENNA, the human rights conference rejected a Serbian-Croatian peace plan that would partition Bosnia and called for the lifting of the arms embargo against Bosnian Muslim forces. The UNITED STATES and most of the countries in EUROPE abstained in a vote of 88 in favor, with only RUSSIA voting against and 54 nations abstaining.
In SARAJEVO, Gen. Philippe Morillon of FRANCE, commander of the peacekeeping force in BOSNIA for more than 16 months, confirmed that he would soon end his assignment.

HEADLINE: Big Powers' Free-Trade Talks Stall

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 24

 BODY:
The leading industrial nations failed today to agree on how to liberalize trade, dealing a setback to hopes of successfully completing negotiations for a comprehensive global accord late in the year.
Trade ministers from the United States, Canada, Japan and the European Community had hoped to forge an ambitious agreement in a two-day session here that would reduce tariffs and other barriers on hundreds of products, with the intention of announcing the accord at the economic summit meeting here next month of the Group of Seven industrial nations. 
 That agreement would then have been presented to the rest of the world as a basis on which to revive the worldwide talks under the aegis of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
 
Plans Fall Apart
 But after what was described as an intense meeting marked by sharp disputes, the trade ministers remained far apart in several significant areas.
"There is a considerable amount of work still to be done between now and the G-7," Sir Leon Brittan, the European Community's Commissioner for External Economic Relations, said at a news conference after the meeting.
The biggest disagreements seemed to have been between the United States and Europe over American barriers on textiles and shipping, and European restrictions on foreign television programming and electronics.
"An outside observer could have sat in that meeting for half an hour and come to the conclusion that this was a hopeless situation," said a senior American official who spoke on the condition of anonymity. But then, heated disputes were to be expected as the negotiations came down to the most contentious items, he remarked.
 
The Rhythm of Negotiations
 The trade ministers said they still thought an agreement could be reached by the summit meeting, which starts on July 7.
"I have never been in a negotiation that ended before it had to," said Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative. "I don't believe it's either surprising or disturbing that we did not reach a full agreement here."
But privately, some officials said it would be difficult to develop as far-reaching a package of market-access measures as they had anticipated. And without a broad package, it will be hard to coax the 100 or so other members of GATT to complete the seven-year-long "Uruguay round" talks by the end of the year.
The negotiations are going on at a time when much of the world remains mired in recession and pressure for protecting markets seems to be growing. Many economists believe that a successful conclusion to the talks is necessary to kindle economic growth.
The mood at the meetings on Wednesday and today was in contrast to optimism expressed after similar talks in Paris at the beginning of the month.
The ministers agreed not to talk publicly about the specifics of this week's negotiations. But some officials said the biggest flare-up came over textiles.
The European Community has been asking the United States to cut tariffs that in some cases exceed 30 percent on fabric and finished clothing. It argues that such duties deter European exports of wool suits and knitted goods and also hurt the economies of poorer countries, some of which depend on textile exports.
The United States maintains that it is already a big textile importer, and that other GATT proposals already contain sufficient liberalization of textile trade.
The Europeans then began to pull back on offers to reduce barriers in some other areas. "That led the meetings downward to a much lower level of ambition," a European official said. But then "we realized we were looking at a much smaller package than anyone wanted," he added, and "we had a radical rethinking overnight."
 
An Interim Recovery
 In the morning, the trade ministers ushered their aides out of the room and met themselves for two and a half hours. "We brought it back from the really low point," the official said.
Big disagreements remain on other fronts. The Europeans want the United States to loosen restrictions on foreign shipping lines. The United States and Japan want Europe to lower tariffs on computer semiconductors and consumer electronics. They are also asking the Europeans to lighten their limits on foreign television programs, something that France in particular says it needs to preserve its cultural identity.
Japan, which has the world's largest trade surplus, has not offered what others view as acceptable proposals for reducing its tariffs on wood and wood products, liquor, leather goods and processed food. The Japanese did win plaudits with some concessions on financial services, agreeing to make it easier for foreign investment advisers to manage Japanese pension funds.
In an effort to secure agreement, the trade ministers have decided to meet in Tokyo on July 6, the day before the summit meeting opens, to complete a report to be presented to the top leaders. Until then, lower-ranking officials will meet intensively in an effort to resolve differences.

HEADLINE: Virginia Voters to Referee Feud of Robb and Wilder

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
Taking one of the nation's nastiest political feuds to the voters, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia announced today that he would oppose Senator Charles S. Robb for the Democratic Senate nomination next year.
Mr. Wilder's candidacy is certain to add fuel to a long-running, highly public battle between the state's two leading Democrats and draw further attention to a Senate race in which Oliver L. North, who became a national figure virtually overnight as a result of the Iran-contra affair, is expected to seek the Republican nomination. 
 Mr. Wilder, who announced his "clear and pretty unequivocal" intentions at the taping here today of "Lead Story," a program on the Black Entertainment Television cable network, wasted no time in assailing Mr. Robb.Although he never uttered the Senator's name, he was clearly referring to Mr. Robb when he said that "character has to be part of" the campaign.
 
Dispute Over Eavesdropping
 Both men have suffered politically for their roles in one of the most drawn- out brawls in American politics. In one of their most recent disputes, Mr. Robb was accused of being involved in an eavesdropping plot against Mr. Wilder. Although official investigations cleared the Senator himself, three of his aides were convicted of distributing an illegally recorded tape in which Mr. Wilder discussed the antagonism between himself and the Senator.
The Governor has also come under attack for his role in the feud and once was led to apologize for "misleading" the press and the public about whether he had ordered a police investigation into reports that Robb aides had threatened people who were telling reporters about rumors of drug use and womanizing by the Senator.
"There's no question but that Wilder's primary motivation is to insure that Chuck Robb should not be re-elected," Thomas R. Morris, the president of Emory & Henry College in southwestern Virginia, said of Mr. Wilder's announcement today. "It will be a difficult task for him to deny the nomination to the incumbent, even though Robb is politically damaged goods."
 
'Virginia Needs Better'
 Mr. Wilder said repeatedly today that he could not cite accomplishments by Mr. Robb after more than four years in the Senate. "Name three things he has done," the Governor said. "I don't know of any. Virginia needs better than that."
Declining to respond directly to the challenge, Mr. Robb issued a statement suggesting that discussion of next year's campaign was premature.
"The 1994 Senate race will be here soon enough," he said. "Until then, we owe it to our state and party to keep our focus on the upcoming race for governor, lieutenant governor and attorney general. In the interim, we need to concentrate on deficit reduction, health care reform, defense down-sizing and creating enough jobs to reinvigorate our economy."
Mr. Wilder, whose term as Governor ends in January and who by law cannot run for a second consecutive term, had hinted for months about seeking Mr. Robb's seat. But his announcement today left some Democrats fretting that he would divide the party and risk the loss of that seat to the Republicans.
Recent polls have given Mr. Robb an edge over Mr. Wilder in a one-on-one matchup. But the Governor, whose popularity in Virginia has not fully recovered from his short-lived bid for the 1992 Democratic Presidential nomination, said he was confident that he could overtake Mr. Robb once a campaign begins.
 
Share Many Views
 Since the Governor and the Senator are both fiscal conservatives and share views on many issues, a number of analysts suggested that Mr. Wilder was being driven largely by a desire to strike out at his archrival.
Virginia Republicans said Mr. Wilder's decision would only help their party's nominee -- in all likelihood Mr. North, who has not yet announced his candidacy but has been traversing the state as if his campaign were already in full gear.
"I take some delight in their party's anguish," said Patrick M. McSweeney, the Republican state chairman. "There's no question that Doug Wilder's got a cast-iron stomach. He's one of the toughest campaigners I've ever seen. But because they share the same base, I can't see how this is going to do anything but tear them apart."
Many leading Democrats had urged Mr. Wilder not to run. And because of his limited support from them, there had been speculation that he would run as an independent, siphoning votes from both Mr. Robb and Mr. North.
But Mr. Wilder said today that he intended to run as a Democrat, telling reporters that "I have always felt that the Democratic Party was big enough" for both him and Mr. Robb. He disputed that he would be handing the election to Mr. North by dividing the vote with Mr. Robb, saying, "There are any number of voters who might not be enamored of Mr. North or the Senator."
Perhaps the most important question in the political equation for Mr. Wilder is how much loyalty he will retain from his base of black voters. In making his announcement on a black cable network program, which will be televised Sunday, he seemed to be seeking to shore up that support.
The Governor said he had used the program as his forum for scheduling reasons, since he is leaving the country this weekend and had promised to make his plans known by the end of June. But his press secretary, Glenn Davidson, asked reporters at the taping today to be sure to mention that Mr. Wilder's comments were at a black station.
Mr. Wilder said he would campaign on his successes in Virginia, including his winning passage of a gun control law fought by the National Rifle Association and his veto of a smokers' rights bill that tobacco interests had pressed through the Legislature.
 
Another Possible Challenge
 The developments in Virginia came on the same day that The Boston Globe reported the possibility of another intriguing match-up for 1994: that Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts, a Republican, was toying with the notion of challenging the state's senior Senator, Edward M. Kennedy, a Democrat.
But Mr. Kennedy's office had no comment on the possibility, and Mr. Weld, who has long denied interest in the seat, insisted today that he was running for re-election next year.
"Some people had approached the Governor over the past couple of weeks and urged him to take a look at a run against Kennedy," said Virginia Buckingham, a spokeswoman for Mr. Weld. "But that's something he has decided he didn't want to do, and he does intend to seek re-election."

HEADLINE: U.S. SETS PENALTY FOR RUSSIAN FIRMS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
The United States has imposed sanctions on Russian companies for selling missile technology in violation of international export controls, Clinton Administration officials said today.
But the sanctions have been waived until mid-July while Washington and Moscow make a last-ditch effort to resolve their differences. 
 The decision to impose the sanctions, which would bar American companies from doing business with the Russian companies, marks a further escalation in the dispute between Washington and Moscow over Russia's export of missile technology.
 
Visit Postponed
 The rift between the two sides was underscored today when Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia postponed his scheduled visit to the United States.
Mr. Chernomyrdin had planned to meet with Vice President Al Gore to conclude an accord on space cooperation. But reflecting its effort to stem the spread of weapons of mass destruction, the Clinton Administration has linked the issue of space cooperation with Moscow's adherence to missile export guidelines. Until the two sides resolve their differences, Washington does not want to offer a share of the lucrative business of launching American commercial satellites or to let Russians share the work on the multi-billion-dollar space station.
American and Russian officials said the issue will be taken up when President Clinton meets with President Boris N. Yeltsin at the meeting of the Group of Seven industrialized nations in Tokyo July 7 to 9.
 
A Last Chance
 That would give the leaders a last opportunity to solve the dispute.
Russia has not joined the Missile Technology Control Regime, an international agreement that restricts the sale of missile technology. But Russia has asserted that it is adhering to terms of the accord.
Despite this, American officials say the Russians have violated its terms by agreeing to sell rocket engine and missile production technology to India.
Other Russian actions have raised concern about Moscow's compliance with the agreement, including a recent Russian shipment of Russian chemicals, which American officials say was intended for Libya.
The sanctions are required by law once it has been determined that a company has violated the guidelines.
 
Seeking a Balance
 Nonetheless, there has been considerable discussion about the issue as Washington has sought to balance its commitment to stem the spread of dangerous weapons with its effort to help prop up Mr. Yeltsin's Government.
Mike McCurry, the State Department spokesman, declined to comment, saying the issue of Russia's missile exports were under discussion between Washington and Moscow.
It is unclear what effect the sanctions will have. One Administration specialist said that Mr. Chernomyrdin was beholden to Russian industrialists and that many of the industrialists favor the sales to prop up their companies.
 
A Compromise Offer
 The Clinton Administration has offered to tolerate part of Russia's sale of missile technology to India. The Russians would have to assure Washington it is strictly observing the missile control regime.
But officials in Russia's Foreign Trade Ministry said that the two sides have been unable to find a compromise, according to the Interfax news service in Moscow.
"Canceling the part of the transaction to which the United States objects would mean Russian subordination to America on space cooperation with third countries," Interfax said.

HEADLINE: San Pedro de Tiquina Journal;
Landlocked Navy's Dream Is to Go Down to Sea

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN PEDRO DE TIQUINA, Bo livia

 BODY:
Senior officers here at Bolivia's largest naval base, tucked along a peninsula that juts into Lake Titicaca, admit they would prefer life on the high seas.
The mission of their 250 cadets, many of whom do not know how to swim, is to police the 150-mile length of the lake with five tiny patrol boats, hoping to catch the occasional Shining Path guerrilla passing by boat from Peru to Bolivia. 
 But the importance of San Pedro de Tiquina lies more in its symbolism. Just as the Argentines yearn for the return of the Falkland Islands, or the Malvinas as they call them, from Britain, Bolivians teach their children with religious zeal that one day they will return to the sea.
"We cannot forget what has been done to us," said Capt. Luis Aranda Granados as he gave a tour of the base. "A great part of our underdevelopment is because we lost our access to the sea. We had no water trade routes. But we will get it back. So now is the time to train for when we return to the sea."
 
The Lost Coastline
 Though Bolivia has lost large stretches of territory to all of its neighbors in separate wars, its one continuing complaint is with Chile.
In 1879, 500 Chilean troops overpowered 130 Bolivian troops, while the country was celebrating carnival, and seized 160 miles of coastline as well as vast deposits of copper and saltpeter.
Today there are no formal diplomatic relations between the two countries and Bolivia continues to petition international groups to take up its cause against the much more affluent and influential Chile. Early in June the Bolivian Foreign Minister asked the Organization of American States at its annual meeting in Managua, Nicaragua, to press Chile to give Bolivia an exit to the sea. But the Chilean delegate said the case was closed.
"Chile continues with the capricious policy of keeping us closed in," Vice Adm. Miguel Alvarez Delgado, the Bolivian Navy commander, said. "We offer no threat militarily, but the Chilean military still believes in the Germanic theory of conquering the vital territory, of pushing into the heartland of the continent."
Meanwhile, Bolivia has tried a different way to the sea, through its northern neighbor Peru. Peru also lost coastline and mineral wealth to Chile, and the two countries still mistrust each other.
In May, the Peruvian Congress agreed to give Bolivia a free-trade zone in its southern port of Ilo. Along a three-mile stretch of coast, the Bolivian Government will be able to build a port, bring in goods free of import duties and transport them over paved roads all the way to La Paz with no Peruvian interference.
"We have broken the deadlock with Chile," Gustavo Fernandez Saavedra, the Minister of Government, said. "We no longer depend on them to get our goods to the Pacific. This will mean a diminishing of economic activity in northern Chile and an increased importance in southern Peru. It could change the balance of things enough to bring Chile to an agreement."
To be sure, the Ilo access for Bolivia does not mean the landlocked country will abandon its hopes of pressing Chile to give it at least some coastline.
The most obvious would be the stretch of no more than two miles between the northern Chilean city of Arica and the Peruvian border. But that territory was actually land Chile took from Peru, and Peru would have to renounce any future claims to it.
Bolivian officials say that the biggest obstacle is the Chilean military, led by Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former dictator, and that very little can be done until the general steps down, which he does not have to do until 1998.
If anything that only fans the flames of nationalism in this country.
Every March 23, the country celebrates the Day of the Sea. Ten beauty queens are selected, one from each of the nine Bolivian departments and one named Miss Coastline.
In 1978, Bolivia founded the Bolivian Coastal Museum, in the heart of La Paz, which has little more then old maps of how Bolivia's coastline use to look. "A Pinochet general once said publicly that Bolivia never had a coastline, and so we started this museum as proof that was false," said Jaime Quispe, the museum manager.
The Bolivian Navy was founded in 1963 mainly to symbolize the country's hopes of regaining access to international waters. In addition to the San Pedro base, the navy patrols the many Amazon rivers.
"We know we are tiny, but we use the meager resources we have," said Admiral Alvarez, conceding that it might be years before he saw Bolivian Navy ships bobbing in salt water.
For now, officers here train their cadets, mostly young Aymara Indian men from surrounding villages, to develop other skills. Perhaps the most useful are learned in 15 hothouses at the base, where they grow tomatoes, beans, squash, cabbage, Swiss chard and other vegetables that otherwise cannot grow in the cold of the high Bolivian Andes.
"They take this knowledge back with them to their villages and it adds important vitamins often lacking in the Aymaran diet," Captain Aranda said.
"There are other advantages of having been here," he said. "They're guaranteed three meals a day, clothes and shelter for a year. Also, they go back home with such prestige that they can marry almost any girl in their village they want."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Despite losing 160 miles of Pacific Ocean coastline in a war with Chile in 1879, the landlocked nation of Bolivia founded a navy in 1963 as a symbol of the country's hopes of regaining access to the sea. One of the navy's boats docked in San Pedro de Tiquina after a recent patrol on Lake Titicaca. (Rickey Rogers for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Jet-Engine Workers Accept Harsh Reality

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST HARTFORD, Conn., June 24

 BODY:
Having reluctantly agreed to a package of work-rule changes and wage concessions, unionized workers at Pratt & Whitney reported to work here today amid a sober recognition that they had lost an unwinnable battle with a company, and an industry, mired in recession.
The workers, faced with a virtual certainty that the jet-engine maker would move at least 2,000 jobs to lower-cost plants in Maine and Georgia, voted by a ratio of 4 to 3 on Wednesday to accept concessions that once would have been considered unthinkable: no wage increases for two years and up to $2 in hourly wage cuts if productivity does not improve.
 
An Incentive Package
 By accepting the Pratt & Whitney proposal, the workers put the final pieces in place for an unusual incentive package in which Connecticut will provide the company with $32 million in grants and tax breaks. 
 "If this deal had gone the other way, we would have been moving people out of Connecticut next week," said Mark Sullivan, a spokesman for Pratt & Whitney, whose jet engine market has been ravaged by the falloff in military spending and a downturn in the commercial airline industry.
The agreement "was the least of all evils," Hank Bielonyza, a maintenance mechanic here, said in an interview today. The company headquarters are at the East Hartford plant, one of the five Pratt & Whitney plants in the state.
Although he voted to accept the concessions, he wondered, "How do we know that the company won't still pick up and leave sometime soon?"
Pratt & Whitney, which has 17,200 employees in Connecticut, said its manufacturing costs in Connecticut soared in the 1980's and told both the union and state officials that it could save as much as $6 an hour per employee by transferring operations to plants in other states. The average Pratt & Whitney plant worker in Connecticut makes $15 an hour in wages plus $7.50 in fringe benefits.
"We have been deadly serious all along," Mr. Sullivan said. "This company is going to lower its costs."
Still, while the agreement on Wednesday may have been inevitable, some people worried about a possible precedent for other financially troubled companies.
"I am outraged," said John Olsen, president of the Connecticut chapter of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. He said the concessions to Pratt & Whitney by the state and the union, District 91 of the International Association of Aerospace Workers, were "a form of extortion" that may now be attempted by other companies in Connecticut.
In accepting the Pratt & Whitney proposal, union workers agreed to a new contract, extending until December 1995, with no raises or cost-of-living adjustments. The workers also agreed to wage cuts of up to $2 an hour if they do not meet productivity objectives to be established by a committee of union and management representatives.
 
Work-Rule Changes
 Even more important to the company, Mr. Sullivan said, was that the union had agreed to work-rule changes that give managers greater freedom to assign workers to different shifts, machines or jobs.
In its agreement with the state, the company is to receive job-training grants and reductions in property and business taxes that it expects will amount to $32 million in the first year.
An important component of the state package is that the company will be rewarded with tax credits for investments in research and development in Connecticut.
 
Talking About the Future
 "Although our discussions with Pratt & Whitney have been wrenching, they are really about something bigger: the future of the aerospace industry in Connecticut," said Avice Meehan, a spokeswoman for Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.
Today, in a letter distributed to all Pratt & Whitney union workers here, Karl J. Krapek, company president, said that by agreeing to the plan, the workers had expressed faith in the future of our company.
Now, he said, the company would undertake a "significant redesign of our manufacturing, engineering and administrative processes."
Some analysts said the agreement to keep Pratt & Whitney from relocating may be a big victory for Connecticut.
"It's certainly a psychological victory," said Nicholas Perna, chief economist for the Shawmut National Bank of Hartford. "This could have been a terrible loss for Connecticut. Now, it's a worst case that didn't materialize."
But not everyone is feeling uplifted.
"It is, I suppose, something of a relief to have this behind us," said Norman Swanson, a parts inspector for 28 years in the East Hartford plant. Like Mr. Bielonyza, he voted to accept the concessions.
"But I'm not happy," he said. "I think the company blackmailed everybody they could."

Workers talked about the vote yesterday outside their union hall in East Hartford, Conn. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New Jersey Base Is Backed at New York's Expense

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
In a decision that helps New Jersey at New York's expense, a Presidential commission today rejected a Pentagon recommendation and voted to create a large East Coast troop-staging base at McGuire Air Force Base in New Jersey and to close Plattsburgh Air Force Base in upstate New York.
Defense Secretary Les Aspin had recommended shrinking McGuire and Griffiss Air Force in Rome, N.Y., and moving many of their missions to Plattsburgh, making it the Air Force's main transportation hub for cargo, soldiers and refueling planes on the East Coast. 
 The Pentagon plan set off a fierce interstate competition, pitting politicians and communities from New York and New Jersey against each other. The commission decided that McGuire's proximity to other bases on the East Coast increased both its training and wartime value. During the Persian Gulf war the Air Force flew 15,000 flights from the base in Wrightstown, N.J.
As a result, McGuire will gain about 2,500 civilian and military jobs at Plattsburgh's expense. The Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission approved the Pentagon's plan to reduce strength at Griffiss, which will lose 1,200 civilian jobs and about 3,700 military employees.
 
Panel Shows Independence
 In its first two days of deliberations, the commission has demonstrated an independent streak. The panel has rejected or significantly modified 9 of the 14 Defense Department recommendations considered so far. In the 1991 round of base closings, the commission changed only four bases.
The commissioners also voted to keep Homestead Air Force Base in Florida open as a reserve base until the site, devastated last August by Hurricane Andrew, is rebuilt as a civilian airport.
Congress last year approved $76 million to help rebuild the base and aid the community. Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida, said today that it would take an additional $25 million to $50 million to build hangars for reservists flying rescue missions and refueling planes.
The panel's generosity, however, extended only so far. Commissioners reluctantly voted to close K. I. Sawyer Air Force Base in the sparsely populated northern Michigan peninsula. Military and community officials estimate that Sawyer's closing will cause unemployment in the area to rise steeply to 24 percent.
 
Final Recommendations
 The commission's final recommendations will go to President Clinton, who has until July 15 to approve or reject the entire package. If he approves, Mr. Clinton then forwards the package to Congress for approval or rejection. Given the pressure to cut military spending, approval appears almost certain.
In March, Secretary Aspin recommended closing or shrinking 43 major installations and 122 smaller sites. The commission later added 47 other major bases and 26 smaller sites for consideration.
On Wednesday, the first day of votes that will run through Sunday, the seven-member commission agreed to spare eight bases, reduce one, increase one and close one.
Commissioners today continued to ignore the Pentagon's recommendations. Against Mr. Aspin's wishes, commissioners reduced the Tooele Army Depot in Utah and kept open the Letterkenny Army Depot in Chambersburg, Pa., expanding it to perform tactical missile maintenance for all the armed services. The Letterkenny decision reflects the commissioners' desire to consolidate repair and maintenance work instead of having each service do its own.
Indeed, the commissioners seem to be relishing their roles as autonomous arbiters. The Air Force, for example, had wanted to close Homestead. But Jim Courter, the commission's chairman and a former Republican representative from New Jersey, said the panel's decision was "reasonable, affordable and makes sense."
"It's not what the Air Force wanted, but that hasn't stopped us," he said.
Today's deliberations delved heavily into technical issues like fuel hydrants, airport ramp space, runway lengths and air traffic congestion. While the commissioners -- who include retired military officers, former politicians and business executives -- all appeared well briefed on the maze of data, the panelists seemed to follow the lead today of Hansford T. Johnson, a commissioner who is a retired four-star Air Force general who headed the United States Transportation Command during the Persian Gulf war.
It was General Johnson who made the successful motion to make McGuire the East Coast transportation hub, instead of Plattsburgh. "McGuire's location was the determining factor," the general said.
New Jersey officials were of course jubilant. "This shows that if you have the facts on your side, you can save bases," said Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey.
New York politicians, however, criticized the panel's rejection of the Pentagon's recommendation. "It goes without saying that this is a devastating blow that was totally unexpected," said Representative John M. McHugh, the New York Republican whose district includes Plattsburgh.
Commissioners face some of their most difficult decisions on Friday, when they begin voting on Navy installations and naval shipyards. Some of the fiercest opposition to base closings has come from Charleston, S.C., and the San Francisco Bay area, which stand to lose thousands of jobs and millions of dollars in revenues if the Pentagon's plan to close major ports in those areas is approved.

HEADLINE: Americans' Incomes Rise

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 24

 BODY:
Americans' personal incomes grew a healthy six-tenths of 1 percent in May and would have increased even more if not for a decline in subsidy payments to farmers, the Government said today.
The increase, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $5.3 trillion, followed a paltry gain of one-tenth of 1 percent in April, the Commerce Department said. 
 Both the April and May advances were held back by a decrease in farm subsidies. April incomes were helped by a rebound from the winter storm that hit the East Coast in mid-March. Excluding the special factors, incomes would have been up an even stronger eight-tenths of 1 percent in May and four-tenths of 1 percent in April.
Personal consumption spending, meanwhile, rose a slight two-tenths of a percent in May, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.29 trillion. But that followed a 1.2 percent surge in April.
Today's report fits with analysts' belief that the economy is starting to bounce back after a pronounced slowdown early this year.
The most-watched component of income -- wages and salaries -- rose a strong 1 percent in May to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.04 trillion after a gain of four-tenths of 1 percent in April.
Farm incomes were down in May. Transfer payments, like unemployment benefits, increased. Most of the gain came in Social Security checks.
Real disposable income -- inflation-adjusted income after taxes -- rose four-tenths of 1 percent in May after a drop of two-tenths of 1 percent the previous month.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Yields Continue to Decline

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Bond yields declined yesterday for the seveth consecutive day, putting the 30-year Treasury issue, with a closing yield of 6.73 percent, within striking distance of its 20-year-low yield set in mid-April.
There was no particular catalyst for yesterday's drop in bond yields, just a general sense among traders and investors that lower inflation and a sluggish economy have combined to create an era of good feeling about fixed income securities. 
 Of course, eras can be short-lived in the bond market, as shown by the market's quick retreat the previous time yields were near the current level. After reaching a price peak on April 15 of 105 7/32, to yield 6.72 percent, the 30-year Treasury bond dropped to 101 2/32, to yield 7.03 on May 21 after a spate of higher than expected inflation reports. In yesterday's trading, the 7 1/8 percent issue due in 2023 was offered late in the day at 105 1/32, up 1 1/32, to yield 6.73 percent, down from 6.76 percent on Wednesday.
Marshall B. Front, president of Stein Roe & Farnham Investment Counsel, a Chicago firm, said the markets' mood was upbeat "because people are still reacting to the muted inflation figures."
Apart from the decline in consumer prices reported last week for May, he noted that anecdotal reports from the United States and Europe "are that savage competition is making it very difficult for businesses to raise prices."
As for short-term interest rates, Mr. Front said he expects them to rise eventually "but with the economy limping along for now, the coming tax increases are likely to put enough drag on the economy that the Fed will have to think twice or even three times bfore raising rates."
 
Softer Economic Data
 William Sullivan, executive vice-president at Dean Witter Reynolds, noted that announcements this week of a drop in durable goods orders, a rise in unemployment claims and weak department store sales "have amounted to a steady drumbeat of somewhat softer economic data."
He said some investors and traders appear to be concluding that the June employment data could be weaker than expected. The June employment data to be announced on July 2 is expected to show an increase in nonfarm payrolls of 155,000 according to a survey by MMS International, a reseach firm.
In the Treasury note market yesterday, the new 4 1/8 percent two-year note was offered at 993 1/32, up 3/32, to yeild 4.14 percent, while the 5 1/8 percent issue due in five years was up 5/32, to 992 8/32, to yield 5.15 percent. Both issues are above the prices set at auctions earlier this week.
In the bill sector, the Treausry's new one-year issue auctioned yesterday sold with an average rate of 3.40 percent, down from 3.93 percent at the previous auction four weeks earlier.
Traders said prices of Treasury notes and bonds were benefiting from strong demand from investors and speculators looking ahead to the light supply of new issues in coming weeks. The next Treasury note offering is the regular monthly sale of a two-year issue in late July.
The paucity of Treasury offerings has led many investors to the corporate market, where yields are higher and the supply of new issues can be rapidly increased to satisfy demand.
The Stone Container Corporation acted quickly yesterday to raise $400 million in two transactions handled through Salomon Brothers. A $150 million issue of 12 5/8 percent senior notes due in 1998 with a junk-bond rating of B-1 by Moody's Investors Service, was offered at par. A companion $250 million issue of seven-year senior notes yielding 9 percent and convertible to common stock at $11.55 was privately placed. Stone is issuing the convertible notes without seeking shareholder approval. Its stock closed yesterday at $8.75, up 12.5 cents.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
A Slight Rise in Gold Prices Defies Consensus on a Trend

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold futures prices edged higher yesterday, but analysts differed on whether the slight gain was proof of the market's strength or a disappointing coda to a burst of buying on Wednesday.
On other commodity markets, silver futures slipped; grains and soybeans were mixed; crude oil futures rose, and livestock and meat futures were mixed. 
 Gold for August delivery rose 60 cents on the New York Commodity Exchange, to $376.10 an ounce; July silver slipped 0.3 cent, to $4.392 an ounce.
The action followed a gain of $5.80 in gold and a jump of 13.5 cents in silver on Wednesday, which analysts attributed to investment fund buying and inflation jitters.
Martin Reichenberg, the manager of trading services for Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J., said yesterday's performance proved "gold is still strong."
He said the market had cause to go down in light of profit-taking, stronger German bond prices and the weakness in the grain markets. Instead, it ended higher after weathering an early round of profit-taking.
 
'Disappointing' Performance
 He predicted August gold soon would return to $380 an ounce, a level it has not held since late May.
But Bernard Savaiko, a senior metals analyst with Paine Webber Inc. in New York, called the metals' performance "kind of disappointing," and said gold would encounter substantial resistance in reaching $380.
Savaiko said gold's future course would depend on whether the Federal Reserve Board perceived enough of a threat from inflation to raise interest rates.
Wheat futures weakened on the Chicago Board of Trade after the Government announced new export subsidy offers that were at the low end of the expectations of traders. Corn and oat futures edged higher; soybeans ended narrowly mixed.
In energy trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil for August delivery rose 3 cents to $18.89 a barrel; July heating oil fell 0.11 cent to 51.96 cents a gallon; July unleaded gasoline rose 0.66 cent to 54.75 cents a gallon, and August natural gas rose 7 cents to $2.159 per 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues Advance Vs. Mark; Yen Strengthens

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar resumed its rally against the German mark yesterday, soaring past the important 1.7000-mark level after news that French and German finance officials would meet to discuss monetary policy.
The Japanese yen strengthened, however, on comments by an influential United States-based economist that the dollar should trade below 110 yen as a way to help curb Japan's global trade surplus. 
 The dollar rose in Europe early yesterday after the French Economics Minister, Edmond Alphandery, said he had expected Germany's central bank chief and finance minister to attend a French-German economic council today. The meeting was to discuss central bank interest rate policy.
The German Finance Ministry later announced that the meeting had been postponed for scheduling reasons. A new date was not immediately set.
 
 
Signal From Bundesbank
 But currency market participants took Germany's action as an expression of independence by the Bundesbank, which has remained steadfast in its policy of slow interest rate reductions despite international pressure for faster cuts.
"That was a clear signal that they weren't going to be pressured into an interest rate cut by the French," said David Gilmore, currency analyst with MCM Inc.
The development helped stem further dollar purchases for the day, capping the currency's gains at below the 1.7100-mark level in New York trading, Mr. Gilmore said.
In European trading, the dollar closed at 1.7110 German marks, up from 1.6930 late Wednesday. But in New York trading, the dollar rose to only 1.7070 marks from late Wednesday's 1.6913 marks.
 
 
Impact on Trade Gap
 The yen, meanwhile, strengthened on suggestions from C. Fred Bergsten, a Washington-based economist and former adviser to President Clinton, that the trade deficit with Japan could be curbed if the dollar remained below 110 yen.
In theory, a stronger yen would cut Japan's surplus by making Japanese imports more expensive and American goods cheaper in Japan.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 108.60 yen, down 1.97 yen from Wednesday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 109.55 yen. By 4 P.M. in New York, the dollar was quoted at 108.70 yen, down from late Wednesday's 109.05 yen.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.4675, from $1.4725 late Wednesday. By 4 P.M. in New York, the pound fetched $1.4690, less than late Wednesday's $1.4720.

HEADLINE: Diner's Journal

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:

Musical Chairs and Table
Pino Luongo is busy reshuffling the deck in his restaurant empire. The tenure of Marta Pulini as chef has just ended at Le Madri, 168 West 18th Street, and Gianni Scappin, who comes from the Venice region with a long resume, has replaced her.
Ms. Pulini has been named executive chef of the new uptown Barneys at Madison Avenue and 61st Street by Mr. Luongo, who has the food-management contract for the store. When it opens in the fall, the store will have Mad 61, a food complex on the lower level with an espresso bar, a wine bar, a retail food shop, a catering service, a cafe and a 100-seat restaurant. Mr. Luongo said he would like the restaurant to offer "Manhattan cuisine," an American-French-Italian fusion. The second floor will have the Chelsea Cafe, emphasizing salads, and on the ninth floor there will be a 50-seat American restaurant with a buffet. 
 Mr. Luongo is also preparing to install a Manhattan edition of Sapore di Mare, his restaurant in Wainscott, L.I., at the edge of East Hampton, into the plush space once occupied by Mondrian, 7 East 59th Street. He just closed another Sapore di Mare on St.-Barthelemy in the Caribbean after two seasons, deciding for economic reasons not to exercise an option to buy the Castelets resort where the restaurant was. A chef for the Manhattan restaurant has yet to be designated.
And at Mr. Luongo's Coco Pazzo, 23 East 74th Street, Mark Strausman, the chef, has left, hoping to open his own restaurant. Mr. Luongo has little patience for chefs who show such signs of independence. Cesare Casella, the chef and owner of the highly regarded Il Vipore restaurant in the Tuscan town of Lucca, is gradually taking charge of Coco Pazzo; he is spending 10 days a month in New York until October, when the job becomes full time. His family will continue to run Il Vipore through the winter, the slow season. A schedule like that could well justify the name of the 74th Street restaurant, which means crazy chef in Italian.
Meanwhile, Mr. Strausman, whose only firm commitment at the moment is to run a food festival in Baltimore for the all-star baseball game next month, has been negotiating to become a consultant for Il Cantinori, 32 East 10th Street. Il Cantinori just happens to be the place where Mr. Luongo began his New York restaurant career before going on to establish his near-flung empire.
 
Around the Country
 In November, Larry Forgione, the owner of An American Place, 2 Park Avenue, at 38th Street, will unveil an outpost called An American Place Harborside on 111th Street in North Miami, in the former Jockey Club overlooking Biscayne Bay. Also before the end of the year, Gilbert and Maguy Le Coze, the owners of Le Bernardin, 155 West 51 Street, plan to open a second edition of Brasserie Le Coze, their restaurant in Coconut Grove, Fla., in the Lenox Center in the Buckhead district of Atlanta.

HEADLINE: TV Weekend;
'Front Page': Light News for the Small Screen

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
The spirit of MTV strikes again! The youngish hosts, the flashy graphics, the with-it sounds, the smart-alecky tone stamp "Front Page" as a news magazine for people who grew up on television. This offering from Fox Broadcasting, which is not in the habit of straining attention spans, bops along on the line between information and entertainment. To judge by tomorrow night's sprightly debut, the latest television news magazine will cause no loss of sleep over Bosnia or health coverage.
Ron Reagan possibly apart, the program's regular reporters -- Andria Hall, Tony Harris, Vicki Liviakis and Josh Mankiewicz -- are not household names. But all are personable, energetic and younger than Mike Wallace and Barbara Walters. 
 Ms. Liviakis leads off the first show with a Hollywood expose. It appears that the Paramount producer Robert Evans and his partner, William J. MacDonald (the fiance of Sharon Stone, star of "Sliver," which they produced), have been involved with two operators who have been accused of bilking elderly investors. Glimpses of Ms. Stone are provided.
Ms. Hall follows with a story about plastic surgery on adolescents, notably a girl who went for a nose job and liposuction on her thighs. Unfortunately, the liposuction also shrank her breasts, so she had to go back for breast implants. Glimpses are provided of this young woman and of another, who sought to have her size 38DD bosom reduced.
There follows a brief discussion by the "Front Page" reporters on the propriety of high-priced surgeons' working on adolescents. Their moralizing may remind you of those reformers who used to visit brothels for the ostensible purpose of rescuing their inhabitants.
And finally, Mr. Reagan delivers an amusing report on a Utah man who has been prevented from developing his land because it is home to a rare snail. Interviewing an official of the Sierra Club about the ever-growing lists of endangered species, Mr. Reagan asks, "How many pearly mussels do we need?" The Sierra Club man says we need them all. There are glimpses of the snails, which Mr. Reagan describes as "reclusive, vegetarian and bisexual."
Between the reports, the reporters and several other commentators -- Mike Lupica of The New York Daily News, Chris Matthews of The San Francisco Examiner, Joe Bob Briggs, a syndicated columnist, and Lisa Birnbach, an editor of Spy magazine -- offer snappy comments to snappier graphics on this and that, with glimpses of this, that and the other.

'L.A. Behind Bars'
A&E, Friday at 9 P.M
Tonight's offering on "Investigative Reports" is a vivid look inside the Los Angeles County Central Prison, the world's biggest jail. Its 6,000 inmates are awaiting disposition of their cases, the charges against them ranging from murder to drug trafficking to traffic violations. One of the 165 unarmed deputies who are entrusted with keeping this uncommunal community under control says, "It's a very entertaining job."
You can watch the processing of newcomers, in chains, and, later, hear them complain about their mass-produced meals. Periodic cell searches find jail-made weapons and drugs, which keep making their way into the jail despite all precautions. (One prisoner gives a demonstration of how to make a shank, or weapon, suitable for slicing up someone who has looked at you the wrong way.)
The prisoners, who are segregated by what a guard calls life style (which means gang members in one section, homosexuals in another, "head problems" in still another) tell of the constant pressure to prove themselves as tough as the next inmate. "Eventually," one muscular recidivist says, "you're going to get got." By the end of the hour, you may be marveling that there isn't more getting got among men for whom violence seems to be a way of life, whichever side of the bars they happen to be on.

'Swords to Plowshares'
'The Price of Peace'
CNN, Sunday at 9 P.M.
What does New London County in Connecticut have in common with Nizhni Novgorod in Russia? The answer, available on this hourlong report, is plenty of trouble, owing to the end of the cold war. "Swords to Plowshares," reported by Frank Cesno in the United States and Miles O'Brien in Russia, focuses on closed plants, lost jobs and deep economic disarray in areas that prospered during the arms buildup of the 1980's.
Unfortunately, the information is delivered in bits and pieces, with too many interruptions and repetitions and too little coherent continuity. Mr. Cesno and Mr. O'Brien deserve sharper producers. But the point is effectively made. Although no American region can match Russia's difficulties, the former enemies have had to turn their attentions from their ideological struggle to a certain amount of cooperation in the struggle to pay what Mr. Cesno calls "the price of peace."

Front Page
Fox, tomorrow at 9.
(Channel 5 in New York.)

Small, co-producer; Rob Yarin and James Platt, senior editors; Joe Carolei, senior producer; David Browning, senior broadcast producer; David Corvo, executive producer.

HEADLINE: Review/Film;
The Self Stays Strong Amid Shades Of Prejudice

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
Kathe Sandler's documentary film "A Question of Color" begins with a sequence in which a group of black men and women of varying complexions recite many of the terms, from "high yellow" to "chocolate" to "blue-black," that are used to describe differences in skin tone. From this formal opening, the film plunges bravely into the ticklish subject of color consciousness among blacks.
What it finds is the prevalence of a subtle caste system in which those whose looks come closest to approximating white European standards of attractiveness tend to fare better in American society than those who look more African. It also finds that the tensions generated by this system, which is really an internalized expression of white racism, leave almost everybody feeling insecure. While those who are darker skinned are made to feel less desirable as mates and tend not to do as well economically, light-skinned blacks can find themselves accused of being pretenders to their African heritage. 
 For a film dealing with such a loaded subject, "A Question of Color," which opened yesterday at Film Forum 1 on a double bill with Marlon Riggs's "No Regret," is remarkably evenhanded and free of rhetoric. The film, which includes interviews with everyone from urban teen-agers to a 96-year-old woman in rural Alabama, also puts the issue into historical perspective. Dr. Benjamin Payton, the president of Tuskegee Institute, talks about the days of slavery, when a slave owner could have any woman he wanted and how the interracial sex resulted in a rainbow of skin tones.
The only moment in American history when that white-oriented color consciousness among blacks seemed to be crumbling, the film says, was in the 1960's when the black-consciousness movement, with its slogan "black is beautiful," prompted millions to adopt the Afro hairstyle. For Ms. Sandler, the white reaction against that movement is symbolized by the pressure brought against a television anchor, Melba Tolliver, who risked losing her job for wearing an Afro.
The movement's sense of exhilaration was short-lived. As the political pendulum swung toward the right, the old values were re-entrenched.
The film has an intriguing personal footnote. In 1977, after Ms. Sandler, who is light-skinned, was photographed with her mother on the cover of a mother-daughter issue of Essence magazine, she says, the publication was deluged with letters complaining that it had put a white woman on the cover. She goes on to reflect sadly on why she, and not her darker-skinned sister, was chosen for the cover.
In "No Regret," whose subtitle, "Non, Je ne Regrette Rien," is the name of one of Edith Piaf's signature songs, Mr. Riggs interviews five black gay men who are H.I.V.-positive. His subjects -- Michael Lee, Joseph Long, Assoto Saint, Reggie Williams and Donald Woods -- are all courageous, articulate advocates for personal disclosure about both their homosexuality and their H.I.V. status.
Among the issues touched on are how to break the news to a parent, whether to continue to have sex and how to maintain morale in a society that attaches a moral stigma to AIDS.
Of the five, Mr. Long may have had the most difficult journey toward disclosure. A devout churchgoer and recovering alcoholic who led a sexually closeted existence for 40 years, he has become an AIDS educator in the church, an institution that he says is in deep denial about the extent of H.I.V. infection among its flock.
Like Riggs's 1989 video documentary "Tongues Untied," which was attacked by Senator Jesse Helms and excerpted by Pat Buchanan in an ad for his campaign for the Presidency, "No Regret" is part documentary, part cinematic collage. Interwoven with the personal testaments are fragments of a poem by Mr. Woods, "Prescription," and stirring a-cappella gospel singing by Linda Tillery.
Both "A Question of Color" and "No Regret" were clearly made on shoestring budgets. If their scratchy soundtracks, crude visuals and rather haphazard structures make them occasionally hard to follow, their sensible, positive messages about self-acceptance in the face of racism and homophobia resonate strongly.
 
 
The Question Of Color
 
Directed and produced by Kathe Sandler; written by Ms. Sandler and Luke Charles Harris; released by California Newsreel. Film Forum 1, 209 West Houston Street, South Village. Running time: 58 minutes. This film has no rating.
 
No Regret
 
Directed and produced by Marlon Riggs; music by Blackberri, Linda Tillery; released by Frameline. Film Forum 1, 209 West Houston Street, South Village. Running time: 38 minutes. This film has no rating.

HEADLINE: Demagoguery on Taxes

 BODY:
The muddle-headed spirit of Ronald Reagan stalks Washington this week. Mr. Reagan promised Americans they could maintain their society without taxing themselves to do it. The theory went like this: Limit revenues, and spending will come down.
But under Presidents Reagan and Bush, spending went up, especially for defense. The limits on revenue didn't stop that; the country just went into the red to pay for it. Meanwhile the underclass grew, social divisions sharpened and attitudes toward suffering took on a Dickensian hardness. 
 Reaganomics II, as now peddled by Bob Dole & Co., offers only a slightly different plan. SenatorDole doesn't promise, as President Reagan did, that spending will magically drop if revenues dry up. The Dole plan offers a mechanism. Cap benefits, the Republicans insist, and our problems are solved. Let the human wreckage pile up at the bottom of society; the wealthy can take care of themselves.
Bill Clinton offered a different vision, and Americans bought it. In partnership with the private sector, Mr. Clinton wanted to create opportunities while reducing the deficit. The idea was to shrink the underclass, increase the middle class, bring those who "played by the rules" out of poverty, and face up to the fact that the vision had a price tag. Americans agreed they were willing to pay that price -- as long as he delivered.
Congressional Republicans aren't buying it. With their pledge to oppose all taxes, they are busily transposing the Reagan siren song into the new fiscal demagoguery: You can have a safe, healthy and prosperous society without paying for it.
Americans are not taxed excessively in comparison with citizens of other developed countries. It's instructive to look at the formula being proposed by the new conservative Government in France, which also faces a large budget deficit and high unemployment: spending cuts -- including salary cuts for Government ministers -- coupled with tax increases.
It sounds exactly like the truthful prescription being promoted by the Senate majority leader, George Mitchell. Cravenly eyeing the 1994 elections, Mr. Dole and the Senate Republicans are peddling a tired and dangerous vision that can only add to the deficit that piled up while Ronald Reagan led the country into the land of dreamy dreams.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Fear of Compassion

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
At last, the Government of the United States is pulling itself together -- White House, Congress, Supreme Court -- to show how determined and target-minded it can be when it comes to handling a social crisis.
Well, not all social crises -- not things like controlling the gun epidemic that sickens American life, or helping the mentally ill to get the care to take them off the streets, or pushing the war against drugs to the victory in sight. 
 But when it came to some boatloads of people fleeing China and Haiti, the Government showed its stuff pretty quick.
First, the Chinese were hustled off to prisons distant from human rights lawyers. And now Haitians have been taught by the Administration and the Supreme Court that the Coast Guard can hijack them at sea and send them right back home; never mind what Mr. Clinton promised to the contrary when he was running toward the White House instead of living in it.
Some Americans are ashamed -- among them liberals, radicals and conservatives. They are connected by the belief that the open-held arms of American history is one of those things that makes the country more than a very large piece of real estate.
But many more Americans -- liberals, radicals, conservatives -- react as if refugees must be fought from ship to cell. They seem afraid of the American sense of compassion and welcome that makes people all over the world bless the name of the land.
Among these Americans are descendants of immigrants who simply have become bigots themselves, clones of those who warned that this country would be ruined by Jewish peddlers, Italian gangsters and Irish layabouts. America provides many things, but no vaccine against hate.
But mostly coldness to immigrants comes from economic fears and confusion about the complications of immigration and asylum.
About 800,000 legal immigrants enter America annually. Sometime, lying in a hospital emergency room, look up at a Philippine nurse bringing relief. Decide whether the U.S. needs fewer immigrants or more.
About three million foreigners live illegally in the U.S., many of them Mexicans who saw no moral reason why they should not go from their poor country to seek work in a rich country across a historically recent border. We can stop this by helping the neighbor become somewhat less poor, or saying our house is your house. Otherwise -- argue with America's lusty history, which made its borders too big to patrol.
In any case, immigration creates national wealth, not national burden. It does add government costs in some places -- which Washington wrongly shoves off on cities and states.
About 90,000 to 100,000 other foreigners arrive every year to ask for asylum as refugees -- people who fear death, imprisonment or torture if returned. Most prove their cases.
But suppose some do pretend to be "genuine" refugees, to find economic survival. Is that a reason for America to panic against the ideals of immigration and refuge, which helped create the country?
Groups like the New York Immigration Coalition and the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights explain the much-publicized backlog problem of 250,000 pending asylum cases.
Sweden has 800 officers handling asylum cases. Germany has 3,000. America has 150. Who created the backlog -- desperate people seeking a safe life or the U.S. bureaucracy, the same bureaucracy that allowed Mideast terrorists to get through despite strong existing laws?
Haitians have no clout in the U.S. But the truth is they flee Haiti to escape "endemic widespread human rights abuses," dictatorship and "the worst poverty in the hemisphere." Doris Meissner, the immigration specialist, wrote that in December.
Candidate Clinton said the Bush policy of hijacking Haitians on the high seas to send them back was so cruel that he would reverse it. But then President Clinton fought successfully in the Supreme Court to uphold the Bush order.
Dr. Meissner is now Mr. Clinton's nominee to head the Immigration Service. Perhaps she can convince the President that although the Court gave him the right to go back on his word it is not forcing him to do so.
In the end, faithfulness to compassion as national interest remains a matter of choice, for Presidents as for all Americans.

HEADLINE: I'm the Same Old Bob Dole

BYLINE: By Bob Dole; Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, is Senate minority leader.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Don't worry, the "old Bob Dole" is still on the job. And I can still spot a phony deficit package a mile away.
I appreciate Alice M. Rivlin's nice comments on this page Wednesday about my record on staying tough on the Federal deficit, but I can also appreciate that as deputy budget director she is doing her best to put some happy hype on a terrible product: President Clinton's tax-infested $347 billion deficit-reduction package. 
 Now, I have tremendous respect for Alice Rivlin, a talented and dedicated public servant, but she should spend less time waxing nostalgic for the "old Bob Dole" and start wondering whatever happened to the "New Democrat" Bill Clinton.
Unfortunately, President Clinton has left Candidate Clinton in the dust, taking a hard left turn out of the mainstream and speeding onto the liberal autobahn, where there are no limits on taxing and spending.
Left in his exhaust are all those middle-class Americans still waiting for their promised tax cut, all those Americans who will have to pay for the President's new energy tax, all those employers who will now be penalized for making their small businesses successful and all those voters who thought they were voting for real change in November.
That's why Senate Republicans will continue to oppose the President's economic plan, because it is lopsided with $271 billion in gross tax increases, lets the deficit skyrocket again after 1998, cuts Federal spending only by $15 billion during the next three years and asks the American people to look the other way as the Clinton Administration takes credit for $44 billion in deficit reductions that the Bush Administration enacted into law three years ago.
How that kind of Washington magic will create jobs, inspire Wall Street and boost the recovery is beyond me.
Unfortunately, the President and his Senate allies are determined to win a political victory, a shortsighted mission that may earn a few headlines this weekend but will haunt them once the taxpayers find out they've been shortchanged again.
If Alice Rivlin is really longing for the old Bob Dole, she would have blown the whistle on the bogus plan, exposing the fact that it does not produce the President's ballyhooed $508 billion in deficit reduction.
The old Alice Rivlin would have endorsed our Republican alternative that gets the deficit under control by freezing spending and not raising taxes.
And the old Alice Rivlin would have cheered our plan as it dropped the deficit every year after 1998 while her boss's plan lets it shoot right up again after that date.
She is right: I have made some tough choices on the deficit front. In 1985, as Senate majority leader, my Republican colleagues and I put together the toughest deficit-reduction package in history, eliminating entire Federal programs and freezing spending across-the-board, including cost-of-living adjustments for entitlement programs.
Did Democrats applaud this bold move? Did they vote for our plan? Did they accept our offers to be players? No way. Only the late Edward Zorinsky, Democrat of Nebraska, had the courage to join us. So forgive us if we deficit veterans don't get too excited about President Clinton's big-tax, low-cut, one-party agenda.
Yes, Alice, there's still an old Bob Dole. He's still fighting the old tax- and-spend liberals, even if they now wishfully call themselves "New Democrats."
