HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Test of Leadership

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

 BODY:
The Soviet-American treaty banning all but underground nuclear tests is nearly 30 years old now, and we tend to take it for granted. We forget that it exists only because a President was courageous enough to lead.
June 1963 was a time of high tension in the cold war. Less than eight months before, we had come to the brink of nuclear war over Soviet deployment of missiles in Cuba. The American political mood was overwhelmingly hawkish. 
 In that climate President Kennedy moved to reduce tensions with the Soviet Union. In a speech at American University on June 10 he called for steps toward peace, if not to end differences with Moscow then at least to "make the world safe for diversity." Most concretely, he called for "a treaty to outlaw nuclear tests," which he said would "increase our security [and] decrease the prospects of war."
The test-ban proposal aroused powerful opposition in Congress and the military. Public opinion was skeptical. When negotiations produced only a limited test-ban treaty, allowing underground tests to continue, even that was fiercely resisted. Theodore C. Sorensen, who was Kennedy's special counsel, described the resistance when he spoke this June 10, also at American University.
"But the President carried the fight to the Senate," Mr. Sorensen said, "to the Joint Chiefs, to the public, with speeches and phone calls and meetings and arm-twisting. . . . And he prevailed. No other signing ceremony in the White House gave him greater satisfaction."
Thirty years on, that history is acutely relevant. President Clinton faces an important decision on nuclear testing, one with profound implications for the spread of nuclear weapons. And once again the outcome depends on Presidential courage and commitment.
Last year Congress imposed a moratorium on U.S. nuclear testing until this July 1. After that the legislation allows up to 12 tests for the "safety" of nuclear weapons and 3 for their "reliability."
The military services have told the President they favor further tests, but they are not pushing with great zeal. They are not eager to spend the vast sums needed to deploy new warheads or weapons, now that the cold war is over, and the law allows tests only if the services plan deployment.
The real push for tests comes from the nuclear weapons laboratories, which want to justify their continued existence. And they have friends in Congress.
The arguments for testing are essentially ones of domestic politics, not science. In terms of national security, the arguments are overwhelmingly against new tests.
The United States in fact faces one extremely serious nuclear threat, and resumption of testing would exacerbate it. That is the proliferation of weapons. Intelligence reports suggest that a substantial number of countries could acquire nuclear weapons if there is any weakening of the barriers to proliferation.
If the United States starts testing, France, Britain and Russia may well conduct tests. President Clinton would undoubtedly say that this will be a last test series, but it would be extremely difficult then to get the other nuclear powers to agree on a final stopping date.
All this would have dangerous consequences for nuclear proliferation. The countries without acknowledged nuclear weapons have always insisted that the principle of nonproliferation is acceptable only if those that have them stop testing. And the nonproliferation treaty is up for renewal in 1996.
In fact, the term "safety tests" is a misnomer. There is no danger in existing weapons of unintended nuclear explosions; the only safety to be checked is of collateral matters. And testing would involve real danger to the world: the opposite of "safety."
President Clinton, speaking at West Point last month, said the U.S. "will soon begin negotiations on a comprehensive test-ban treaty, which will increase our political leverage to combat proliferation." Ending the current moratorium on tests would sabotage that negotiation before it can begin.
The necessary test is the one already taking place: the test of Presidential leadership.

HEADLINE: Where Indian Tribes Get Gambling Rights

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Issue of Indian Sovereignty Behind Gambling Case" (Law page, June 11) incorrectly states that the 1988 Indian Gaming Regulatory Act "grants tribes broad powers to issue and regulate gambling licenses." 
 The right of Indian tribal governments to regulate reservation gambling comes from our people. We did not give up that power when we signed peace treaties with the Federal Government in the 1800's. The Supreme Court recognized these powers in the 1987 Cabazon decision.
In 1988, at the bidding of the states, Congress restricted our rights by requiring Indian nations to enter agreements with the states before operating casino-type games. Many Indian nations have worked out agreements with states and have shown we can successfully operate casinos and provide for our people. Now, states that refused to recognize our rights are teaming up with the Las Vegas and Atlantic City interests, which want even more limits on our rights.
Indian tribal governments simply want to keep the right every state has, to determine if we are going to use gaming as a source of revenue. We use the revenue to provide basic governmental services to some of the most economically deprived communities in America.
 
JO ANN JONES
Tribal Chairwoman, Wisconsin
Winnebago Business Committee
Black River Falls, Wis., June 16, 1993

HEADLINE: SPECTER OF TERROR: The Suspects;
Arrested in Yesterday's Raid

 BODY:

SIDDIG IBRAHIM SIDDIG ALI
Mr. Siddig Ali, 32, arrived from the Sudan about seven years ago. The authorities called him the leader of the plot. He lives at 112 Brunswick Avenue in Jersey City.
A member of the al-Salaam Mosque in Jersey City described Mr. Ali as a "religious activist who's outspoken" and who was a leader in helping raise money to pay for the legal fees of the six defendants charged in the World Trade Center bombing and for the defense of El Sayyid Nosair, who was convicted of a gun charge in the murder of Rabbi Meir Kahane. 
 A Muslim associate said Mr. Siddig Ali trained with a group of Muslim militants who frequently practiced what they described as "self defense" techniques in the Harrisburg, Pa., area on weekends.
Mr. Siddig Ali, who was said to have a degree in economics in the Sudan, was described by his lawyer, William M. Kuntsler, as a former security guard and street peddler. He also has worked as a taxi driver in New York City, where he was cited for numerous traffic violations. Mr. Ali was said to have come to New York seven years ago.
 
CLEMENT RODNEY HAMPTON-EL
Mr. Hampton-El, 55 years old, was born in the United States and has lived for more than 25 years in a fifth floor Brooklyn apartment at 1351 New York Avenue, in the Midwood section, where he is more familiarly known as Rasheed Hampton, his Muslim name. On his apartment door were decals in Arabic and English calling on "Muslims to unite."
Neighbors said Mr. Hampton-El is a quiet, pleasant man who kept to himself but also was friendly with many of the children in the building, bringing them candy and fruit. They said he was employed as a laboratory technician in a downtown Brooklyn hospital.
 
MOHAMMAD SALEH
Mr. Saleh, who is 40 years old, is also known as Mohammad Ali. He lives on the first floor of a three family house at 39 Burtis Avenue in Yonkers, where he operates a gas station at the corner of Bronx River Road and Yonkers Avenue. Mr. Saleh is described as a Palestinian from Jordan and has a wife and three small children.
Friends of the couple said they are devoted to their three children and that both spent many hours in daily prayers.
 
TARIG ELHASSAN
Mr. Elhassan, 38, of 390 East 8th Street on the Lower East Side, is a Sudanese who was employed in this country as a cab driver. His friends said he became a devout Muslim in recent years.
Described by neighbors as a shy, quiet man, Mr. Elhassan lived in a sixth floor apartment in a building where a number of other Muslims were displacing many Hispanic and black families. They said he was separated from his American-born wife; they have three small children. One neighbor said one reason or the separation was her opposition to his insistence that she adhere to strict Muslim tradition for women.
One neighbor, Jennie Hernandez, said that Mr. Elhassan was not particularly religious when he moved in three years ago, but added that his Muslim conversion became more pronounced recently.
 
ABDELGHANI FADIL
Neighbors said Mr. Fadil, a 31-year-old Sudanese and former New York City taxi driver, moved from his tree shaded apartment at 120 Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn in January after sharing his home with as many six or seven Sudanese who would make travel often to New Jersey. They described Mr. Fadil and his Sudanese friends as quiet and polite.
The city's Taxi and Limousine Commission said Mr. Fadil's taxi driver's license expired in April, 1992.
 
VICTOR ALVAREZ
Mr. Alvarez, who is 32 years old and a native of Puero Rico, lives in a fourth floor apartment at 42 Wright Avenue in Jersey City, a few blocks from the Journal Square mosque where he and five of the other defendants worshipped and Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, a radical Muslim cleric, preached. His companion said he had been a supermarket stock clerk and was unemployed. He is considered by friends to be a devout Muslim.
 
 FARES KHALLAFALLA
Mr. Khallafalla, 31, of 926 Westside Avenue in Jersey City, is a native of the Sudan who was employed by a company that delivered medical supplies. Neighbors described him as a "very nice man" and said they could "not believe" he could be involved in any bombing plot. To help pay his bills, Mr. Khallafalla also served as the building's superintendent.
Like the other defendants, he worshipped at the Journal Square mosque and was known to send money to his family in Sudan. On a table in his nearly empty two-bedroom apartment was a textbook entitled, "Electronic Devices and Circuit Theories."
 
AMIR ABDOU ZAID
Mr. Zaid lived at 311 Palisades Aevnue in Jersey City. His brother, Gamal, said they immigrated from Sudan 10 years ago and that his brother was a taxi driver in Jersey City.

HEADLINE: Q & A

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:

Getting Stock Certificates
 
Q If I buy shares in a company and don't receive the stock certificate, what can I do?
 
 GLORIA G. OKUN, Brooklyn
A When you buy shares through a brokerage firm, you can leave them in the custody of the firm or ask for delivery of the stock certificates. Many firms are trying to discourage the use of these certificates by imposing charges for delivery. 
 If you do not receive requested stock certificates, contact your broker and, if necessary, talk to the office manager. "You may have to file a complaint with the National Association of Securities Dealers to get results," said John Markese, president of the American Association of Individual Investors. "But even so, it could take months to actually obtain the certificates."
 
Medigap Insurance
Q What is a Medigap insurance policy?
 
CATHERINE AMATO, Princeton, N.J.
A Medigap, or Medicare supplementary insurance, is private health insurance that fills some of the gaps in Medicare coverage. Since Medicare pays no more than 80 percent of most doctor bills and also has holes in its hospital coverage, many people over age 65 also buy Medigap insurance. Neither Medigap nor Medicare provides any significant coverage for long-term care.
"Consumers who shop around for Medigap coverage can probably save money," said James Firman, president of the United Seniors Health Cooperative. "Prices for identical coverage can vary greatly from company to company, sometimes by as much as 100 percent or more."
But all older people do not need Medigap policies, including retirees whose former employers provide supplemental coverage and elderly men and women who belong to a health maintenance organization. In addition, low-income seniors may be eligible for different types of supplemental coverage through the Medicaid program.
 
Called-In Bonds
Q Some of our corporate bonds are being paid off early. Why is this happening, and how can we avoid it?
 
 JEAN MANN, Manhattan
A You are discovering the concept of call risk -- the risk that a bond will be called, or bought back by the issuer before maturity. Most corporate bonds allow issuers to call these securities, and many have recently done so because interest rates have declined and the companies can issue new bonds at lower rates. Such moves are, of course, in the best interest of the issuers of the bonds, not of the investors in them.
To avoid call risk, you can buy noncallable bonds. "Most importantly, you should understand the call provisions of any bonds you want to purchase," said Jonathan D. Pond, author of "The New Century Family Money Book" (Dell, 1993).
"The best measure of the possible adverse effect of a bond call is the yield-to-call, a bond's yield if the bond is called by the issuer at the worst possible time from the standpoint of the issuer."
It usually pays to steer clear of any bond whose yield-to-call is substantially lower than its yield-to-maturity.

LENGTH: 1404 words

HEADLINE: BUDGET SURVIVES SENATE STRUGGLE; NEW FIGHT AHEAD

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
Hours after his budget package took a predawn white-water trip through the Senate and survived, mostly intact, President Clinton said today that he saw "quite encouraging" prospects that the House and Senate would meld their versions into one mutually acceptable bill.
But outside the White House, the signs that Mr. Clinton's budget faces yet another perilous legislative struggle were already mounting. 
 In their vote early this morning, the Senate Democrats needed Vice President Al Gore to move the budget past a united front of Republican opponents by a vote of 50 to 49.
 
Indicator of Trouble
 The clearest indicator of future trouble came hours later from Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma, a conservative Democrat whose attacks very nearly derailed the plan two weeks ago in the Senate Finance Committee. Mr. Boren, who voted for the Senate package, warned today that he would vote against any budget compromise that does not have more spending cuts than tax increases and does not meaningfully restrain spending on Federal benefits programs.
In the House, Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem warned that the House would not approve any compromise that did not raise spending for social programs well beyond the levels in the Senate bill. The President faces a formidable obstacle in Mr. Rangel, a senior member of the Ways and Means Committee, which wrote the House version of the budget, as well as a leading member of the Congressional Black Caucus, whose members will hold the balance of votes on a compromise.
The two lawmakers released the first of what will no doubt be a flotilla of trial balloons leading to the budget conference, each suggesting that Mr. Clinton's budget is doomed to defeat if certain concessions, liberal or conservative, are not granted.
None of that would matter if the first Democratic President in 12 years had a cushion of Democratic support for his budget, which aims to reduce the Federal deficit by $500 billion over five years. But he does not.
When the Senate finished voting shortly after 3 A.M., 6 of the 56 Democrats, most of them conservatives, voted against the package, and one supporter, Patty Murray of Washington, was absent, recovering from gynecological surgery.
The six were Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey, J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana, Richard H. Bryan of Nevada, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, Sam Nunn of Georgia and Richard C. Shelby of Alabama.
Late last month, the House passed a budget measure much more to Mr. Clinton's liking by a bare six-vote margin. There, too, all 176 Republicans voted against the proposal.
Lawmakers from both chambers will start meeting after the Fourth of July to seek a compromise that can pass muster in both the House and Senate. That will be especially difficult because the swing votes lie at opposite ends of the ideological spectrum: conservatives in the Senate; liberals in the House.
Mr. Clinton and his advisers insisted that bringing the opposite sides together would not nearly be as hard as it looked.
"They'll try to bridge those gaps -- I don't think they are particularly large," Mr. Clinton said of Congressional negotiators. He predicted that the talks would yield a budget superior to either version already passed.
 
'Premature to Fret'
 One Administration official who has been deeply involved in the budget fight said, "It seems way premature to fret about this outcome."
But in this case, it is still not clear what the Administration will do next. The official said the White House had no clear idea yet how to draft a workable compromise.
The Senate budget has a decidedly more conservative cast than the House version. It includes fewer taxes, fewer tax breaks for business and more spending cuts in social programs than the House package, which Mr. Clinton has endorsed.
The Administration said the House package would reduce the deficit by $503 billion over five years, with roughly 55 percent of that figure coming from higher taxes and 45 percent from spending cuts.
The Senate bill would cut spending by $256 billion through 1998 and raise taxes by $243 billion, for a total of $499 billion through 1998. That is 51 percent from spending cuts and 49 percent from new taxes.
 
Debt to Keep Rising
 Despite the taxes and spending cuts, the total Federal debt would keep rising under either budget -- by a total about $1 trillion -- over the five years. By the last year, the annual deficit would be reduced to about $200 billion.
The probable sticking points in House-Senate talks have been known for weeks, and the Senate did not much alter them in its final deliberations. Among them are these:
*The Senate version still would cut $10 billion more from the five-year Medicare budget than the House version, which reduces spending by $50 billion. The difference had been $19 billion but was narrowed to win the support of party liberals.
*The Senate version spends less on the earned-income tax credit for the working poor than the House version, although both provide for a substantial increase. The Senate also increases the food-stamp benefit program by less than the House.
*The Senate omits a program that Mr. Rangel and other House Democrats say is nonnegotiable: "empowerment zones" that would grant tax breaks to businesses that locate and employ persons in poor areas.
*The Senate rejected a broad House tax on most sources of energy, opting instead for a gasoline and diesel tax that would raise about a third as much. Late Thursday, the chamber voted to scale back even that tax, exempting aircraft fuel and reducing the total five-year take to about $22 billion.
*The Senate rejected a House-passed break in the capital-gains tax for investors who take long-term gains in certain small businesses.
Early today, the Senate also voted 98-0 to excise from the bill an Internal Revenue Service program, aimed at rooting out small-business tax cheats, that would have required corporations to report all transactions with service companies, like airlines and hotels, that exceed $600 in a year.
Mr. Clinton said he intended to fight in the conference to keep the House's tax breaks for small business and inner-city firms, and suggested that he would look favorably on smaller cuts in Federal benefits programs and other social spending.
An Administration official, who refused to be named, said Mr. Clinton's preferences could add up to more than $10 billion in spending or tax breaks. To afford that, the House-Senate conference would have to retreat on the deficit-cutting goal or raise taxes.
Mr. Boren made that clear today. "There were a good 6, 8, maybe 10 Democrats last night that were just barely there" in support of the budget package, he said in an interview. "If they go back to something that resembles more of the House bill, just barely more spending than taxes, I'm a goner. Absolutely."
The senior Administration official noted that Mr. Boren has rattled swords before to no effect, agreeing as recently as Thursday to accept smaller Medicare cuts than he had earlier negotiated.
 
Democrats Had Reserves
 And several Congressional and Administration officials said the White House had held a stronger hand in this morning's vote than the final tally showed. At least one Democrat who voted against the legislation, Senator Johnston, was ready to support Mr. Clinton if needed, and another of the six defecting Democrats also was ready to switch, they said.
The White House said today that Mr. Clinton followed the voting till the end on C-Span, though he took a break with a videotape of "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid" during a long series of forgone votes on amendments in the middle of the night.
The White House made an overture to the conservatives today, dispatching the budget director, Leon E. Panetta, to order all Government agencies to plan for an average 10 percent cut in "nonpriority discretionary spending programs" in their next budgets.
It nevertheless was clear that Mr. Clinton has almost no margin of error in either chamber in the complex bargaining process to come.
In this and past budget conferences, the chairman of dozens of Congressional panels with stakes in the legislation appoint committee members to negotiate their portions of the bill, usually in private. Formal votes are rare; rather, lawmakers sign tally sheets that register their support or disapproval.

HEADLINE: Panel Votes to Close Staten Island Base; Spares New London

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
Virtually ending any significant Navy presence in New York City, a Presidential commission voted today to close the Staten Island Homeport and move its ships and sailors to Virginia and Florida.
The decision by the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission appears to put an end to one of the Navy's most modern installations, which until 1991 had been the focus of a debate over allowing nuclear-armed ships to be based in New York Harbor. The panel rejected, however, a Pentagon recommendation to shrink the submarine base at New London, Conn.
 
Other Major Closings
 In a body blow to California and South Carolina, the seven-member commission also voted to close the Navy base and shipyard in Charleston, S.C., and a large shipyard and two Navy bases in the San Francisco Bay area. Combined, they employ more than 14,000 civilians, and community officials estimate the closings could indirectly cause the loss of two to three times that many jobs. 
 The panel left open the possibility that it may vote in its two remaining days of deliberations to move other small installations to Charleston to ease the economic damage.
While communities with base closings are predictably angry and filled with prophecies of doom, the reductions and closings will yield billions of dollars in savings as a dividend from the end of the cold war.
President Clinton and Congress must approve or reject the commission's recommendations as a package, and the pressure to reduce the military budget makes approval virtually certain.
In its third day of final deliberations on the fate of 238 installations nationwide, commissioners focused on shrinking the Navy's vast network of bases. Some, like Charleston's, date to the early 1900's. Others, like Staten Island's, were built in the 1980's for a 600-ship Navy meant to fight the Soviet Union all over the globe. With the cold war over and the Navy fleet heading toward 320 ships by the end of the decade, the Navy has more bases than it needs or can afford.
 
Vulnerable Area Base
 After essentially ignoring the need to recommend base closings during the previous rounds in 1988 and 1991, the Navy is having to play catch up this year. As a result, scores of naval bases, shipyards, technical centers and air stations are under consideration.
No base was more vulnerable than the one on Staten Island. Originally designed as a homeport for a Navy battleship and accompanying warships, the homeport is one of the newest bases in the Navy. It now has one Aegis cruiser and five reservist ships, and is also a training center for 10,000 Navy reservists. But, being built at the height of the expansion, its prospects quickly shrank along with the size of the fleet.
The commission made clear that the opposition to the homeport among New Yorkers did not play a role in the decision.
Representative Susan Molinari, Republican of Staten Island, said in an interview that legal action to block closing of the homeport, while possible, would probably only prolong the inevitable. "I'd prefer to move on a more positive course and consider as rapidly as possible alternatives," she said.
Ms. Molinari said she would announce a package of redevelopment options for the port next Tuesday. Under today's vote, the family housing built at the homeport would continue to be used by the military for workers at other nearby bases.
Other states also felt the pain. Scores of community leaders and politicians from California and South Carolina packed a House hearing room today, with dozens of people left outside. Emotions ran high inside and out. One commissioner, Peter B. Bowman, a retired Navy submarine captain, was near tears as he reminisced in a quaking voice about the Mare Island shipyard in the San Francisco Bay area, where he was married 29 years ago. Moments later, he reluctantly voted to close the site.
Officials from Charleston said 38,000 jobs would be lost directly and indirectly as a result of the shipyard and Navy base closing. Community leaders had impressed commissioners with a well-organized campaign to save the installations, including having audiences hold three rehearsals before the panel held a field visit there.
Commissioners considered sending Charleston the submarines now in New London or a mine warfare center in Ingleside, Tex., but in the end, the panelists said, they could not save the bases. "From a monetary sense and a mission sense, nothing seemed to work out," said Jim Courter, the commission's chairman, a former Republican Representative from New Jersey.
South Carolina politicians and officials, who wore yellow buttons emblazoned with "In Defense of Charleston," took little solace in the comforting words. "This is probably the worst disaster that's happened to Charleston in my lifetime," said Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, a 90-year-old Republican.
The outlook was equally grim in California, where 17 installations employing 68,000 workers are already being closed, and the military industry is in deep recession. In the San Francisco Bay Area, the commission closed the Mare Island Naval Shipyard, Alameda Naval Air Station and the Treasure Island Naval Base. Aircraft carriers now based in Alameda will be moved to the homeport in Everett, Wash., which the commission decided to keep open.
 
'An Unfair Hit'
 "California has taken an unfair hit," said Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California.
One glimmer of good news for California came when the commission, after a spirited debate, voted 4 to 3 to keep open the Long Beach Naval Shipyard, which employs about 4,400 civilian workers. Commissioners unanimously agreed to keep open Naval installations in Pascagoula, Miss., and Ingleside, Tex., Meridian, Miss., and Corpus Christi, Tex., as well as shipyards in Norfolk, Va., and Portsmouth, N.H. But the panel voted to close the Navy homeport in Mobile, Ala.
Earlier in the day, the panel voted to keep open depots at McClellan Air Force Base in California, Kelly Air Force Base in Texas, Tinker Air Force Base in Oklahoma and Robins Air Force Base in Georgia, which commissioners had added to the Pentagon list for possible closings. But the panel approved a Pentagon recommendation to close a small depot at Newark Air Force Base in Ohio.
Defense Secretary Les Aspin recommended in March the closing or shrinking of 43 major installations and 122 smaller sites. The commission later added 47 other major bases and 26 smaller sites for consideration. Commissioners have suggested in interviews that they might substitute some bases for Mr. Aspin's choices, but are unlikely to close many more installations than the Pentagon wants.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Job losses in Charleston, S.C., at top, are expected to be severe after the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission voted to close a Navy base and a shipyard. Workers left the Navy base yesterday after their shift. In Long Beach, Calif., workers at the Naval Shipyard celebrated its reprieve in a state where 17 installations are closing. (Associated Press)

Your Money

HEADLINE: Rights Forum Ends in Call For a Greater Role by U.N.

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VIENNA, June 25

 BODY:
After dire predictions that it could mark a serious setback for the human rights movement, a World Conference on Human Rights ended on a surprisingly optimistic note tonight as delegates called on the United Nations to play a larger role in denouncing abuses.
Western delegations were particularly pleased that, after lengthy bargaining, the conference endorsed an American proposal for the creation of a new post of High Commissioner on Human Rights. 
 More than anything, though, the United States and other Western nations were relieved that their worst fears were not realized -- a retreat from the basic tenets of the 1948 Universal Declaration of Human Rights as the result of a bitter North-South clash.
"We came to Vienna with less than high expectations," John Shattuck, the chief American delegate, said tonight of the two-week meeting. "But we worked with other delegations to stop any backsliding on human rights. And, on balance, it was a successful event. It has produced a strong, forward-looking document."
 
Challenge of Relativity
 The West's main concern was that a bloc of mainly Asian nations, led by China, Iran and Syria, might succeed in their attempt to challenge the universality of human rights by arguing that they existed as a function of a country's history, level of development, cultural tradition and religion.
While the conference's final declaration does take note of these variables, it commits states to promote and protect all human rights "regardless of their political, economic and cultural systems." And it adds, "The universal nature of these rights and freedoms is beyond question."
Conversely, because the conference had agreed to work through consensus, only days ago it seemed unlikely that a High Commissioner on Human Rights would be approved. In the end, though, the conference recommended that the General Assembly consider the idea "as a matter of priority" at its annual session this fall.
The conference itself had no legislative authority, leaving crucial decisions to be made later by other United Nations groups. But it nonetheless broke new ground by extending the definition of human rights to embrace the special rights of children, minorities, indigenous people and, particularly, women.
 
Women Declare Victory
 "The key factor has been the unity of women at the conference," said Roxanne Carrillo, an official of the United Nations Development Fund for Women, referring to the strong presence of independent women's groups here. "We strongly believe this alliance is the key to what we are celebrating today."
"These recommendations are a major half-step forward for the women of the world," said Charlotte Bunch, a spokeswoman for the Global Campaign for Women's Human Rights. "It will be a full step when the recommendations are carried out. So we're here to declare victory, go home and start preparing the next stage of the campaign."
Although the rules of the conference required that it not dwell on specific human rights crises, it adopted special resolutions dealing with atrocities in Bosnia and Herzegovina and in Angola. In the main, though, it involved a battle of words, with different governments left to identify where their interests might be threatened.
Non-governmental organizations working on human rights were particularly angry to be excluded from the committee drafting the final declaration. In a joint statement today, they described the declaration as "a flawed document" that confirms many basic rights but also reflects "attempts by governments to shirk their human rights obligations."
 
'Missed Opportunities'
 Pierre Sane, the Secretary General of Amnesty International, was even more critical, describing the conference as "a summit of missed opportunities" because "it dealt with the past and not the future, reaffirming principles agreed to 45 years ago instead of addressing the challenges of the future."
He said recognition of women's human rights was very significant, but the declaration used "condescending" language in referring to non-governmental organizations and made "a dangerous reference" to the media. "These organizations and the media are the key to human rights protection," he added.
Mr. Shattuck, who serves as Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, also expressed concern over a paragraph guaranteeing freedom and protection of the media "within the framework of national law" because many countries have legislation permitting censorship.
As the conference closed in a flurry of self-congratulatory speeches, however, experts said its success could only be measured by how many of its recommendations are eventually carried out. "We'll know how much we have achieved in the General Assembly this fall," said Reed Brody of the International Human Rights Law Group.

HEADLINE: Home-Resale Rise Posted

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
Sales of previously owned homes shot up 4.6 percent in May, the second straight advance after a winter slump, a real estate trade group said today. Each of the nation's four regions reported gains.
The National Association of Realtors said sales of existing single-family homes totaled 3.61 million at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, up from 3.45 million in April. 
 It was the biggest increase since a similar gain last December before adverse weather sent sales sliding for three straight months. Sales rose a revised 2.4 percent in April, slightly less than the 2.7 percent initial estimate.
The median price of a previously owned home was $106,100 in May, up just three-tenths of 1 percent from April and 2.9 percent from a year ago. The median means half of the homes cost more and half cost less.
At the same time, 30-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.47 percent in May, down from 7.48 percent a month earlier and 8.67 percent in May 1992, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
Regionally, sales jumped 7.9 percent in the South, to a 1.37 million annual rate. Sales advanced 4.2 percent, to a 500,000 rate, in the Northeast. In the West, sales increased 2.7 percent, to a 750,000 rate. Sales were up 2.1 percent, to 980,000, in the Midwest.
The realtors group said sales for the first five months totaled 1.38 million, up 1 percent from a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Opening a Wound on Staten Island

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN

 BODY:
Supporters of the Staten Island Homeport reacted with bitter resignation to yesterday's decision by the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission to close the base.
The Staten Island Borough President, Guy V. Molinari, a longtime advocate for the Navy base, called the closing a wound to the borough's pride. 
 "We finally had something other than the garbage dump, something to be proud of," he said. "I'm terribly, terribly disappointed. It's kind of a bitter pill to swallow."
Mr. Molinari said he had watched the commission's proceedings on television from his home, where he was recovering after being hospitalized for exhaustion. He blamed Mayor David N. Dinkins, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and other Democrats for their early opposition to the base and for not supporting the base strongly enough when they dropped their opposition.
 
'I Will Not Forgive'
 "It's true the Mayor flipped in the last month or two and said he was now supporting it, but it was too little, too late," Mr. Molinari said. "The Congressional delegation not only opposed Homeport, but signed letters asking for Homeport to be closed. I will not forgive them for it."
Mayor Dinkins, who originally opposed Homeport because of the possibility that ships containing nuclear weapons would be berthed there, dropped his opposition in 1991 when President George Bush ordered the Navy to remove all nuclear weapons from its surface ships.
In a statement yesterday, Mayor Dinkins called the base closing bad news for New York's economy as well as for national security, and he said he would ask President Clinton to reject the commission's recommendation.
Outside the base headquarters yesterday, a billboard alerted passers-by to the date and time of the commission's hearings. Inside, workers listened to the debate over an intercom.
The $300 million Homeport is home to 2,000 active-duty military personnel and employs 450 civilians, said Lieut. Roxie Thomsen, a base spokeswoman.
 
Worry About Jobs
 One of those workers, 33-year-old Gregory Nakshin, said he had moved to Staten Island from Brooklyn to be closer to the base.
"Everybody is tense," Mr. Nakshin said. "I wouldn't say depressed because we knew it was coming."
Mr. Nakshin said he had already starting searching for a new job.
"It's kind of scary," he said. "I'm probably going to be out of work for a couple of months, then, God knows."
A similar reaction came from Monica Hackett, 32, of Red Hook, Brooklyn, who works in the Navy exchange store. She said: "I hate to see it close. I've really enjoyed working here."
Carlo Vinaccia, 61, the manager of Plaza French Cleaners, adjacent to the base, said that he would probably lose several hundred dollars a week in business and that local restaurants in the area would be hit even harder.
"It's stupid to close the base after spending all that money on it," he said. "It just isn't right."
 
Sailors Resigned
 The closing is less difficult for the sailors stationed at the base, because they transfer every two or three years anyway, Lieut. Thomsen said.
"For us in the Navy, the uniformed guys, we see the big picture," she said. "Still, it makes a lot of the troops nervous. They see the budget cuts, the personnel cuts. It's the uncertainty of the big military 'downsizing.' "
Not everyone was upset about the vote. Members of a group called Coalition for a Nuclear-Free Harbor held a press conference outside the base to applaud the decision.
"It never made sense to base a nuclear-armed World War II battleship in New York Harbor," said a coalition leader, Thomas De Luca.
Other New York politicians, already reeling from Thursday's decision by the commission to close Plattsburgh Air Force Base in upstate New York, condemned the Homeport vote.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said it made no sense for the Navy to close one of its newest and most efficient facilities.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said, "It's a sad day for our nation's defense, a major blow to New York's economy, and it shows a total lack of sensitivity to New York and its people."

GRAPHIC: Table: "What the Base Commission Decided" lists decisions regarding base closings by the Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Precious Metals Advance; Grains and Soybeans Down

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Precious metals futures prices forged higher yesterday as the dollar weakened against other major currencies and South African mine labor talks reached an impasse.
On other commodity markets, grain and soybean futures fell; cattle futures rose sharply, and crude oil futures fell. 
 On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for August delivery gained $2 an ounce, to $377.30, and July silver surged 9.8 cents, to $4.49 an ounce.
Platinum for July delivery rose $3.20 on the New York Mercantile Exchange to $385.70 an ounce.
 
 
Technical Factors
 The advances extended a precious metals rally that began on Wednesday and had been attributed to currency fluctuations, inflation jitters and technical factors.
Technicals played a role again yesterday when silver broke through resistance at $4.44, touching off fresh buying.
Gold benefited from the dollar's fall against other major currencies after President Clinton was quoted as saying Senate approval of his budget cuts was a clear signal that interest rates should be kept down.
Lower interest rates make the dollar a less attractive investment, which raises demand for gold.
Support also stemmed from news that national mine workers contract talks in South Africa, a major gold and platinum producer, had reached a stalemate and were headed for arbitration.
Profit taking in the wheat and soybean pits pressed grain futures prices lower on the Chicago Board of Trade.
In addition to cashing out with big gains from rain-related soybean planting and winter wheat harvesting delays, traders began to even up their positions ahead of a Government report on prospective plantings due out Wednesday.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil for August delivery slipped 5 cents, to $18.84 a barrel; August heating oil rose 0.32 cent, to 52.28 cents a gallon; August unleaded gasoline rose 0.26 cent, to 55.01 cents a gallon, and August natural gas fell 0.2 cent, to $2.157 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: European Bank Chief Quits Amid Criticism of Spending

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, June 25

 BODY:
The chief executive of the bank set up just two years ago to help foster free market economies in Eastern Europe resigned today amid mounting questions about his spending of taxpayer money and his progress toward the bank's goal of promoting capitalism in the former Soviet bloc.
The resignation of Jacques Attali as president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development came after months of news reports about his use of expensive private jets and his spending on a lavish new headquarters building here, and just weeks before the release of an internal audit report that is expected to be highly critical of his management.
 The departure of Mr. Attali, a 49-year-old former aide to President Francois Mitterrand of France, should end a storm of bad publicity and internal bickering at the institution. But since the bank did not name a successor it raises a new question about a successor at a time when there are many concerns about the policies of the bank -- including such basic issues as whether it can effectively make loans on tough commercial terms to fledgling enterprises in formerly Communist countries, as its charter requires it to do. Some officials said Mr. Attali's departure would lead to a broad reappraisal of the operations of the bank in an effort to overcome its slow start. 
 The bank's board will hold a meeting, probably in the next several weeks, to begin the selection process, and the issue is likely to come up among representatives of the United States, the European Community and Japan at their summit meeting in Tokyo next month. Mr. Attali said he would stay on until his replacement was ready to take over.
The European Community, whose member nations own 51 percent of the bank, is likely to have the greatest say in choosing a new president. As a result, speculation centered on a European, and the names most prominently mentioned within the bank today were Karl Otto Pohl, the former president of the Bundesbank, and Jacques de Larosiere, the governor of the Bank of France.
Over the last several weeks, the bank's board has considered a plan to bring in Ernest Stern, currently the No. 2 official at the World Bank, as second in command to Mr. Attali and as day-to-day operating chief. But Mr. Stern, an American, is not seen by bank officials as a serious candidate for the top job.
 
 
A Grand Vision
 Mr. Attali, a writer and economist with no previous experience in international finance, has pursued a grand vision of using the bank to help build a politically stable and economically vibrant single market across the whole of Europe and the former Soviet Union.
His grand vision often seemed to extend to his own job, which he viewed as statesmanlike and often entailed him traveling from capital to capital by private jet, at a cost of hundreds of thousands of dollars a year.
But in recent months Mr. Attali has faced fierce criticism, both from the news media and from the nations that fund the bank with taxpayer money, including the United States, its largest financial supporter. The criticism was prompted by the disclosure in April that building and equipping the bank's lavish new headquarters in London to Mr. Attali's exacting specifications, and paying for the bank's operations, had cost $300 million -- more than the bank had channeled in loans and other aid to the emerging free-market economies in Eastern Europe.
The Financial Times quickly dubbed Mr. Attali's institution "the bank that likes to say yes -- to itself." In the United States, the House declined to appropriate the $70 million in additional capital the nation is committed to providing the bank this year, and Senate leaders said they would take the same position until the management problems at the bank were cleared up.
Since then the efforts of Mr. Attali to defend his record have been undercut by a series of disclosures about his spending, including his travel expenses, and about his work outside the bank.
 
 
Book Controversy
 In May, Mr. Attali was caught up in charges that his latest book, "Verbatim," used without attribution passages from interviews between Mr. Mitterrand and the writer Elie Wiesel. Mr. Attali's book is an account of his years working alongside Mr. Mitterrand. Similar passages based on the interviews are included in a forthcoming book by Mr. Wiesel about Mr. Mitterrand.
Mr. Attali did not deny using the passages or transposing them from 1988, when the interviews took place, to portions of his book purporting to cover events between 1982 and 1986. But he denied any suggestion of plagiarism, saying that he had been present during most of the interviews and that he had told Mr. Wiesel of his intention to quote from them.
What may have been the last straw for Mr. Attali came today, when The Financial Times reported that he was reimbursed twice for a $10,500 first-class round-trip flight to Tokyo last year. Mr. Attali said the double reimbursement had been the result of a clerical error.
The reimbursement is among a host of issues being studied by the bank's audit committee, which is due to release a report next month on the spending policies of the institution and the apparent laxity of its financial controls. The report is widely expected to be critical of the administration of Mr. Attali and of his personal expenses at the bank.
In his resignation letter, Mr. Attali defended the bank's accomplishments and his own conduct.
"As you know, the bank has come under increasing negative press attention in recent months," Mr. Attali said in the letter to Anne Wibble, Sweden's Finance Minister and chairman of the bank's board. "I know of no action that I have taken that in any way could be worthy of reproach. Unfortunately, this attention has begun to have a detrimental effect on the bank's work, and on its staff, and it is with the interests of the bank in mind that I have taken this decision."
Scott Dykema, a spokesman for the United States Treasury, said the spending excesses at the bank under Mr. Attali had been regrettable.
"The bank must now focus on quickly fixing its management problems and then, of course, getting on with the business of supporting the economic reforms of Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union," Mr. Dykema said.
Representative David R. Obey, a Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the House Appropriations Committee's Subcommittee on Foreign Operations, said the bank should move vigorously to "clean up its act" after Mr. Attali's resignation.
Asserting the resignation was overdue, Mr. Obey said he would continue to oppose any American funds for the bank until it carried out large-scale reforms in handling taxpayers' money.

HEADLINE: U.S. Finds 'Cheerleading' In Monitoring of Empire

BYLINE: By DEAN BAQUET

 BODY:
A United States Senate subcommittee examining Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield criticizes state insurance regulators, who missed even the most obvious signs of trouble, and expensive auditors, who made only the most cursory examinations of the company. But it says that at the heart of Empire's deep financial crisis is the "gross mismanagement" of the company's own top executives.
The 200-page report offers a devastating portrait of the company that insures 8.2 million people, mostly in New York. It charges that Empire is losing money because of service so abysmal that some of the biggest institutions in America -- from Fortune 500 companies to universities and labor unions -- have dropped their insurance policies and turning elsewhere, even if they have to pay more. 
 And it portrays a company so badly run that it cannot perform even the most basic tasks of an insurance company -- setting prices, paying doctors and hospitals and reimbursing customers.
In a news conference, Harold E. Vogt, Empire's chairman, called the report "one-sided," denied that the company was mismanaged and offered statististics to buttress the company's claims of efficiency. He said the company would defend itself next week, when its representatives are scheduled to testify before the committee.
 
Collapse of Regulation
 The committee's report, the result of a six-month investigation, is based on interviews with dozens of present and former Empire executives and board members, and a review of internal company records.
The report describes a system of insurance regulation that in the case of Empire virtually collapsed.
The Insurance Department abdicated its responsibility to regulate Empire, the report said, and took the company at its word when it blamed all of its problems on unfair competition from for-profit insurance companies. The committee said the department and its Superintendent, Salvatore R. Curiale, seemed almost paralyzed by the fear of doing anything to harm a company whose collapse might leave some of the poorest and sickest New Yorkers without health insurance.
Indeed, the report concluded that the department, one of the best-financed and largest in the nation, acted more like a "cheerleader for Empire's cause" than an "aggressive regulator." And it described a pattern of inaction that it said "bordered on favoritism."
 
An Advocate for Empire
 "This pattern," it said, "included a propensity by the department to reverse itself when such action would be to Empire's benefit, the failure by the department to enforce its authority over Empire in certain instances, a willingness on the department's part to allow Empire to ignore department recommendations and regulations with impunity, and the transformation of the department into an advocate on behalf of Empire."
Kevin Foley, the Insurance Department's deputy superintendent, said it had been aggressive in regulating Empire. He also said there was nothing wrong with being concerned about the company's customers.
The report also strongly criticized a state-sponsored study by Arthur Andersen & Company Associates, the accounting and consulting firm. Concerned about this year's 25 percent rate increase, the State Legislature paid Arthur Andersen about $2 million to do an exhaustive examination of Empire's management. After the examination, the accounting firm said that while Empire had some management problems, it was losing money because of "cherry-picking," the drawing away of its healthier customers by competing for-profit companies, who did not have to insure everyone.
 
Audit Called Unskeptical
 But in a section titled "Arthur Andersen: A Flawed Report," the Senate subcommittee attacked the audit as an unskeptical look at the insurance company's finances. It said Arthur Andersen failed to interview any Empire customers, or former executives who might shed light on Empire's management problems.
The subcommittee report said the accounting firm probably should not have been given the contract because it had a potential conflict of interest: its consulting arm had done work for Empire. And it quoted a partner in the firm, Eric P. Edelstein, acknowledging that one reason the firm had sought to win the contract was as a way to get business from other Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans.
Mr. Edelstein said today that he would have no "specific comment" about the criticisms until he received a copy of the committee report. But in general, he said, "we fully stand by our work product in its entirety.
 
Entitled to Rent Limousine
 Although the report criticizes the system that regulated Empire and the accountants hired to audit the company, it saves its harshest words for the insurer itself. Empire's management is too arrogant to take blame for the problem, the report asserted, or to give up luxuries that rival those of executives at big for-profit corporations.
When his company limousine broke down, Empire's chairman, Albert A. Cardone, rented one for two months -- at a cost of $11,000, according to the report. When the subcommittee asked why he did not use one of the company's pool cars, the committee said that Mr. Cardone responded, "I was recruited by this company and I was promised a car."
Empire's board members were wined and dined at lavish retreats, where the annual themes ran from Broadway to Art Deco, the report said. At one retreat, board members received gift baskets, luggage, and Tiffany decanters. The subject of one session: "Cost Containment."
In 1990, according to the report, Empire spent $17,000 to on buy cashmere blankets for its board members. It paid $2,000 on Tiffany mugs for retired board members.
Mr. Vogt dismissed charges of excessive spending on perquisites, including the gifts to board members. "I don't believe it was extravagant," he said.
 
Unwillingness to Save
 The subcommittee has investigated other Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans across the country, and the executive spending at Empire is similar to the others. Indeed, some operate even more lavishly than Empire. But the report said that the perquisites, although only a small part of the company's costs, reflected an unwillingness to contain costs.
And in the area of mismanagement and poor service, the report detailed a situation at Empire that appears far more serious than at other Blue Cross plans. The most damaging evidence came from Empire's customers, whose stories offer powerful evidence to contradict the company's assertions that it is losing money because of unfair competition from for-profit insurance companies.
Subcommittee investigators interviewed officials of 42 large companies that have left Empire for other insurers. Most left the company because of poor service or excessive prices, the report said.
 
'Dealing With a Black Hole'
 "Dealing with Empire was like dealing with a black hole," said one unnamed executive in the report. Another said: "Let me put it this way. I have a full crop of gray hair and every damned one of them came as a result of my dealings with Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield."
In one case cited by the committee, an Empire customer submitted a claim for $2,600, and received four checks for $2,600 each. When she called Empire's service representatives about the mistake, she was told that this "was her lucky day" and that she should keep the checks.
Recounting how Empire came to lose $250 million in three years, the committee said, "Gross mismanagement, wasteful expenditures, fraud, and a history of inattentiveness and non-action by its board of directors and the State Insurance Department have made it critically ill."
The report also criticized Empire for awarding a highly technical, multi-million dollar computer contract to a new company set up by a board member -- a dentist with scant computer experience.
 
Odd Job for Dentist
 Empire selected Sigma Imaging Systems, headed by Dr. William N. Stratigos, after dismissing the more experienced company it had previously hired. Dr. Stratigos had also been the dentist for Edwin Werner, Empire's former chief executive, and other top company officials.
The subcommittee report said that Sigma's work, which began five years ago, was far behind schedule. In the meantime, the company that was dismissed has already completed a similar system for another company.
After reviewing the arrangement, the subcommittee concluded, "Dr. Stratigos and Sigma were awarded a very important and extremely lucrative contract without any competitive bidding and apparently only because of Dr. Stratigos' special relationship to Mr. Werner, the former C.E.O., as his personal dentist and being a voting member of the board."

HEADLINE: Annuities Help Feather Retirement Nests

BYLINE: JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:
Many people nearing retirement fear that if today's low interest rates continue, they will live more like paupers than princes. To be sure they will have the income they need, they are buying record amounts of variable-rate annuities, which mimic mutual funds but have the added appeal of tax deferral.
"With the expected increases in tax rates, tax deferral becomes even more significant, and people of all ages may want to consider annuities for their long-term investments," said Avery E. Neumark, a partner in Weber, Lipshie & Company, a Manhattan-based accounting firm. "I would first encourage clients to take full advantage of plans that use pretax dollars like a 401(k) plan," he said, "then use annuities for additional investments." 
 John Febles, president of Professional Clinical Labs, a Manhattan medical laboratory, fits the profile of the typical buyer. He is approaching 50 and looking for a comfortable retirement cushion. Having already invested his business's pension plan with Metropolitan Life, he is considering a $50,000 investment in a variable annuity from the insurer.
The annuity packs a punch from tax benefits. If it and a comparable mutual fund each grew 10 percent annually, the tax-deferred holding would be worth $208,863 when Mr. Febles is 65, but the mutual fund, assuming a 31 percent tax rate, would be worth only $136,031.
When payments were made from the annuity, he would have to pay taxes on the growth portion, but not on the part that is a return of capital.
"I'm a very conservative person," Mr. Febles said, "and I believe the Met Life annuity will provide a good retirement income with minimal risk." He said he also wanted professional financial management, so he could concentrate on his business.
Although variable annuities have an insurance "wrapper" guaranteeing their payouts, their returns come from an underlying portfolio that can include stocks, bonds and other investments managed by a brokerage house, mutual fund or professional money manager. The annuities, available from insurance companies, banks and brokers, offer holders flexibility in switching portfolios and eventually in structuring withdrawals. Furthermore, because after-tax money is used, there are no investment limits.
Sales of variable annuities rose 55 percent in the first four months of this year, to $9.525 billion from $6.150 billion a year earlier, according to the Investment Company Institute. They increased sixfold from $3.068 billion in 1988 to $19.469 billion last year.
Unlike fixed-rate annuities, which now yield only about 4.5 percent, variable-rate products are chalking up strong returns. Wood Logan Associates Inc. of Old Greenwich, Conn., an independent marketer of annuities and mutual funds, offers a stock portfolio managed by Goldman, Sachs that achieved a total return of 18.9 percent last year. Its global portfolio, managed by Oechsle International, grew 19.5 percent, and its moderate asset allocation fund with both stocks and bonds, managed by Fidelity Investments, grew 9.5 percent.
Despite the potential returns, variable annuities are not for everyone. One reason is that they are long-term investments that can entail expensive surrender charges if holdings are liquidated in less than seven or eight years. Also, if an investor begins withdrawals before age 59 1/2, there is a 10 percent tax penalty.
Variable annuities are particularly attractive to people who have "a very long-term investment horizon," especially those over age 50, said Tim Kochis, a partner in Kochis & Fitz, a San Francisco-based fee-only financial planning firm. "The tax-deferred compounding can continue almost indefinitely -- you don't have to start taking money out until you're 85." The I.R.S. requires that withdrawals from most retirement plans, including I.R.A.'s, begin after age 70 1/2.
If an annuity holder dies, the estate is guaranteed the original investment less any withdrawals, though some plans offer more generous terms.
Mr. Neumark, who as a benefits specialist at Weber, Lipshie, reviewed Mr. Febles's choice, said investors should take care in choosing an annuity, particularly checking out the insurer underwriting it.
"Buy only from an insurance carrier with the highest rating," from A. M. Best, Moody's or Standard & Poor's, he said.
And keep in mind that top ratings do not guarantee health. Executive Life and Mutual Benefit had high ratings before they collapsed, leaving annuity holders unsure of how much they would recover, and when.
"Then look for hidden charges for administration and surrender fees," disclosed in the prospectus, Mr. Neumark said, noting that fees can reduce an expected return by up to 2 percentage points. "And compare fund performances with the S.& P. 500" or a bond index, if appropriate. He also advised people putting in a large amount to get a disinterested expert evaluation.

LENGTH: 372 words

HEADLINE: Dreamland, N.J.

 BODY:
It's every incumbent politician's dream -- an election-year tax cut. In New Jersey, Republicans in the State Assembly fancied that a cut in the personal income tax this year would put Gov. Jim Florio on the spot and, of course, enhance their own popularity. But the politically astute Governor has pulled a fast one and also lobbied for a tax cut -- not as big as the G.O.P.'s, but still a cut.
A scorecard may help here: Governor Florio, a Democrat, is seeking a second term. But the huge tax increase he pushed through the then-Democratic Legislature three years ago was so unpopular that a year later the Republicans won veto-proof majorities in both houses. Thus chastened, Mr. Florio is unlikely to force another showdown on taxes anytime soon. 
 The Legislature has just passed a $15.4 billion budget for the year that starts July 1. For the most part it follows Mr. Florio's January budget, except that it earmarks $150 million as a "taxpayer relief fund." The Governor calls it a "slush fund," and may yet seek to strike it out. In any event, the game is more political than fiscal.
Even the Republicans are split on this one. The leader of the Assembly wants to cut the personal income tax now. The Senate president and the Assembly Budget Committee chairman are against it. And their party's gubernatorial candidate, Christine Todd Whitman, seems to lean toward a cut, but hedges by saying she wants to see what spending would be cut or revenues raised to compensate.
It is too early to know if there is room for a tax cut in the 1994 budget, because the state's economic recovery is still hesitant. And unless the upturn gathers unexpected strength, a tax cut in 1994 would surely mean more trouble balancing the budget for 1995, when a new gap of at least $1 billion will have to be closed by one means or another.
New Jersey, like other states from coast to coast, has lately been hard pressed to balance each year's budget. In the process it has resorted to one-shot savings and gimmickry, like selling pieces of state highway to the New Jersey Turnpike Authority. There will be time enough to cut taxes when budget conditions truly improve. For now, fiscal prudence says no to electioneering tax cuts.

HEADLINE: Equivalency Diploma Still Has Value

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your June 15 article questioning the value of the General Education Development diploma, especially relating to New York City, misses or misstates several salient points. 
 Nobody "encourages" students to drop out of school to prepare for the G.E.D. The G.E.D. becomes an option -- perhaps the only option -- for a student who has no chance of earning all the required credits for a standard diploma before reaching 21, the age at which New York State withdraws funds for school attendance.
In addition, the bulk of registrants in preparation programs for the General Education Development diploma have left school months or years before re-enrolling in a test-preparation program. Increasingly, immigrants, who enter the country far too late to complete a full high school diploma, are enrolling.
The G.E.D. is not intended as a substitute for standard high school course work. Each year, the test is "normed" by being administered to thousands of high school seniors across the United States. To receive a G.E.D. diploma, a candidate must outperform the average high school senior taking the examination.
In New York State, the required passing score is higher than in many other states, so that recipients of the diploma in New York score at approximately the 60th percentile, nationally. In short, a G.E.D. diploma means that the student has done better at reading, writing and computing than the average high school graduate across the country.
Finally, the number of students pursuing G.E.D.'s is directly related to the educational inflation that has taken place since the early 1970's. People who dropped out of high school in the 1960's could still get jobs, without high school diplomas. Today, a high school diploma -- of any kind -- is needed even for the lowest-paying job.
As Ray Domanico, director of the Manhattan Institute's Center for Educational Innovation, whom you quote, pointed out, "Students leaving with a G.E.D. are better having one than not."
 
STEPHEN E. PHILLIPS
Superintendent, Alternative High Schools and Programs, Board of Education
New York, June 17, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: 2 Tell Subcommittee Insurer Altered Data In Order to Mislead

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
Two former employees of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield appeared before a United States Senate subcommittee today and gave the first public evidence that the nation's largest nonprofit health insurer intentionally misled the New York State Legislature and Insurance Department for years.
The witnesses said they were told by Empire's chief financial officer that loss figures sent to the state had been "manipulated" to make them "politically correct." They said they were transferred from the company's executive suite after discovering that Empire kept two sets of books. And one said that Empire officials joked about the two sets of numbers at a party. 
 The testimony of Joan Boyle, a former vice president of Empire, and William Fuessler, who worked for Ms. Boyle, came as the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations released a searing report that, among other things, criticized state insurance regulators who missed obvious signs of trouble at Empire. It also said that auditors hired by the state did only the most cursory of examinations.
But the report levied its harshest assessment against the insurer itself, blaming much of Empire's financial crisis on "gross mismanagement" and lavish spending. [Page 24.]
Ms. Boyle and Mr. Fuessler testified that a month before they were transferred, they had stumbled on a discrepancy between a secret set of financial documents and the reports the company had filed with the state.
Known as the "Black Book," the secret documents contained figures that showed that Empire had lost substantially less money on its high-risk accounts than the company had reported to regulators.
In documents released by the Senate today, Empire's chief financial officer, Jerry Weissman, is quoted as saying he changed numbers on financial reports at the behest of Empire's chief executive and chairman at the time, Albert A. Cardone.
Mr. Weissman could not be reached for comment today. Mr. Cardone's lawyer, Steven Thal, said that he had not had time to analyze the report and the testimony, but believed that there was an innocent explanation.
 
Losses Exaggerated
 Mr. Boyle and Mr. Fuessler made the discovery in February 1992, as Empire was in the final stages of a fierce lobbying campaign for a change in state law that would force its competitors to also accept high-risk customers.
Empire officials acknowledged last week that inaccurate numbers were sent to the state, but said they were unsure if that had been intentional.
Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who is the chairman of the subcommittee, said that Ms. Boyle and Mr. Fuessler provided a "strong case that misleading information had been passed on to the state," and added that the panel would decide next week, after the hearings are completed, whether to refer the matter for criminal prosecution.
 
No Explanations
 The unexpected emergence of Ms. Boyle and Mr. Fuessler prompted Senate investigators to cancel the appearances today of a string of Empire officials, including Mr. Cardone. He is now to testify on Wednesday, when the hearings reconvene.
Instead, Ms. Boyle and Mr. Fuessler, whose story became known to the investigators only days ago, told a tale of intrigue in the executive offices that prompted them to leave the company within months. Neither came forward voluntarily, investigators said. Each was subpoenaed and testified with lawyers at their sides, sometimes whispering in their ears.
The first hint that something was amiss came in early 1992, when Mr. Fuessler, an accountant, was reviewing some financial documents for a presentation to company officials on executive bonuses. "I just happened to see a number that didn't look right," he recalled.
Mr. Fuessler, who had worked for Empire for about 18 months, compared the documents that had been filed with the state against a set of internal records called the Black Book, which circulated only among certain high-ranking executives.
Puzzled by discrepancies, he asked the actuarial department for an explanation, he said. But the actuaries told him they could not give an explanation and told him to consult Jerry Weissman, the chief financial officer.
Instead, he spoke to Ms. Boyle, his superior. At the time, Ms. Boyle, who had been the executive vice president and chief financial officer of the New Jersey Blue Cross plan, had worked at Empire for about three months.
Ms. Boyle said she had been familiar with the Black Book and believed that it held "the most-up-to-date figures on Empire's gains and losses," and that only Mr. Cardone and Mr. Weissman had copies.
She waited until most of the staff had gone home to confront Mr. Weissman, she recalled. "When I showed Jerry the numbers, he appeared nervous," she said. She quoted Mr. Weissman as saying, "The Black Book numbers were for internal purposes and the actuarial numbers were for external purposes."
When she asked Mr. Weissman which numbers were accurate, "He said that the Black Book figures were right and the others were more politically acceptable," she recalled.
"I was very disturbed by this and told Jerry that he had a professional obligation to consistently report accurate figures," she said, adding that Mr. Weissman then "folded his arms and told me that I should talk to Al."
The following day, she said, she confronted Mr. Cardone, who "told me he didn't know anything about it."
But Mr. Cardone added, she recalled, "Nobody knows what figures are right."
The incident was so disturbing, she said, that she went home and wrote a memo for her files about the events of the previous days. She produced the memo for the Senate investigators.
She said Mr. Cardone began treating her coolly and stopped inviting her to meetings. Within a month, she and Mr. Fuessler were moved to different jobs in another building.
Several months later, at a reception for the company's board of directors, Mr. Fuessler found himself among a group of managers who were laughing about the discrepancies. "It was taken on the light side, the fact that there were two sets of books," Mr. Fuessler recalled.
By the end of the year, both Mr. Fuessler and Ms. Boyle quit Empire.
They said they were not sure why the company kept two sets of books, but believed that the false numbers showing inflated losses on high-risk accounts were used by the company to seek rate increases from the state. The losses apparently were shifted from segments of Empire's business that are less closely regulated by the insurance department, they said.
Harold E. Vogt, Empire's chairman, said at a news conference this afternoon that the company was surprised by the testimony, and that neither he nor Donald L. Morchower, the company's acting chief executive, had ever met Ms. Boyle or Mr. Fuessler or been aware of their discovery.
Asked about the existence of two sets of books, Mr. Vogt responded: "We don't have an explanation. That's currently under investigation." And he added a little later, "If in fact we find this to be true, it doesn't paint a very good picture of how Empire handled things."
 
 
 
AT A GLANCE
GIFTS AND OTHER SPENDING AT EMPIRE
 A report released by a United States subcommitee report cited perquisites that it said reflected a "blue chip mentality of Empire executives." It said the company "operates as if it is a profitable Fortune 500 company, rather than a non-profit health insurer." Here are some of the items included in the report.
 
DIAMONDS, PEARLS AND OTHER GIFTS
About $255,000 in 1992 and more than $1.1 million over the last five years for gifts to employees from the specially designed Empire gift catalogue. They included diamond and sapphire jewelry, Waterford crystal, pearl necklaces, gold wristwatches engraved with the Empire logo, grandfather clocks, carriage clocks and wall clocks. There also were presents of up to $2,500 in cash.
 
CARTIER'S AND TIFFANY'S
About $58,000 in gifts from corporate accounts at Tiffany's and Cartier's over the last seven years to employees and others.
 
LIMOUSINES
More than $226,000 on limousines over the last six years, with $50,000 last year and $91,000 in 1991, the two years that Empire lost more than $250 million.
$11,000 was spent in two months by Albert Cardone, the former chairman and chief executive, an average of $300 a trip from his home in New Canaan, Conn., to his office in Manhattan.
 
EXECUTIVE TRAVEL
$30,000 for a Lincoln Town Car for Mr. Cardone. The company also paid for his chauffeur, who also served as an armed bodyguard.
 
PERSONAL SECURITY SYSTEM
$17,000 to install a security system at Mr Cardone's house, plus $2,000 a year in maintenance.
 
EXECUTIVE APARTMENT
$48,000 per year for a corporate apartment at the Dumont Plaza in Manhattan for the chairman's use. Empire ended the arrangement in 1989, because Mr Cardone wanted accomodations with 24-hour food service.
 
CHRISTMAS PRESENTS
$3,700 for ginger jars for retired directors and $14,133 for silver punch bowls and ladles for the 19 active board members in 1991.
 
SEMINARS FOR THE BOARD
An average of about $142,000 for annual weekend seminars for board members, usually held at hotels outside of New York City. The events often had themes, like "Amadeus" in 1990. At that one, as part of its masquerade motif, almost $3,000 was spent for 147 masks and another $2,500 to decorate the room. At least $25,000 more was spent on Ghurka bags, golf umbrellas and gift baskets.
 
 
 
GLOSSARY
Insurance Terms
 High-Risk Pool: The group of 2 million New Yorkers, including the bulk of the state's oldest and sickest residents, who receive insurance from Empire, often because private companies reject them. The pool is comprised of individuals and those in groups of under 50.
 
Cherry-Picking: The practice of passing over insurance risks, like the elderly, and seeking only the healthiest customers.
 
Blue Cross Blue Shield: The trademark name for a network of 70 independent nonprofit insurers that account for 20 percent of the nation's private health insurance market. The companies are committed to insure the oldest and sickest customers, who cannot get insurance elsewhere. In return, they receive favored tax treatment and discounts.
 
For-Profit Insurers: Companies, like MetLife and Equitable, that try to generate profit for shareholders. They are often called "commercial" insurers.
