HEADLINE: Court Again Rejects a Limit on Punitive Damages

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 25

 BODY:
The Supreme Court today upheld a $10 million award of punitive damages for a $19,000 injury in a ruling that once again dashed the hopes of critics of the civil justice system who wanted the Court to place a meaningful constitutional limit on punitive damages.
The 6-to-3 ruling made little if any new law and was not supported by a single majority opinion. It was the fifth time in recent years that the Justices did not issue a definitive ruling on punitive damages after suggesting that they were troubled by the issue. 
 In a plurality opinion by Justice John Paul Stevens, the Court upheld a ruling by the West Virginia Supreme Court of Appeals, which in turn had upheld a jury's verdict in a case involving disputed rights to an oil field in McDowell County, W. Va.
The jury found that the TXO Production Corporation, a subsidiary of the USX Corporation, acted in bad faith when it brought a frivolous lawsuit intended to deprive another company, Alliance Resources Inc., of oil and natural gas royalties that TXO had promised to pay Alliance in return for Alliance's rights to the property.
 
Legal Strategy Vindicated
 Justice Stevens said that while there was a dramatic and even "shocking disparity" between the $19,000 that Alliance spent fighting the frivolous lawsuit and the $10 million it won in punitive damages, "that shock dissipates" in light of the millions of dollars that Alliance stood to lose had it not managed to defend itself and preserve its right to the royalties.
The outcome vindicated the strategy of Alliance's lawyer, Laurence H. Tribe, the Harvard Law School professor whom the company hired to defend the award after the Supreme Court agreed to hear TXO's appeal.
Mr. Tribe came up with the idea of defending the award on the basis of the "expected gain" or potential harm from the thwarted fraud, a rationale that was not part of the original case and that the Court had not previously considered.
When the case was argued in March, Mr. Tribe asked the Court to disregard the fact that the punitive damage award was 526 times greater than the actual damages, and instead to consider that it was at most twice the size of the $5 million at stake in the dispute.
During the argument, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, the Court's leading critic of punitive damages, accused Mr. Tribe of "trying to concoct something" by presenting a new theory with figures that had not been tested in the trial court. But Mr. Tribe's gambit worked, and Justice O'Connor expressed her frustration today in a dissenting opinion that described the expected gain theory as "having been produced exclusively for our consumption."
Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justice Harry A. Blackmun joined the plurality opinion of Justice Stevens. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy voted separately to uphold the punitive damage award, as did Justice Antonin Scalia in a separate opinion that Justice Clarence Thomas also signed. Justices Byron R. White and David H. Souter joined the dissent.
 
Insurance Fraud Case Cited
 The question in the case, TXO Production v. Alliance Resources, No. 92-479, was whether the damage award violated the 14th Amendment's guarantee of due process of law either as a matter of substance or procedure.
The substantive question was whether the award was so "grossly excessive" and disproportionate to the harm as to be arbitrary and oppressive. Two years ago, in a case called Pacific Mutual Life Insurance Company v. Haslip, the Court said the due process clause did place some outer limit on punitive damages.
In upholding an award of punitive damages in that insurance fraud case, in which the award was four times the size of the actual damages, the Court said the 4-to-1 ratio "may be close to the line." So when the Court last December agreed to hear TXO's appeal in a case with a 526-to-1 ratio, many people assumed that the Justices would find the line to have been crossed.
The award was "certainly large," Justice Stevens said. But he added that the award was justified by the amount of money at stake, the "bad faith" of TXO, that company's wealth and "the fact that the scheme employed in this case was part of a larger pattern of fraud, trickery and deceit."
The second, procedural question was whether the West Virginia Supreme Court had given meaningful appellate review to the award. Justice Stevens found that it had, despite an opinion by one of the West Virginia Justices, Richard Neely, who wrote that a "really mean" defendant like TXO deserved to be assessed punitive damages of more than 500 times the harm it caused. Justice Stevens said that Justice Neely's "colorful reference" did not determine the outcome of the case.
 
Justice O'Connor in Dissent
 In her dissenting opinion, Justice O'Connor said the Court's ruling two years ago in the Haslip case "held out the promise that punitive damages awards would receive sufficient constitutional scrutiny to restore fairness in what is rapidly becoming an arbitrary and oppressive system." But today's decision "renders Haslip's promise a false one," she said.
The search for limitations on punitive damages, both in court and through legislation, has long been on the agenda of critics of the civil litigation system. Business groups, municipalities and other defendants in punitive damages cases appeal many cases to the Supreme Court every year.
It is possible that the Justices will select one of them for another effort at addressing the issue. A case involving negligence rather than a commercial dispute would remove the factor of expected economic gain from consideration and perhaps put the defendant in a more favorable light.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
The Small-Yield and Sound-Sleep School of Investment

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:
Some investors could not care less about stocks, options or even mutual funds. They want complete safety -- a Federal Government guarantee -- and are willing to sacrifice some yield to get it.
Among these investments, the best bet is Treasury securities, with interest rates at 3.35 for one-year bills and yields at 5.10 for five-year notes. "I recommend this alternative for those seeking the highest quality, lowest-risk alternative," said Lewis J. Altfest, president of L. J. Altfest & Company, New York financial planners. 
 A big advantage of Treasury securities is that they offer interest income exempt from state and local taxes, meaning the tax-equivalent yield for people in high-tax locales like New York is even higher. They can be bought at no charge from any Federal Reserve bank or at a small fee from a brokerage firm or bank.
Another investment backed by the full faith and credit of the Government is a United States Savings Bond, available at many banks and through payroll deductions at some companies. The guaranteed interest rate on bonds held for six months or more was lowered to 4 percent from 6 percent on March 1. But investors who hold these securities for at least five years will receive a market-based rate, which is adjusted twice a year to 85 percent of the average return for five-year Treasury notes. That rate will be 4.78 percent for bonds purchased through Oct. 31.
Like Treasury securities, these bonds are exempt from state and local taxes. The Federal tax can be deferred until the bonds are redeemed. And if they are redeemed to pay for college tuition, a Federal tax break may be claimed, depending on adjusted gross income.
Bank certificates of deposit -- insured up to $100,000 by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation -- are the most convenient choice for many of the risk-averse. To get the most out of C.D.'s, whose one-year rates average 3.11 percent and five-year rates average 4.9 percent, split up the money, "laddering" the maturities.
"If you have $100,000 to invest, I would divide the assets into five parts of $20,000 each and buy five C.D.'s with maturities ranging from one year to five years," said Bill E. Carter, president of Carter Financial Management in Dallas. "If interest rates turn back up, you are not totally locked into low rates."
Janet Steig, president of the Crossroads Financial Group in Roseland, N.J., said, "You should never give up sleep at night to get return if you are not comfortable with the investment."

HEADLINE: Dr. Jeffrey Sachs, Shock Therapist

BYLINE: By Peter Passell; Peter Passell is an economics writer for The New York Times.

 BODY:
The lobby of the Metropole, Moscow's lovingly restored grand hotel a few blocks from Red Square, is almost deserted on this gray spring afternoon. That's just fine with Jeffrey D. Sachs, a boyish-looking 38-year-old Harvard professor who is now probably the most important economist in the world. He has appropriated a cluster of comfortable armchairs for a meeting with two members of his team, Americans who work full time in Russia.
The agenda is Russia's safety net or, more precisely, whether unemployed workers will be able to make ends meet. Russia is plunging out of Communism, if not directly into a capitalist free market. Whether this huge, humiliated nation will stoically bear the pain of the transition is far from clear, and the strength of the safety net could make the difference. 
 There are plenty of laws on the books, but do they count? "All Russian citizens are legally entitled to free health care," points out Judith Shapiro, a senior lecturer on policy economics who is on leave from Goldsmith College at the University of London. The catch: they often "only get what they pay for."
While employees of Government and big enterprises generally have access to adequate service at their own clinics, the less fortunate are denied modern surgery, drugs and even decent sanitation. The problem is apparently growing worse, she notes, because inflation has far outpaced physicians' salaries, which weren't high to begin with. Many are now emigrating, or deserting their posts for more lucrative jobs, like driving taxis.
Sachs's immediate concern is the implication for the Government's budget, which must be slashed in order to bring inflation under control. If much of the nation's health expenditures are now buried as fringe benefits on the books of enterprises that depend on Government subsidies, who will pick up the cost once the enterprises are forced to economize?
Getting a handle on the magnitude of the problem is obviously difficult in a country that cannot even explain why life expectancy has fallen sharply in the last two decades. But some number is better than none. And by pressing officials to address this and other pivotal issues, Sachs hopes to accelerate the pace of reform.
Sachs's message of urgency is not universally accepted. Plenty of Western as well as Russian economists contend that a more gradual approach is not only possible but necessary. "Economic reform is a political process," says Padma Desai at the Harriman Institute at Columbia University. "First, you must build consensus."
And even his sympathizers acknowledge that Sachs's high profile and world-class impatience could generate a backlash in a nation still adjusting to the reality that it is no longer a superpower. "There's a real dilemma here," says Stanley Fischer, an international economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "You have to make a lot of noise to get the attention of the West. But the more noise you make, the more you make it seem that the reform program is a Western program. And that could be the kiss of death."
Still, Sachs's brand of "shock therapy" has worked elsewhere. And there is good reason to believe that Russia's future will turn on how well its leaders learn the catechism of change that he has worked so hard to promulgate.
TO AN AMERICAN JADED BY THE CHOICE OF breakfast flakes with or without bran, dates, sugar-coated raisins and 12 essential vitamins, there's nothing much to tease the palate or the eye in the Gastronom Smolensk near the center of Moscow. Deli counters, dominated by slabs of butter and wheels of stuff that must be cheese, are still presided over by gorgons in white smocks. Cans of vegetables still bear labels that look like rejects from high-school print shop. Odors of sour milk, industrial cleaner and damp wool assault the senses.
But Sachs recognizes what skeptics often miss. "You should have seen these food stores before the price reforms," he exclaims. Those were the lean years of perestroika, when everything but the dregs ended up in the commissaries of the well connected or fell off the backs of trucks on the trip from the warehouse.
Yes, there still are queues. But the lines are a result of socialist retailing practices, not food shortages. Shoppers first wait to pick out items for weighing and pricing. Then it's on to the cashier's line, where, after interminable delay, they exchange their rubles for receipts. Then it's back to the food-counter line to collect their 200 grams of smoked fish or half-kilo of margarine.
But goods are largely being allocated by price, notes Sachs, "rather than by whom you know." And the daily frustrations of shopping will be eased when privatized stores discover that supermarket-style checkout saves scads of money.
It's easy to overlook the significance of these modest signs of progress, and many Russians and Western intellectuals do. In spite of the strong popular vote of confidence that Boris Yeltsin won in the April referendum, they view Sachs's relentless optimism about Russia's capacity for rapid change as a denial of the inertia of a thousand years of Slavic feudalism.
But it is precisely Sachs's impatience, bolstered by seemingly infinite energy and a sophisticated grasp of modern economics, that has made him a force to reckon with. As an adviser to reform-minded governments from Bolivia to Slovenia to Poland, Sachs led successful battles for fiscal and monetary discipline in economies written off by more cautious practitioners of the dismal science. And as a fierce advocate of international debt relief for essentially bankrupt countries, he helped break the financial gridlock that consigned Latin America to economic stagnation for much of the 1980's. Now he is prodding the radicals who sometimes have the ear of Boris Yeltsin to press their advantage while they can.
"Poland, with its reforms in place, is the fastest-growing economy in Eastern Europe," says Sachs. "If Poland can do it, so can Russia."
SACHS, A specialist in monetary theory and international finance, started down the road to fame and controversy by accident. True, he was a prodigy at Harvard, passing his general exams for a Ph.D. in economics while still in college. And he was invited to join the university's Society of Fellows, an honor that might not qualify the recipient as a Friend of Bill but confers more status in academia than a Rhodes scholarship. And he won tenure in one of the nation's best economics departments at the age of 29.
But what might have been merely a distinguished scholarly career took an abrupt turn toward the practical in 1985. Harvard was host to a group of Bolivians, Sachs recalls, including one of his former students -- "and I was the only economist on the faculty to show up."
At the time Bolivia, the poorest country in South America, was suffering what may have been the most virulent inflation any economy has ever suffered outside wartime -- an astounding 24,000 percent annual rate. When the discussion turned to the near impossibility of stabilizing prices without triggering a killer recession, Sachs demurred. The least painful way to beat inflation, he argued, was a clean break with the past, a regimen of fiscal and monetary discipline combined with an end to economic regulation that protected the elites and blocked the free market. "If you think you can do it," challenged one official, "come to Bolivia and prove it."
He did, and quickly persuaded the newly elected Government to go along. Within weeks, hyperinflation was only a bad memory. And after months of tense negotiation, the country settled its mountain of debt to international lenders for about 11 cents on the dollar. "What Bolivia showed," concludes Sachs, "is that stabilization is doable, possible, sustainable."
As Sachs is the first to admit, what later become known as shock therapy was not plucked whole from thin air -- similar approaches had more or less worked in Germany after both world wars. Sachs's special insight was that the logic could apply to economies with no collective memory of free markets or history of evenhanded rules of contract law and property rights. In fact, he is confident that revolution is the natural means of economic change. "If you look at how reform has occurred, it has been through the rapid adaptation of foreign models," he concludes, "not a slow evolution of modern institutions."
Poland's success in stabilizing its currency and jump-starting growth is potent evidence that Sachs is right. But no test could be tougher -- or more important -- than the effort to transform the Russia of Stalin, Brezhnev and Gorbachev into a prosperous, consumer-driven economy in a single generation.
THE PRESSURE IS ON this morning in Sachs's temporary Moscow headquarters, a tiny suite in the Ministry of Labor that he and his assistants share with a group from the London School of Economics, two quietly efficient translators, a welter of computer equipment and a few empty pizza boxes. (Yes, they deliver in Russia.) A more comfortable home in the Ministry of Finance is still weeks away.
Topic A is the new agreement between the Finance Ministry and the Russian Central Bank, intended to tame the inflation that is running at 20 to 30 percent a month. It is, in Sachs's view, a cancer on the economy that is close to metastasis. Sachs has been deeply frustrated by the fatalism and political drift over the past year that has brought the economy to the brink. "Nobody says that 26 percent a month inflation is deeply ingrained in the Russian soul," he scoffs.
In most successful economies the central bank acts as a bulwark against politicians who have trouble denying goodies to their constituents. But in today's Russia the roles are reversed. Boris Fyodorov, the finance minister whom Sachs admiringly characterizes as "utterly matter of fact, not prone to rhetorical flourishes," is resolved to curb the inflationary budget deficit. But Viktor Gerashchenko, the chairman of the Central Bank, is an old-school bureaucrat who is publicly skeptical that capitalist monetary theory applies to the Motherland.
More to the point, Gerashchenko owes some allegiance to the Parliament, which is dominated by former Communists, pragmatic provincial pols and enterprise managers who share a common desire to keep the socialist patronage machine creaking along. And this means easy credit for giant state-owned enterprises that had always depended on a single customer -- a Moscow ministry -- to tell them what to make and where to get the materials.
Gerashchenko has also been playing Uncle Sugar to the former Soviet republics, handing out rubles to republic enterprises that are Russian industries' best -- sometimes only -- foreign customers. Sachs estimates that one-tenth of Russia's productive capacity last year was devoted to propping up the periphery of the old Soviet empire, with the ruble payments surging back to stoke the incipient hyperinflation.
Now -- thanks in no small part to Sachs's tireless lobbying -- America and the other rich countries have at long last assembled a hard-currency life raft to keep the reforms afloat. In return, the Finance Ministry has bludgeoned the Central Bank into an austerity pact designed to reduce inflation to a mere 5 percent to 10 percent a month by the end of 1993.
The bank has reluctantly promised to pare loans to the basket-case enterprises, to charge interest that approaches the rate of inflation and to leave decisions about credits for other republics to Russia's foreign-policy makers. But the Government budget must also be disciplined, and Sachs has taken on the job of outlining the cuts that Finance Minister Fyodorov could propose.
Sachs talks frequently with Fyodorov and the other dynamo of the economic reform drive, Anatoly Chubais, the chairman of the privatization agency. He has a good working relationship with other senior reformers, including Aleksandr Shokhin, a Deputy Prime Minister, and Sergei Glaziyev, the Minister for Foreign Economic Relations. But he is not an employee of the Russian Federation. "I make it a policy not to take money from the Governments that I advise," he says. "It's better for me and better for them."
Sachs does, however, need cash to cover his own travel expenses and to support a sizable staff. Over the last three years most of the money came from the United Nations World Institute for Development Economics Research in Helsinki. Now a good chunk consists of grants from the Swedish Government, the United States Agency for International Development and the Ford Foundation.
The task before Sachs and his Western economists this day is to identify the most expendable items in the budget. A primary target is energy, which Russia still produces (and wastes) in abundance. How much money would a cut in consumer subsidies on natural gas save? How much would it reduce the consumption of gas -- and could the resulting surplus be sold to Europe for hard currency? Since nobody present is an energy specialist, one economist is dispatched to research the experience in the former Eastern European satellites, which were left on their own to buy oil and gas when Mikhail Gorbachev cut them free.
It will be a long day -- indeed, days -- for the group to come up with a series of suggested budget savings that might withstand scrutiny from a skeptical presidential cabinet and a hostile Parliament. But nobody is complaining: Sachs, in spite of chronic jet lag, works harder than anyone. In fact, during most semesters, he actually carries a full teaching load at Harvard, squeezing his trips abroad between classes and during breaks in the academic calendar.
Besides, Sachs is offering these mostly young economists a role in the redemption of Russia -- a heady experience for academics who might otherwise be holed up in some dusty office calculating how many parameters could dance on the head of a computable general equilibrium model.
THE SCENE IS A CLEAN, well-lighted place with comfortable blond furniture, a conference room that could be found in a dozen northern European countries. But this pleasant chamber, part of the offices of the Russian Federation's Center for Economic Reform, is within the walled compound that was one of Stalin's country homes, a 10-minute drive from the Kremlin. Across the road in a grove of white birch stands the dacha of the late, unlamented Andrei Zhdanov, Stalin's ideologist in charge of purging socialist culture of bourgeois influences like Dmitri Shostakovich.
The center, which serves as a think tank for the Russian Government, holds regular seminars at the compound for the Moscow reformers, plus distinguished visitors. But the lecture that day is not inspired by pressing issues of Russia's transformation. An economist from the International Monetary Fund is amplifying his views on Spain's post-Franco conversion from stagnant, regulation-ridden state capitalism to member in good standing of the European Community.
What is Jeff Sachs doing here? Has he interrupted his Moscow workathon for a busman's holiday? Has he brought along a minivan load of his worker bees to enlighten them about Spanish steel making? "Listen to the subtext," he suggests.
It doesn't take much listening. The discussion quickly turns to the difficulties of pruning the privileges of special interests in a democracy -- and in particular, of letting big state-owned companies go bankrupt. Even when workers on unpaid furlough are counted, unemployment in Russia is now probably below 2 million out of a labor force of some 70 million. But an end to the bankrolling of dead-end enterprises this year could easily push this figure above five million, and everyone with an inkling of Russia's sad, violent history is apprehensive about the political consequences. That is why Sachs and his team are so passionate about the social safety net.
A senior Russian economist alludes to the success of Chile's reforms in the 1980's, implying that there are advantages to buttressing painful change with blood and iron. Others are impressed by China, whose octogenarian leaders have succeeded in following a capitalist line without abandoning the socialist legacy of state ownership. Sachs, who has been fiddling with his new Psion Series 3 palm-top computer, bursts into a well-practiced lecture intended to stiffen the spines of those committed to democratic capitalism.
General Pinochet was a tyrant, Sachs says, but he did represent the interests of the Chilean middle class and was thus a strong supporter of market reforms. In Russia, by contrast, an authoritarian government would undoubtedly serve as a front for the military-industrial complex, which Sachs believes is the primary obstacle to a capitalist rebirth.
China may be able to grow rapidly without shedding the burden of the industrial base that Mao built, Sachs goes on, but all the growth is taking place in the free market. China is no model for gradualism in Russia, he concludes, because the inefficient Russian state sector is so much bigger than China's and thus demands a level of care and feeding that would inevitably break the Government budget.
Now Sachs returns to the offense -- his preferred stance.
"Stabilization is good politics," he says flatly. Stable prices, preferably associated with easy convertibility of the ruble to Western currencies, he argues, would bring an enormous sense of relief. And while unemployment would exact pain, he concedes, "governments can survive high unemployment but not high inflation."
In any case, Poland's experience with shock therapy is upbeat evidence that the effect on living standards is likely to be more modest than popularly assumed. While the official Polish statistics showed output falling by a third after the shock, Sachs is certain that "the alleged drop was largely illusory." Some 700,000 small businesses sprang up in the first year of market liberalization, he estimates, employing 9 percent of the work force -- much of it off the books to avoid taxation.
Average consumption of meat and fruit, rough proxies for overall consumption, actually rose between 1989 and 1991. So, too, did the number of cars, washing machines, color TV's and VCR's owned by the typical household.
Plainly, there are losers -- mostly employees of the grotesquely inefficient heavy industries -- and they constitute a powerful constituency. Indeed, just last month Solidarity displayed its displeasure with reform by deserting the ruling coalition and bringing down the Government. But the numbers, Sachs argues, should be put in perspective. "Unemployment, while high," he concludes, "did not rise beyond levels familiar in Western Europe."
The first goal for reformers, says Sachs, is to get across the message that democracy and capitalism are inextricable. Sachs, as a matter of principle, refuses to advise unelected governments: When approached by Poland's Communist junta to help renegotiate the country's foreign debts, he turned them down flat. Sachs's unbending stand, one must assume, has more than a little to do with the experience of his wife, Sonia Ehrlich, a pediatrician in Cambridge, Mass., who fled Communist Czechoslovakia with her family at age 12.
The Russian researchers accept Sachs's interpretation of Chile and China without complaint, though it is difficult to know whether they are convinced or simply unaccustomed to challenging authority. At lunch over borscht, pork cutlets and cheese pastries, all the talk is about who is winning and who is losing at which ministries.
THE STATUE OF FELIKS Dzerzhinsky may be long gone from its pedestal in front of Lubyanka prison. Moscow's upwardly mobile may swarm McDonald's each day for a chance to savor two all-beef patties, special sauce, lettuce, cheese, pickles, onions on a sesame-seed bun. But time stands still in the anteroom of the former Central Committee building. Stonefaced guards in starched uniforms stare sullenly at the Americans walking the richly paneled, red-carpeted halls.
They may be sullen, but they know an order when they hear one. Once the proper permissions have been logged, Sachs is free to lead his small contingent to the cluttered office of Maksim Boiko, adviser to the chairman of the Committee on State Property Management. Sachs is paying a quick call on the Russian privatization agency), both to keep Boiko abreast on the latest monetary machinations and to lend moral support to the embattled agency.
The agency and its hard-driving chairman, Anatoly Chubais, whom Sachs labels "a freedom fighter," have been under attack by Parliament. The old guard wants to slow the privatization, or at least funnel more of the gravy to friends.
While the mechanics at the local level have proved more laborious than expected, there is apparently little popular resistance to small-scale privatization outside agriculture. Some 60,000 little businesses have been sold, and the pace shows no sign of slowing. In fact, a series of cross-cultural surveys conducted by Boiko along with Robert Shiller of Yale and Vladimir Korobov of the Kherson Pedagogical Institute strongly suggest that Russians are as enterprising as Westerners, and even as accepting of the vicissitudes of free markets. Russians are merely more suspicious that the rules will be rigged against them.
The decisive political battle on privatization (and perhaps the entire economic reform effort) will not be over the fate of small businesses, however. It will turn on the privatization of the larger enterprises, particularly the ones that equipped the Red Army with the latest weaponry. Many have been formally converted to joint-stock companies, and Russians have all been given vouchers that they can use to bid for shares. A recent showcase sale of ZIL, the conglomerate that made the stretch limos used by Kremlin big shots, was widely acknowledged a big success.
But Chubais's enemies have, for the moment, managed to exempt a good chunk of transportation, energy and high-technology enterprises from the auction block. And hand-wringing over the fate of these ersatz jewels in socialism's crown strains Sachs's steady affability. Concern for these mega-enterprises is motivated by "a mix of self-serving politics and wishful thinking," he says with scorn.
The output of the giant factories that had been integrated into the planned economy of Russia fell sharply in the last year, as it did in most of the industrial establishments of post-Communist Eastern Europe. And critics, Western and otherwise, cite this as evidence that shock therapy is a failure. Indeed, the conventional wisdom after Poland's sweeping reforms in 1990 was that collapsing output proved shock therapy was . . . well, too shocking. By the same logic, many analysts have linked the survival of an orderly Russian transition to a deal with the "centrists" in Parliament who represent the mega-enterprises.
"You just can't leap from here to there," argues Stephen F. Cohen, the director of Russian Studies at Princeton University, "and Yeltsin knows it." While Cohen acknowledges that Russians now accept the idea that free markets are needed to bring the nation to Western living standards, he thinks there is little support for changes that would shut down giant industrial employers. "The state sector will remain large: it's a tradition," he says, one that will not be broken by democratic means.
But Sachs notes that falling production of unwanted goods -- steel plate for tanks no longer being built, chemicals made so inefficiently that the finished products are worth less on world markets than the raw inputs -- does not reduce human welfare. In fact, he thinks it is critical that the military-industrial complex be left to fend for itself in order to free capital and skilled labor for market-driven development.
Sachs is also more optimistic than his critics about the capacity of some Russian enterprises to swim with the foreign sharks. In fact, he sees an industrial comeback worthy of postwar Japan. Russian industrial exports now total about $5 billion. "I'll bet they reach $50 billion by the turn of the century."
IT IS ALMOST TIME for Sachs to board a Swissair jet for Zurich (business class). There he will connect for the 6,000-mile flight for Sao Paulo, where he has been invited to spend a few days proselytizing shock therapy. Then it's on to Tokyo. Sachs, who seems to spend a quarter of his life on airplanes, usually orders the vegetarian plate.
But before leaving, he squeezes in an hour for cruising the Arbat, a once-quaint shopping street that has become a flea market. Tourists can buy everything here, from trash art to Red Army colonels' caps to a pensioner's family jewels. And the raw bargaining brings a rare glimpse of the material side to Sachs. "My wife hates it when I shop for bargains," he confides -- his gain, she reasons, must come at the expense of sellers who live on far less.
Sachs does like collecting old currency, and he is besieged by dealers. Here, in clear plastic envelopes, are rubles issued by the czars -- orders to pay proclaimed by absolute rulers with an absolute faith in their own legitimacy and that of their bank notes. Here, too, is the new money of the 1917 revolution, whose denominations, Sachs points out, quickly grew to six figures during the years of the Bolsheviks' fight for control. It is a sobering deja vu: a ruble, which had roughly the purchasing power of a dollar at the beginning of the Gorbachev era, is now worth less than a penny. And 10,000-ruble notes are now circulating on the streets.
Will the hopes of Yeltsin's reformers be smashed (as were those of Gorbachev's) against a wall of mismanagement, avarice and cynicism? "Big economies are harder to change than little ones," Sachs readily concedes. This evangelist for democratic capitalism leaves no doubt where he wants the Russian people to go. The giant question is whether they are prepared to follow.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 5; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1337 words

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Bradlees at Atlantic Center;
Retailing Opens a New Front in Brooklyn

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
THE unflattering term applied in development circles to the suburban discount merchandisers who are tirelessly on the lookout for sites in the metropolitan area is "big box users."
"They are always looking for big square footage on one floor, surrounded by five acres of parking," says Bruce Ratner, president of Forest City Ratner Company, the developer of Metrotech in downtown Brooklyn. And, in New York City, not finding it. 
 But Forest City has persuaded Bradlees, the soft-goods chain from Braintree, Mass., to accept a two-level store -- with underground parking but no on-site surface parking -- in the commercial portion of Atlantic Center, the 24-acre mixed-use development in the Atlantic Terminal urban renewal area in central Brooklyn.
Forest City will go into construction this fall on a store for Bradlees of 150,000 square feet on two levels (some may even go on a third level). The underground parking is for 366 cars. The store will open late next year or early in 1995.
As part of the same phase of construction, Forest City will also start another two-level retail facility, with 120,000 square feet and most likely a supermarket as the tenant on the first level. It will have underground parking for 120 cars.
The architects for these stores are Ehrenkrantz & Eckstut of Manhattan and Planned Expansion Group of White Plains. Stanton Eckstut, the design architect, promised a design that reflects the railroad history associated with the site, one that "urbanizes these suburban users."
For all the expansion of the large-scale discount retailers in New York City lately, perhaps none is so telling from a land-use standpoint as their arrival at Atlantic Center, which lies at the terminus of the Long Island Rail Road in Brooklyn, where major throughfares and subway lines converge. It signifies a sharp turn from the 80's to the 90's in how developers conceive a large-scale urban site can be utilized.
And it brings to an end almost 40 years of uncertainty on the use of land that Brooklyn's leaders in the 50's hoped would appeal to a Dodgers team restless with Ebbetts Field. The Dodgers left for Los Angeles, but the urban renewal work that started with a stadium in mind plodded onward.
Change is discernible in the planning for housing as well as commercial uses at Atlantic Center, both of which follow the arrival of Forest City as partner of Rose Associates as developer of the urban renewal land. The housing plan done for Rose in a different housing era by Skidmore Owings & Merrill called for duplex condominiums around an internal mews with grouped open parking. Instead, there are to be three-family town houses with parking at the rear on the owner's land.
Forest City plans to break ground in September or October on the first phase, comprising 42 three-family houses, each for a buyer and two renters. They have been designed by Carl Meinhardt of the firm of Swanke Hayden Connell Architects with distinctively brownstone elements that will make them seem at home in their Fort Greene neighborhood.
EVENTUALLY there will be 122 houses in three- or four-family buildings, with a total of 440 units. That compares with 640 units in the Skidmore plan, in which half the apartments were one-bedrooms or studios. Though the number of units is lower in the new plan, the apartments will be larger, reflecting the greater marketability of the three-family form to larger families. All the units will have two or three bedrooms.
But the commercial phase, which is off Flatbush Avenue between Atlantic Avenue and Hanson Place, is drastically diminished in scale from the 80's plan. Rose was hoping to produce 1.8 million square feet of office space, a 4,000-seat multiscreen theater, a 50,000-square-foot supermarket, a 53,500-square-foot health club and a 1,000-car parking garage. Allied with this would have been only 205,000 square feet of retail space. The plan was approved by city government after land-use review.
Forest City Ratner is the New York affiliate of Forest City Enterprises of Cleveland, a national building company. In a second retail phase, it plans 190,000 square feet of stores between Flatbush Avenue and Fort Greene Place, with Atlantic Avenue on the south and Hanson Place on the north. The two phases together are likely to produce no more than 10 stores, and probably fewer, for a total of 410,000 square feet of retail use.
THERE is a Phase 3 lurking in the future, and that could be 1.2 million square feet of office space. But even if it is all built, the total development would be half a million square feet smaller than the original plan.
Bradlees is the company that bid unsuccessfully against the Caldor Corporation for six former Alexander's department stores in the metropolitan area. Caldor, based in Norwalk, Conn., has already started reconstructing the 200,000-square-foot store on Bruckner Boulevard off White Plains Road in the Soundview section of the Bronx (which was a Korvette's and TSS store in earlier incarnations), and the 183,000-square-foot Flushing store (once an S. Klein's and later a Korvette's), and the five-level 300,000-square-foot Alexander's store on Fordham Road and the Grand Concourse in the Bronx.
In Yonkers, Caldor bought a multilevel Alexander's store and later leased it to Bradlees, which has opened its first multilevel store there. Future Caldor construction is planned at the former Alexander's store on Queens Boulevard in Rego Park, Queens, and in Valley Stream, L.I.
None of these projects involve the establishment of a new retail location, as at Atlantic Center. "Retailing is what it should have been," in Mr. Ratner's view. "This is a great retail hub."
From the tax standpoint, the new stores are likely to be most productive to New York City from sales tax revenue rather than property taxes. Because the location is a "special abatement area," property taxes on the building are abated for 23 years. But sales taxes at 8 1/4 percent on projected revenue of perhaps $30 million to $40 million a year would be substantial.
Mr. Eckstut, the architect, noted that all the stores would be entered from the street rather than from an interior mall and would use building materials compatible with their Brooklyn surroundings.
"We're determined to build a store that is sympathetic to its urban environment, not just a suburban store plopped down on a city street," said Paul A. Travis, executive vice president of Forest City Ratner.
As for the revised housing plan, it appears to reflect not so much a market change but rather the only recently acquired ability to provide buyers of city-assisted three-family houses with mortgages. Mortgages to home owners who have two renters in their houses have only recently been approved by the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae).
This breakthrough on the financing side makes it possible to produce fee-simple houses with parking on the owner's property at the rear of the house, said Kathryn Wylde, president of the New York Housing Partnership, which acts as intermediary for private development of for-sale housing on city-owned land. The Atlantic Center housing has Federal, state and city assistance.
The three-family house tends to widen the market by bringing in intergenerational buyers -- relatives living in private units of the same house. Also, under the underwriting standards, full value is to be given to rental income in calculating the financing for which a buyer qualifies. Buyer income is likely to be limited to about $70,000 a year (165 percent of areawide median income) and Forest City said prices should be approximately $210,000 a house. But prices will not be definite until sales begin, probably in the fall.
Another way of looking at the housing redesign is that more money will go into the house itself -- in the form of larger living unit -- and less into site improvements. And the third rental unit makes for greater affordability for family buyers, widening the potential pool of buyers.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 7; Column 5; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 646 words

HEADLINE: Q and A

 BODY:

Security Refund
 
Question: I have rented an apartment in a rent-stabilized building for about 25 years. I initially paid two months' security and upon each two-year renewal of the lease I also paid an additional amount to bring the security in line with the increased rent.
About a year or so ago, though, I believe a law was enacted that stated that only one month's security was necessary. Since then I have tried to get one month's security returned to me, but the owner informed me that I'm not entitled to a refund since the law stated two months when I moved in. 
 This seems very unfair. Am I right? . . . Elizabeth Buckley, Brooklyn
 
Answer: According to Lou J. Ganim, a spokesman for the state's Department of Housing and Community Renewal in Albany, which oversees rent regulation and stabilization, the law requiring only one month's security was changed in 1987. But a section of it states that if the initial lease required two months' security and the tenant has continually occupied the apartment, then the two months' security deposit requirement continues.
 
Working Fireplaces
 
Question: In August 1990, I bought a condominium in Hoboken, N.J., with two fireplaces. I was told before the purchase by the seller-developer and the agent that they could not be converted into working fireplaces. But after I bought the unit and met the upstairs owner-tenants I learned that their fireplaces had been converted and were working.
The upstairs neighbors, however, said that they would want a huge "inconvenience fee" if I desired to convert my fireplaces.
At the time of the purchase there was not a proper board or management in place, except the developer. It also appears that the developer worked on other fireplaces without local permits. I want fireplaces. Do I have any recourse? . . . Richard DeVita, Manhattan
 
Answer: Yes. According to Ronald A. Sher, a White Plains lawyer, a basic tenet of condominium law in both New York and New Jersey holds that the unit owner may possibly seek recourse against the developer based upon a material misrepresentation or the failure to disclose a prior purchase inducement or incentive.
"The imposition of an inconvenience fee is apparently improper, although the unit owner may be responsible for expenses regarding the fireplace conversion," he said.
Mr. Sher added that the condominium declaration and bylaws must be reviewed since chimneys are normally considered part of the common elements and unit owners are usually granted an easement in common with all other units regarding common elements.
Further, Mr. Sher said the unit owner should contact the local building department regarding code requirements, as well as arrange with the condominium board for an inspection of the chimney stack and fireplace to ascertain the feasibility and scope of the project.
 
Storage-Space Rights
 
Question: I have lived in a building for 21 years, first as a tenant and later as a co-op owner. All these years I stored my trunks in the storage room provided by the building, even though I know that trunks are forbidden by the fire law.
Now the co-op board has decided that no more storage space will be available except through the renting of lockers that it is going to install.
Can it just revoke my rights of 21 years? Is this legal? . . . Albertine van Thiel, Manhattan.
 
Answer: Yes. According to Stuart Saft, a Manhattan lawyer and chairman of the Council of New York Co-operatives, it is legal.
"The board has complete descretion over the operation and management of the building," he said.
Mr. Saft added that the situation might be different for renters, as it would entail a reduction of services, and thus possibly the need for some sort of reimbursement or replacement of services.
"But once you bought your unit," he said, "your rights as a renter ended."

HEADLINE: Interpreting: a Business Spurred by Diversity

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
THE increasing ethnic and racial diversity of New Jersey has produced a huge demand for interpreting and translating services in courts, state agencies and corporations, officials and business executives say.
With scores of multinational corporate headquarters now nestled in New Jersey's suburbs, and with large communities of non-English-speaking Hispanic, Asian and other immigrants settling in the state's urban centers, this demand has led to the creation of hundreds of agencies that use the services of thousands of independent interpreters and translators. 
 In fact, the interpreting industry has grown so large so fast that it may now be experiencing some growing pains.
In the past, people who claimed to be fluent enough in English and another language could simply place their names on a list to be called on by the court to interpret. Now, some of the state's counties are preparing lists of "approved" interpreters who have passed tests demonstrating their skills; only those on the lists will be allowed to work in the courts. And the Administrative Office of the Courts is planning to adopt the practice statewide.
 
Concerned Over Audits
 At the same time, representatives of interpreting agencies say they are concerned over a number of audits of agencies being conducted by the State Department of Labor. The representatives say they fear that the department will require that all agencies pay unemployment compensation and temporary disability taxes on the freelance interpreters and translators they use. Such a requirement, they say, could put many smaller agencies out of business.
 
Bill for Exemption on Tax
 Officials at the Department of Labor say no such requirement is being considered. But last week, at industry urging, a Bergen County state senator introduced legislation that would specifically exempt interpreting agencies from paying unemployment and disability taxes.
Alan Ashkinaze, an industry lobbyist, said the individual translators and interpreters are often listed with a number of different agencies, which refer them to companies or courts as the need arises. For many, such assignments are their primary source of income, while for others they represent a second income.
Over the last 10 years, state officials say, the number of people needing interpreters in the courts has nearly doubled.
"There's just a tremendous influx of folks from around the globe who don't speak English well enough to get by in court without an interpreter," said Robert Joe Lee, chief of the Court Interpreting, Legal Translating and Bilingual Services Section of the Administrative Office of the Courts.
In 1983, Mr. Lee said, the state's Superior Courts used court interpreters 27,888 times; by 1992, the number had reached 49,094.
In the state's municipal courts, he said, the increase has been even greater. "We don't have actual numbers, but our projection for 1992 was that the volume was about 126,188 events in municipal courts," he said. In 1983 there were 59,688 instances in which court interpreters were used.
 
Difficulty in Adapting
 James W. Hughes, an associate dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, said he was not surprised.
"You have an immigrant base that now comes from poorer countries whose legal systems might be quite different from ours," Mr. Hughes said. "They have a little more difficulty adapting to our system." Between 1980 and 1990, he said, the Hispanic population in the state grew by 50 percent, while the number of Asians and Pacific Islanders rose by 162 percent.
Industry officials say they have no objection to the state testing programs for court interpreters and translators as long as the testing is fair and consistent.
"It's sorely needed," said Joseph A. Murphy, president of the Bergen Language Institute Inc., an interpreting and translating agency based in Teaneck. "It's a good goal to try to find some way to evaluate people as to their professional ability and their expertise."
What troubles the industry, however, is the possibility that the State Department of Labor might begin to classify freelance interpreters as employees for purposes of assessing unemployment compensation taxes.
Such a move, said Mr. Ashkinaze, the industry lobbyist, would "wipe out a cottage industry."
 
Paying Their Own Taxes
 As it now stands, he said, individual interpreters and translators are treated by both the Federal and state governments as independent contractors for tax purposes. As such, they are responsible for paying taxes on the money they receive.
Under New Jersey law, said Steven R. Weinstein, a Newark lawyer who specializes in labor and employment law, an independent contractor is an individual who is free from the supervision and control of the agency that hires him, who performs his work outside the business office of the referring agency and who is engaged in an independently recognized trade, craft, profession or business.
If translators or interpreters were to be treated as employees rather than independent contractors, Mr. Weinstein said, the agency that hires them would have to pay 3 percent of their gross wages to the state for unemployment compensation and temporary disability taxes.
"Three percent may not sound like a lot of money, but they can go back five years, and then it becomes very substantial," he said, referring to the time frame within which the Department of Labor may audit a company's books. In addition, he said, many agencies work on such small profit margins that even 3 percent could make them unable to compete with out-of-state agencies that do not have to pay the taxes.
"It could also have a ripple effect," Mr. Weinstein said. "If they're employees for these purposes, do we have to provide them with workers' compensation coverage? Do we have to make state and Federal withholdings? Do we have to make FICA contributions?"
 
'A Natural Reaction'
 Mr. Murphy of the Bergen Language Institute said a requirement to pay unemployment compensation for his freelancers would "significantly change" the way he does business.
"In my company we translate and interpret 58 languages," he said. "I only have a few people on staff, and the 58 languages are taken care of with a network of about 600 translators I have around the country." If unemployment compensation had to be paid, he said, "it would be a natural reaction for agencies like mine not to ask any New Jersey translators to work for them."
Carmen Barros, the owner of International Interpreters, a small interpreting company in Hackensack, said that she used 50 or 60 interpreters and that the unemployment compensation requirement would have a significant effect on her business. "Just the accounting you would have to do is incredible," she said. "And if you take into consideration the fact that most people who have small agencies do everything themselves, they wouldn't be able to operate."
Gene Herman, a spokesman for the State Department of Labor, said that the Division of Employment Security Revenue was now auditing only one interpreting agency. That agency, which he declined to name, is being audited because a claim for unemployment benefits was filed against the company.
In the course of that audit, Mr. Herman said, "the Division of Employment Security Revenue determined that there is a relationship that is an employer-employee relationship." The audit covered only this year and last year, he said, and "the division has no intention of expanding it beyond that."
The division, he added, "has no indication that other firms are not in compliance with the law."
Mr. Weinstein, however, said he has personal knowledge of four agencies that are now being audited by the division. "One is my client," he said, "and there are three others that I know of. And in my client's case, they've gone back five years." He refused to name the agencies.
Donna Siegel Moffa, a Haddonfield lawyer who also specializes in labor law, said she has a client who is being actively audited by the division. "It started out with one year, and now they're asking for five years back."
The legislation to exempt the interpreting industry was sponsored by State Senator Gerald Cardinale, Republican of Demarest.
Mr. Weinstein said: "Rather than fight this out through litigation, we think it's ripe for clarification by the Legislature. We're dealing with a number of small businesses here. These are mostly minority-owned or female-owned businesses, and they provide a lot of jobs in the New Jersey economy."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Familiar Score: Perception 1, Reality 0

BYLINE: By Kurt Eichenwald

 BODY:
SCRATCH any market participant, and you're sure to find something of a hysteric, braced to think the worst on the slightest bit of bad news.
That fact emerged resoundingly over the past two weeks, as currency traders holding yen made a dash for the exits after a Japanese political revolt doomed Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa's Government, threatening decades of rule by his Liberal Democratic Party.
For five months, economic fundamentals -- from the Japanese trade surplus to signs of economic recovery -- had helped push the dollar down against the yen, to a record close of 105.08 yen. But on June 18, when Mr. Miyazawa lost a vote of confidence in the Japanese Diet, traders threw out fundamentals, pushing the dollar up more than three yen. 
 Oops. Last week, the traders reversed again. The yen rally revived, as traders sold dollars and bought Japanese currency. By Friday, the dollar was trading just above 106 yen, near its level when the crisis erupted.
The selloff was "largely a knee-jerk reaction," said John Lipsky, chief economist at Salomon Brothers. Indeed, none of the fundamentals -- from the trade surplus to the recovering economy -- changed in the Diet vote. And near-term fiscal policy in Japan was already set with passage of a budget and a supplement.
Many currency traders knew that. But they, like most everyone in the markets, are prisoners of perceptions that often outweigh reality.
Think of a trader who, convinced that the Diet vote should have little effect on the yen's value, did not change positions. By week's end, that fictitious (or now unemployed) trader had a loss. Meanwhile, many of those traders who rode the perception that political turmoil in Tokyo meant currency chaos won profits.
Perception could well prove its importance again this week, with Friday's release of American unemployment figures for June. Last year, when those were announced, a firestorm erupted. Unemployment grew to 7.8 percent in the month, from 7.5 percent in May 1992, the Government announced, with employment down 117,000 jobs. Minutes later, the Federal Reserve cut a key interest rate, and the markets moved accordingly.
White House advisers split about how positive then-President Bush should be, with some arguing the figures did not reflect reality. Later, they were proved right: Revisions showed employment down only 16,000 jobs that month.
But perception was what mattered, helping win bond traders millions of dollars, and Bill Clinton the White House.
This week, the new figures arrive as Mr. Clinton's budget rolls through Congress. If bad, they're sure to be used against the package's tax increases -- even if they are inaccurate.
Mr. Clinton could always argue about the numbers' reliability. But perhaps last year's experience has taught him the lesson every bond trader will apply: When you want to play to win, play to perceptions.

HEADLINE: Betting the Farm on Managed Care

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
FOR an idea of what's coming in health care, we leave Hillary Rodham Clinton's recently disbanded task force and join Lawrence P. English's Connecticut-based army as it advances on the New York metropolitan region. Mr. English, a division president at the Cigna Corporation who commands 25,000 employees, is leading a bet-the-company drive to become a dominant force in the new world of "managed care" health plans. New York is his next big battleground.
His troops, it seems, are everywhere: 
 * In the Bronx, one of his 38 New York salesmen, a dapper 28-year-old named Art Howard, is busy reassuring employees at a small business that they can expect top-flight care now that they are enrolled in Cigna's medical network. Mr. Howard is a veteran at calming employers with promises of lower medical premiums while soothing workers concerned that managed care means callous care.
* Across the metropolitan area, Cigna representatives led by Dr. Jonathan S. Kaplan have been calling on more than three dozen hospitals and hundreds of doctors, asking them to join the network as well.
* In Great Neck, L.I., Mildred Tanner, a stout, forceful nurse, is on the phone, trying to gather enough information for a ruling on whether to pay for rehabilitation of a stroke victim and a heart transplant for a priest. In the next cubicle, another nurse is authorizing brain surgery for a man with AIDS. Altogether, six nurses track treatments ordered by Cigna's growing web of physicians, now more than 3,000 in New York and its suburbs.
* At health-care headquarters just outside Hartford, more than 2,000 workers in vast rooms are processing medical information, many of them crunching numbers to estimate what Cigna is paying out in claims and what it will charge customers in the coming year.
Cigna's invasion of New York is a vivid example of a revolution taking place nationwide in the health-care industry regardless of whether proposals for reform go anywhere in Washington. Like electrical utilities at the turn of the century or cable-television operators today, Cigna and its competitors are rushing to organize networks that they hope will generate big money for decades to come.
 
Emerging Giants
 In just a few years, experts say, perhaps five to eight medical networks run by insurance giants or other health-care businesses will dominate the New York metropolitan region. They will have enormous power over who gets what kind of medical care, how much the providers of care are paid, and whether medical costs can be satisfactorily controlled.
But for the insurance companies, medical networks also represent a substantial gamble. They are extremely expensive to set up, the competition is fierce, and the industry is uneasy about the possibility of government price controls that could squeeze profits. "The $64,000 question is whether you can deliver better care at lower cost and make a profit," said Michael Frinquilli, an insurance analyst with Salomon Brothers. "Price controls or competition might make the margins on this business too thin."
Cigna hopes within five years to increase its share of managed-care customers in southern New York State to more than 1 million from the current 55,000, and produce annual revenues here of more than $1.5 billion in today's dollars. One person who has studied Cigna's plans for New York said the company hoped to pay no more than 84 percent of its premiums on medical claims, and maintain administrative costs at 10 percent. Cigna would pay about 3 percent in taxes, so the company would reap a profit of 3 percent, or more than $40 million a year in the New York market alone. (The current margin on Cigna's managed care is lower.)
The growth of medical networks like Cigna's has already had enormous repercussions in the New York area. Some employers, workers and physicians are quite satisfied. But Cigna must contend with patients who worry about being forced to find a new physician because their old one is not in the network; with doctors unhappy about Cigna's limits on their fees and proposed treatments, and with hospitals that fret that they will not be paid enough to continue training doctors and providing care for the poor.
There is also a widespread uneasiness about the way medical networks like Cigna's pay their participating physicians. Doctors have long been paid more for doing more; now, because of a flat fee per patient system, they can actually profit more when they do less.
Finally, critics of the way medical networks are evolving argue that any cost savings are illusory, that savings squeezed from doctors and hospitals are lost in, among other things, higher administrative costs.
Many of the medical networks across the country are expected to be operated by five insurance giants: Cigna, Prudential, Aetna, Travelers and Metropolitan Life. In the New York region, other major contenders include the networks operated by Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York (H.I.P.), U.S. Healthcare, Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield and Oxford Health Plans.
Under managed care, an employer pays a fee to a medical network, usually called a health maintenance organization or a preferred provider organization. Employees are given a list of doctors in the network, who in return for the referral of patients have agreed to limit their fees and to clear all major treatments with the network before performing them.
 
Cigna's Stake
 More than any other large insurance company, the Cigna Corporation, a $19 billion publicly traded company listed on the New York Stock Exchange, has staked its future on managed-care networks. "We are rapidly moving from the insurance business to becoming a health-care delivery system," said Mr. English, president of Cigna Employee Benefits Companies. "New York, because of its size, is critical to us," he added.
Since 1984, Cigna has organized about 150 networks that together serve more than 2.6 million people nationwide. The company will not say how much it has invested in managed care. But after years of losses, the managed-care operations are now profitable, and health plans are responsible for the lion's share of the company's earnings.
Indeed, Cigna, whose property-casualty business is doing poorly, lacks the profit centers that other insurance behemoths have. If it fails in managed care, analysts say, it has almost nothing to fall back on.
The New York market has long resisted managed care. Many doctors in the area are specialists associated with teaching hospitals who refuse to be organized by an outside institution. Many hospitals are less profitable than in other regions and resist giving discounts. Complex regulations have scared off some network operators. In addition, the initial investment in networks in such a populous region is huge.
But in the last 18 months, sharp rises in premiums for traditional health insurance plans have forced companies to start looking for cheaper alternatives. Then, on April 1, a change in New York State law required insurers to offer the same rates to all companies, no matter how sick or healthy their workers are. One result is that many employers' premiums have jumped, making them more eager to look for lower rates.
"Two years ago, the attitude was so negative we couldn't even get in the door," said Bill Corba, the sales manager for Cigna in New York, who has just trained 30 salespeople to begin work this week. Now, "our phones just keep on ringing."
 
The Wider Impact
 Cigna's managed-care network has already been felt in many ways in the New York region.
Some employers are converts. The Nobody Beats the Wiz chain of electronics stores moved to Cigna on March 1 with 2,100 employees, including 1,500 in New York. The company had found that most of its workers could no longer afford its traditional insurance plan, on which they were asked to pay half the premium. So the company offered them a choice of Cigna plans, including an H.M.O. with rates 30 percent lower. The number of workers who signed up for health insurance nearly doubled, to 60 percent of the Wiz work force.
"For many, it is their first experience with managed health care and the reaction is very favorable," said Ralph Bulle, vice president for human resources at Wiz Distributors.
In the South Bronx, the Banana Kelly Community Improvement Association, a nonprofit housing-development company that can no longer afford traditional insurance, will switch to Cigna on Thursday.
But its president, Wendy Seligson, is wary. Cigna pays many of the doctors in its network in the following way: the doctors are paid on a fee-for-service basis for the first 50 patients they agree to care for. After that, they're paid between $9.50 and $58 per patient per month for additional patients -- no matter how sick the patient may be that month and no matter how much work the doctor does. In fact, the less work the doctor does, the lower his or her costs, and the more money the doctor pockets.
Banana Kelly recently abandoned another managed-care plan whose doctors, workers say, sometimes did not return calls. "My concern is that the doctors have the wrong incentives," Ms. Seligson said, "that they will take on too many patients and our workers will not be satisfied."
At a recent meeting, Mr. Howard, the Cigna salesman, told Banana Kelly employees that they would have to choose a primary-care physician from a Cigna-approved list. Regina Franklin's hand shot up. For years she had suffered from severe asthma, and visited doctor after doctor until she found one who listened and found a medication that helped. He was not on the Cigna list, so now she would have to start looking again.
"I have little trust in doctors," she said. "It's real important that I have a doctor I'm comfortable with."
Mr. Howard persuaded Ms. Franklin to urge her doctor to apply to join the Cigna network. As more doctors hear such pleas from patients, Mr. Howard said later, they will come to realize they must either participate in networks like Cigna's or see their income decline.
 
Pressure on Doctors
 Indeed, the pressures to join networks and accept lower fees are growing for primary-care physicians -- internists, pediatricians and family practitioners. But eventually economic forces may take their heaviest toll on highly trained specialists and subspecialists whose numbers, at least in Manhattan, are far greater than the needs of managed-care networks, said Michael A. Stocker, president of Cigna Healthplans. For example, he said, some hematologists and gastroenterologists here may have to retrain for other specialties.
On the other hand, some doctors, particularly young primary-care physicians seeking to expand their practices, speak highly of their business partnership with a company that sends patients their way.
"I am getting a younger, somewhat healthier group of patients," said Dr. Kenneth R. Ackerman, an internist in Great Neck who joined the Cigna network a year ago. "People from law firms, accounting firms. They are more interested in preventive care. For me, it's more fun."
But Dr. Sergio Piomelli, director of hematology and oncology at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan, said the doctors in his group practice are extremely nervous, not so much about a loss of income as about the prospect that patient care will suffer.
In several cases, he said, he has seen networks refer children with rare blood and bone diseases to less expensive local hospitals where the proper diagnosis was missed or where advanced treatments were not even available.
"I fear there is more rigidity in these plans than there should be," he said, while conceding that the physicians in his practice would have to sign up for networks to stay afloat.
Anxiety has spread to some hospital administrators as well. Cigna pays hospitals in the New York area as little as $600 a day for its patients. Some teaching hospitals say their costs per patient are more than twice that high. But as their physicians join networks like Cigna's, the hospitals feel compelled to join, or face the prospect of growing numbers of patients being referred elsewhere.
Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, said hospitals in New York have far narrower profit margins than those in other states.
The leaders of several teaching hospitals that have signed agreements with Cigna -- Columbia Presbyterian, Mount Sinai and Long Island Jewish -- warned that as they are pressed to give discounts to network patients, they may have to cut programs for the training of interns and residents, as well as care for the poor. Or, the taxpayer might have to bear more of such costs.
"Academic health-care centers are a national resource and we just can't compete on cost with nonacademic hospitals," said Dr. William T. Speck, president of Columbia Presbyterian.
But a nearly religious calm prevails at the offices of Cigna's medical director for the New York area, Dr. Kaplan, whose team oversees medical decisions for New York patients. Workers at the office in Great Neck glow with faith that they are transforming medicine for the better.
Dr. Kaplan said there is protection for patients in a system in which doctors can profit by doing less. Cigna frequently surveys patients about the care they received, and checks doctors' records for signs of cutting corners or inappropriate treatment, he explained.
Teaching hospitals, Dr. Kaplan added, will have to learn to be more efficient. But Cigna, which needs to sign up such prestigious institutions in order to attract customers, is also paying them considerably more than $600 per day per patient.
Perhaps the most difficult task for Dr. Kaplan's team is deciding when to authorize extremely expensive or experimental therapies with only a small chance of doing any good.
One day recently, Ms. Tanner, a nurse who spent more than two decades working in long-term-care facilities, was asked to approve a long rehabilitation program in a hospital for a stroke victim. The family wanted to try everything. But Ms. Tanner wanted to know whether less expensive therapy at home would work.
"The doctor may be thinking that a hospital is better because he can control things there -- that is his milieu," Ms. Tanner said. "If I approve hospitalization for somebody with limited rehab potential, I am not really doing anything for anybody. There is only so much pie to cut up."
At the same time, Ms. Tanner was gathering information on a priest too sick to undergo a second heart bypass operation, but a candidate for a heart transplant. The cost of the transplant at Columbia Presbyterian would be $162,000. But if he could benefit, Ms. Tanner said, it seemed certain to be approved.
Cigna executives say that although they must hire people like Ms. Tanner to run a managed-care network, for every dollar the company spends on higher administrative costs, it saves $2 to $3 on medical bills.
In the end, however, "we are also competing on the basis of quality," Mr. English said. "If we do a bad job, people will complain and leave us. Our real incentives are to keep people from getting sick."
