HEADLINE: Business Diary/June 20-25

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
At Empire Blue Cross, Definitely a Week to Forget 

"Enormous uncertainty" -- that's what Otto G. Obermaier, a former United States Attorney hired as an investigator by Empire Blue Cross, saw last week. Translated, that means "a mess." Here's the latest: It seems that even in a world increasingly run by computers, Empire decided it was too much trouble to program its computers properly, so it just paid many claims -- about one in six -- without checking for fraud or duplication. Also, the Manhattan District Attorney has begun a criminal inquiry, and the Senate began its own hearings. Trying to put the past well behind it, Empire decided it didn't make sense to keep paying a $205,000 salary to its top financial officer after sending him packing, so it suspended him without pay. And what does Albert A. Cardone, recently ousted as chairman, say to accusations of mismanagement? They are "but another effort by special interests to discredit me and a fine institution."
 
G.M. Brings Some Jobs Home
 
Detroit is moving jobs across the border again, but the United Auto Workers thinks it's just fine. That's because this time the route is reversed, with General Motors shifting some Chevrolet Cavalier production from Mexico to Lansing, Mich. As many as 1,000 jobs will be created, with some to be filled by laid-off workers. It's not that G.M. has forgotten how low Mexican wages are -- just that it has felt a lot of union pressure on exporting jobs, and with the American auto market finally stirring to life, it doesn't want to risk any disruption. And last week G.M. and the U.A.W. began talks on a national contract.
 
T. Rex, 38; Arnold, 15
 
As the film tycoon Charles Dickens once said, "Expectation $19 million, gross $20 million: result, happiness; expectation $21 million, gross $20 million: result, misery." It was misery indeed at Columbia Pictures after "Last Action Hero" grossed "only" $15.3 million its first weekend. Now, for any mortal film, that's a lot of tickets, but the studio was counting on megahit numbers -- $20 million or so -- for this one. To make it worse, "Jurassic Park" made $38.5 million its second weekend. That settles it: with all his undulating muscles, Arnold Schwarzenegger (the star of "Hero") is no match for a dinosaur.
 
One Company, Indivisible
 
RJR Nabisco is still mainly a tobacco company, no matter how hard it tries to fine-tune that label. In March it made plans for a separate class of stock linked to its food business, hoping to raise $1.5 billion. But last week, citing poor market conditions, it dropped the plan. One problem is that food company shares are not doing well these days. And in any case, the food shares would still have represented ownership of the whole company, smoke and all. With anti-smoking fists raised nationwide, some may see that as a less-than-healthy investment.
 
Cheeriexes? No, Sounds Funny
 
General Mills, by daring to tamper with an icon of modern civilization, may just have hit on a way to sell more breakfast cereal. As parents well know, if there are children around, a lot of cereal already winds up scattered around the table, on the floor or in the couch's remotest corners. If a cereal maker can just increase the amount that never reaches the mouth, it will clearly sell more. So General Mills may have had a brainstorm last week when it added X's to its Cheerios, inviting tic-tac-toe games with a grid on the box. What's next? At parties that go flat, the hors d'oeuvres could be shaped like chess pieces, and the cheese board divided into 64 squares.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Closing the Door on Steel
 
It's the same old story. The world makes too much of something, and a lot of the excess winds up in the ultimate market, the United States. But the United States, trying desperately to hang onto far more than its fair share of the world's plenty, cries foul and slams the door. And then everyone yells at Washington. Last week it was steel, as the Administration announced steep tariffs on steel from 19 countries, saying they were selling it for less than they charge at home. American steelmakers applauded, speaking of the "egregious distortion" that foreign companies create. But the view abroad was harsh, as one official said steel imports were being treated as "a whipping boy" for America's problems.
 
Meanwhile, the recent optimism on a breakthrough in global trade talks seemed premature, as trade ministers meeting in Tokyo failed to achieve a hoped-for accord on reducing many tariffs and were back to square one.
 
'Low Point' at Lloyd's of London
 
Lloyd's of London. It sounds so British, so solid. Its dignified backers are not "investors" but "names." But those "names" came face to face with some awfully undignified numbers last week, when the insurer reported its annual loss (a loss, by the way, for 1990; Lloyd's always allows such a civilized interval). And the deficit was huge -- at $4.3 billion, even worse than expected. The loss is "in every way the low point of Lloyd's history in the last 305 years," said David Rowland, the chairman. And a low point for a lot of those "names," too, who are out of pocket, on average, more than $150,000. When added to previous losses, that's put a big dent in a lot of fortunes. New investors are lining up, though -- in part, perhaps, because in the future they will not face unlimited liability.
 
World Falters, Russia Pays
 
It looked good on paper -- a $4 billion global fund to help Russian enterprises go private. The Clinton Administration, committed to increase Russian aid, proposed the fund in April, and the President is determined to make good on his promises. Congress seemed willing, but this nation's allies may not be. Last week the Administration, facing the reality that Japan and Western Europe might have too many troubles of their own to chip in, said the fund would shrink. The hope now is that half the amount can be agreed to later.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Thank You for Smoking?
 
The logic is flawless. Since smoking doesn't cause cancer -- that's what the tobacco industry has maintained all along -- it naturally follows that secondhand smoke doesn't either. The Environmental Protection Agency, of course, says other people's smoke causes up to 3,000 lung-cancer deaths a year, and that declaration has led to a lot more smoke-free restaurants and offices -- most recently, a ban last week on smoking in all Los Angeles restaurants. But the tobacco industry hates to see office workers puffing madly while they huddle in rainy doorways -- some of them might actually quit. So last week an industry group -- one with no ties whatever to the Flat Earth Society -- sued, asking a court to rule that what the E.P.A. has demonstrated just isn't so.
 
A Worried Economy
 
This is a nation waiting for two axes to fall -- they're called taxes and health care reform. And while it waits, the economy is treading water -- or so says the Federal Reserve, which in its latest survey of business conditions, out last week, foresaw "slow to moderate" economic growth. Investment and hiring are being delayed, the central bank said, by those twin uncertainties. That certainly seems plausible. But some Administration officials spy another wrinkle, suspecting that when business people say the sky will fall if taxes rise, what they're really doing is a bit of grass-roots lobbying against tax increases. If you've ever seen a 6-year-old predicting the certain end of civilization if she doesn't get ice cream now, that seems equally plausible.
 
For its part, the White House, holding its finger to the economic winds, now says the year's growth will probably be more like 2.5 percent than the 3.1 percent it had projected.
 
Who's Minding the Air?
 
Some Federal agency is surely looking out for air quality in airplanes, right? Actually, no. The F.A.A., it seems, mainly covers flight safety. OSHA cares, as long as the problem is on the ground. The E.P.A.? Again, no. But as airlines circulate less fresh air through the cabins, raising levels of carbon dioxide and fumes from cleaners and pesticides, flight attendants and passengers have complained of headaches and other maladies. So last week the Transportation Department stepped into the vacuum, as Secretary Federico Pena ordered a preliminary inquiry into the air quality of plane cabins.
 
A Budget Bill, by a Whisker
 
For President Clinton, it's make-or-break time. The waffling and missteps and runway haircuts, he hopes, will turn to forgotten dust if he can just cajole and strong-arm his budget plan through Congress. So senators lined up in neat rows last week, each wildly cheering the home team -- the Democrats trying to make their party's day, the Republicans trying to break this enemy Presidency. In a typical Democratic swipe, George Mitchell of Maine said that if Mr. Clinton "sent a bill up here to praise apple pie and motherhood," the Republicans would try to amend it to say "apple pie is evil and motherhood is insidious." As for the Republicans, John Chafee of Rhode Island said, "We were just plain left out." The Democrats held ranks, though, fending off all efforts to peck at the bill. The overall bill, though, squeaked through only on a tie-breaking vote by Vice President Gore. Next stop, a House-Senate conference.

HEADLINE: Profile/Myron E. Ullman 3d;
Changing the Mood at Macy's

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
SAN FRANCISCO
It was the end of a long day of sobering business reviews this month in the West Coast division of R. H. Macy & Company. Inventories were way out of line, portending heavy markdowns and a hit to the bottom line.
First one, then another Macy executive took responsibility for the poor planning, though neither had been in charge when the plans were made. Then one of them, Thomas C. Shull, turned to look at Macy's chairman and chief executive, Myron E. Ullman 3d, and said with a smile: "But now that I think about it, the fish does stink from the head." 
 The other executives, who unlike Mr. Shull were all Macy's managers of long standing, waited nervously for Mr. Ullman's reaction.
Mr. Ullman chuckled. "It was one of the last and most visible vestiges I had seen of the end of an era in which teasing the boss was something like committing suicide," Mr. Shull recalled.
In this and many other ways, the 47-year-old Mr. Ullman is changing a company long known as a hierarchical, backbiting organization that was dominated until its bankruptcy filing last year by an imperious if talented executive, Edward S. Finkelstein.
Under Mr. Ullman, who became sole chief executive this month, the minnows are now allowed, in fact encouraged, to laugh with, challenge and even criticize the whale. Mr. Ullman is also eliminating the trappings of imperialism that had become Macy's hallmark. He sold the company airplane. He prefers to attend meetings with Macy merchants in their offices instead of summoning them to his office or the stern board room. The corporate dining rooms on the 13th floor of Macy's flagship store in New York's Herald Square, once the preserve of a handful of senior executives, are open to any manager for meetings.
More important, the change in Macy's culture is defined by better dissemination of information among the company's 60,000 employees. Mr. Ullman is overseeing the installation of the technological infrastructure of a modern department-store company -- computerized systems used to track customer preferences, buy merchandise and manage inventory and the deployment of store employees, all in the name of efficiency and responsiveness.
Merchandise managers can now peer into their computers to find where inventories are backing up and quickly take markdowns. And planners who allocate merchandise to stores can discover quickly that women shopping in the lingerie department of the store in Queens have fuller figures and make sure enough larger-sized bras are in stock there.
Later this summer, Macy will even have a satellite network to communicate with its employees across the country -- to show sales associates how to best display a collection of garments or to fill in employees on the company's performance.
In the past, Macy "was a hierarchical organization, and information resided at the top," said G. G. Michelson, a senior adviser to Macy and a board member. "Mike has made a conscientious effort to get everyone on the same wavelength, to have people buy in."
Finally, at a company that had a stable of talented merchants but few people skilled in operations, Mr. Ullman has peopled the Macy universe with managers good at the nuts and bolts of inventory management, computerized merchandise allocation and other tasks that have become increasingly important to a retailer seeking cost efficiency.
In short, Mr. Ullman has laid the groundwork for a comeback at the 137-year-old retailer, and all without internal panic.
It remains to be seen whether Mr. Ullman has prescribed the proper antidotes. Macy has met its projections for sales increases and cash flow only for the last three months, but few people will call that a turnaround. "He seems like he's got the thing thought through, he seems like he has the right answers," said Robert M. Miller, the lawyer who represents Macy's bondholders. "But to me the proof of the pudding is in the eating, and the jury is still out."
Mr. Miller does not question Mr. Ullman's qualifications. Rather he wonders whether any retail company in Macy's weak condition can fully recuperate without improvement in the economy. He also wonders whether Mr. Ullman's nuts-and-bolts approach is right for a retail company where glitz and glamour are necessary parts of the business.
Indeed, while Mr. Ullman has assembled a strong operations team for Macy, his biggest challenge is to find a chief merchant for the whole organization as well as one to lead the West Coast division. These executives are critical to enhancing Macy's image among shoppers and suppliers.
FORCING people to adapt to new ways of doing things is not easy, and Mr. Ullman has confronted resistance along the way, particularly in the West, where problems have been complicated by the weak economy in California.
What softens the impact of these decisions is Mr. Ullman's style of management, which gives employees the sense that he's there to help them rather than simply to order them around. "I think of myself as a servant-manager," he said. "My job is to help others in the organization get their job done by giving them whatever tools they require."
Mr. Ullman, an alumnus of the University of Cincinnati, started by selling computers for I.B.M. (and became comfortable with technology). Then he became an administrator at his alma mater (where he helped the university turn itself around financially). Next he served as a White House Fellow in the Office of the United States Trade Representative, then joined the Sanger Harris chain of Federated Department Stores (and helped create computer-assisted buying and planning programs). Finally, he gained management experience by running a Hong Kong conglomerate, Wharf Holdings.
For all the changes Mr. Ullman has forced since coming to Macy in 1988, most outsiders think of him as a bean-counter, a financial officer hired by Mr. Finkelstein to police a heavily indebted company. Mr. Finkelstein, a visionary merchant tired of being criticized for his lack of financial expertise, presented Mr. Ullman that way.
 ACTUALLY, Mr. Ullman, who had little hands-on experience in managing finances, brought in Diane Baker from Salomon Brothers to deal with that part of the job while he began re-engineering the company's operations. But the "numbers guy" description stuck and was reinforced by Macy's board, which appointed Mr. Ullman and Mark S. Handler, a popular merchant, to a joint office of the chairman and chief executive when Mr. Finkelstein retired in April 1992.
At the time, the biggest knock against Mr. Ullman was that he was no Allen Questrom, the merchant hired to lead Federated Department Stores out of bankruptcy. Mr. Questrom, with his knack for public relations and a glamorous social life, attracted journalists, retailing experts, the financial community and even his competitors. Mr. Ullman, whose suits looked as though they came from J. C. Penney, who has a standing date with his wife every Friday night and who devotes Sundays to his five children, seemed to lack a certain panache.
"Questrom was the chief executive selling a grand vision of the hereafter that I think inspired a lot of other merchants to stay with him or jump on board," said Jeffrey A. Sonnenfeld, director of the Center for Leadership and Career Studies at Emory University. "Ullman still has the challenge of somehow getting the Questrom job done."
Mr. Sonnenfeld thinks the appointment of Don Hewitt, the executive producer of CBS's "60 Minutes," to head Macy's recently announced home-shopping-channel venture is Mr. Ullman's first step in that direction. Mr. Ullman has also changed his style somewhat, discarding rep ties for more stylish ones and adding elegant suits from I. Magnin, Macy's high-end specialty store. He has also begun revealing himself more to the press and public in ways like power-lunching with Michael F. Coady, president of Fairchild Publications, which publishes the gossipy trade paper Women's Wear Daily.
"There are different points in time where different kinds of leaders surface to lead," said Arie L. Kopelman, president of Chanel Inc., which sells cosmetics and other luxury goods to Macy. "Clearly at this point, it is Mike Ullman's time. It's far easier to find a great merchant to tend to the creativity needs of the business than to find a leader who can hold all the strings in his hands with confidence and know which to pull when."
Finding a chief merchant with stature and ingenuity to play second fiddle to the youthful Mr. Ullman may be difficult without assurances that Mr. Ullman intends to leave the chief executive's office within a year or two of when Macy emerges from bankruptcy protection in the next few years.
Macy's creditors are determined that whoever arrives to put the goods on the more efficient structure that Mr. Ullman and his operations team have erected must stay for the long run. Mr. Ullman has already broached to Macy's creditors the possibility of appointing Michael Steinberg, a former colleague who recently resigned as president and chief executive of Foley's, to the No. 2 spot. But creditors have rejected the notion, at least for the time being. Mr. Steinberg is in his sixties.
Mr. Ullman's goal is to have someone in place by August, and he says there is plenty of room at the top of Macy for both himself and another dynamic personality. "I'm trying to build bench strength here," he said.
Some Macy watchers worry that Mr. Ullman's ego will prevent him from appointing someone strong to the position. But others who know him well disagree. "I know Mike believes that he's not capable of doing it alone," said James M. Zimmerman, president and chief operating officer of Federated, who got to know Ullman when he worked for that company. "That's why I think he will be successful."
Mr. Ullman said his goal is to pull off what he calls "the turnaround of the decade." Asked whether he would succeed, Mr. Ullman recounted a story about his sister Christine Stubbins. Several years ago, she startled her husband by telling him she wanted to join the Junior League in Cincinnati. Her husband discouraged her, saying they weren't blueblooded enough to meet the league's standards.
But she persisted, not only winning acceptance as a member but also rising to the organization's international board. "I think," he said, "she's the person in my family who I'm most like."
 
 
MR. ULLMAN'S IMPORTS
 THE cast of characters at R. H. Macy & Company, once a club of lifetime employees who had risen through the merchandising ranks, has changed dramatically in the last year. Mr. Ullman has brought in a number of executives whose careers are decidedly unlike those of traditional Macy managers. Among them:
* Thomas C. Shull, group vice president for business development and personnel, who met Mr. Ullman when the two were White House Fellows. Mr. Shull, a West Point graduate and former faculty member there, later joined Mr. Ullman at Federated Department Stores, and has also worked at the management consulting firms McKinsey & Company and Meridian Strategies.
* Jane Sanford, senior vice president of buyer-planner-stores systems, who helped Mr. Ullman create the computer systems at Federated.
* Jim Kenney, group vice president for corporate planning in the West division. An expert on corporate turnarounds, he also worked at Meridian and McKinsey.
* Tim Lupfer, Mr. Kenney's East division counterpart and the newest addition to the senior ranks. He completed a 20-year military career as an Army lieutenant colonel, leading a charge on Iraqi forces during Operation Desert Storm without a single casualty among his troops. Mr. Ullman likes his organizational skills.

HEADLINE: Mirror, Mirror

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

 BODY:
OUT of all interior spaces, perhaps none are as fearsome as the fitting room. Laden with secret psychology, they are spaces in which life's truths are tripled in tripartite mirrors. Setha Low, a professor of environmental psychology at the CUNY graduate center, calls them "the ultimate confrontational space."
Anne Cole, the California-based swimsuit designer, admits that there are "worse things in life than fitting rooms -- I just can't think of what they are." 
 As swimsuit sales multiply and beach blankets beckon, it is the season to contemplate the fickle nature of fitting rooms. Why is it that one can make you look languorously zucchiniesque (falsely) while another makes you look like a tomatillo's soul sister?
I was determined to unravel the secrets of their design, which seem to have all the dignity of Port-o-Sans, so I set out to explore fitting rooms across Manhattan, hoping to buy a bathing suit in the process.
"Wear black tights," suggested Ellin Saltzman, the fashion director for Bergdorf Goodman. "Real life isn't as harsh as a fitting room with a three-way mirror."
I began at Macy's. I knew Macy's was in bankruptcy; I wanted to keep an open mind. But Macy's was a prime example of the Confessional School of fitting room design (a claustrophobic box that left no doubt that I had sinned). The space was tiny, about 3 feet by 4 feet. It made me feel empathy for gerbils. All that was missing were cedar chips and a water bottle.
In search of decent lighting, customers parade out the fitting room doors into the store, past a retinue of husbands and boyfriends.
"This isn't so bad, right?" one woman squished into a too-tight suit said to her companion.
He lied.
I was thinking about the advantages of TV Macy's, the home-shopping channel to come, as I headed downtown. Accompanied by Harvey Bernstein, a designer who is working with Speedo Authentic Fitness, makers of bathing suits and other fitness gear, I visited Daffy's, a discount clothing store, which has chaotic communal dressing rooms, like Loehmann's. Mr. Bernstein pointed out globs of exposed mirror adhesive, which can sometimes result in mirror distortion.
This brought up the question of whether mirrors are rigged. I have long wondered about a conspiracy on the part of the nation's mirror manufacturers. Stan Rosen, who supplies mirrors to many New York retailers, later squashed this theory. But he confirmed that since the recession, many stores have opted for thin, quarter-inch mirrors, which if applied to a wavy surface can distort more than half-inch mirrors.
At Herman's World of Sporting Goods at Union Square an uplifting sign said "Health Regulations Prohibit Undergarment/Athletic Support Returns."
Herman's dressing rooms were tiny closetlike chambers. If claustrophobics wrote mythology, this would be Hades. A helpful sales person suggested that I should ask for the downstairs dressing room next time, which has been enlarged to comply with the Americans With Disabilities Act of 1990.
For comparison's sake, I decided to visit Emporio Armani on lower Fifth Avenue. There, the dressing room mirror was a freestanding piece of furniture, oak to be exact, rimmed with frosted lights that projected a flattering, luminous glow like a theatrical makeup mirror.
Mirror length is a telling thing. At the Gap, the mirrors do not quite extend to the floor, so you can't see your feet. This trick, while somewhat annoying, is "psychologically lengthening" Mr. Bernstein explained.
Lighting is the biggest secret in a dressing room's secret psychology. The most common placement is a spotlight, usually fluorescent, beaming down upon the shopper's head. But down-lighting tends to cast weird facial shadows, dappling the face and eliciting perspiration a la Richard Nixon in a Presidential debate. Dressing room designers could learn something from television talk shows, which always include a batallion of lights on the floor, tilted up slightly. "This wipes all the wrinkles away," Mr. Bernstein said. "It makes your complexion look fabulous."
One reason people get depressed while trying on bathing suits, said Diana Mesh, a lighting designer with the Walker Group/CNI, a retail design firm, is that severe shadowing in dressing rooms makes the skin look puckered. What a relief it is to know that shadows can give you cellulite.
PERHAPS the most bothersome fitting room feature, besides pins on the floor, is the half-door, beloved by discounters, in which you are crammed into a tiny cubicle with half a door. The door functions like a slip, disguising but also revealing. Your feet and calves are on view for all the world to see and your head looms above the door like a dazed giraffe.
"Most fitting rooms are designed by accident," said Paco Underhill, managing director of Envirosell Inc., which tests designs and studies how people shop. Still, slowly, the ethos is changing: while fitting rooms, like bus stations, still tend to be in menacing places -- like those forgotten corners beneath the air-conditioning ducts -- they seem to be growing a bit.
Kurt Barnard, publisher of a retail marketing report, said retailers were beginning to realize that design tactics that emulate police interrogation rooms don't work. Because of the competitive retail climate -- of catalogues, home-shopping networks, et al. -- stores are starting to enlarge their dressing rooms and pay more attention to shelves, furniture and other amenities, including lighting.
A little-known fact: Nationally, dressing room size is growing, said Janet Groeber, the editor of Visual Merchandising & Store Design magazine. Five years ago, the typical room was 3 feet by four 4 feet. Nowadays, it is 5 feet by 6 feet.
While dressing rooms are expanding, sales folk still seem to be disappearing. There is nothing worse than being stranded in the fitting room with a size 8 bathing suit only to discover you need a size 10. The sales person is nowhere to be found. Do you risk humiliation and go search for the correct size as is? Put all your clothes on? Leave in disgust? Where, you wonder, is the flight-attendant call button?
But such cosmic thoughts did not help my immediate plight. I stopped briefly into a Banana Republic downtown, in search of a decent dressing room. I found one. There were no hard shadows, there was room to turn around and there were industrial lights and wainscotting that brought the store's imagery into the dressing room.
Still suit-less, I finally worked up the courage to face Bloomingdale's. I quickly spied a nice bathing suit by Karla Coletto, with a net over it and a slit up the back, a Nicole Miller in a pastel plaid, and a skirted navy blue suit by Anne Cole that covered the thighs and looked depressingly promising. I perused the Calvin Kleins, mystified by tags that weren't color-coded by size, and wondered if it was Ralph Lauren's idea to call beach towels "body sheets."
The dressing rooms were a pleasant surprise -- quite roomy, with handsome bleached wood racks to hang clothes on, a shelf with room for a purse, several hooks placed strategically and a comfortable chair to sit on. The rooms were big enough for a stroller.
A sign told me that the inventory control clerk would be monitoring me and that I was limited to eight pieces, and thanked me for my cooperation.
Just outside the rooms was a three-way mirror that allowed a rational assessment without a public parade (I don't love a parade). Buoyed by this luxury, I said no to the Karla, the Nicole and the Anne, and yes to the Calvin ($127.74)
Was there a correlation between the gentility of the fitting room and my decision to buy a bathing suit? I suspect so. It's hard to tell.
In parting, I thought about what Anne Cole tells her customers before they go bathing suit shopping: "I suggest a dry martini."
Make mine a double.

Clara York Bingham and David Tead Michaelis, writers in Washington, were married there yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Robert K. Massie 4th performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

HEADLINE: Don't Tax, Don't Cut, Don't Panic Over Deficit

 BODY:
To the Editor:
With virtually no votes to lose, the Administration must now reconcile a House version of its economic plan that counts on the ill-fated British thermal unit tax and a Senate version that substitutes other unpopular taxes and spending cuts. A better substitute for the energy tax: Nothing! 
 Republicans and some conservative Democrats would cut spending, particularly on Medicare and other entitlements. Liberal Democrats argue this would injure lower- and middle-income citizens. Some of these Democrats would raise business taxes. Either would hurt the economy.
The core of the problem is President Clinton's insistence, egged on by some in Congress and the insatiable Ross Perot, that the proposed deficit reductions are sacrosanct. The reductions in the proposed budget are much more than Mr. Clinton ever promised in his campaign. He justified these larger deficit reduction demands on questionable new forecasts that indicated deficits beginning in 1996 and 1997 would otherwise begin rising much faster than anticipated.
There is no need to impose taxes now, largely to take effect later, on the possibility that further deficit reduction would be in order. There is no reason to add taxes effective now or to cut spending now. Either would seriously injure our weak economy.
President Clinton has a large -- possibly too large -- deficit reduction package on the table. Losing $70 billion or $80 billion of some $500 billion of accumulated deficit reductions in the next five years would be a small price to pay for getting his economic package through.
And the paradox is that the lesser deficit reductions would bring a more prosperous economy, which would very possibly reduce those future deficits after all.
 
ROBERT EISNER
Prof. of Economics, Northwestern U.
Evanston, Ill., June 25, 1993

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Next Week, the World Stage Clinton's Well-Timed 'Escape to Tokyo'

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHEN President Clinton steps from Air Force One onto Japanese soil on the afternoon of July 6, he will be granted a sort of magic wish.
Overnight, he stands to be transformed from a President struggling up a steep learning curve into a world leader of stature and weight. Arriving for the economic summit meeting with a deficit-reduction measure in hand that embodies the United States' promises to set its fiscal house in order before demanding the same of others, he will have accomplished what the other weakened leaders could only fantasize about. 
 At least this is the scenario the White House is counting on. Mr. Clinton's advisers are convinced that politics on the world stage is just like politics at home. Everything is relative.
No one knows this better than Bill Clinton, who rushed before the microphones on Friday, hours after his budget bill survived the Senate by a 50-to-49 vote, to claim victory and put it in a global context. "If you look at the level of aggression this country has displayed in trying to do something about its economic circumstances, as compared to what is going on in these other nations, the political and the economic problems," he said, "I think the United States should be very proud."
In spite of -- and perhaps because of -- the troubles here, White House officials are looking to the summit meeting with an odd mix of low expectations and giddy confidence. One senior adviser described the escape to Tokyo as "an opportunity made in heaven."
Administration officials had said a Senate defeat for the President's economic plan would have been "catastrophic" for the Asia trip. Now, even if the bill's immediate prospects remain up in the air -- a House-Senate conference must resolve differences over taxes and Medicare cuts -- Mr. Clinton's foreign policy and economic advisers say the disputes will not significantly change perceptions abroad.
"It's only the really close observer who goes beyond the fact that it looks like the President proposed a deficit cut and that's what he got," the official said. "So he goes with a win. And, moreover, it's a win precisely in the area where we have been being badgered for years."
At past economic summits, the United States has resisted pressure, coming especially from Japan, to lower its deficit as a step toward stimulating global growth.
This year is different. Months ago, the United States began taking a lead role in the Group of Seven, or G-7. The April meeting of the group's finance ministers marked the third since Mr. Clinton took office, and the countries' senior officials have been in contact ever since. The United States has also expanded its role as Russia's champion at the G-7 table.
 
About American Leadership
 "What this summit is really all about is American leadership," said Robert D. Hormats, a vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International and a former Assistant Secretary of State for economic and business affairs. "There are questions abroad about America's will to lead in the post-cold war period, about America's military presence abroad and concerns about American trade policy.
"There's an opportunity for the President at this summit to dispel these concerns and to rally other countries, despite their weakened conditions, around American goals and priorities."
All of this would bode well for Mr. Clinton's political future here. He and his senior advisers subscribe to a tenet that has guided most Presidents: When in trouble at home, look abroad.
Stan Greenberg, Mr. Clinton's pollster, said the President stands to gain from his Asia trip. "This is the first meeting of all the allies where the issues are almost wholly economic," he said.
The scales are weighted in Mr. Clinton's favor for several other reasons. Whatever setbacks he has suffered, when he meets with the leaders of Britain, Canada, France, Italy, Germany and Japan, he will be the only one who can be fairly certain that he will still be in charge of his country as few as three years hence.
As one American official put it: no other foreign leaders will be arriving at the summit with poll ratings higher than their shoe size or the prime rate.
Mr. Clinton also stands to regain substantial footing in the United States' relationship with Japan, which, having soured after a White House spat over trade issues, is now rebounding as the Japanese survey their collapsed political system.
"It is an enormous opportunity if we play it right," said Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics.
"If the President with his enhanced stature because of successes here and failures within Japan can play it skillfully and encourage political pluralism in Japan, it really could help us tremendously in the long run."
American negotiators who have been skittering across the Pacific for preparatory meetings have laid much of the groundwork for the substance of the meetings. Few expect that the communiques that are released in Tokyo will effect global economic change.
Mr. Clinton will arrive with three basic pitches: increased aid to Russia, combined efforts to boost the global economy and broader trade opportunities between the United States and its partners.
He can push only so far. The good news, of course, is that he can appear to be a worthy world leader when he stands for the ritual group photographs with other prime ministers and presidents. The drawback, his advisers warn, is that he cannot press too hard for concessions from leaders who have such severe popularity problems at home.
"What makes it tough is that all of those guys have to be extremely cautious," one State Department official said. "But it also makes it somewhat easier because all these folks are looking for achievements they can point to as well."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 938 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Iran's Zealots Get a Jolt Out of Failure

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES

DATELINE: TEHERAN

 BODY:
FOURTEEN years after the overthrow of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, the Iranian revolution has failed to achieve either prosperity or sustained hope. A costly eight-year war with Iraq, economic mismanagement and endemic corruption coupled with executions and arrests have left the clerics who rule Iran isolated and ever more dependent on the repressive organs of state security for control. Discontent is so widespread that even Government officials wonder aloud how they managed to lose so much support.
But amid these failures the Government has embarked on a new radicalism both within Iran and abroad and seems in many ways as potent as ever. 
Anti-vice squads and Islamic vigilante groups are back on the streets, harassing women for improper dress and searching cars for alcohol and Western videos. A five-day roundup ended last week in the arrest of 8,615 people described as drug addicts.
Abroad, Israel, Egypt and Algeria accuse Iran of supporting armed Islamic fundamentalist movements pitted against them. And Iranian dissidents have been gunned down in Rome and Berlin -- at the behest, it is widely believed, of mullahs here.
On the surface, the failures of the fundamentalist Government and its drive toward even greater extremism appear somewhat contradictory. But it is the very collapse of revolutionary ideology that is fueling Iran's new militancy.
Authoritarians who take charge in the name of the people but who fail to deliver on promises to uplift the downtrodden often fall back on the harsh tactics used in first securing power to keep hold of it. And, as in Iran, they frequently manipulate paranoia of the outside world to shore up their position.
Initially Iran was buoyed by the enthusiasm and sense of purpose that come with building a new society. Utopian Islamic ideology and the chimera of a new order brought masses to the streets to denounce the "Great Satan" during the United States Embassy hostage crisis. Later, after the 1980 invasion by Iraqi troops that triggered the Iran-Iraq war, young men zealously enlisted en masse and charged headlong into Iraqi machine guns. But with hundreds of thousands of Iranian war dead went the revolution's innocence and quixotic magic. Only the paranoia was left.
The end of the war in 1988 was supposed to bring with it not only peace but prosperity. But Iranians who sacrificed their youth and careers or lost friends or kinsmen have been rewarded with mounting unemployment, high inflation, housing shortages and a state-run economy that has driven industry into the ground.
The postwar malaise that has swept Iran has led many, especially the young, to idealize Western pop culture and turn away from religion.
"By creating this theocracy, by intertwining religious and political symbols, the clerics are building a nation of atheists," said a political scientist.
President Hashemi Rafsanjani, the so-called pragmatist who was re-elected by a less-than-resounding margin this month, has been unable to attract much foreign investment, lure back professionals in exile or wrench state industries from the hands of huge Islamic charity foundations, which control billions of dollars of assets and produce everything from cars to candy.
As discontent and unrest swells, the President has found that he must rely on hard-liners, many of whom head such foundations, to keep control. These are the very hard-liners who predicted his reforms would never work and made sure by sabotaging them.
Through clerics at local mosques, the Government is at least aware of its unpopularity. And while it does not shrink from brutality, it tolerates a level of dissent that would land an Iraqi in prison or in front of a firing squad.
Still, it has neutralized any organized opposition. Political parties and secular organizations are banned and every institution, from the universities to the army, has been purged of dissidents. The press is tightly controlled by clerics who, while permitting debate on economic or foreign policy, do not allow commentators or reporters to question the sanctity of the Islamic state. Neighborhood committees keep tabs on dissenters.
The mullahs have also had some success in blaming outside forces for their failures. America, still the "Great Satan," is portrayed as behind an array of problems, from drug addiction to ennui among the young.
Unless the clerics have a crisis of faith, at which point the fundamentalist state could collapse like a house of cards, their peculiar interpretation of Islam will remain sacred and unassailable.
And so economic decline and discontent have sparked in believers a new sense of urgency. While diplomats consider the Iraq-based opposition group, the People's Mujahedeen, a spent force, its perceived threat has taken on prominence in Government circles, which is why Iran, according to diplomats, braved international censure by gunning down an opposition leader, Mohammed Hussein Nagdi, in Rome in March.
In the old Intercontinental Hotel here, now a seedy stop for out-of-luck European executives and reporters, a Government theorist likened the new drive by the clerics to a passage in the Hadith, a collection of the prophet Mohammed's sayings.
In the passage, Mohammed and his followers are returning victorious from battle. The fighters look forward to an easy peace. But the prophet warns them that the battle they just finished will be nothing compared with the holy war, or jihad, they will soon have to engage in for people's hearts and minds.
"We return from the little jihad," the theorist said, quoting the prophet, "to the greater jihad."

LENGTH: 1046 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Labor Has a Big Job for Its New Friend Clinton

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
ORGANIZED labor, or what is left of it, has high hopes for the Clinton Presidency. But so far the Administration has put on the back burner all the proposals that might give labor more power, except for one: a bill that would prohibit management from replacing strikers permanently with newly hired workers. And now that bill has become the defining labor issue of the young Clinton Presidency, as important today as the air traffic controllers strike was in the early Reagan years.
The heart of the matter is not in the bill's details, although they are important. The heart of the matter is that both unions and management have chosen the bill for one of their periodic battles over the balance of power between them. A union victory would probably be followed by other union gains. And if the managers win, then President Clinton, for all his sympathies toward workers, might not be much better for organized labor than Ronald Reagan or George Bush. 
 "This is make or break," said Jeffrey H. Joseph, the chief lobbyist for an alliance representing thousands of companies trying to defeat the Cesar Chavez Workplace Fairness Act, which is named for the late farm workers leader. The House approved the bill earlier this month, but three or four votes are still lacking in the Senate to prevent a Republican filibuster that would defeat the bill when it comes to the floor next month. Mr. Joseph is lobbying hard to make the filibuster work.
"Enacting this bill would upset the marketplace pricing of labor," he said. "It would price workers above their market value."
And that is the issue: Should union workers earn only the lower pay and benefits that outsiders would accept if they could get their hands on union jobs? Or should unions regain enough power in collective bargaining to insulate the wages and benefits they have won over the years?
The Clinton Administration has come down on the side of strengthening collective bargaining through the Chavez bill. The President promised such a remedy during the election campaign and John Zalusky, a senior economist at the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said the "union movement certainly expects the Administration to put its whole weight behind the bill."
Testifying before Congress, Secretary of Labor Robert B. Reich has argued: "Without a viable right to strike, employers have less incentive to engage in serious bargaining with their unions, to hammer out mutually satisfactory solutions. And unions see no point in trying to work cooperatively with management" to increase their efficiency and output. To this, Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, a Kansas Republican, replied that without the threat of replacement, "there is little incentive for labor to make demands that are reasonable and reflect market realities."
The right to replace strikers has existed since 1938, when the Supreme Court legalized the practice. But until the 1980's it was hardly noticeable. Mostly, unions and managements signed ever richer labor contracts and the companies covered the higher labor costs by raising the prices of their products. Equally important, unions had other powers -- now outlawed -- that discouraged companies from hiring replacement workers.
People on strike, for example, could retaliate by picketing their company's suppliers and customers. Or union members at other companies could legally refuse to handle a struck company's products, or "hot cargo" -- a labor right outlawed in the largely pro-management Landrum-Griffin bill in 1959. That was the last major labor law passed by Congress, and now a changed world -- in which American companies are less dominant -- has brought on today's battle.
 
A Pool of People
 Rising competition from imports in the 1980's made it harder to raise prices to cover rising labor costs. It became easier for companies to move operations to lower-wage countries. And unemployment in a weak American economy made millions of people willing to grab at union jobs that paid higher wages than they could earn in nonunion work.
Drawing on this pool of people, President Reagan replaced the nation's air traffic controllers when they struck in 1981. Strikes by Federal Government employees are illegal, which justified the Reagan action. But corporate America found parallel justification in the Supreme Court's 1938 replacement worker ruling. Such prominent companies as International Paper, Greyhound, Eastern Airlines and Trans World Airlines hired thousands to replace strikers. And President Bush promised to veto a bill similar to the Chavez one, if Congress had passed it last year.
Not only replacement, but just the threat of it, made many union workers willing to accept concessions without striking -- or to end a strike abruptly, as 14,000 workers at Caterpillar Inc. did last year. The General Accounting Office, a research arm of Congress, found that more than 30 percent of all companies involved in strikes in the late 1980's announced they would hire permanent replacements. Not surprisingly, the number of major strikes has declined very sharply since the 1970's.
"The replacement worker bill, if it passes, would close an era that opened up with the air traffic controller crisis," said Charles A. Jeszeck, a G.A.O. labor economist. "And it might portend broader changes in the future."
The unions, for example, are pressuring the Clinton Administration for such things as a higher minimum wage and laws that would make organizing nonunion workers easier. But these requests have been referred to a blue ribbon commission that won't report until next May. Only striker replacement is on the table, and Harry Katz, a collective bargaining expert at Cornell University, says that unions might be wrong to attach so much importance to it.
"They are blaming too many of their troubles on management's right to replace strikers, and they are focusing too heavily on a legislative panacea to their declining power," Mr. Katz said. Temporary replacements, for example, would still be legal, which might keep a factory going for months.
Whatever the gamble, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. wants striker replacement gone. "If the bill is defeated, you will see alternatives to strikes developing," Mr. Zalusky said, "like working to rule or mandatory arbitration."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Its Competitors Distracted, France Gets to Be a Power

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
PERHAPS the only thing that France dislikes more than bowing to American leadership is having to recognize Germany as Europe's main power. The collapse of the Soviet bloc thus gave it good reason to worry: The United States was left as the sole superpower, while united Germany seemed destined to dominate the new Europe.
Yet France's fears of losing its clout appear premature. With the United States sending conflicting signals about its role in the world and Germany forced into introspection by economic and social problems, France has grabbed the chance to reassert itself as the only European power with global vision. 
 Even the ouster of a Socialist government by conservatives in elections in March seems to have worked to its advantage. The meeting of European Community leaders in Copenhagen last week could well have exposed rifts between the Socialist President, Francois Mitterrand, and the conservative Prime Minister, Edouard Balladur. Instead, they spoke as one: France has a single foreign policy.
Indeed, this policy has had the same objective since General de Gaulle decided in the 1960's that France should have its own independent nuclear deterrent: to convince Washington, Moscow and its European partners that France is a great power -- "une grande puissance." When this status was threatened by the cold war's end, the French elite was thrown into a tizzy. Now its proud image of itself is on the mend.
Oddly, the crisis in the former Yugoslavia has helped France in this regard. By assigning 5,000 troops to United Nations peacekeeping forces there, it has done what neither the United States nor Germany has done, a point that it is not shy to recall publicly. This in turn has given France moral authority to define the international response to the conflict, working -- unusually -- in tandem with Britain, which has 2,500 of its own soldiers in the field, many of them also in Bosnia.
Thus, when Washington contemplated air strikes against Serb artillery or, last week, when the German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, echoed President Clinton's call for lifting the arms embargo against Bosnian Muslims, France and Britain swiftly objected: Escalation would turn their troops into easy Serb targets or, perhaps worse, force them to abandon their humanitarian mission by withdrawing entirely.
 
Projecting Influence
 Far more than Britain, though, France seems intent on projecting its influence. It is participating in United Nations peace-keeping forces as far away as Somalia and Cambodia, but it also sees opportunities for initiatives in Europe itself. Aware of the region's failure to anticipate and then to halt the wars in former Yugoslavia, for example, it is now promoting the idea of an international conference next year to settle frontier and minority problems elsewhere in Eastern Europe.
Uncertainty in Europe has in turn prompted France to view the United States with new eyes. During the cold war, it never missed a chance to display its independence from Washington. After the Persian Gulf war, it feared that President Bush's oft-proclaimed "new world order" was a disguise for American domination, particularly of the Middle East, where France was once a major player. But now, with the Clinton Administration seemingly ambivalent about its global role, France is eager to maintain an American presence in Europe and is moving closer to NATO.
One reason is that the European Community has so far failed to live up to expectations as a new economic and political superpower. Barely 18 months ago, France hoped the Maastricht Treaty on European union would anchor Germany in a community committed to creating a single currency and common foreign and defense policies. But delays in ratification of the treaty combined with an economic recession have left the community drifting rudderless.
Relations between France and Germany, the traditional motors of European integration, have also been marked by new tensions. France blames high German interest rates for its economic slowdown, while Germany accuses France of blocking progress toward a new global trade liberalization accord in order to defend its farmers. A rare level of mutual irritation even forced cancellation of a ministerial meeting last week.
Certainly, with presidential elections to pick a successor to Mr. Mitterrand less than two years away, Mr. Balladur's conservative government is under strong pressure to show early results in the form of economic recovery. And this is feeding the temptation for still greater trade protectionism.
Yet while Germany, Britain, Italy and Spain as well as the United States and Japan all seem consumed by domestic problems, France has identified the absence of global leadership as an opportunity to make its voice heard. After community governments agreed last week to contribute more "men and money" to the United Nations effort in Bosnia, for example, France was the first to offer 800 extra troops.
Certainly, more than any of its allies, France has a clearly focused foreign policy today. And it knows that it has no time to waste. Already this month, the United States said it favored giving Germany and Japan permanent seats on the United Nations Security Council. In the past, this idea has included the suggestion that France and Britain lose their permanent seats. More than to provide leadership, then, France is eager to show that it still deserves the grand title of "une grande puissance." And, on this, there is a domestic consensus. It is, quite simply, a matter of honor.

HEADLINE: U.S. Will Focus on Reducing Pesticides in Food Production

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
The Federal Government has decided to reduce the use of chemicals in the production of the nation's food, assigning a higher priority than in the past to protecting children's health and the environment.
If the change of policy is fully carried out, it could alter everything about the way food is grown and what Americans eat. It was announced Friday by the Environmental Protection Agency, the Food and Drug Administration and the Department of Agriculture and will be reinforced in a scientific report to be issued Tuesday. 
 The announcement by the three agencies will "create incentives for the development of safe pesticides" and will "remove those pesticides that pose the greatest risk from the market," Dr. David A. Kessler, the Commissioner of Food and Drugs, said in an interview.
 
'Landmark' in Food Safety
 "The Administration is committed to reducing pesticides," he said, and supports "integrated pest management," a farming method that uses pesticides sparingly, increasing the use of beneficial insects and crop rotation.
Dr. Kessler said the Administration strategy underlying the three agencies' announcement was "a major landmark in the history of food safety."
Until now, critics have charged, agencies have been at odds over agricultural chemicals, and in recent years, especially during the Reagan and Bush Administrations, there has been little effort to restrict their use.
There has been no coordinated effort among the agencies, except when concerns about individual pesticides have raised public alarm. Otherwise, the environmental agency has dealt with analyzing the safety of pesticides, the health agency has tested for pesticide residues in food and the agricultural agency has promoted pesticides to help farm production.
"The Agriculture Department, E.P.A. and the Food and Drug Administration are working together in a way they have never done before to benefit the American people," said Carol M. Browner, Administrator of the E.P.A.
Both the food industry and the environmental movement worry that the new message could discourage people from eating fruits and vegetables, just when the Government is also stepping up efforts to persuade Americans to eat more of them.
The long-delayed National Academy of Sciences report, which will be made public on Tuesday, hedges its findings, saying that infants and children may be uniquely sensitive to pesticides. The report says the changes are necessary in chemical regulations to protect infants and children because of this possible sensitivity, and because their diets differ from those of adults.
 
Putting Health First
 "Infants and children differ both quantitatively and qualitatively from adults in their exposure to pesticide residues in foods," the report says, because they consume more calories per unit of body weight and tend to eat fewer types of food than adults.
The academy found that the data on what children eat and on how to set tolerance levels for pesticide residues for children were inadequate to make certain that they are protected.
While acknowledging the need for pesticides to increase the amount of fruits and vegetables available, the academy recommends that the E.P.A. put health considerations, rather than agricultural production, foremost in making decisions.
This is a significant change from current policy. In determining tolerance levels for pesticide residues, the E.P.A. now factors in economic benefits along with risks to human health.
 
More Sampling Urged
 The report also recommends that testing for pesticides be done on young animals, whose systems are more nearly like children's, than on adult animals, on which most testing has been done. It also calls for the collection of additional food-consumption data and more frequent sampling of foods that children eat in large quantities. And it says all exposures to pesticides, not just those from food, should be considered when setting tolerance levels.
The report concludes that "children should be able to eat a healthful diet containing legal residues without encroaching on safety margins."
A second report, which is to be made public on Monday, was done by the Environmental Working Group, a nonprofit research organization in Washington. It says that much of an individual's exposure to pesticides in food occurs by age 5 because children eat far more fruits and vegetables in relation to their body weight than do adults.
"Millions of children in the United States receive up to 35 percent of their entire lifetime dose of some carcinogenic pesticides by age 5," according to the report. By the time the average child is a year old, the report said, he will have received the acceptable lifetime doses of eight pesticides from 20 commonly eaten foods.
The report emphasizes that the levels of exposure to pesticides that the E.P.A. considers either probable or possible human carcinogens are low, but that the health effects are not known and have not been investigated.
 
Food Producers Object
 Both reports are being criticized by the food industry. In addition, the F.D.A has criticized the Environmental Working Group's report for its methodology and its conclusions.
But Dr. Kessler said while scientists may disagree on much of what is in the report, "the questions raised in the report, in conjunction with the forthcoming academy report, point out an absolutely valid message: 'We've got a lot of pesticides out there, and we ought to be doing something to reduce them.' "
Trade associations for the food industry have spent the last several weeks preparing press releases and advisories to tell their side of the story. There is a lot at stake, since response to the cumulative effect of these reports and the Government's announcement could eventually mean not only tighter controls on the use of pesticides but, more immediately, a precipitous drop in sales of fruits and vegetables.
What has the industry working so hard to forestall a crisis are memories of the Alar scare with apples.
 
'Alarmist Language'?
 "We fully expect," the Center for Produce Quality said on June 16, "that activist groups may use the N.A.S. report as an opportunity to use high-visibility press events, celebrities and alarmist language to generate public concern." The center is the information arm of the United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association and the Produce Marketing Association.
The references to celebrities and the news media involve the actress Meryl Streep and the CBS television program "60 Minutes," which persuaded much of the public in 1989 to boycott apples because some of them were being sprayed with Alar, a growth regulator that has caused cancer in animals. That all apples were not sprayed with Alar was lost in the resulting uproar, and millions of pounds of apples were destroyed, ruining some farmers.
Ken Cook, executive director of the Environmental Working Group, said at a news conference on Friday, "Any publicized purge in the nation's kitchens, of the sort that the Alar controversy inadvertently generated in 1989, will almost certainly work against efforts to make the food supply safer from pesticides."
Efforts to place greater control on pesticides, to reduce their use through such agricultural methods as organic farming, began in the 1960's but did not find much broad public support until the 1980's. In 1985, Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, introduced legislation to strengthen pesticide regulations.
In 1987, a National Academy report said that the nation's food supply was inadequately protected from cancer-causing pesticides. In 1989, the year of the Alar scare, the Natural Resources Defense Council released its report "Intolerable Risk: Pesticides in our Children's Food." But the Federal Government took did nothing significant to change the pesticide regulations.
The current pesticide legislation introduced by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Representative Waxman addresses some of the findings of the two new reports.
The food and chemical industries say that the food supply is safe but agree that changes in regulations are in order. "We need to be especially concerned about children," said Lester Crawford, executive vice president for scientific affairs of the National Food Processors Association, "because they will get 70 years of exposure. Changes ought to be made in E.P.A. regulations."
Despite the food industry's defensive posture, it has been working for a decade to reduce the amount of pesticides used in food. The National Food Processors, the Grocery Manufacturers of America and the United Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Association have been recommending that their members use Integrated Pest Management. "We have 500 members," Mr. Crawford said, "and at least 25 percent of them have some commitment to integrated pest management."
Gerber Products Company, the baby-food manufacturer, requires its growers to use pest management techniques.
"We need to make a reduction in the use of pesticides," said Ms. Browner of E.P.A., "and we want to see children protected."
 
 
ADVICE ON PRODUCE: EAT IT ANYWAY
 Despite the cautions about pesticides in children's food, the executive directory of the Environmental Working Group, said, "Don't throw out those fresh strawberries, Mom."
Consumer and environmental groups like the Natural Resources Defense Council and the Consumers Union are telling parents to keep feeding their children fruits and vegetables whether they are organic or not.
"In fact," said Laurie Mott, a senior scientist with the defense council, "eat more fruits and vegetables because there are anti-carcinogens in fruits and vegetables." In addition, they are filled with vitamins, minerals and fiber and have virtually no fat.
Consumer and nutrition experts also recommend that shoppers urge grocers to stock organic foods or those certified as having no detected pesticide residues.
They also say produce from farmers' markets has less pesticide contamination because the crops do not have to travel far. And it is easier to find organically grown food at these markets than in most supermarkets.
Washing and peeling vegetables and fruits, the experts say, can eliminate some pesticide residues.

HEADLINE: Poll Finds Tide of Immigration Brings Hostility

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 26

 BODY:
With both legal and illegal immigration into the United States approaching historic highs, a public reaction against immigration is also growing, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
After decades of heavy immigration that has included large numbers of Hispanic laborers and Southeast Asian refugees, and at a time when many Americans are out of work, a large majority of Americans surveyed said they favored a decrease in immigration. Many cited the economy as a factor in their opinion. 
 The poll shows that anti-immigrant feelings are also colored by a perception -- contrary to the facts -- that most immigrants are in the United States illegally. But the survey also shows that people are much more willing to welcome immigrants when the issue is couched in personal terms.
 
Anti-Immigrant Trend
 When asked whether immigration into the United States should be "kept at its present level, increased or decreased," 61 percent of those answering the national telephone survey last week preferred a decrease. That preference is up from a 1986 Times/CBS News poll, when 49 percent favored a decrease.
One of the poll respondents, Dorothy Lepping, a 33-year-old postal worker in East Stroudsburg, Pa., said her opinions had been shaped by the way she had seen immigrants treated in her hometown. "I saw the amount of aid that went out to them and the way that was abused," she said in a telephone interview after the poll. "I feel that our economy is in a bad state and we should take care of our own."
Such sentiments have grown over the decades. When the Gallup Poll posed the same question in 1977, just 42 percent favored a decrease in immigration; in 1965, when a new law ended four decades of low immigration, just 33 percent called for a decrease.
Shifts in public attitudes seem to parallel changes in economic conditions. In 1965, the nation's unemployment rate fell to just over 4 percent, as compared with the 6.9 percent reported for last May, and the economic growth rate then was 5.6 percent, as compared with this year's forecast of 3.1 percent, a prediction that may be scaled back.
According to the Immigration and Naturalization Service, 8.9 million people have immigrated legally into the United States over the past decade, and an estimated 3 million more have slipped into the country illegally. Immigration experts say the numbers approach those of the great wave of European immigration at the turn of the century and are the highest since comprehensive immigration laws were enacted in 1924.
"What people are reacting to now is the reality of the past 20 to 25 years," said Ira Mehlman, a spokesman for the Federation for American Immigration Reform, a lobbying group that seeks to reduce immigration. "There are unprecedented levels of immigration and the numbers are growing, and the American people are saying, 'Enough is enough.' "
 
Economy Affects Opinions
 The tightening economy also seems to be a major reason for the increasing anti-immigration sentiment in the new poll, which was conducted Monday through Thursday and questioned 1,363 adults nationwide. The poll has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points. The participants in the 1986 poll and last week's poll were asked, "Do you think that, in general, the United States should welcome immigrants who come here with very little to try to make a success of their lives, or are conditions here today too hard for this to be practical?"
In the new poll, only 32 percent said the country should welcome immigrants, while 60 percent said this was not practical because of hard conditions.
In 1986, when the same question was asked at a time when economic conditions were better, 43 percent said the country should welcome immigrants, approximately equal to the 45 percent who said it was not practical because of hard conditions.
"If we had a robust economy, even a sustained high level of immigration would not create much controversy," said Arthur C. Helton, director of the Refugee Project of the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights. "I think if you look at the development of immigration policy, the impact on the work place would emerge as a decisive factor."
But only 36 percent of respondents last week and 34 percent in 1986 said they believed that most immigrants "take jobs away from American citizens." In contrast, 55 percent in the new poll and 52 percent in 1986 said immigrants "mostly take jobs Americans don't want."
 
Black Point of View
 Black Americans were nine percentage points more likely than whites to see immigrants taking jobs away, but blacks were nine points less likely to prefer a decrease in immigration than whites.
Another reason for the growing sentiment against immigration seems to be the perception that most recent immigrants are here illegally. In the new poll, 68 percent agreed that "most of the people who have moved to the United States in the last few years are here illegally." In 1986, that number was just 49 percent.
"If you can picture the image of the Statue of Liberty dissolving," Mr. Helton said, "and being replaced by the image of the World Trade Center after it was bombed, you have the sense of the negative trends in the current debate."
Other images of immigrants -- some unflattering and some more positive -- have remained relatively stable over time. While 44 percent of the people surveyed in 1986 and about half of those asked in the recent poll said that most new immigrants "cause problems," nearly half of the respondents in both polls said that "today's immigrants work harder than people born here."
Mr. Mehlman said he was concerned that a backlash against immigration could lead to increased acts of violence against immigrants, like those that have swept Germany. But the new poll shows that while many Americans may be ready to slam the country's door on immigrants, they remain unwilling to be personally rude to them.
Asked what would happen "if some of today's new immigrants moved into your neighborhood," 67 percent of respondents in the poll said the newcomers "would be welcomed." In 1968, 68 percent offered a similar welcome.
"You want to give them a fair shake," Mrs. Lepping said.

HEADLINE: Naval Depots in 3 States Face Closing

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
Paring Navy installations that support the fleet, a Presidential commission voted today to close large naval maintenance depots in California, Florida and Virginia that employ nearly 12,000 civilian workers.
On the panel's fourth day of final deliberations on 238 installations, the commission voted to shut down 21 installations and keep open 32 others, while 9 were either pared back or expanded. 
 With the end of the cold war, declining military budgets have forced the closing of many well-known bases. But maintenance depots, which provide critical support to the bases, actually employ a much larger number of civilian workers than the military installations.
The Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission recommended closing naval aviation depots in Alameda, Calif., which employs 3,900 civilians, in Pensacola, Fla., with 3,800 civilians, and in Norfolk, Va., with 4,100 civilians. The Pentagon has said it has more than 50 percent more depot capacity than it needs among all the armed services.
 
Moving 'Top Gun' School
 The commissioners also approved a Navy plan to move its famed "Top Gun" fighter pilot school at Miramar Naval Air Station in San Diego to Nevada. In a complex realignment, the Pentagon will close two Marine Corps air bases in Southern California and transform Miramar from a Navy fighter base into a home for Marine Corps jets and helicopters, an unusual combination.
The panel also agreed to close Agana Naval Air Station in Guam, one of the few installations that the Pentagon wanted to keep and the local community wanted to close. Guam's elected officials have wanted to close the base for years and find other uses for its choice waterfront property.
Commissioners also recommended closing Cecil Field Naval Air Station in Jacksonville, Fla., and moving its aircraft and forces to naval or Marine air bases at Cherry Point, N.C., Beaufort, S.C., and the Oceana base near Norfolk
The commission concludes its votes on Sunday and will send its final recommendations to President Clinton, who has until July 15 to approve or reject the entire package. If he approves, Mr. Clinton then forwards the package to Congress for approval or rejection. Given the pressures to cut military spending, approval appears almost certain.
 
Following Pentagon's Plans
 In March, Defense Secretary Les Aspin recommended closing or shrinking 43 major installations and 122 smaller sites. The commission later added 47 other major bases and 26 smaller sites for consideration. Commissioners had suggested in interviews that they might substitute some bases for Mr. Aspin's choices, but are unlikely to close many more installations than the Pentagon wants.
The panel, after tinkering with Mr. Aspin's recommendations in its first two days, have largely approved the Pentagon's proposals. If Mr. Aspin's recommendations were to be accepted, the Defense Department would spend $1.7 billion to clean up and close those installations, and then expect to save $3.1 billion a year beginning in the year 2000.
Closing maintenance depots yields large savings from the salaries of the civilian employees there. The Navy had said it needed to close three of its six depots, but maintain at least one of the two depots on the West Coast. The commission's decision on Friday to close the naval air base in Alameda, Calif., in the San Francisco Bay area, made inevitable the closing of the supporting depot there. The other West Coast depot, the North Island depot in San Diego, will be kept open.
That left the four depots on the East Coast. Commissioners decided to close the naval aviation depots at Norfolk and Pensacola, and keep the more efficient installations at Jacksonville, Fla., and Cherry Point, N.C.
The commission did not directly consider a broader and related issue to direct more maintenance work to commercial military contractors that have been hurt by shrinking Pentagon budgets. Mr. Aspin has said the Pentagon is reviewing the balance between military and commercial depot work.
 
Minimal Economic Pain
 The Pentagon's plan to move Navy and Marine Corps aircraft in Southern California causes minimal economic disruption, except in Orange County, where two Marine bases, El Toro and Tustin, will close. The panel voted in 1991 to close Tustin, but commissioners were reconsidering the decision.
Under the plan, 110 CH-46 and CH-53 transport helicopters at Tustin will move to Miramar or two other bases near San Diego, Camp Pendleton or North Island. The Marines will move 121 F-18 fighters at El Toro to Miramar. To make room at Miramar, the Navy will send 120 F-14's to the Lemoore base near Fresno, Calif., and the "Top Gun" school to Fallon, Nev.
It is unusual to base large numbers of slow-flying helicopters and supersonic jets at the same base for safety and training reasons. The wash from helicopter blades, for example, can propel pebbles and other debris into the sensitive intakes of jet engines if precautions are not taken. But commissioners decided they were in no position to second-guess the Navy on such military decisions, and approved the move.
