HEADLINE: Political Memo;
States' Top Democrats Get Appeal for Patience

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., June 26

 BODY:
For a party that assumed the White House only five months ago, the message at a convention of state Democratic leaders here was a candid admission that amounted to a political confessional: Lower your expectations and be patient with your President. He's learning from his mistakes.
In public and in private, David Wilhelm, chairman of the Democratic Party, devoted hours this weekend trying to convince restive state leaders that President Clinton had a bright future, even while conceding the party's shortcomings. 
 "We all look at ourselves in the mirror and say, 'What have we not done as well?' We have not responded as aggressively or as effectively as we might have to attacks," Mr. Wilhelm said at the summer meeting of the Association of State Democratic Chairs. "And we need to do that." Repeatedly, he told his followers that "the thing we did not do well is communicate what we are doing."
Faced with what even Mr. Clinton's supporters concede has been the most traumatic debut for a President in modern times, the best the Democrats could do was blame themselves and Mr. Clinton for the blunders, always reminding themselves that there was still time, that a Presidency is not made in five months.
 
'I Thought He'd Take Off'
 "I didn't expect Clinton to come in and make the mistakes he made -- I thought he'd come in and take off," said Robert F. Thomas, chairman of the Tennessee Democratic Party. "People in the grass roots are still very unhappy. I still see a lot of 'Impeach Clinton' stickers. But I'm confident we're on the upswing. I just think he's learning how to do things."
Stanley Greenberg, Mr. Clinton's pollster, sought to put the best face on the record low popularity ratings for a President at this early stage in office when he told the conference, "There are a lot of governors in this country who would take 40 percent job approval."
But he conceded that Mr. Clinton was hampered by an alienated electorate that is pessimistic that much can be done to improve the economy. After weeks of tumbling poll ratings that started when the President's package to stimulate the economy stumbled in Congress, Mr. Greenberg said, "We are at a point, I think, of stability."
 
Heady Days Long Past
 It was a long way from the heady days after the election, when Democrats gloated about mandates and trumpeted the era of the "New Democrats." In their yearning for the White House, many party leaders had not considered the down side of gaining power. As the adage goes: Be careful of the things you wish. Wishes come true.
Aiming to improve things, Mr. Wilhelm today unveiled a long-promised effort to expand the party at the local level -- and make inroads into Ross Perot's base -- with a Perot-style network built on using toll-free telephone numbers, national petition drives and newsletters to reach out to Democratic voters. Mr. Wilhelm also said the party was planning a national convocation of young voters for later this year.
"Now that we have a President in the White House," Mr. Wilhelm said, "our mission changes. That is why these initiatives are so crucial." For all the buildup, Mr. Wilhelm was short on specifics, unable to even offer a rough estimate of how much he will budget for the initiatives.
But his most important task was to reassure uneasy Democrats about his own leadership as well as the future of the party. Several said that for now, they were heeding Mr. Wilhelm's call to withhold judgment as the President tries to enact a new economic program, a new health-care system and a national service plan.
 
'A Learning Process'
 "Of course there's some concern," said Marlys Matuszak, the chairwoman of the Wisconsin Democratic Party. "But when you take over anything, there's a learning process."
Rick Stafford, the party chairman in Minnesota, conceded that the Democrats' post-election swagger had given way to the rigors of governing. "We got complacent given the euphoria that came with the election," he said. "But I think we've been apologizing too much. We should not blame our President. He is a human being. He is not a God. He is not a monarch. I think we expect too much."
This guarded optimism was encouraged by good timing: Hours after the state leaders arrived here, the Senate approved Mr. Clinton's budget. It was by the closest of margins, and the measure faces an uncertain future in a House-Senate conference, but Democrats still touted the vote as a big victory.
James J. Brady, who is chairman of the Louisiana Democratic Party and president of the Association of State Democratic Chairs, said Mr. Clinton could not help but invite controversy by proposing a program that would raise taxes and cut spending. "I don't know anybody that runs up and says, 'Give me all the castor oil you can,' " he said. "But he's telling the American people truthfully how things have to be."
As much as he tried to put the best face on Mr. Clinton's first months in office, even Rahm Emanuel, the outgoing White House political director, warned Democrats not to read too much in the President's recent good fortune. "No one should take the last week to mean that we're out of the woods," he said. "We've got a lot of work to do."
Mr. Emanuel, who had been criticized as too prickly, is himself a casualty of the new Administration's growing pains. He will head the White House's campaign-style "rapid response" effort to react to attacks from Republicans. He will be replaced by his deputy, Joan Baggett, whom Mr. Emanuel described to the gathering as capable of running "a kinder, gentler political operation."
 
Rallying to the Chairman
 At least for now, Mr. Wilhelm, a longtime friend of Mr. Emanuel, has endured sniping from Capitol Hill and the White House over his own leadership. This weekend, many Democrats rallied to the side of the Chicago political strategist was Mr. Clinton's campaign manager.
Al From, the president of the Democratic Leadership Council, the centrist group that Mr. Clinton turned to for ideas as he sought the Presidency, said the attacks on Mr. Wilhelm were unavoidable.
"David's in a very tough spot, and the reason is we are a party that hasn't had a strong President in a quarter century," said Mr. From, whose group has improved relations with the Democratic National Committee after years of tensions.
"We have to build a new party infrastructure, and it's very different from the old party infrastructure where you just go to a few leaders and organize your troops," he said. "David's looking at ways to really do some grass-roots organizing."
The plea from Mr. From and others this weekend, was simple: Give Mr. Clinton some time.
"A year from now," Mr. Brady predicted, "they'll be saying, 'The President's the greatest thing going since sliced bread.' "

HEADLINE: In Miami, Talk of Talking With Cuba

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, June 26

 BODY:
Emboldened by the change of administrations in Washington and deteriorating economic conditions in Cuba, new voices calling for a more flexible attitude toward Fidel Castro's Communist Government are emerging in the Cuban exile community here and challenging the hegemony of established groups.
The resulting political ferment most threatens the Cuban-American National Foundation, which for a dozen years has dominated, if not monopolized, exile politics. Having identified itself with the Reagan and Bush Administrations, the group has, in recent months, seen its influence diminish in Washington and had its political agenda increasingly questioned here. 
 One of the most visible signs of the new political atmosphere is the formation of an organization called Cambio Cubano, or Cuban Change. It is led by Eloy Gutierrez Menoyo, a former guerrilla commander and Cuban political prisoner, who says he is "prepared to dialogue with anybody" in Havana. The group favors more contacts between exiles and Cuba and opposes tightening the economic embargo against the Castro Government.
 
Orthodox Views Assailed
 The Cuban-American National Foundation, in contrast, was the architect of a law passed last year that prohibits foreign subsidiaries of American companies from doing business with Cuba. The foundation dismisses those calling for negotiations with Havana as hopelessly naive or tools of President Castro.
Domingo Moreira, a foundation director, said Mr. Gutierrez Menoyo's views "represent a minute fraction of the Cuban-American community." Mr. Gutierrez Menoyo is one of many people, Mr. Moreira said, "who want to stake out their political ground now that they have seen Castro's end is near."
But anti-Castro Cubans still living on the island and their allies in Miami have also intensified their involvement in the fray, issuing manifestos that criticize orthodox exile positions that would tighten the trade embargo and shun negotiations with Mr. Castro.
Orestes Lorenzo, the Cuban Air Force defector who became a hero among exiles when he flew back to Cuba in December 1992 to rescue his wife and sons, provoked a controversy earlier this year when he recommended that Cuban exiles load medicine, food and clothing onto boats and sail to Havana as part of a "Crusade of Love" to relieve suffering among Cubans.
Simon Ferro, a Cuban-American lawyer here who is a former chairman of the Florida Democratic Party, said: "Because we have a Democratic Administration that is more inclusive than past Republican administrations, maybe people are not as afraid to come out and talk publicly about the varying degrees of political opinion that exist within the community. Those voices were always there, but I think they weren't expressed because they didn't think they would get a fair shake in Washington."
The Cuban-American foundation, established in 1981, has become the most powerful Cuban exile organization in this country through adroit lobbying, financial muscle and, its critics assert, intimidation of potential rivals and manipulation of the Spanish-language news media. Last year, the human rights group Americas Watch issued a report criticizing foundation leaders for contributing to "a repressive climate for freedom of expression" here.
Mr. Lorenzo's aid proposal came amid reports of growing shortages of essentials in Cuba, including a scarcity of food that some doctors now believe may be responsible for a mysterious epidemic of blindness. "We need to take food, not bullets," Mr. Lorenzo said in a recent speech here. "We need to show them we care."
Exile groups that favor intensifying the embargo against Cuba have attacked Mr. Lorenzo's plan, saying it would only help prop up Mr. Castro. But many Cuban-Americans here, concerned about the health of their relatives in Cuba, grumble about that hard-line approach as they quietly flock to pharmacies to buy vitamins and medicine to ship to those relatives.
 
Unusual Credibility
 It is not clear how large a following Mr. Gutierrez Menoyo and the others of his view have, especially since their political agendas have been attacked by local Spanish-language radio stations that dutifully echo the foundation's more confrontational attitude. But his role as a founder of the paramilitary group Alpha 66 and the 22 years he spent in Cuban jails as a political prisoner give him unusual credibility. He was also an early supporter of Bill Clinton's campaign for President.
The foundation, in contrast, got off on the wrong foot with the Clinton Administration by helping sabotage the nomination of Mario Baeza, a Cuban-American lawyer from New Jersey, as Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs. The foundation considered Mr. Baeza too conciliatory toward Havana. The organization continues to wield considerable influence in Congress, where it makes generous donations to members from both parties, but, as a human-rights lobbyist in Washington put it, "it no longer has a pipeline to the Oval Office."
As a result, the future of TV Marti, long a pet project of the foundation, is in jeopardy. The House Appropriations Committee refused on Thursday to authorize any money for the station's broadcasts to Cuba, and the White House has made no effort to have the decision reversed.
Another sign of the Administration's disenchantment with the foundation came last month when about 100 prominent Cuban-Americans were invited to the White House ceremony observing Cuban Independence Day. The guests ranged from the pop star Gloria Estefan to Mr. Lorenzo and even Republican members of the Cuban-American delegation in Congress, but notably absent were foundation leaders who in the past routinely had access to the White House and the President.
Mr. Ferro, the former State Democratic official who helped organize the ceremony, cautioned that "just because more people are now advocating a softer, more conciliatory stance toward Cuba doesn't mean that is what Clinton is going to do."
But, he added: "The new atmosphere in which debate can develop lacks the kind of stress that existed before. People are jockeying for attention because they feel there is more room for voices now."
For its part, Washington has made it clear that it will not permit groups to the political right of the foundation to attack Mr. Castro. Last month, agents of the United States Customs Service arrested nine members of Alpha 66 after they were caught in the Florida Keys aboard a boat loaded with semiautomatic rifles and explosives. An Alpha 66 leader admitted that the men were heading to Cuba with the intention of sparking a rebellion.
Last month, a State Department spokesman, Joseph Snyder, said, "The United States Government does not support, condone or encourage any such illegal activities." He said the Government would prosecute those caught organizing attacks against Havana in violation of neutrality laws.

HEADLINE: How Scandal Undercut Japan's Smug Leaders

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 26

 BODY:
For the aging postwar rulers of Japan, the end began with a shady real estate deal: nothing too big, just a sleek glass office building in front of Kawasaki Station.
To construct the building on such a choice location in the mid-1980's, the president of a high-flying company called Recruit passed enormous amounts of unlisted stock in his company to powerful members of the governing Liberal Democratic Party. 
 It turned out to be just a first, wayward drop from a river of corruption, one that in time led to ties between politicians and the underworld, multimillion-dollar deals for companies that urgently needed changes in Japanese regulations, and finally a safe full of gold in the offices of Shin Kanemaru, the party's sly, craggy-faced fixer.
Through it all, the party's conservative leadership never really worried about survival. After 38 years of unchallenged rule, they gained a sense of invulnerability, which was born of a confidence that while individual politicians might rise or fall, the party that presided over Japan's incredible postwar ascendancy faced no real challengers.
 
Destruction by Proteges
 But by last week, five years, four scandals and three prime ministers later, those same leaders watched their power and their party implode in just hours -- destroyed not by their rivals, but by their own proteges, who abandoned Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa and voted for a motion of no confidence in their own Government.
It was as if the Liberal Democrats' infrastructure, seemingly massive and unshakable from the outside, had rotted so thoroughly from within that a small tap sent it to splinters.
The party's most wily and respected political strategist, Masaharu Gotoda, who at age 78 serves as Deputy Prime Minister and Justice Minister, volunteered this week that the party's leaders had it coming. Recalling the first disclosures of corruption in 1988, he said, "That is when we should have had sweeping political reform. If we had done it then, we would not be facing a situation like this today."
But more than reform was at stake. The end of the cold war meant that the old fear -- that the toppling of the Liberal Democratic Party would destroy the country's economic system and its alliance with the United States -- had slowly evaporated. A stubborn recession and new trade tensions made many realize that the party that built Japan by protecting its markets, its farmers and its manufacturers -- often at the expense of its consumers -- might be an impediment in the next stage: learning how not to be the object of the world's economic resentment.
 
Socialists May Also Split
 Now the tremor is spreading. Japan's Socialist Party, the nation's perpetual opposition, also appears on the verge of splitting, dividing the old left-wing ideologues off from a more pragmatic, far younger group of legislators. Together, the rebels on both sides seem likely to form a coalition government that, if it survives, will cut out many of the older leaders who have dominated the nation for four decades.
Many people believe that the change could lead to actual debate about the country's future and its isolationist tendencies, something rare in Japanese history. It is the greatest chance here since the end of World War II to create a political system in which parties may alternate in winning power.
What has happened is clearly not a people-power revolution: it came about with none of Italy's street demonstrations, none of South Korea's tear gas. But the popular disgust created an opportunity for ambitious younger politicians.
Still, when the dust settles, many Japanese are asking, will a new party structure solve anything? Will it end the abuses of power, or simply redirect the graft? In a few years, will the parties spinning off from the Liberal Democrats come together again, purged of conservative elders who did not retire or die fast enough? And for America, will this ultimately create a Japan more geared toward the lives of consumers -- and thus more interested in lower prices, freer markets and more imports?
 
Origins of Power: Anti-Communism Party Keystone
 From its birth in 1955, the Liberal Democratic Party had a single raison d'etre: anti-Communism. The sudden rise of the Communist and Socialist Parties in Japan sparked union movements and deep opposition to the mutual security pact with the United States and the building of Japan's Self-Defense Forces. The United States was so worried that the Central Intelligence Agency gave the party aid for years.
But by the late 1960's the opposition had been virtually neutralized and the party had become the umbrella group for virtually every Japanese special interest, from farmers to car makers. As its power grew, the Japanese business community, certain its survival depended on keeping the party in power, funneled vast sums of money into the system. In turn the Liberal Democrats made sure that the Socialist and Communists got just enough seats and money to form a credible, but non-threatening, opposition.
In the mid-1970's the culture of Japan's "money politics" was exposed when it became publicly known that the Lockheed Corporation had made millions of dollars in payoffs in connection with the sale of its planes in Japan, including $2.1 million to Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka. But even after Mr. Tanaka resigned and was convicted of bribery charges, cash was still king and ideological ferment was banished. Self-perpetuation became the goal.
"There was no policy debate," said Chalmers Johnson, a professor at the University of California at San Diego, and long a student of the distribution of power in Japan. "So for 30 years these guys have done nothing but plot their own re-election, or the re-election of their sons."
 
Failure of Reformers
 Periodic promises of reform sometimes narrowed the pipelines of money, but never rebuilt the machines that sucked it in. And as the economy boomed in the 1980's, small and mid-sized companies like Recruit, looking for influence and a chance to break into the market, began flooding the governing party with money.
The Recruit scandal swept away Mr. Miyazawa, then serving as Finance Minister, and eventually Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita, who was forced to resign in 1989. His most loyal political fund-raiser, master of selling $14 million in "tickets" to parties for Mr. Takeshita, committed suicide, perpetuating the party's conspiracy of silence about where the money came from.
The first warning from the voters came that year, stripping the party of its majority in the less-powerful upper house of Parliament. Though still divided and weak, the opposition had a monkey-wrench to throw into the machine: the ability to block everything but budget resolutions in Parliament.
But after the ritual cleansing of an election loss, the party bowed, apologized and seemed to come back. After the brief, disastrous premiership of Sousuke Uno, who resigned amid a sex scandal, the party installed a reform-minded Prime Minister with little independent initiative, Toshiki Kaifu.
Popular and well-intentioned, he provided a clean facade for the party barons. But when Mr. Kaifu briefly stepped into his own, indirectly threatening to dissolve Parliament unless a political reform bill was pushed through, they pulled the rug from beneath him, forcing him out of office in hours.
He remains bitter, remembering that Mr. Miyazawa suggested to him that he might not be ready to play "professional league baseball."
"I wonder what he thinks of baseball now," Mr. Kaifu said, musing about Mr. Miyazawa, who is expected to be deposed once the election is over.
 
'The Don of Dons': Kanemaru's Greed Speeds the Fall
 If any single person is responsible for bringing the Liberal Democratic Party's era to an end, it may be Shin Kanemaru.
At 78, Mr. Kanemaru is a brooding presence, with heavy-lidded eyes that make him look like a movie-studio parody of an aging kingmaker. He never held the premiership, and never really seemed to covet it. But with a few choice words, he determined the routes of multibillion-dollar bullet train projects and placed his lieutenants in strategic posts around the country.
The source of his power was the Takeshita faction, the biggest and richest of the half-dozen or so party groupings. But over time Mr. Kanemaru got sloppy. Last summer he admitted that he had taken $4 million in illegal contributions and stepped down as the vice president of the party. But he refused to be questioned. Instead, he negotiated a token fine of $1,700 -- less than the top fine for overnight parking on Tokyo's streets. And after mailing it in he headed off to work the next morning as if nothing had happened.
Prime Minister Miyazawa, who had been installed by Mr. Kanemaru, refused even to acknowledge a problem, stalking away one day when Japanese reporters had the temerity to ask about it.
The extraordinarily light treatment accorded Mr. Kanemaru prompted a public outcry that emboldened the leadership's many enemies. The Mainichi Shimbun, a major daily, called Mr. Kanemaru "the don of all dons." Then new evidence emerged that he had sought the help of gangsters to silence critics of Mr. Takeshita when he ran for Prime Minister in 1987. Mr. Kanemaru finally gave up his seat in Parliament.
That did not end matters. One Saturday night in early March, the prosecutors, stung by charges that they had let him off too easily, suddenly arrested the fallen politician for tax evasion. As they emptied his safe, they found $50 million, including the gold bars that became a symbol of how the party enriched itself. Mr. Takeshita, called to testify in Parliament, denied knowledge of virtually everything. So did Ichiro Ozawa, Mr. Kanemaru's chief protege, who said he had only served drinks during the critical meetings.
Mr. Gotoda, who as Justice Minister is believed to have given the arrest order, told a visitor to his office this week: "Somebody like Kanemaru could not have lasted that long. Factional politics was pushed to the limit." The party's split, he said, "was inevitable."
 
The Collapse: Party Implodes In Power Vacuum
 Mr. Kanemaru's downfall led to the breakup of the Takeshita faction and accelerated a power free-for-all. Mr. Ozawa broke away to form a faction of his own with Tsutomu Hata, a former Finance Minister.
Their platform was political reform, something many Japanese have a hard time accepting from Mr. Kanemaru's chief lieutenant. His group soon was at war with Mr. Takeshita's remaining loyalists.
The other factions were also falling apart. After the death in 1991 of Shintaro Abe, his faction -- the party's second largest, now led by Hiroshi Mitsuzuka -- saw its influence decline. Another powerful faction leader, Michio Watanabe, fell ill with what is believed to be cancer and had to resign as Foreign Minister. Though faction leaders still issued pronouncements, few listened. Discipline broke down. Many party members described themselves as "ronin," the term for samurai wandering the countryside without loyalty to a feudal lord.
Mr. Miyazawa, never known for his skills at intraparty politics, observed the chaos and did nothing. Earlier this month, he was still promising to pass political reform legislation before Parliament recessed for the summer. But hard-liners in the leadership refused to compromise with the opposition, insisting on an electoral plan that would have given the Liberal Democrats an even bigger majority. The effect, they knew, would be to kill the reform effort altogether.
Their effort to sustain the status quo touched off a revolt that had been building for years. The opposition parties called Mr. Miyazawa a liar, and Mr. Ozawa saw his chance.
When a motion of no confidence arose, he gathered his troops to oust his old colleagues. Twenty percent of the party's legislators, most of them young, abandoned Mr. Miyazawa and voted for the motion. Another 10 legislators, headed by the disillusioned head of the Liberal Democrats' reform committee, joined the revolt. Seiroku Kajiyama, leading the conservative forces of the party, threatened to throw them all out of the party. He never had the chance. They voted to bring down the Government, then quit.
 
The Future: A Smashed Party, A New Order
 In the maze of scenarios and theories about the next few weeks and months, there is only one seeming certainty: the Liberal Democratic Party, as configured since 1955, will be smashed apart.
After the mass defections of the last eight days, the party holds about 228 seats in Parliament, or 28 less than it needs for the barest majority. In the election to be held on July 18, it seems likely to lose more.
If the party can keep its losses to a minimum, it may be able to take the lead in a coalition government, presumably with one or more of the "reformist" breakaway groups.
The second possibility is that the Liberal Democrats will do so badly that they will be frozen out of a coalition by some combination of new parties, which carry names like Renaissance and Harbinger. The coalition might include part of the Socialist camp.
Yet a third possibility, one that could take months or years to play out, is that the Liberal Democrats will spin apart even further -- many believe that about 100 pro-reform members led by Mr. Kaifu could still walk out -- and then reconstitute themselves after purging the older conservatives.
But that may leave Japan once again with what amounts to one-party rule. Many say that would be a disaster: the only way to assure that consumers and urban voters get a voice is to insure that interest groups are split across at least two conservative parties, so that one can play off against the other.
"The system that lasted since 1955 is over," said Shigezo Hayasaka, a political commentator who once served as a political secretary in the Tanaka era. "The old L.D.P. is gone."

HEADLINE: Two Communities Savor Victory Over Pentagon Plans for Cutbacks;
Lives Constructed Around Military Can Go Forward

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WRIGHTSTOWN, N.J., June 25

 BODY:
McGuire Air Force Base, the military enterprise that sustains this region, went from the brink of extinction this week to an expanded role that seems to assure a prosperous future for its neighboring communities into the next century.
Not only will McGuire be kept open as an active Air Force base, contrary to a Pentagon recommendation in March, but it will expand in size and stature as the chief air mobility wing for the eastern United States, the Base Closing and Realignment Commission decided on Thursday. 
 The reversal of fortune was stunning not only for the base's 4,500 airmen, their 6,000 dependents and 2,200 civilian employees, but for local business people and thousands of retired military families who settled in the piney woods of South Jersey to enjoy the benefits of the base hospital and commissary.
"These past few months have been scary time for everyone," said Marjorie Stine, widow of a retired Air Force sergeant. "Everyone's been on pins and needles waiting for the axe to fall."
Leroy Wilkins Sr., a retired Air Force captain who now sells real estate in the Wrightstown area, said, "People were thinking of selling and moving out for the past few months, but they couldn't find any buyers. Now I believe we are going to see a lot of buying, not selling."
The communities around McGuire -- Wrightstown, Browns Mills, New Egypt -- had braced for the base closing commission to ratify the Pentagon's plan to transfer most of McGuire's military supply function to Plattsburgh Air Force Base in upstate New York.
"If that happened, Wrightstown and everything else around here becomes a ghost town," said Ms. Stine, who moved here two years ago from Philadelphia when the navy yard there was shut, ending the availability of military medical care.
 
Other Good News
 Instead, the commission overruled the Pentagon and reversed the fates of the two bases. Plattsburgh is to be closed and its fleet of more than 20 KC135 refueling tankers permanently relocated at McGuire, designated as the staging area east of the Mississippi River for Air Force transport missions and rapid deployment of troops.
In addition, McGuire is to acquire 19 KC10 tankers -- larger jets that also provide midair refueling for Air Force and Navy planes -- now stationed at Barksdale Air Force base in Louisiana, the commission decreed.
The planes would join the 51 C141 Starlifter cargo and troop carriers in McGuire's 438th Airlift Wing and two squadrons of KC 135 tankers operated by the Air National Guard, adding an unspecified number of new jobs to the base payroll, eventually reaching perhaps as high as 2,000 to 3,000, sources said. Tens of millions of dollars to be spent on upgrading hangars and other base facilities.
It is expected that some civilians at Plattsburgh will be offered the opportunity to transfer to McGuire. The changes are expected to take a year or more to accomplish.
The reprieve for McGuire was not the only good news for New Jersey. The commission rejected a plan to move the Army's Communications Electronic Command from Fort Monmouth, near Red Bank, N.J., to Illinois. Instead, it decided to move the unit from leased property off the base to buildings on post being vacated by a military intelligence command and the Army Chaplain School.
The commission also voted Friday to reject the Pentagon's recommendation to shrink the submarine base at New London, Conn. But it voted to close the Staten Island Homeport, virtually ending any significant Navy presence in New York City.
 
'A Game of Table Stakes'
 The commission's recommendations on base closings and realignments now go to President Clinton and then to Congress.
"I can't imagine the President, with the sensitivity at the moment on budget cuts, rejecting the recommendations of an independent commission," said United States Senator Frank Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey. He spoke at a news conference here today with Senator Bill Bradley, also a Democrat of New Jersey, and Representative H. James Saxton, a Republican whose Third District includes the air base.
Should the President ask for any revisions, Senator Lautenberg explained, the commission would have to reconsider the entire proposal. "It's a game of table stakes -- he either accepts it all or gets nothing," he said.
Representative Saxton, in an interview, said the suspense of waiting for the fate of McGuire to be decided was "very unsettling" to an area economically dependent on the base. Real estate prices, already depressed by the lackluster economy and cutbacks at nearby Fort Dix, dropped further, he said, and planning for schools and businesses was suspended.
 
Some Problems as Well
 A few local residents had a somewhat different reaction.
"I couldn't say everyone would be disappointed if all the bases closed," said Virginia Detrick, head of the library at Browns Mills, a crossroads town near the entrance to Fort Dix. For all the prosperity the military contributed, she said, it brought some problems as well, such as rowdiness and crime.
Before the buildup of military bases in the area a local economy based on sawmills and gristmills barely supported a sparse population of farmers, hunters, wheelwrights and blacksmiths living deep in the pine and cedar woods, 30 miles from Philadelphia and 60 miles from New York City. Some subsistence farming remains, but there is no other major industry except the military.
Fort Dix opened in 1917 to train doughboys. In 1949, the Army landing field at the fort became an Air Force base in 1949, named in honor of Major Thomas B. McGuire Jr., a flying ace and Congressional Medal of Honor winner from New Jersey who was killed in action in 1945.
gfcrosslineSympathy for Losers
Now that McGuire's place seems secured into the next century, Jozsef Farago, Mayor of Wrightstown, is upbeat about the future.
Mr. Farago escaped from his native Hungary during the 1956 revolution and was able to enter the United States by volunteering for Army service. He rose to be a drill sergeant at Fort Dix during the Vietnam War, married a local girl, and after leaving the service 16 years ago bought Kelly's Bar, a Wrightstown landmark that had been a U.S.O. club during World War II.
"We'll do okay here with the Air Force," he said. "But do you know what bothers me? What bothers me is what's going to happen to all those people in Plattsburgh? What are they going to do with no more air base? Where are they going to go?
"They, you know, are now going to live our nightmare."

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Policy Sublime: A White House Tennis Handbook

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 26

 BODY:
President Clinton is a regular runner, a semiregular golfer and an avid basketball couch potato.
Tennis, he leaves to others. 
 To fill that void, the White House has come up with a detailed policy on the use of its tennis courts.
The rules of the courts, prepared by Patsy Thomasson, the special assistant for administration, run to five pages and include a map of the White House complex complete with instructions on the best way to get to the tennis courts, at the southwest corner of the grounds.
The courts, according to the memorandum, are open to all members of the Cabinet, members of Congress and senior White House staff members. It leaves unclear whether recalcitrant Republicans are as welcome as supportive Democrats, but most people in Washington know the lay of that land.
White House workers and people who work for the Vice President or the Office of Policy Development may gain access to the courts only through a Wednesday lottery and may play only between 10 A.M. and 1 P.M. on weekend days. And they must play doubles.
In boldface type two-thirds of the way down the first page are these cautionary words: "Guests of the First Family have priority use of the court."
The Clinton tennis era is much more casual than that of the last Democratic President, Jimmy Carter. Often chastised for his micromanagement, he was an avid player who was noted for the attention he paid to who got to use the White House courts and when.
A memorandum circulated around the White House in June 1977, Mr. Carter's first summer in residence, said tennis players needed personal permission from the President to use the courts. Mr. Carter's aides used to joke about how they could plot to delicately broach the subject of tennis time after a meeting on the Middle East peace talks.
There appears to be no such problem with the Clintons. Although Mr. Clinton, too, has been known to micromanage an issue or two, tennis is not his game.
 
Barber Chair for Rent
 More on the office-space front.
David R. Gergen, the high-profile, new counselor to the President who has been struggling mightily of late to keep his profile as close to the ground as he can, may have been handed the optimum solution.
There is basically no room for the new Presidential adviser on the West Wing's prime first floor near the Oval Office. So Mr. Gergen has wedged himself in underground.
The office he has taken over is down a flight of stairs, next to the men's room and a stone's throw from the mailroom in the basement of the West Wing, roughly under the visitors' lobby. It is windowless and of such modest size that his assistant, Diana Pierce, is camped across the hall next door to the White House photographer.
More important for symbolism's sake is the office's previous use. The room was once the shop used by the President's barber. As often noted, Mr. Clinton has been seeking outside tonsorial advice, and the space once occupied by the White House barber, Milton Pitts, is now valuable real estate.
 
And One More Thing
 Mr. Clinton's political advisers fumed when their boss got tagged with a label that he confirmed as true within weeks of the start of his new Administration. He had, he admitted, lost his focus.
Nobody could fault him for lack of focus last week. In a coordinated and disciplined effort that represented a tour de force in single-minded determination, Mr. Clinton spoke of virtually nothing but the economy. And he went to extraordinary lengths to do it.
He talked about it to schoolchildren and to members of Congress, to reporters and to business leaders. He talked a blue streak, and when he stopped, his advisers trotted out senior officials like Lloyd Bentsen, the Secretary of the Treasury, and Leon E. Panetta, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, to pick up where he left off.
And just to make sure no one would miss the point, two of the week's regular daily news briefings, which normally touch on a wide variety of issues, were canceled to make room for Mr. Bentsen and Mr. Panetta. Then, in case that turned out to be underkill, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Panetta suddenly popped up before cameras on Wednesday, the day before the big Senate vote, to denounce a Republican alternative and praise their own initiative.
Mr. Clinton even extended his campaign into outer space, talking up his plan to continue support for the space shuttle during a conversation with the astronauts aboard the Endeavour.
"We've got some important votes coming up in the Congress in the next two days," Mr. Clinton said during the hookup. "While you're up there, we're going to be down here voting on this project. And I very much hope that we can prevail. And I think frankly your success and your work will help us to prevail. You're doing as much up there to help us win the votes down here as anyone, and I thank you for that."
It must have worked. He won. And then he talked about it some more.

HEADLINE: In Cleaner Harbor, Creatures Eat the Waterfront

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON

 BODY:
Mariners used to joke that New York City was a "clean harbor" -- a quick way of saying that the water pollution was so severe that it killed any organisms attached to the hulls of their ships. But now the tables have turned: the waters around New York are so much cleaner that voracious mollusks and crustaceans have returned and are devouring the waterfront.
After decades of effort to reduce the pollution from sewage and petrochemicals that fouled the harbor, officials from the city and from New York and New Jersey have had trouble accepting the idea that clean water somehow poses a problem. 
 But in a perverse measure of environmental progress, the officials are now realizing that they could lose many of the wooden bulkheads and piers that line the waterfront unless they spend hundreds of millions of dollars to protect the timbers from the insatiable creatures, collectively known as bore worms.
"It may not be the cockroach that ate Cincinnati, but the bore worm is quickly becoming the mollusk that swallowed New York," said Lynn Tierney, a spokeswoman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, a major owner of waterfront property.
By the end of next year, New York City will have spent about $100 million to brace and wrap plastic around thousands of pilings supporting 12 of the most vital piers, including the South Street Seaport in the East River and the three Hudson River piers of the Passenger Ship Terminal (No. 88, at 48th Street; No. 90, at 50th Street and No. 92, at 52d Street), including the berth for the Queen Elizabeth 2.
But officials say the cost of fending off the bore worms will certainly rise. The borers have infested submerged wooden structures from Kennedy International Airport to New Jersey, as well as footings for the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive and local bridges. In addition, the wooden bulkheads that surround much of the city and northern New Jersey are presumed vulnerable.
"We're talking a lot of money," said Ann Buttenwieser, the vice president of waterfront planning and development of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, who was among the first to sound the alarm. "No one has calculated the total cost. But any agency and property owner with piers is suffering from exactly the same problem."
Unlike most other types of maintenance, the work cannot be deferred, even for a short period. Mrs. Buttenwieser notes the worms have "nothing to do but eat 24 hours a day" and can devour 12-inch-thick pilings in a couple of years. So the bore worms will soon reduce any unprotected wood structure along the water to a fading memory.
The attack of the marine borers is one of a number of unanticipated consequences of progress in the fight against water pollution. The problems, in some ways, are as profound and unwelcome as the degradation caused by pollution. In April, for instance, a steel pier collapsed in Hoboken in large part because clean water sped corrosion.
"The oil and grease used to coat the steel and protected the pier," said Edwin J. Chius, the city's business administrator. "The cleanliness of the water has had a bad effect."
Environmental progress is something of a double-edged sword, with costs as well as benefits, on land as well as in the water. The reforestation of large portions of the Northeast has allowed deer to multiply, scientists say, aiding the spread of ticks carrying Lyme disease across the region and causing a sharp jump in traffic fatalities from collisions with the animals.
"When Bambi carries a fatal disease, his return somehow doesn't seem quite as wonderful anymore," said David Burg, the president of the National Audubon Society's New York City chapter, the country's largest.
But environmentalists point to the slaughter of laughing gulls on Long Island as perhaps the clearest example of the perversity syndrome. The birds were almost hunted to extinction at the turn of the century, yet were lured back to the area by the creation of the Jamaica Wildlife Refuge. But after transportation officials said the thriving colony is a hazard to jets using Kennedy Airport, the Department of Agriculture two years ago began shooting thousands of the birds.
"It's kind of a hot potato," acknowledged Thomas Bancroft, a senior scientist for the National Audubon Society. "It's not something that's been addressed thoroughly."
Saving the region's waterfront from the bore worms is likely to prove more complicated than protecting planes at Kennedy. The borers have bedeviled seafarers and waterfront communities for centuries. They are blamed for the hole in the dike that the Little Dutch Boy plugged with his finger. (Apocryphal? "It may very well be that the little boy put in more than his thumb. He probably put his whole arm in there," says Ruth D. Turner, the curator of mollusks at Harvard University's Museum of Comparative Zoology, who wrote her first paper on the worms almost 50 years ago.)
The creatures claimed two of Christopher Columbus' four wooden galleons in Panama during his last voyage to the New World. And in 1833, the New York City Board of Aldermen, frustrated by demands to protect waterfront structures, passed a resolution declaring that "piers and wharves, as now constructed of timber, are temporary, and generally endure only from 14 to 17 years before they are destroyed by worms."
The waterfront was saved by pollution. It killed most marine life in the inner harbor and seemed to relegate the borers to a footnote in New York City's history. Andrew Willner, the American Littoral Society's baykeeper for the New York and New Jersey Harbor Estuary, noted that some areas like Newtown Creek had so much tar and oil in the water that skippers used to sail into them as a cheap way of caulking their boats and plugging leaks.
But water quality has improved steadily since the 1972 passage of Federal Clean Water Act, allowing countless marine species to return to the area. While some sediments remain polluted with toxics and heavy metals, many fishermen now swear that the city has some of the best fishing in the world -- an argument that was bolstered last year when a new world record was set near the Battery for a striped bass landed with light tackle. "When I haul my boat in every Spring, I have barnacles on any metal surface that isn't covered with bottom paint," Mr. Willner said with delight.
In the early 1980's, marine biologists began noticing an increase in the numbers of one type of borer, a shrimp-like, quarter-inch-long creature, Limnoria lignorum, known as a gribble. It attacks the surface of the wood and gives pilings their characteristic hourglass shape. But that caused little alarm, since the damage they cause is superficial and readily apparent.
But in 1983, another type of borer -- called the shipworm, even though it is a mollusk of the Teredinidae family -- was again detected in the inner harbor. The worms drill into the wood and, in the South Pacific, grow to six feet.
The two types of borers, working in tandem, make a double-barreled attack. In tests around the harbor, researchers found that the voracious mollusks made soft pine panels as porous as sponge in a year. But city officials could not believe that they threatened the decades-old waterfront.
"When I started talking about this a couple years ago, people said she's crazy," Mrs. Buttenwieser recalled. "But now it's become something of an emergency."
A study of the four piers at the Brooklyn Army Terminal found that the borers turned the thickest pilings into relative matchsticks in about two years. When the study began in April 1991, the pilings were 8 to 12 inches thick; by the next September, they were only about 6 inches. Many have now been reduced to as little as 2 inches and can barely support their own weight. Mrs. Buttenwieser said that when city officials arrived two months ago to inspect Pier 4, they found that Pier 1 had collapsed during the night.
"The preservation of the facilities that are infested with marine borers will require significant protective and rehabilitative expenditures," concluded a 1991 Port Authority study conducted by Vernon C. Berndt, a materials engineer and Cas Bognacki, a supervising engineer. "Hopefully, effective materials will be developed that can encapsulate and preserve our structures."
Dr. Turner of Harvard said the way to control the borers is to limit their food supply and to impregnate waterfront structures with preservatives like creosote. "Don't let any trash wood lie around," she said. "Chop it up and get rid of it."
But those solutions cause almost as many problems. Researchers say evidence is mounting that the borers have become tolerant of creosote, a liquid made from coal tar. In any case, such preservatives tend to leach out of the wood, polluting the harbor. The United States Army Corps of Engineers has proposed pulling out collapsed piers. But many environmentalists note that the pilings have been there for years and form artificial reefs, the spawning grounds for countless species, and strongly oppose the idea.
"The original attitude was to take it all away, but now we want to preserve it as part of our heritage," Mrs. Buttenwieser said.
Some West Coast ports have been wrapping their piers since the 1960's, when Los Angeles was hit by a severe borer attack. Officials say the process is not particularly difficult, but it is time-consuming and expensive because the piers have thousands of pilings, each one of which must be individually wrapped by a diver.
That has led to another approach: the city is replacing the dilapidated Tiffany Street pier in the Bronx with a dock made entirely of recycled plastic.

HEADLINE: Report on Empire Assails Albany's Insurance Dept.

BYLINE: By DEAN BAQUET

 BODY:
While Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield was being mismanaged, the New York State Insurance Department seemed helpless to address the company's financial crisis and overly concerned that it might generate bad publicity for Empire, a scathing report on the nation's largest nonprofit health insurer says.
The 200-page report released on Friday by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations portrays a department that was fearful that the company would collapse, leaving some of the state's sickest people uninsured. And so, the report asserts, regulators often appeared to bend to Empire's wishes. 
 The department has said it has little power under state law to interfere with the way Empire runs its business. And the report considers that the task of regulating the company may simply be too vast.
But, the committee staff also said, the department can approve rates Empire charges many of its 8.2 million customers, and ultimately has the right to take the company over. And it questioned "whether what is missing is not the authority to regulate, but rather the will to regulate."
 
Concerned for Customers
 Kevin Foley, Deputy Superintendent of Insurance, said on Friday that the department has not had the chance to digest the report. But he rejected criticism that the department has been soft on Empire. And he said that there was nothing wrong with being concerned about Empire's customers.
An aide to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Arda Nazerian, said yesterday that the Governor had not yet read the report and would not comment until he has done so.
The report charges that Salvatore R. Curiale, the State Insurance Superintendent, unskeptically accepted Empire's argument that its losses -- $250 million over the last two years -- were the result of unfair competition from for-profit insurance companies. Empire has accused its for-profit, or commercial, competitors of "cherry-picking" the company's youngest and healthiest customers, while Empire was required to insure everyone.
The report did not discount that as a factor, but it laid blame for most of Empire's losses on "gross mismanagement," serious service problems and a pattern of high corporate living more appropriate for a profitable Fortune 500 company.
 
'Almost Indistinguishable'
 Yet, the report asserted, "At times, Mr. Curiale has seemed almost indistinguishable from Empire officials in the vigor with which he has propounded Empire's cherry-picking argument as an explanation for Empire's recent financial woes."
Although the report questioned whether Empire's problems were too large and complex for insurance regulators to handle, it concluded that "the staff believes that if the Insurance Department had acted aggressively in the past to specific, incremental problems and issues, the current situation may not have come about."
The report shows Mr. Curiale repeatedly "asking, rhetorically: 'What am I supposed to do? I don't have the manpower or expertise' to tell Empire how to make money.' " And it recounts several examples of the department's caving in to Empire on significant matters of regulation.
In 1986, the company persuaded the department to back away from its decision to require Healthnet, Empire's new health maintenance organization, to file its own financial accounting with regulators, separate from the company's overall balance sheets. According to the subcommittee, the department changed its mind after a heavy campaign by Empire's lobbyists, the Albany law firm of Hinman, Straub, Pigors & Manning.
 
Leniency Reduced Safeguards
 A result of this seemingly minor change was important, the committee said. Had Healthnet filed a separate balance sheet, it would have been required to maintain hefty reserves to protect its customers. Moreover, it would have been far easier to spot early problems in the health maintence organization, which eventually lost $100 million.
The committee also cited instances in which the department seemed to minimize criticism of Empire. In 1990, a department insurance examiner included a section in his annual analysis that criticized Empire for being uncooperative in supplying financial information. The report was placed in the public record.
Empire's chairman, Albert A. Cardone, became upset, subcommittee records show, and telephoned the department to complain. The department then took the highly unusual step of "unfiling" the report from the public record, the examiner, Michael Scharff, told the subcommittee staff.
Mr. Cardone lobbied to have the criticism about Empire's lack of cooperation stricken from the report, Mr. Scharff recounted in a deposition filed with the committee.
The report was not returned to the public record until six months later. The criticism remained. But a new paragraph was added, in which Empire executives said they were unaware of the lack of cooperation, presumably by lesser company officials.
In his deposition, Mr. Scharff said it was not inappropriate for Empire to have the opportunity to comment on an annual report. He said he had no problem with the change, but called the handling of the report unusual.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Harold E. Vogt, left, chairman of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, and Donald Morchower, chief executive, commenting Friday on charges made by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Steinbrenner Is Just One More Car Alarm

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
The time has come to call the Fat Man's bluff; Governor Cuomo and Mayor Dinkins have to bite the baseball, swallow and say, "You know what you can do with your ball club, George."
And make no mistake. It is George Steinbrenner's ball club, not America's, not New York's, not yours or even mine, with all my prattle about having been born in the South Bronx and sitting with my dad as the Great DiMaggio "drifted" under fly balls. I have been a registered Yankee fan since birth, except for those times, while covering them, when I put my passion in a blind trust. 
 Never trust blindly, or some felonious loudmouth will come along and buy the team and blackmail the city. So go, already, George.
For politicians and tycoons, the purpose of local sports teams is to create a joyful noise that will drown out the screams in the night. A major league franchise plugs a city into the Happy News Network of sportschatter. Tourists and investors are lured by what the South Bronx once called "allrightnika," the illusion that all is well.
For example, years will go by in which the only positive news that comes out of, say, Detroit, are sports stories. Recently, however, Chicago and Montreal suffered the negative whiplash of such stories when championship celebrations were crashed by vandals and looters.
But this has never been the case in New York, not even the case in regions of New York, at least not since Brooklyn, the borough that should have been a city, allowed itself to be defined by a baseball team. New York has always been too large, too fragmented, too important as an imperial city to need sports. There are people in New York who cannot identify Anthony Young, John Starks or Adam Graves. These are people who have fax machines in their cars.
Now, if the Yankees officially changed their name to the Bronx Bombers and became a positive force in that borough, a working member of the community rather than a developer's "anchor," there would be reason to pay off George to stay. If the owner had made good on all his 20-year-old promises to turn the area around the Stadium into a safe, well-lighted neighborhood, perhaps attendance would not be down. And there would be more sympathy for the Governor and the Mayor, who do not want to be remembered, unfairly, as the politicians who lost the Yankees.
Better they should be remembered as the statesmen who wouldn't be bullied, by George.
New York does not need the Yankees. New York needs the Broadway theater and the television networks, and it needs the publishing, advertising, financial and clothing industries, and it needs its museums and concert halls and art galleries. But anyone who claims that the Yankees are critical to the economics or the soul or, their favorite word, "chemistry," of the city is probably making money from the Yankees or has been spooked by the fall of the Mets.
Some irony here. Thirty-one years ago, when the Mets were really in the toilet, sportswriters scared they would lose their livelihoods rallied New Yorkers by touting the Mets' incompetence as symbolic of underdog struggle. Come to the Polo Grounds and watch the pageant of your lives. The Yankees were so good then they were sneered at as the team for bankers and tourists.
Now the Mets are just losers, and the sportswriters get quivery describing how the new manager, Dallas Green, yelled at the players and ranked on them in public. They are making fun of Anthony Young when he should be awarded the role medal; he hangs tough and keeps coming back. Meanwhile, the Yankees are winning and the Fat Man is passing out ransom notes.
So what if the Yankees move to New Jersey, where so many New Yorkers now live? You don't think Steinbrenner, of the Cleveland Steinbrenners, came all this way to call his team the Garden State Yankees? And remember what happened the last time a New York team moved to New Jersey. When the Giants won the Super Bowl, did anyone call them the Secaucus Eleven? Or label L. T. the Hackensacker? They were still the New York Giants on the Happy News Network, and for many who lived in the city, it was easier to get to their games.
Such lessons seem to have been lost lately in this frantic New Jock City with its concurrent seasons and a fandom maddened by tabloid wars and radio daze. The Rangers slipped out of the playoffs and we are still looking for targets; who can be Harazined for losing the Beezer? The Knicks gave us a gallant year; it would be unfair to keep replaying someone's missed shots in the time of Michael Jordan. Besides, Pat Riley cashing in on "three-peat" T-shirts is such a New York thing to do, even if he got the idea in Los Angeles. The Devils and the Isles and the Nets gave promise of hot seasons to come. Don't forget the Giants and the Jets. And the Mets will come back.
Forget about the Yankees. New York doesn't need them, not in Yankee Stadium, probably not even downtown, as badly as New York needs responsible ownership that considers itself the steward of a public resource and stand-up politicians and citizens who will join me in putting their Yankee love on hold until Steinbrenner gets it or gets out.
As far as I'm concerned, it's over until the Fat Man leaves.

HEADLINE: JUNE 20-26: Young Steps Down;
Detroit Now May Face A Referendum on Revival

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

 BODY:
His voice laboring from the effects of emphysema, Coleman A. Young, who is 75, said last week that he did not have the energy to seek a sixth four-year term as Detroit's mayor. The city's mayoral race instantly became a wide open contest among more than a dozen candidates, and could well turn into a referendum on the economic future of what is arguably the country's most depressed big city.
Mr. Young, whose principal contribution was to bring political enfranchisement to blacks, failed to lure investment and business after a massive flight of whites during the 1960's and 1970's. 
 Mr. Young has brought about some large public and private development projects. And a recovering auto industry should increase employment somewhat. Still, economists say the next mayor must draw investors, businesses and residents on a much larger scale. One big advantage the next mayor will have is a huge amount of vacant property and low asking prices.

HEADLINE: Services Count Also

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Trade Gap Widened in April" (Business Day, June 18) aptly summarizes the important changes in the United States merchandise trade deficit reported by the Commerce Department for April and the year to date. Yet in equating these merchandise figures with the United States net "trade deficit," you ignore the growing trade surplus in private services and consequently vastly overstate our trade woes. This is an example of a national misperception that only overseas sales of American merchandise count as exports. 
 One has only to examine the 1992 and 1993 first quarter trade statistics, released June 15 by the Bureau of Economic Analysis of the Commerce Department, to understand the importance of the booming nature of United States private services trade.
The bureau, recognizing the need to link the merchandise and services trade statistics, introduced a new net trade figure. While the merchandise trade deficit for fiscal year 1992 totaled $96 billion, trade in private services resulted in a $61 billion surplus; the United States net trade deficit for 1992 thus came to $35 billion.
Taking only merchandise into account is understandable. The Commerce Department's April numbers include no mention of services. Indeed, there is no monthly compilation of United States service export statistics, only a quarterly figure. However, the Bureau of Economic Analysis plans to begin issuing monthly private services and net trade statistics next year.
 
HARRY FREEMAN
Executive Director, Multilateral
Trade Negotiations Coalition
Washington, June 18, 1993

HEADLINE: Saving and Trade

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Trade Sanity With Japan" (editorial, June 16) falls back on an old shibboleth of free traders: "Longstanding trade deficits reflect insufficient saving." There is a good argument for free trade, but that is not it. 
 The equation that links investment, saving and trade works in both directions, and it is just as rigorous to argue that a lower trade deficit will increase savings. Common sense should tell you that the situation you describe, in which Americans buy more goods than they produce and therefore must import the balance, is only true if the United States were operating at full capacity.
If it isn't -- and our relatively high unemployment should signal to you there is plenty of slack in the economy -- then your assertion is logically imprecise.
Free trade benefits all participants through comparative advantage, but participants can "cheat" and come out ahead of the game. If the trade partners of the United States are protecting domestic companies and industries with nontariff barriers (difficult to detect and surmount), subsidies or dumping, it behooves the United States to use its political and economic muscle to open these markets.
Economic theory misunderstood and sloppily applied leads to political tensions and beggar-thy-neighbor policies. Above all, it harms the cause of free trade.
 
ANTHONY SWEENEY
New York, June 16, 1993
 
The writer directs corporate development for the AMAX mining company.

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
Without a Commissioner, Padres Unload Their Stars

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Where is Bowie Kuhn when we need him?
During his 15 years as commissioner, Kuhn made integrity the byword of his office. He considered himself so much the commissioner of the game's integrity that he acted swiftly when he thought that integrity was being compromised. 
 Seventeen years ago this month, for example, Kuhn prohibited Charlie Finley from stripping his club, the Oakland Athletics, of its best players.
No one is around now, though, to prevent the owners of the San Diego Padres from decimating what less than a year ago was a division contender.
The Padres are acting under the guise of a so-called small-market club trying to lower its payroll and survive in these so-called troubling economic times, but they nevertheless have undermined their ability to give the paying public a competitive team. The Mets, at least, have done that on merit.
 
Sheffield Jettisoned
 Gary Sheffield, who only came close to winning the Triple Crown last season, was the latest star player the Padres jettisoned. Fred McGriff, one of the most consistent home run hitters in the major leagues, goes next. The Padres will probably ship him to the Atlanta Braves or the Yankees, or maybe somewhere else, by the All-Star Game break. Bruce Hurst already would have been traded if his shoulder had permitted him to pitch.
Preceding Sheffield out of town were Tony Fernandez, Benito Santiago, Darrin Jackson, Randy Myers, Craig Lefferts, Mike Maddux and Larry Andersen.
When Kuhn blocked Finley's efforts to divest the Athletics of Vida Blue, Rollie Fingers and Joe Rudi in 1976, he wrote that the sales would strip the team of "much of its finest talent" and leave it with "little chance to compete effectively in its division."
"Public confidence in the integrity of club operations and in baseball would be greatly undermined should such assignments not be restrained," Kuhn concluded.
Bud Selig, the owner responsible for the integrity of the game in the absence of a Bowie Kuhn, Peter Ueberroth or Fay Vincent, rejected the Finley precedent in discussing the Padres' plight.
Finley tried to sell his players for money, Selig noted; the Padres, except when players have left them as free agents, have received players in return, albeit often minor league players.
"I've thought a lot about it," Selig said. "I don't think that's a proper analogy. No. 1, the Padres are getting back young players. It's not dissimilar to what Houston has done, and they've become a good club. And obviously the environment has changed. It's tough to analogize between 1976 and now. Here you have a club that's trying to get its payroll back into an area where it can make money or at least break even. They're not liquidating. They're getting good young talent back. Who among us is smart enough to predict how they'll turn out?"
Donald Fehr, head of the Players Association, sees it differently. "The approach in San Diego," he said, "is things aren't going well so the only thing we can do is dump salaries, and if that hurts the team, alienates fans and drives down TV ratings, there's nothing we can do about that."
In return for the salaries they have shed, the Padres received Erik Schullstrom, Ricky Gutierrez, D. J. Dozier, Wally Whitehurst, Raul Casanova, Roger Mason, Mike Freitas, Derek Bell, Trevor Hoffman, Jose Martinez and Andres Berumen.
Selig is right: No one can predict how they will turn out. But experience says most of the young players won't attain the ability level of the players they were traded for, and certainly not in time for the fans who bought tickets this year to get their money's worth.
That is why two Padres fans have sued the club, claiming that the Padres reneged on a written promise -- made in a letter to season-ticket holders -- to keep Sheffield and Jackson this season. Furthermore, the Padres' 15-man ownership group has violated the pledge it included in the team's media guide.
Ownership, the pledge says, "is committed to building a strong and cohesive team, a team consisting of strong management and talented players with the desire to win."
It was reported yesterday that in the aftermath of the Sheffield trade, the Padres will offer prorated refunds to those who bought season tickets after the written promise was issued. "Everything I said in that letter was true as the facts existed at that time," said the team's president, Dick Freeman. "Nevertheless, the goodwill of our fans is important."
Selig, who has his own small-market problems in Milwaukee, said he understands the fans' frustration. But speaking of the team's primary owner, he added: "I have great regard for Tom Werner. He's doing what he feels he has to do. Knowing the economics of his team as I do, it has nothing to do with the capital structure of that ownership. It has to do with the payroll getting up so high you can't make it work in the market."
The Padres began the season with a $24.5 million payroll. It is $21.2 million now, but the owners want to slash it to perhaps less than half that amount.
Recalling that the ownership group bought the Padres only three years ago, Fehr said: "Teams have behaved this way in the past. The big difference is ownership bought the team recently, thought it could operate the team in a certain manner but obviously has had capitalization problems.
"This is a group baseball said was O.K. and approved. You don't have a commissioner who can make inquiries into these things. I'm not saying there's anything wrong, but given the chaos baseball has, if there's reason for inquiry, there's no one to make that inquiry. So if they want to do it, they just do it."
Selig, who sees nothing to inquire about, said he didn't think the ownership group has a problem. "They were the strongest group," he said. "A lot of people were bidding for the club. A lot has to do with the payroll compared with anticipated gross revenues." Payrolls of $30 million or $35 million just don't go well in a small market, not unless you're willing to lose a lot of money."
 
Pitching Around
 Don Baylor, the beleaguered manager of the Colorado Rockies, became so desperate for an effective starting pitcher that he gave the ball last week to Jeff Parrett, a six-year veteran whose first 31 appearances this season had been in relief and whose career record consisted of 367 games in relief and 5 as a starter.
Parrett is one of 17 pitchers the Rockies have used, but they have nothing on the Cleveland Indians. Mike Hargrove has used 20 pitchers. Eleven have started games and 16, including 7 who have started, have relieved. Parrett was the Rockies' ninth starter. They have had 14 pitchers relieve, including 6 of the 9 who have started.
The Indians, however, have recently eased their earned run average under 5.00. The Rockies' staff e.r.a. is moving in the opposite direction, soaring beyond 6.00 in San Francisco's 17-run onslaught last Thursday. The Rockies have endured 17 games in which the opposing team has scored 10 runs or more. The other six teams in the National League West have experienced 17 such games.
 
Powerless Red Sox
 With only 36 home runs entering yesterday's game, the Boston Red Sox are certain to finish at the low end of the team home run totals again. Last season they hit 84, outslugging only Milwaukee (82) and Kansas City (75) in the American League. What has happened to the team that not long ago seemed to have a bunch of home run hitters?
"Jim Rice retired, Dwight Evans retired, Don Baylor and Tony Armas no longer are playing baseball," Mike Greenwell said.
Greenwell, whose five home runs place him second on the team, said the Red Sox would love to have home run hitters, but "having home run hitters didn't translate into championships, so they went into the pitching part of the game more."
"We have to find a balance of hitting and pitching. If we had the power we used to have with this pitching staff, we'd have an awfully good team." But given the type of team the Red Sox have, the left fielder added, "speed and a better defense would help."
"Our pitching is going to keep us in a lot of games," said Greenwell. "If we could get another run or two, we could win some of the games we're losing."

SECTION: Section 8; Page 12; Column 3; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 1026 words

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
How to Go Safely From Here to Fall

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
HERE is an oddity. A paradox, actually. We have an organization that the insurance companies hate, but the organization is telling us how to get safely through the summer.
The entity is called Radar, which is an acronym for the Radio Association Defending Airwave Rights, a lame-name umbrella group for the makers of radar detectors, those little black boxes that beep when they spot a trooper speed-reading up ahead. 
 The reason the insurance companies dislike Radar, of course, is that the organization's avowed goal is to help us get to our destinations quickly and without contributing unduly to municipal coffers via speeding tickets.
But Radar has long been the motorist's friend in other ways, too, publishing a monthly newsletter on transportation issues and serving as a clearinghouse for information on drivers' rights, speed traps and radar abuses by the police. Which brings us to the point of all this.
The newsletter, called Radar Reporter and published at the group's headquarters in Tipp City, Ohio, notes that summer poses a particular dilemma for drivers, with extra traffic creating more safety hazards at the same time that motorists want swift travel.
Thus, it says, you should pay particular attention to other vehicles and know that five types of mishaps account for 75 percent of all accidents and 83 percent of road injuries. In descending order, they are: running a red light; a stopped vehicle hit from the rear; running off the road; improper lane changes, and left turns in front of oncoming traffic.
In addition, the newsletter says, the few seconds you might save by driving fast are overshadowed by summer's increased hazards. Instead, drive at the posted limit, stay out of the way of faster traffic and allow extra room ahead and behind. On busy roads, go with the flow of traffic and be careful when changing lanes.
When in doubt, the newsletter advises, remember that research shows that vehicles traveling a few miles per hour faster than the average speed of traffic have the lowest involvement in accidents, while vehicles going much faster or much slower have the highest accident rates.
It is important, too, to watch everything on the road. Scan ahead so you have time to react. As you watch the traffic, formulate evasive plans and be poised to act. "When driving at night," the newsletter says, "assume everyone else is drunk and might do something unpredictable."
Even when driving by day, the newsletter says, remember that running with headlights on can double the distance at which you are visible to oncoming traffic.
There is the usual advice about leaving three seconds' worth of space between your car and the one ahead. Conversely, if you are being tailgated, just let the offender go by.
"Be a signal skeptic," the newsletter says. "Just because somebody has his turn signal blinking doesn't mean he's going to turn. It may have been on since he pulled out of Bubba's Tavern five miles back." It is also true that many vehicles have inoperative taillights.
Rearview mirrors are equally untrustworthy. Every car has blind spots, so look over your shoulder before changing lanes.
You need to know your vehicle, too, although that can be a problem when driving a rental. Still, pay attention. Do the brakes grab when wet? Does your truck run out of oomph on uphills when towing the boat? Don't forget to compensate when following another vehicle or in passing.
Similarly, become familiar with the sounds and vibrations of your steed. If something changes, it could be a warning of mechanical woes.
Far too many accidents occur when drivers are fatigued and trying to stretch the driving day, and it is important to know when to stop.
"Recognize when you are tired or your concentration is waning and get out from behind the wheel," the newsletter says. "Try to stick with your normal meal and sleeping schedules, and don't prop yourself up with mass quantities of caffeine."
All that may seem obvious, but the basics are still the basics, and when it comes to stopping accidents, restating them can't hurt.
Besides, much of the information in the newsletter and otherwise available from the organization is more arcane. If you want more, the address is Radar, 4949 South 25-A, Tipp City, Ohio 45371.
 
 
 
SUMMER AND THE OVERLOAD FACTOR
 True, you have six kids, a dog, a sick hamster, and the in-laws want to come along. But holiday-bound motorists should be careful not to overload the family buggy, the Tire Industry Safety Council warns.
The council, which represents most of the world's tire makers, notes that excessive weight causes abnormal flexing in a tire's sidewall, which in turn generates excessive heat.
Thomas E. Cole, the council chairman, said the added weight can also cause springs and shock absorbers to fail.
"An overloaded vehicle is hard to drive and hard to stop," he said. "Couple the overloading problem with the all-too-common problem of underinflated tires, and you have real potential for trouble."
Heat is a tire's worst enemy, Cole said, adding that a buildup -- particularly at highway speeds -- can start a separation of the tread from the body of the tire, eventually leading to failure.
The load that a tire will carry safely is a function of its size, its load range and the corresponding inflation pressure.
"Proper inflation is critical," Cole said, adding that it should be measured when cold, which means that you should get out the gauge before you get behind the wheel. Officially, cold pressure is the pressure of a tire driven a mile or less.
A tire's load capacity at its maximum inflation is molded into the sidewall, but the council recommends checking for a vehicle's proper inflation in the owner's manual. Usually, a label is also inside the glovebox door or on the driver's doorpost.
"Add up the maximum load of all four tires," Cole said, "and you get the total gross weight, including vehicle weight, passengers and cargo, that the tires can support. But remember, it's the manufacturer that determines the load that your vehicle can safely accommodate."
Maybe you can get a housesitter for the hamster.
