HEADLINE: Two Communities Savor Victory Over Pentagon Plans for Cutbacks;
Lots of Hard Work Yield Good Night Of Sleep in Groton

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GROTON, Conn., June 25

 BODY:
Frank O'Beirne Jr. said today that he was looking forward to his first good night's sleep in months after hearing that the Base Realignment and Closure Commission was unanimously recommending that the Navy maintain its submarine base here.
Mr. O'Beirne, a retired Navy captain and one of the leaders of a coalition formed to save the base, helped perform a computer analysis that showed that closing other facilities could save up to $1.6 billion in the next seven years. He made six trips to Washington to share those results with the commission staff, and one trip to Boston to testify at a regional hearing. 
 "After 30 years in the Navy, I really hate to say this, but the Navy didn't have its act together," Mr. O'Beirne said. "They never looked at options, and then when we did, even the base closure commission had to sit up when you're talking more than a billion dollars."
Norbert V. Fay, who organized demonstrations in support of the base whenever it was visited by members of the commission, said he watched the vote on television today and described it to a union official at the base.
 
'Blow by Blow' Account
 "It was almost like a prize fight, the way I was giving him a blow by blow," Mr. Fay said. "It wasn't until I hung up the phone that I realized we had won.
"I look upon this vote as way of holding the community together for my grandchildren, to make it a place for them to grown up and thrive. If it had gone the other way, I think they would have had to move away to find jobs."
State and local officials joined members of the Sub Base Realignment Coalition in rejoicing at the commission's recommendation that submarines continue to be berthed in Groton, where visitors are greeted by a large blue sign that proclaims the city the submarine capital of the world. Besides the submarine base, Groton is home to the Electric Boat shipyard, which builds nuclear submarines and has undergone repeated layoffs.
The Navy had proposed moving most of its submarines to King's Bay, Ga., at a cost of $300 million, eliminating 2,227 jobs in southeastern Connecticut. Supporters of the Groton base contended that it made no sense to move the submarines while maintaining a training center in Groton, which the Navy said would be too expensive to move.
 
Not Out of the Woods
 "I'm elated," said Representative Sam Gejdenson, a Democrat whose district includes Groton. "This is one of the best days of my life."
Mr. Gejdenson said the region still has to worry about the next round of base closings, in 1995, but this decision sets an important precedent.
The Connecticut Municipal Electric Energy Cooperative provided the computer experts to do the analysis of the base-closure plans, because the base accounts for 15 percent of its electricity sales.'
"Everybody here is celebrating," said Richard D. Currier, the director of finance and accounting at the cooperative. "We had provided an awful lot of ammunition and it was apparently very hard to refute. But we all had our fingers crossed."
"I'm not surprised, just relieved," said State Representative Lenny T. Winkler, a Groton Republican. "The coalition did a fantastic job, a lot of research, and the case they presented made it hard to vote in favor of moving the submarines."
 
Savings Were the Ticket
 Mrs. Winkler said she believed what swayed the panel was the savings the Navy could realize by keeping submarines in Groton, and not the potential economic impact on the region, which the Federal commission was also supposed to consider.
"Every community that had a base on their list could prove that the economic impact would be devastating," she said. "But the coalition presented them with facts to show how the Navy could save money by keeping Groton open."
Mr. O'Beirne agreed: "You never know what's going to happen in a politically inclined environment. The pressure that can be brought to bear from any number of quarters can be enormous, and probably was. This was never a sure thing. It was a tense situation, right down to the vote."

HEADLINE: After a Year, Neighbors In Yonkers Live Warily

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: YONKERS, June 25

 BODY:
In the Crestwood section of this city with a racially troubled past, neighbors grumble to each other about the newcomers, about the graffiti on a suburban fence, the lawn that was brashly invaded by bicycle riders, the blaring music that jarred a languorous afternoon.
But such complaints also mask a collective sigh of relief. 
 For the homeowners of this leafy thicket of colonials and tudors acknowledge that things have not worked out as badly as they feared in the year since 48 low-income families moved into a cluster of functional brick town houses constructed under a Federal desegregation order. In the Crestwood complex and in four other court-ordered town house developments in the city, there have been no crime to speak of, no racial clashes and no significant white flight, city officials say. Home prices have dropped, but they have done so almost everywhere in Westchester County.
Still, residents say their fears have not been put to rest.
In a new stage in the 13-year-old Yonkers housing desegregation case, Judge Leonard B. Sand of Federal District Court in Manhattan is weighing plans to place subsidized tenants in private buildings, either new construction or existing housing, in largely middle-class areas of Yonkers. Longtime residents are worried that as many as four new developments could spring up within a mile of the 48-unit Dr. James F. X. O'Rourke Town Houses in Crestwood, "tipping" the neighborhood's racial balance and leading to a white exodus.
"We don't want to be saturated," says Eleanor Bourke, head of the Whitman Homeowners Association, whose 200 predominantly white-owned homes surround the public-housing site. "If more housing comes here we could have a problem."
The nub of the latest stage of litigation involves the creation of Federal and state subsidized apartments for families who earn $67,000 or less in privately run buildings. Mayor Terence M. Zaleski, proclaiming a change of heart from the city's rebellious history, said he wants to settle its integration obligations by finding 450 apartments in existing cooperatives, building 115 new ones and renovating 144 apartments in the largely black and Hispanic section of southwest Yonkers.
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, which helped bring a 1980 lawsuit charging intentional segregation in locating public housing in southwest Yonkers, contends that reliance on existing apartments is impractical because cooperative boards are reluctant to sell to subsidized tenants. It wants a far more new construction.
Judge Sand could also select from options put forward by the court-appointed Fair Housing Implementation Office that call for as many as 1,700 apartments and houses on 18 sites, including four near the O'Rourke town houses.
On June 17, Judge Sand indicated in an interim opinion that he thought Yonkers could find no more than 250 homes in existing cooperatives and would have to rely more heavily on building new apartments. On Monday, the judge is to hear arguments on how much and what kind of new construction should be undertaken.
 
Question of Class
 It is additional construction that worries Mrs. Bourke and her neighbors. A resolute woman in her 60's who has lived in Crestwood for eight years, Mrs. Bourke, who is white, denied that she was ever opposed to the presence of black families, pointing out that several already belong to her association. "The attitude was that if you could afford to buy a house, you were welcome," she said.
Rather, she and her neighbors suggested, there were questions on the mixing of people of disparate economic classes, of people who had bought homes with heavily subsidized renters, many of whom are on welfare. Helene Ellen, who recently sold a house near Mrs. Bourke, said she also resented that the town houses swallowed up a Little League field and a tennis court.
But much resentment seems to be based on misinformation. Homeowners have complained that the O'Rourke tenants were given lawn furniture, air-conditioners and lawn mowers, for example. But the washer-dryers belong to the Municipal Housing Authority, housing officials said. Whatever lawn furniture and lawn mowers the O'Rourke tenants have, they say they bought themselves. The apartments come with slots for air-conditioners, but not the appliances themselves.
Cheryl Jones, a 43-year-old neighbor of Mrs. Bourke who is black, said she had barely noticed the presence of the newcomers. But she did notice how many white neighbors stopped her to explain that their opposition to public housing was not based on race.
"It's like they owed me an explanation," said Ms. Jones, who recently retired as a New York City Transit Authority train operator.
Still, she wondered how much thought Judge Sand has given to the practicality of mixing different economic backgrounds. "Is he willing to have low-income people in his neighborhood?" she said. "He's making that decision for everyone else. But is he willing to do that?"
She said her prime concern was that additional housing would draw the traffic and hubbub that made her leave the Inwood section of Manhattan. "I don't want it crowded," she said. "I lived crowded before. I don't want it again."
 
A Welcome Change
 At the O'Rourke town houses, the tenants also have complaints, particularly about the small size of the rooms, but they say they appreciate the chance to be away from the incessant gunfire and tantalizing drugs of the projects.
Janice French, who moved last June from the William A. Schlobohm Houses, a cluster of eight public high-rises in southwest Yonkers, said much of the crime in the high-rises was caused by intruders or guests in buildings too teeming for control. "You can't stop people from having company," she said. "Here everybody knows everybody."
One thing both sides acknowledge is that there has been little true mingling among adults, the tacit goal of the integration lawsuit, although some town house children play with those living in a nearby development of 1,083 garden apartments called Crestwood Lake. Forty-three percent of that development's population was minority members, including many receiving Federal subsidies, even before the town houses were built.
"We try to get along," said Mrs. Bourke of her relations with the O'Rourke tenants. "We're not blood brothers. I don't invite them into my home and they don't invite me into theirs."
Some opponents of housing integration have drawn parallels with Judge Sand's allied efforts to integrate Yonkers 32 schools. Since 1986, voluntary busing has created far more racially mixed schools, but the citywide numbers of white students has declined to 7,080, from 9,989 in 1985-86. Since then, the number of black students has climbed to 5,750, from 4,557, and the number of Hispanic students to 7,416, from 4,289.
Jerilynn Fierstein, a spokesman for the Yonkers Board of Education, said studies have shown that white flight specifically attributable to desegregation "has not been significant." The racial changes, she said, are the result of broader demographic shifts that have seen a doubling of Hispanics in a decade and an aging of the white population.
Intriguingly, the arrival of the town houses has created a sturdy, if diplomatic, relationship between Mrs. Bourke and Valerie Carroll, the tenant supervisor for Yonkers Municipal Housing Authority, who is black. Whenever any homeowners have a complaint about the town houses, Mrs. Bourke will visit Mrs. Carroll and she said she had been pleased with the quick responses.
But Mrs. Carroll complained that many homeowners too readily assume that if there is a blight like graffiti, it must have been caused by the town house dwellers. "How would they know it was one of our people?" she said. "Our people don't walk around with T-shirts saying 'I live in Dr. James F. X. O'Rourke houses.' "
She added: "I heard a little girl here say: 'It's like the country. It's wide open spaces.' The children can ride their bikes. They can roller skate. This is something everyone has a right to as long as they can take care of it."
Mrs. Bourke said that she felt she had patched the neighborhood together and that she worried most about panics like those decades ago in the Bronx, the embarkation point for many Yonkers citizens. She said she was grateful that a weak economy is frustrating home sales and hoped that those considering selling their homes would hold on to see that the neighborhood has not been hurt by the town house tenants.
Mrs. Carroll understands that some people might resent that the government pays so much of her tenants' rents. But she asks: "Why should they begrudge a person for moving up a little. I can understand their aspirations and anxieties. They should be able to understand our aspirations and anxieties, too."

HEADLINE: Jamaica: Prosperous Isle in Queens

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

 BODY:
When Ken Bernard and his two partners decided recently to open an upscale bistro offering Caribbean and other dishes and sidewalk dining, they looked past obvious spots like TriBeCa, SoHo or the Upper West Side.
Instead, they invested about $270,000 in a vacant storefront in downtown Jamaica, a commercial hub in southeastern Queens that not long ago had deteriorated amid the urban decline that ravaged other commercial districts in New York City and across the nation. 
 "There's enormous untapped potential here," Mr. Bernard, 28, said one recent afternoon as a lunchtime crowd of office workers, college students and shoppers filtered through the new establishment, S.I.B., at 92-32 Union Hall Street.
For years the boosters of downtown Jamaica have maintained that the area has been revitalized, offering as proof ambitious private ventures and, to a far larger extent, a diversity of government-financed projects like a new Federal building, a network of new subway stations and even a farmers market.
To a large degree, city planners and others say, the recovery has been sustained by government spending that revived and expanded the neighborhood's institutions.
But this alone, they say, does not account for the area's ability to rebound and thrive with low retail vacancy rates while the city has struggled against a recession that stalled construction projects elsewhere and created a glut of empty stores and shops.
Essential to the revival has been the increasing economic strength of a black middle class that has emerged throughout southeastern Queens.
In surrounding neighborhoods like St. Albans, Hollis and Springfield Gardens, as in other parts of the borough, black households have reached an economic milestone: virtual income parity with white households in Queens, according to the 1990 census records. Situated at the crossroads of these neighborhoods, Jamaica has profited to a great extent from an influx of new merchants, many of them immigrants, who have brought shops and other businesses in the hopes of tapping into the wealth.
 
Prosperity Seems Within Reach
 Bob Richards, president of the Jamaica Chamber of Commerce, said: "The black middle class of southeastern Queens has had a large role in Jamaica's revitalization. They are Jamaica's future."
Now prosperity seems within reach. Up and down the district's streets, the once-shuttered retail storefronts are virtually all occupied. People bustle along sidewalks, swarming a recently arrived department store called Wertheimers, scores of smaller merchants, Iranian jewelry vendors and food stands serving West Indian dishes. Thousands of civil servants stream in and out of the new Federal building, and students surge through the gates of the recently constructed campus of York College.
There are also a number of shops and street peddlers selling dashikis, African artworks, posters of Malcolm X, beads, headdresses and other goods that have made the district something of a center for black culture and commerce.
"It's like being black is in style again," marveled Saiyd Muallam, 35, as he hawked books by black nationalists and historians from a card table on Jamaica Avenue. "There's a real consciousness out here. It's like an awakening."
Jamaica has struggled with many of the same problems that other downtowns across the country have faced, as white households fled the inner city and new suburban malls lured customers away. Throughout the 1970's and early 80's, the district was also hobbled by the loss of its most venerable and stalwart institutions: the headquarters of Jamaica Savings Bank, The Long Island Press and department stores like Macy's and Gertz.
 
2-Decade Redevelopment
 As a result, the redevelopment efforts of business leaders took two decades, with visions of transforming the fading shopping district into an intricate center of government, education and commerce. It was intended to cater to the tastes and needs of the surrounding neighborhoods, where longtime white residents who moved elsewhere were gradually replaced with black middle-income families who have made economic strides in recent years.
Bounded roughly by Hillside Avenue and Liberty Avenue on the north and south, and 175th Street and Sutphin Boulevard on the east and west, downtown Jamaica has been a natural hub for such a development, experts say, because it ties together several subway lines, dozens of city and private bus routes and the Long Island Rail Road.
"The area shows the amazing ability the city has to reinvent itself," said Eric Kober, a director with the New York City Department of Planning. "It's the resilience of these areas that sets the city apart and makes it an amazing place."
There are still many reminders of how much work lies ahead, however.
Just a few blocks from a new $30 million mall and office complex, on a shadowy side street, security guards with dogs patrol the courtyard and hallways of an apartment building that neighbors say was plagued by drugs and dealers. Much of the district's office space remains vacant. And Jamaica has yet to attract large numbers of high-end shops, say merchants and others.
 
Sense of Optimism
 "The job is not done by far," said Carlisle Towery, the president of the Greater Jamaica Development Corporation, which has intensively lobbied four mayoral and gubernatorial administrations to support downtown Jamaica's economic interests.
Even so, there is a sense of optimism and security on the streets now that projects like a $110 million Social Security Administration building and the $550 million Archer Avenue subway line, have been in place for several years and helped draw more people through the area for daily affairs. "We've got the basic public investments in place now," Mr. Towery added.
Pakeeza Pleasant, a 38-year-old real-estate consultant who lives in nearby Laurelton, says she travels to Jamaica rather than to malls in the neighboring suburbs of Long Island because of its bazaar-like atmosphere and the ethnic and cultural flavor of its streets.
"It offers so much," Ms. Pleasant explained after an afternoon of shopping with her small son. "You can bargain on almost anything."
Such willingness to spend has enticed a number of ambitious new entrepreneurs to the district, which has more than $300 million in retail sales each year, according to the Jamaica Chamber of Commerce.
 
Curry Goat and Class
 Six months ago, after shutting down their restaurant in downtown Brooklyn, Marcia Henry and Pamela Quashie moved the business to Jamaica, using their homes as collateral to expand the venture into a trendy dining nook inside a sleek food court at the new farmers market. There they serve West Indian dishes of oat-bran porridge, curry goat and ackee and codfish.
In the months before the move, they said, the partners sized up several other sites for the business, called Paradise Splash, but were ultimately lured to Jamaica because they felt it had high commercial traffic and a large appetite for their home-style cuisine.
"We know there's money to be made here," said Mrs. Quashie, an immigrant from Tobago. "We didn't have a dime when we started, but we hope to franchise one day."
The operators of S.I.B., the club on Union Street, also had high ambitions when they opened two months ago, bent on providing something they feel the district lacks: sophisticated entertainment spots.
As longtime residents of nearby neighborhoods, Mr. Bernard and his business partners realized that many of their neighbors often traveled to night clubs and restaurants far outside the area. They decided that people would prefer to spend their money where they live.
In preparing for the restaurant's opening, Mr. Bernard and his partners decorated the space with the paintings and wood carvings of artists from Guyana, their homeland. They also placed a dance floor in the rear amid high ceilings and muted lighting.
"What we're trying to do here is create an environment people would normally go to Manhattan for," explained the club's manager, Derek Drakes. "We're hoping to set a standard in Jamaica."

HEADLINE: Conversations/William Kristol;
A Conservative Cheerfully Argues That 'Family Values' Has a Future

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
So why should we care about values issues after the 1992 campaign, after the Murphy Brown imbroglio and the backlash to the Republican National Convention? Haven't the liberals basically won on issues like abortion? Shouldn't we all just settle down and talk about the economy?
"To the contrary," says William Kristol, former chief of staff to Vice President Dan Quayle, now a conservative strategist trying to chart the movement's future. "Despite the clumsiness with which those issues were raised in 1992, the fact is that values issues -- to use your phrase -- are back stronger than ever." 
 He is sitting in his modest Washington office preparing to head off to the National Right to Life Committee's convention in Milwaukee later in the week, and other stops on the conservative circuit. He sees numerous signs that the politics of values is alive and kicking.
He cites the recent cover story in The Atlantic Monthly, "Dan Quayle was Right," a grim appraisal of what divorce and single parenthood do to children. He talks of the parents' revolt in Queens over what values their children should be taught. And notes the uproar over lifting the ban on homosexuals in the military.
As for the triumph of the liberals? Liberalism may dominate the government, the media, higher education and most of the cultural institutions, he says. "But on the other hand, liberalism is in a way very weak, it's very hollow. It's lost its force, its real conviction, its real confidence in itself.
"The analogy I use sometimes," he adds, with a small, unapologetic smile, "don't get this wrong -- but it's a little bit like communism, Eastern Europe in the late 1970's, early 1980's. It dominates all these institutions of society, but even the believers have lost confidence in it. And the people have certainly lost confidence in it."
He remains adamant that the American people are "pretty conservative" on basic values.
But -- don't get this wrong -- they didn't exactly rally to the image of "family values" presented by the Republican Party last year, did they?
 
'Just Empty Feel-Good'
 Mistakes were made, he acknowledges. "I don't think it was Dan Quayle's mistake -- but the mistake that was made by some in the campaign was to talk about family values without linking the values issues to concrete outcomes, results, effects on people's lives," he says. "So that too often all the talk about values sounded either like harsh moralizing or just empty feel-good: it's family night at the Republican convention with all the grandchildren on stage.
"The issue of family breakup is not simply an abstract issue of moral preferences. It's an actual issue of the life chances of kids in our society."
Mr. Kristol, who is 40, is no stranger to the cultural elite he derides. The son of the neoconservative writer, Irving Kristol, he is a Harvard Ph.D. who taught political science and public policy at the University of Pennsylvania and Harvard's Kennedy School of Government before entering the fray himself. He was chief of staff to William Bennett when Mr. Bennett was Secretary of Education and joined Mr. Quayle's staff in 1989. He has a reputation for being very smart and very conservative.
He is presently the director of the Bradley Project on the 90's, a conservative think tank. He has a vision of conservatives as the counter-culture, the renegades, taking on the chillingly P.C., liberal-dominated bureaucracies and crashing through for the people.
But whose values are the true values of the people? The Republican Party's platform on abortion, which would effectively outlaw the practice, is very much a minority view, according to public opinion polls.
"Look, I was for changing the abortion plank," Mr. Kristol says. "It's just that Bush didn't have the credibility with the prolife forces to carry it off. Everyone knew that plank was anachronistic in 1992."
This, however, is not to say that the abortion struggle is over -- just different, he argues. "I think the great majority of abortions will be legal for the foreseeable future," he says. "I think that's unfortunate, but that's a fact." Still, he predicts that more and more people will reconsider abortion in the years to come, that the anti-abortion forces will have an ever more receptive audience.
"Insofar as the pro-abortion agenda is not just to make it legal, but to remove all stigma from it, to make it not just a right but right, I think that's not going to happen," he says. "And it shouldn't happen. The unfettered right to abortion -- if you think it through -- is based on the notion that the right to abortion is as great a dignity as the right to free speech. And therefore it's something that should not only be tolerated, but maximized -- by having the Federal Government pay for it, by prohibiting anyone from trying to discourage anyone from exercising it."
 
Limiting Gay Rights
 Similarly, he sees a clear line on just how far the gay rights movement should go. "At the end of the day, I do not think society can or should treat homsexuality the same as heterosexuality, or at least the same as the heterosexual family." What then, is the appropriate government stance? "Legal protection for marriage and lack of legal recognition, in a sense, of homosexual unions of whatever sort, but not persecution of homosexuals in their private lives."
In all of these areas, Mr. Kristol argues, President Clinton is far out of step with the country, and is very much of the cultural elite.
But, you might ask, didn't he spend 12 years as Governor of Arkansas, not exactly a training ground for the cultural elite?
"It's as if he went underground," Mr. Kristol muses. "It's the Manchurian President. He went underground for two decades, acclimated himself to local traditions." Once elected, Mr. Kristol asserts, "It's Hollywood, New Haven redux."
But isn't there something unseemly about using values as political tools, "wedge issues" to swell a vote count?
"Look, I agree that you should not use these issues cynically," he says. Mr. Quayle's famous Murphy Brown speech was never given "with the notion that this was going to save the Bush campaign," he says. There were others in the party, he argues, without giving names, who seized on these issues to try to save a hemorrhaging campaign, and used them badly.
But these days, he says, he looks beyond Washington and is heartened. He scoffs at the notion that issues like gay rights are a distraction from the real business of government.
"There's this notion here in Washington that everyone should spend all their time discussing individual lines of the budget, and whether the tax rate should be 34 or 35 percent for corporations. But you can make the case that, in fact, over the long term society is going to be much more shaped by the lessons we teach our kids and the public policies we pursue regarding homosexuality, the family, issues like that."

HEADLINE: Putting It in the Market

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Trade Sanity With Japan" (editorial, June 16) states that the American economy suffers from a lack of savings, presumably as witnessed by the low percentage of money invested in banks, and that this low rate of bank savings has prevented American companies from raising capital for modernization. I disagree. 
 The primary source for capitalization in the United States is the stock market, and as your business pages state daily, individuals are pouring billions of dollars into the stock market each week. After the real estate scandals of the 1980's, pouring money into banks certainly wouldn't help improve our industrial base.
Moreover, recent articles report that mutual funds have more capital than banks and that banks no longer fulfill the mission of providing capital for business. Since small investors in Japan do not have access to mutual funds and have to rely on banks as middlemen, comparing our system with Japan's is pointless.
Our antitrust laws (designed to protect the little guy) would prevent the overt misallocation of capital that Japan's Finance Ministry engineers in favor of larger companies. Our reliance on a market mechanism prevents Japanese-style economic engineering and is quantitatively fairer to United States citizens.
As long as necessary steps are taken to insure that accurate corporate data are available and that the market remains liquid, the stock market should provide a superior mechanism for financing long-term growth. It is high time that economic prognosticators consider the impact of individual investments in the stock market and consider the money involved as savings and not the wages of a day at the races.
 
ZACHARY PITLUK
New Haven, June 18, 1993

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2725 words

HEADLINE: Rethinking 42d St. For Next Decade

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
"IT'S going to be a more beautiful Times Square in a hurry," Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said last August, as four giant office towers on 42d Street were postponed in favor of an interim rehabilitation of existing buildings.
But "hurry" means something different on 42d Street than almost anywhere else. After all, it has been 10 years since Mr. Cuomo said, "Today we have laid the final cornerstone to rebuild the most famous crossroads in the world." 
 So the 10 months to prepare a new plan seem like the blink of an eye -- at least to those involved in the project. "We had to totally rethink what 42d Street is going to look like in the next 10 to 15 years," said Rebecca Robertson, president of the 42d Street Development Project Inc., a subsidiary of the New York State Urban Development Corporation. "We think rethinking a plan in 9 to 10 months is something of a miracle."
Guidelines for the interim project -- which would last at least a decade -- are now being discussed with the development team, a joint venture of the Prudential Insurance Company of America and Park Tower Realty, as are the terms of the interim lease for the state-owned property.
The chief executive of the Prudential Realty Group, Brian J. Strum, said Wednesday that "there are substantial revisions that have to be accomplished with those guidelines."
For now, the vision of a new 42d Street remains just that.
There are critics who hope the project stays on the drawing board. They say that the public subsidies -- easily more than $100 million for site acquisition alone -- are no longer warranted, if they ever were. Under the new deal, for instance, the developers are relieved of their obligation to contribute $91 million to rebuild the Times Square subway station. And much of the construction that the project was supposed to spark around Times Square has already occurred. Meanwhile, critics say, the very life has been drained from 42d Street itself while it awaits long-delayed resuscitation.
Having condemned and emptied most properties on the east end of the block between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, the 42d Street Development Project hopes to "reanimate" the street with a large-scale art exhibition using storefronts, facades, vitrines, marquees, billboards and even roll-down grates. On display from July 8 through Oct. 31 will be the work of artists and designers like Jane Dickson, Jenny Holzer, Tibor Kalman, Todd Oldham and William Wegman.
Eventually, 42d Street is to be a commercial, as well as esthetic, grab-bag -- "a little something for everyone," in the words of a marketing plan prepared for the state by Garrick-Aug Associates Store Leasing and the Phillips/Norwalk Company.
About 153,000 square feet of commercial space would be created on four large parcels at the crossroads of Broadway and Seventh Avenue that the state assembled for the office towers. These were -- and eventually are -- to be developed by Prudential and Park Tower, headed by George Klein.
UNDER the interim plan, buildings that were to be razed to make way for the towers will be rehabilitated as restaurants, nightspots, stores and service offices.
Another 112,000 square feet of space would be created in nine historic theaters and adjoining buildings that the state owns between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. Finally, the plan calls for 147,000 square feet of commercial space on the Eighth Avenue end of the blocks between 41st and 43d Streets, which are still privately owned.
"Commercial facilities selected for 42d Street will generally be popular-priced establishments which together will generate excitement, fun and round-the-clock entertainment," the retail consultants said. "Forty-second Street cannot be pigeonholed like a 'festival marketplace,' a shopping mall, or Main Street, U.S.A. The street will always mirror New York City with all of its vitality and turbulence."
As a design parallel, one of the architectural consultants, Robert A. M. Stern, said 42d Street "should look noisy, historically layered and unplanned," with a "jumble of different scales, sizes, styles and historical periods" and "bold, brash and varied signs."
Prudential and Park Tower would develop the interim project with $20 million of their own, for interior demolition and reconstruction, some tenant installations, storefronts, streetscape improvements, facade restorations, roof replacement and asbestos removal. Large commercial signs, like those on rooftops, will be paid for, built and leased by sign companies, Ms. Robertson said.
The developers would pay the state $3.3 million a year in rent, adjusted for inflation. In turn, they would collect rent from their commercial subtenants. The estimated gross income for all four sites has been projected by the retail consultants at $8.64 million a year for the first five years and $9.94 million a year for the second five years.
But Mr. Strum of Prudential said rents would cover the investment only if the developers signed 10-year leases with uniformly strong tenants. "We probably wouldn't make any profit, but we wouldn't lose any of the $20 million," he said. "On the other hand, that's the most optimistic view."
The Prudential-Park Tower team has paid site acquisition costs as they arise, a figure that now amounts to $186 million and could reach $241 million. But ultimately, the developers are responsible only for $88 million of that amount. The balance is to be refunded in the form of forgiven taxes.
That means the public will owe the developers at least $98 million for property and fixture settlements paid to owners along 42d Street. In addition, some interim rent paid by the developers would be refunded, as would their $18.2 million contribution to the theater renovations and their $2.6 million contribution to streetscape improvements.
Besides that, the money spent by the developers on environmental impact statements, appraisals, title reports, title insurance premiums, surveys, filing fees, transfer taxes and some legal fees would also be refunded.
And this is to be paid back with interest. Under the old deal, interest was calculated as the prime rate plus 1 percent. (Currently, that would mean 7 percent.) Under the new deal, interest is calculated as the yield on 10-year Treasury bills plus 1.1 percent. (Currently, that would mean 7.06 percent.)
Under the old deal, interest would have run for the whole period of development; under the new deal, interest is suspended until construction begins on the office towers.
State Senator Franz S. Leichter, a Manhattan Democrat, has long criticized the economics of the 42d Street project as a needless public subsidy. His chief of staff, Erwin Rose, said last week that under the new deal, "the size of the subsidy may turn out to be very different and potentially could be higher."
But Ms. Robertson said the "overall financial deal has improved tremendously" for the public, particularly with the suspension of the interest accrual and the renegotiation of the interim rent for the office tower sites to $3.3 million a year from $1 million.
Current negotiations involve the design, use and occupancy guidelines that are to shape the new project. Tension is already evident between officials and the developers over signage and lighting requirements, as well as the question of what kind of tenants will be permitted in which location. "The state isn't in that business," Mr. Strum said. "We are. And there are little things that, if you write them in cement, can cripple you."
"If you say, 'This piece of space can only be used for the sale of food,' " he said, "that means you can't put in a Hard Rock Cafe, because they sell a lot of T-shirts."
Ms. Robertson said, "Guidelines should not only be flexible enough to attract retail tenants but exciting enough to attract really good tenants and maintain the essential spirit of 42d Street and Times Square."
Elsewhere on the street, the historic mid-block theaters might be used by nonprofit theater groups, a tourist center, a jazz or blues club, a nightclub and a theme restaurant. One of them, the Apollo, is already a home for rock concerts. The most celebrated of the group, the New Amsterdam, has long been seen as the one most likely to return to use as a Broadway house.
Six of them -- the Apollo, Liberty, Lyric, Selwyn, Times Square, Victory -- are controlled by the nonprofit New 42d Street Inc., which is responsible for finding new uses. The president of New 42d Street is Cora Cahan, who had been executive director of the Feld Ballet and was instrumental in the development of the Joyce Theater, at Eighth Avenue and 19th Street, and the Lawrence A. Wien Center for Dance and Theater, 890 Broadway, at 19th Street.
"WE knew, when the towers were not going up, that we had to revise the notion of long-term uses for the theaters," Ms. Cahan said. By shortening the lease terms to 10 years for some of the theaters, she said, "livelier and feistier" interim tenants might be found, to complement nonprofits making longer commitments.
"Anything that can move quickly here is better than requiring that everything be long-term," Ms. Cahan said. "There has to be experimentation and revision. We want the ability to revise."
Ms. Cahan said a plan ought to be ready for four of the theaters by the end of July. "We postponed making an announcement about any of the theaters until a public announcement of the entire revised plan for 42d Street," she said, "so the public had a sense that it was not a series of isolated things happening, but a major push."
Last August, when the 42d Street office towers were indefinitely postponed, Ms. Robertson said a plan would be ready in six months. But it is only now nearing completion. The main reason it got off schedule, she said, was that it contemplated something no earlier plan had: rehabilitating dozens of structures along 42d Street.
No one had paid much attention to the condition of these buildings before, as they were simply going to be fodder for the wrecking crews. Then, in an abrupt reversal, they were to be brought back to functional life. From cellars to cornices, every square inch had to be scrutinized.
"Our objective was to make the plan real," Ms. Robertson said. "We don't want a restaurant in a space where the column spacing is too tight or signage on a roof where the structural members can't support it."
"We wanted to come up with an answer that worked," she said, "that could be built now, that was economically feasible and that suited the needs of Times Square."
But Leonard J. Weiss, who owns a parking lot at 250 West 41st Street that may be condemned as part of the project, takes a different view. "As should be obvious to any sane person," he said, "nothing is happening and nothing is going to happen."
Even those who believe something may happen are growing anxious.
"We have to see a plan," said Frederic S. Papert, president of the private 42d Street Development Corporation, which created Theater Row on the block between Ninth and 10th Avenues and is planning a 42d Street trolley. (Despite similar names, the organization headed by Mr. Papert bears no relation to that headed by Ms. Robertson.)
"It's an embarrassment to New Yorkers that 42d Street has fallen so far from grace," Mr. Papert said. "In my view, it's worse now than it was. At least, it was operating."
All but 21 of 269 tenants have been cleared from properties on the state-owned sites. Of the nine historic theaters, only two are now in use: the Harris (where first-run features are shown for a $6 admission) and the Apollo.
Howard Swernoff's family has owned the six-story office building at 233 West 42d Street since 1928. The cloud of condemnation has made it almost impossible to find tenants, he said, with the exception of pornography operators, who have offered to lease space at a "handsome increase" over existing rents. "We're the only building that hasn't had porn in it," he said. "But I'm between a rock and a hard place. We may have to rent it to them."
Douglas Durst, an owner who has long been among the most forceful opponents of the 42d Street project, said officials were "continuing to make a huge mistake in believing they can build office towers and trying to lease it up on an interim basis.
"It's very difficult to bring good tenants in for short-term leases," he said. "I think they're going to have problems with that."
John Goldman, a real-estate developer and Clinton resident, asked: "Why don't they open it up again, give the keys out -- maybe with some discretion -- to the closed-up businesses and bring the place back to life?"
But it is a condition of the deal that the state deliver the sites vacant to the developer, although nothing theoretically would bar the return of a papaya counter or gyro stand.
Both the financial deal and the land-use plan "should get a full public airing," said Joseph B. Rose, the chairman of the land-use committee of Community Board 5. "The interim solution, whatever gets done, is likely to look a hell of a lot like the permanent solution. So it becomes crucially important what happens."
Senator Leichter's chief of staff, Erwin Rose, who is not related to Joseph B. Rose, said the renegotiated deal would yield a "completely different project than the one approved by the Board of Estimate in 1984 and should be subject to public review."
MS. ROBERTSON is a veteran of the public review process, having come to the 42d Street project in 1987 from the city's Planning Department, where she was deputy director of the Manhattan office and the senior planner involved in a 1984 rezoning of the Upper West Side.
She said the revised plans would be shown to interested parties, like the community boards, in advance of the public hearings by the Urban Development Corporation. "We intend to meet people and inform them," Ms. Robertson said. "We have a road show and we expect to go on the road."
Under one scenario, used by officials to gauge the cost and potential of the project, but not meant necessarily to limit the kinds of tenants on any specific site, the office tower parcels could accommodate 153,000 square feet of commercial space, 88,000 of that on the ground floor.
Garrick-Aug and Philips/Norwalk recommended that the stores be geared to visitors.
Some of the retail units would be as small as 800 square feet. The largest would be:
* The former Nathan's Famous Restaurant and Big Apple Theater, at Broadway and 43d Street, would house a two-level theme restaurant, a nightclub and a specialty store, with about 17,000 square feet. The building dates to 1940.
* The lower floors of the Long Acre Building, at Broadway and 42d Street, would be used for a bookstore and other specialty shops, about 11,000 square feet. This 12-story building was completed in 1912.
* The Rialto Theater, at Broadway and 42d Street, would become a music store with a video theater and second-floor restaurant, a total of some 11,000 square feet. Built in 1935, this is a minor gem of Art Deco design, but not one of the historic auditoriums.
* The base of the former Ninth Federal Building, on Broadway between 41st and 42d Streets, would become the 10,000-square-foot "Exchange," a service center with a bank, currency exchange and ticket desks for theaters, airlines, excursions and tours. The 11-story building was finished in 1915.
There is also to be one new building on the south side of 42d Street, between Broadway and Seventh Avenue: a two-story, 3,300-square-foot newsstand, cafe and coffee bar. This will replace the "temporary" police and visitor center, fashioned from trailers, that was built in 1986.
The Times Square Business Improvement District has already established a small beachhead of its own, having set up a tourist and travel information office in the corner of the Rialto Theater building.
Gretchen Dykstra, president of the Business Improvement District, said the new plan "maintains what I think of as Times Square vitality within limited resources, and it holds out hope of bringing life back to the street as quickly as possible."
"If they're talking about as little as $20 million, there's not a whole lot you can do, so it's best not to show the hubris of big plans but to do something modest and appropriate," Ms. Dykstra said. "There is value to creative modesty."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2350 words

HEADLINE: The Most Entertaining Americans? Canadians

BYLINE: By RICK MARIN; Rick Marin, who was born in Toronto, writes about the arts for Vogue and TV Guide.

 BODY:
WHAT'S SO FUNNY ABOUT Canada? It's a big country with a lot of snow, Mounties and politely boring people who say "eh." The British novelist Kingsley Amis put a fictitious tome titled "Canadian Wit and Humor" on his list of the World's Shortest Books. "Worthwhile Canadian Initiative" was the winner of The New Republic magazine's Most Boring Headline contest.
Joke-wise, Canada gets no respect. But it should, especially since Canada has produced some of America's funniest comedians, actors, writers, directors -- a veritable army of renegade humor professionals. Without them, there would have been no "Saturday Night Live," no "SCTV," no Spy magazine, no "Ghostbusters," no "Wayne's World," no sidekick for David Letterman to take with him to CBS. Expatriate Canucks like Dan Aykroyd, Michael J. Fox, Mike Myers, Phil Hartman, John Candy, Rick Moranis and Martin Short could gather on Thursday to celebrate Canada Day, a holiday most Americans would rank somewhere below National Pickle Week. 
 Thanks to their nearly undetectable accent and their proximity to the United States, Canadians have insinuated themselves into the pop culture of the United States, from Mary Pickford ("America's Sweetheart") to the Amazing Kreskin. "Field of Dreams," the mythic movie about the great American pastime, was based on the baseball novel "Shoeless Joe," by the Canadian W. P. Kinsella. Television is filled with Canadians, from Lorne Greene in reruns of "Bonanza" and the space cowboy William Shatner on "Star Trek" to Jason Priestley, the heartthrob on "Beverly Hills 90210." "Generation X," the bible of the 20-somethings, was written by a Canadian. Even Superman, defender of truth, justice and the American way, was the invention of Joe Shuster, from Toronto.
"I remember a time when America wasn't Canadian," somebody laments in an old "Saturday Night Live" sketch that posited an invasion of the United States by its deceptively innocuous neighbor from the North. Spy magazine (co-founded by the Ottowa-born E. Graydon Carter) once ran a mock-paranoid feature titled "The Canadians Among Us."
They are indeed among us, but it's in the realm of comedy -- on both sides of the camera -- that their presence seems so weirdly disproportionate. Scratch the surface of television comedy over the last three decades and you'll find Canadian writers and producers behind such shows as "The Smothers Brothers Comedy Hour," "Rowan and Martin's Laugh-In," "The Mary Tyler Moore Show," "The Sonny and Cher Comedy Hour," "Hee Haw," "Taxi," "Fernwood 2-Night," "SCTV," "Major Dad," "Home Improvement," "Seinfeld," "The Simpsons" and "The Ren and Stimpy Show."
Why is this? Interviews with dozens of Canadians and Canada-watchers reveal that boredom, cold and an obsession with American television have propelled Canadians -- with their irreverence and their sense of irony -- into the solar plexus of American pop culture.
"Toronto in the 1950's was a very safe and ordered place, so the chief thing to be overcome in my childhood was boredom," says Lorne Michaels, who came to the United States 25 years ago to write jokes for Woody Allen and "Laugh-In" before creating "Saturday Night Live." In Canada Mr. Michaels performed in a television show called "The Hart and Lorne Terrific Hour," in which his partner, Hart Pomerantz, dressed up as a beaver (Canada's national animal) and Mr. Michaels interviewed him.
Assimilation was easy. Canada is, in many ways, a slice of the same white bread American heartland that produced Johnny Carson, David Letterman and Jay Leno. Citizens of the United States generally know nothing about Canada and care less. Canadians, on the other hand, are experts on the United States. "I know more about America than most Americans," boasts Peter Jennings, the ABC anchorman, saying "aboot" for "about" in the Canadian accent he denies having.
Once Mr. Michaels had skipped south of the border, he did what most immigrants do: imported more of his countrymen. He brought his partner's brother Earl Pomerantz, who went on to write for "Mary Tyler Moore" and "The Cosby Show" and was the creator of "Major Dad." ("We wanted to get to a warmer place," Mr. Pomerantz recalls.)
Mr. Michaels also asked Mr. Aykroyd to join the original cast of "Saturday Night Live." More recently, he brought "The Kids in the Hall" to HBO and then to CBS. And, securing his lock on late night, he will be the executive producer for NBC's new Conan O'Brien show, scheduled to replace "Late Night With David Letterman" in August.
 
Comedy
The Gross National Product
 Ask Canadians in the comedy business about influences and they invariably invoke two names: Wayne and Shuster. Johnny Wayne and Frank Shuster (a relative of the Shuster who created Superman) were a comedy team whose literate buffoonery became a staple on "The Ed Sullivan Show." Their big routine was a parody of Shakespeare's "Julius Caesar" called "Who Killed Big Julie?" Sample shtick:
Wayne: "I'll have a martinus."
Shuster: "Don't you mean a martini?"
Wayne: "If I want two, I'll ask for them."
Before Wayne and Shuster, there was Stephen Leacock, sort of a Mark Twain-meets-James Thurber humorist whom every Canadian youth is compelled to read in high school. Another influence: the cross-dressing, pants-down humor of "Monty Python's Flying Circus," which was broadcast in Canada several years before it was in the United States. "Americans appreciate British humor like Monty Python, but they don't always get it," says Andrew Malcolm, a former correspondent for The New York Times and author of a narrative history titled "The Canadians." "Canadians get it."
They also get satire and political humor, despite being famously deferential in the face of authority. Canadians will say "Thank you" to a bank machine. Yet they rebel in their comedy, channeling repression into humor. The Winnipeg-born David Steinberg did political stand-up in his Vietnam-era "Tonight" show heyday. Mort Sahl, who left Montreal at an early age, virtually invented the form. Rich Little, who is from Ottawa, impersonated Richard Nixon to death, as did Dan Aykroyd on "Saturday Night Live," a tradition continued by another Canadian, Phil Hartman, who does Bill Clinton.
"When I came to NBC there was this curiosity as to why I would want to do political comedy, because it was a sure ratings killer," says Mr. Michaels. "America was founded on the distrust of authority. In Canada, you don't feel secure in that right, so you exercise it. Defying authority in a small way is a big Canadian thing."
Paul Shaffer, the David Letterman sidekick who migrated south in the wake of musicians like Neil Young and Joni Mitchell, likens the Canadian comedy phenomenon to the British invasion of the American pop music scene during the same decade. Like the Beatles and the Rolling Stones, he says, Canadians "had an even more intense reverence for America than the Americans themselves."
 
Tube Power
Either On It Or Watching It
 When the comedian Mike Myers was in the eighth grade, he did a project called "Canadians in Comedy." He also did one on Lorne Michaels, he says, "in the hope that he would someday give me a job." Which, of course, he did.
Mr. Myers, who drew much of the suburban heavy-metal mythology of "Wayne's World" from his Torontonian youth, says he remembers Martin Short telling him, "When Americans watch TV, they're watching TV, but when Canadians watch TV, they're watching American TV." That distinction, Mr. Myers says, "makes you notice things."
Even before cable, Canadians were saturated with television. "If you were living in Vancouver or Toronto in the 70's, you were living in the most TV-dense place on the planet," says Doug Coupland, whose book "Generation X" is laced with American pop references.
Most of the country's 26 million citizens are massed along its southern border; they survive the long winter nights with antennas that pick up the indigenous channels plus signals from across the 49th parallel.
" 'Looney Tunes' was our introduction to American culture," says Mr. Carter, who is now the editor-in-chief of Vanity Fair. "We felt slightly above the pop cultural circus of the United States but slightly envious at not being a part of it." Dave Foley, a cast member of "The Kids in the Hall," claims that he honed his "observational sensibility" by spending his formative years watching "Green Acres."
Many Canadians cut their teeth on local television as a result of a strict nationalist cultural policy, enforced by the Government-run Canadian Broadcasting Company, mandating that 40 percent of all television and radio programming contain "Canadian content." Almost anyone in Canada who wants to be on television can do so. Los Angeles became the terminus for an underground railroad of CBC-trained talent. "By end of the 1960's, American variety television was controlled by Canadians," says Norman Jewison, who left Toronto to be a television producer in Hollywood before he started directing films.
 
Outsiders
The Funhouse Mirror
 Although founded on anti-Americanism (many early Canadian settlers were British loyalists), Canada is perhaps the world's most pro-American country. Robert MacNeil, who is cohost of "The McNeil/Lehrer Newshour" on PBS and plans to write a book about being an expatriate Canadian, describes this love-hate relationship as "ironic distance." Sean Kelly, a founding editor of the National Lampoon who instituted the magazine's satiric "Canadian Corner" feature, draws an analogy to the "insider/outsider" culture of the Jews or the Irish: "You're part of the culture," he says, "but you're observing that culture."
Many Canadians agonize over questions of "national identity," wondering what it is and why they don't have one. There are hardly any Canadian heroes, except hockey players. Mr. Jewison says he gathers Hollywood's Canadian cabal at his Malibu beach house for Canada Day parties, but when they sing "O Canada," "nobody can remember the words."
Michael J. Fox, who became famous as the arch-conservative Republican teen-ager Alex P. Keaton on the long-running sitcom "Family Ties," says that "playing this Reaganite kid, I was free to parody and play with the idea because, being Canadian, I had nothing at stake." He also managed to make a potentially odious character nice, a distinctively Canadian trait. Jim Carrey, a cast member of "In Living Color," leavens his often deranged characters (like safety-crazed Fire Marshall Bill) with goofy Canadian charm.
Niceness is one reason Americans like -- and permit -- Canadians to make fun of them. It may also explain why these mocking foreigners have been so successful here. They are harmless, totally nonthreatening, profoundly silly. Could an American have made "Meatballs," "Ghost busters" or the gently cutting White House satire "Dave" -- all of which were directed by the prolific Canadian comic auteur Ivan Reitman.
"There's something slightly absurd about Canada," says Harold Ramis, the screenwriter and director who moved from Chicago to Toronto to work on "SCTV," the inspired television parody that launched the careers of John Candy, Rick Moranis, Martin Short and Catherine O'Hara. The very idea of Canada cracks up the writing staff of "The Simpsons," who hired a television writer from Calgary to supply them with jokes about the Canadian Football League and the location of the world's largest nickel (Sudbury, Ontario).
Mike Myers, who says "I bore people with my Canadianness," admits to weeping sometimes with homesickness. To cheer himself up, he subscribes to a publication called Hockey Night in Toronto.
Expert at mocking others, Canadians can be stuffily humorless about themselves. Perhaps the only thing that the comedian Howie Mandel and the economist John Kenneth Galbraith have in common is that they don't regard their compatriots as necessarily funnier than residents of the United States.
"One should not exaggerate the influence," counsels Mr. Galbraith. Mr. Mandel agrees: "I don't know if they're producing any more comedians than any other state."
 
<O CANADA: THE LIST
 Canadians are the pod people of American pop culture, as Spy magazine (co-founded by a canadian) once pointed out. They look like people who live in the United States; thay act like them, and they talk like them (sort of). Are they taking over? Casual perusal of any "Who's Who" reveals the large percentage of famous Americans who are, in fact, Canadian - or wer at least born there. PUB-DATE: June 27, 1993

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1042 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
The Primordial Ooze of a Budget Bill

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN building a house, every time a brick is laid or a room completed, the house looks more like the final product. But a bill in Congress is not like that -- especially not such a monumental measure as the five-year deficit-reduction legislation that squeaked through the House of Representatives last month and the Senate last week.
This has gotten lost as the budget bill has moved through Congress. Because the latest development is what makes the news, when the House or Senate has modified the energy tax, dropped a tax break or a new spending program or made some other change in the legislation, it has often appeared that the bill was unraveling further. 
 In fact, the final legislation, after the two chambers' versions are reconciled in a conference committee next month, could look mostly like the House's or mostly like the Senate's. Or it could be an amalgam of the two with only passing resemblance to either, like the way orange paint is quite different from the red and yellow mixed to make it.
"There is not a human being alive who can tell you what the outcome of the conference will be," said Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader.
Often conference committees work magic. This year, it might take a King Solomon to forge a deficit-reduction bill that can be enacted. Dozens of lawmakers will be conferees, since so many panels have jurisdiction over parts of the budget. But the final package will doubtless be written late next month in a small room by a handful of Democrats.
Three Senators will be at the table: Mr. Mitchell; Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, chairman of the Finance Committee, and Jim Sasser of Tennessee, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee. Four Representatives will certainly be there: Thomas S. Foley of Washington, the Speaker of the House; Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader; Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, chairman of the Ways and Means Comddmittee, and Martin Olav Sabo of Minnesota, chairman of the House Budget Committee. And a few top Administration officials who are former lawmakers will certainly participate.
Their task is a daunting one -- to write a bill that can be passed in full by the House and then by the Senate with no amendments.
 
Slim Margins
 The Senate approved its bill shortly after 3 o'clock Friday morning by the narrowest of margins, 50 to 49, with Vice President Al Gore casting the tie-breaking vote, the first such vote by a Vice President in six years. The House passed its version on May 27 by a six-vote margin. This means that if only one Senator or three Representatives switch because they do not like the compromise struck in the conference, the whole bill will fail.
Mr. Rostenkowski said he was treating this conference differently from any other he had ever been involved in. Normally at this stage, he said, he would be trying to figure out how he could squeeze every last drop of what he wanted out of the bargaining. This time, he said, he was calculating what concessions he and his colleagues needed to make so that something could become law and serious embarrassment to the President and Democrats in Congress could be averted.
The close votes arose for two reasons: Every Republican in both houses voted against the legislation, and President Clinton's popularity is not such that Democratic politicians fear standing up to him.
On the first point, the Republicans are betting that a rigid stand against higher taxes is their ticket back to the White House and possibly even to control of Congress.
In the Senate last week, the Republicans offered a substitute budget that purported to reduce the deficit as much the Clinton budget by relying just on spending reductions. It was bogus. It was assembled at the 11th hour, and it did not identify by name a single Government program to be cut. But it was a rallying point for Republicans worried that if they simply voted against everything, they could be charged with fomenting gridlock.
Richard A. Baker, who has worked as a historian in Congress for 25 years and been the Senate historian since 1975, said he could not remember a time when an important bill became law after every Representative and Senator from one of the parties voted against it, as is the case with this bill.
On the question of Mr. Clinton's political strength, most of the Democrats in Congress believe that for the sake of their own survival they need to show that their party can confront the country's problems when they control both the White House and Congress. But they have been independent contractors for 12 years and are not in the habit of following a White House blueprint. And most of them are more politically secure than Mr. Clinton.
 
What Will Survive
 The Clinton proposal most likely to be part of the final bill is a steep increase in the taxes on the wealthy. Beyond that, the conferees must walk a tightrope between liberal Democratic Representatives, who favor a broad energy tax and more spending for social programs, and more conservative Democratic Senators, who worry about higher taxes and favor cuts in benefit programs.
Three of the six Democratic Senators who voted against the bill Friday have tough re-election fights next year: Richard H. Bryan of Nevada, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona and Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey. The other three are conservatives who simply do not like the Clinton program: J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana, Sam Nunn of Georgia and Richard C. Shelby of Alabama.
Several others had their arms twisted almost out of their sockets before they voted yes. They include Herb Kohl and Russell Feingold of Wisconsin, Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, Bob Graham of Florida and Howell Heflin of Alabama.
Senator Kerrey's position was especially dicey. He lost to Bill Clinton in the New Hampshire primary last year when Mr. Clinton made everything sound easy, including a middle-class tax cut. Now Mr. Kerrey was being asked to save Mr. Clinton's political life by voting for a gasoline tax, a tax on Social Security benefits and new Medicare limits.
He bit the bullet Friday morning. Next month, he will be asked to do it again. Depending on what comes out of conference, it may be asking too much.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: June 27, 1993

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 6; Column 3; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1417 words

HEADLINE: 'Power Lunches' in a Converted Barn

BYLINE: By BARBARA STURKEN

DATELINE: FLORHAM PARK

 BODY:
NEAR the intersection of Route 24 and Columbia Turnpike, where cows once grazed on rolling farmland, gleaming office parks rise from landscaped lawns. Only a weathered brick barn appears untouched by the development.
But close inspection reveals that it, too, is part of the change. This "historic barn," as a bold-lettered sign explains, is the unlikely home of a new organization called the Park Avenue Foundation and Club. 
 By the end of this year, the club's sponsors plan to open a private dining club and an affiliated foundation that will use any profits from the club to benefit local charities and cultural institutions. Civic leaders have already united to raise several million dollars toward renovating the aging structure. They say they aim to preserve not just the building but the traditions of the private dining club, an institution that seemed headed for extinction in New Jersey's changing economy.
The club takes its name from its location on Park Avenue, a suburban corridor that is as different from Park Avenue in Manhattan as the new club will be from the men's clubs of yore, many of which have closed in recent years.
In Newark, the Essex Club shut down last year, following the demise of two other venerable institutions, the 744 Club and the Downtown Club. They were casualties of the sagging economy and the exodus of large corporations from Newark, Manhattan, Trenton and other cities for suburban office developments in places like Florham Park and surrounding Morris County.
 
Disrupting Old Habits
 The Morristown area was one of the fastest-growing regions of the state in the 1980's, gaining some 10,000 jobs from 1982 to 1990, according to the New Jersey Labor Department.
For uprooted executives, the transition from city to suburbia disrupted old habits. Those accustomed to strolling two blocks to meet a business associate for lunch or drinks now needed a car to get anywhere. Some corporations opened their own private dining rooms for executives, but this did not answer the needs of lawyers, stockbrokers, accountants and others who wanted a place to take clients.
To cater to such displaced diners, work is proceeding furiously on the hundred-year-old barn, once part of a dairy farm owned by the Sisters of Charity. Where cows once chewed their cud, executives will dine on meals prepared by "culinary experts," the club's brochure says. Where a silo once stood, corporate directors will hold forth in meeting rooms. A paneled library and grill room and bar will also be available to members.
Although the club bears little resemblance to a working barn, some local residents are pleased that the building has been saved. Betty Heinig, vice president of the Morris Museum Foundation, in Morristown, said that because of all of the new construction in the area, residents began to form a sentimental attachment to the hulking structure. "It is one of the few genuinely old buildings still left in that area," she said.
The Morris Museum is one of the seven nonprofit organizations participating in the foundation that will divide club revenue remaining after operating expenses. Others are the New Jersey Symphony, the Jersey Battered Women's Service, the Morris-Sussex Area Council of the Boy Scouts of America, the Boys and Girls Clubs of Newark, the Morris Habitat for Humanity and the New Jersey Special Olympics. Each organization contributed toward the initial fund to start the enterprise.
 
A High-Profile Board
 "This is more a community project than a private club," said the club chairman, David Hedley, a managing director of the investment firm Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and a Mendham resident.
The club already has close to 700 members, and it plans to establish a waiting list after membership reaches 1,100. On the advice of the Club Corporation of America, a Dallas-based business that will manage the Park Avenue Club, Mr. Hedley helped to assemble a board of governors composed of well-known civic leaders -- including former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, president of Drew University in Madison; Christopher Forbes, vice chairman of Forbes Magazine, and Peter Burgdorff, a real-estate broker.
Mr. Hedley said that a demographic survey showed that "the audience for this is there," noting the concentration of corporate headquarters in the area, including Exxon International, Allied-Signal and Schering Plough.
For those who want a private environment to combine business and socializing, there are few alternatives in the area, said Deborah Rooney, project associate at the club. "We are encouraging people to come and do business here," she said. "We expect there will be power breakfasts, power lunches."
A "young executive" membership category, which offers reduced fees for people 34 or younger, is already sold out, according to the club newsletter.
While country clubs nearby serve meals during business hours, Ms. Rooney said that most of them discouraged members from conducting business too openly and that some even have rules against the display of business papers in their dining rooms.
There is one establishment in Morristown that fits the stereotype of an exclusive private club, the century-old Morristown Club, founded in 1884. The club moved in 1929 into its present quarters, an old unmarked brick mansion at 27 Elm Street. It began as a men's luncheon club and still serves only lunch, except for one evening each month when it has a dinner and speaker.
The Morristown Club, which has 275 active members, has changed with the times. In the 1980's, it began admitting women as members. It also plans to accept up to 50 new members this year, said Irene Meehan, an investment adviser with the Tucker, Anthony brokerage firm in Morristown, who joined after the all-male restriction was struck down.
The club's board of governors is headed by Peter Perretti, a former State Attorney General who is a partner in the law firm of Riker, Danzig, which is one of the donors to the Park Avenue Club.
There is no reason why both clubs can't thrive. Ms. Meehan said, "It is right that there be a more broad-based club" that is open from morning into the evening hours.
The idea for the Park Avenue Club came at a party several years ago, when Mr. Hedley struck up a conversation with Stanley Gale, president of Gale & Wentworth, real-estate developers in Florham Park. The talk turned to saving the barn on a large tract that Mr. Gale was developing.
That led to interest from the Morris Museum and others arts organizations that were hoping to expand. But efforts to turn the barn into an arts center foundered because of inadequate funds.
Mr. Gale, whose company had already erected an office park on the property, decided to donate the barn and a plot of land, which it valued at $2 million, to the new foundation. Labor and construction materials for the renovation were donated by local businesses and unions.
The value of the entire project has been estimated at $4 million, although much of that has been made in in-kind donations. Fund-raising events have propelled the project along, including a cocktail party at the Morris Museum, with a talk by Mr. Kean, and a series of gatherings marking construction-related events, like a "topping off" ceremony.
 
'A New Angle on It'
 The club's leaders describe the combination of a foundation and social club as unique, and several academic experts on philanthropy did not challenge that claim.
"This seems to have a new angle on it," said Jon Van Til, professor of urban studies at Rutgers University. "It may well be that these seven organizations by coming together may have a more effective fund-raising organization."
But he warned that combining two disparate functions could raise problems. "There could be an unholy mixing of taxable and nontaxable activities there," Professor Van Til said. "But funding is tight, and the profession of fund-raising is growing."
In its brochure, the club explains that donations to the foundation are tax-deductible charitable contributions, while club dues and expenses can be deducted only as business expenses.
Mr. Hedley said that based on projected membership and fees, which are $1,500 for joining and $75 a month thereafter (young executives and nonresident members will pay $500 to join and $50 a month), he can predict that the participating nonprofit organizations will most likely receive a better rate of return on their investment than they might otherwise receive.
