HEADLINE: Its Courtship Over, E.D.S. Seems Eager to Play the Field

BYLINE: By KATHRYN JONES

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
WHEN Britain's largest telephone company backed away last month from a proposed alliance with the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, the initial reaction from some investors and industry observers was one of pity.
But Lester M. Alberthal Jr., chairman, president and chief executive of the Dallas-based computer services company owned by the General Motors Corporation, says far from being the wallflower at the global dance, E.D.S. is doing just fine, thank you. 
 "We have no interest in trading one owner for another owner," Mr. Alberthal said in an interview last week about the collapse of the deal with British Telecommunications P.L.C., which would have involved the sale of 25 percent of E.D.S. stock. "We're not out there trying to find a partner. We're trying to have discussions and pursue all the major players to see if there are any business relationships that make sense."
If that sounds a lot like someone suddenly embracing the single life after being stood up at the altar, it may also not be such a bad thing for E.D.S. to do, analysts say.
"They don't really need to pick a specific partner," said Timothy R. McCollum, a Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. analyst. "They just need to align themselves with as many companies as possible."
After all, E.D.S., which was founded by Ross Perot in 1962 and purchased by G.M. in 1984, remains strongly profitable and has made plenty of aggressive moves on its own in Europe, a hot market now because of economic unification and the opening of the east.
What's more, technology alliances have had a spotty record, particularly when corporate cultures don't mesh. In this case, the analysts say, British Telecom sought a degree of control over E.D.S. that promised clashes down the line. Though owned by G.M., E.D.S. remains strongly independent in the way it does business.
That business, which produced sales of $8.2 billion last year, is serving as a butler and nanny to companies' increasingly complicated computer systems. It ties together computer services, taking over billing and other functions and running data processing departments -- a practice known as "outsourcing." Incrementally, it has put together the world's largest private communications network to link customers' desktop computers and data terminals with massive information storage libraries and to transport data via telephone lines and microwave and satellite transmission.
Still, analysts say, E.D.S. does need to forge a strong relationship with one or more telephone companies if it is to continue to grow long-term.
The computer services market is an increasingly global one, they say, in which the lines between computers and telephones are blurring and the International Business Machines Corporation and others are becoming aggressive competitors. Although E.D.S. already leases telephone lines in bulk from providers like the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the MCI Communications Corporation and Sprint, closer ties to one or more carriers could provide greater access to their worldwide networks, making it possible to reach more customers.
SETTLING down with British Telecom, however, instead of playing the field in Europe could have been costly to E.D.S., said Sean Phelan, principal analyst with the Yankee Group Europe, a consulting and research firm in London. "While I can see the advantage for European carriers in a tie-up with E.D.S., I don't see the advantage for E.D.S.," he said. "E.D.S. can manage and coordinate the services of multiple European carriers far better than they can coordinate among themselves. And while E.D.S. is independent of any carrier, they are all potential clients."
For his part, Mr. Alberthal, 49, said E.D.S. has been talking with every major telecommunications company -- among them A.T.& T., the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation and European companies, including even British Telecom after the deal fell through -- looking for what he also calls stronger relationships.
But if any new relationship gets so strong that it involves the sale of E.D.S. shares, it will have to overcome the hurdles posed by the unusual nature of the G.M.-E.D.S. stock structure.
Shortly after acquiring E.D.S., G.M. created class E shares, which offer a stake in E.D.S.'s performance through dividend payouts but not in its ownership, since G.M. holds all of the company's capital stock.
While G.M. has been talking for some time about selling part of E.D.S., it is not clear just how a buyer would get a voice in running the company under the current structure.
In British Telecom's case, all that is known for sure is that it offered to buy 25 percent of class E shares. Analysts say G.M. sought as much as $5 billion for the shares and also wanted to structure the deal as a tax-free transaction. Otherwise, G.M.'s taxes could have been as much as $1 billion, analysts said, reflecting E.D.S.'s increased value since G.M. acquired it for $2.5 billion. British Telecom refused to pay more than $4 billion, and in early June bought a 20 percent stake in MCI instead for $4.3 billion.
"British Telecom wanted a steal," said Stephen T. McClellan, an analyst with Merrill Lynch & Company in San Francisco. "It turned out G.M. was a little less desperate for cash than they thought."
But apart from questions of price, G.M. would have to give up some equity in E.D.S. for any deal to work, analysts said. And they doubt the auto maker is willing to do that since E.D.S. is one of its few profit-making centers. "I don't think anything is imminent," Mr. McClellan said.
E.D.S. will do well even without a partner, analysts said. The company holds about a fifth of the $28 billion United States market for outsourcing and related computer business services and its finances are strong, with $543 million in cash and securities and cash flow that is double its earnings level. Indeed, E.D.S. has plenty of cash and lines of credit to make acquisitions, the analysts said, although not enough to lay its own fiber optic lines for expanding its communications network. Since G.M. acquired E.D.S., it has consistently racked up double-digit increases in net earnings. Last year, it earned $635.5 million; Mr. McClellan estimates it will earn $729.6 million this year.
YET E.D.S. is being challenged as never before. In only two years of existence, I.B.M.'s computer services subsidiary, the Integrated Systems Solutions Corporation, has passed Andersen Consulting, the Digital Equipment Corporation and others for the No. 2 position. I.S.S.C. last year racked up $1.8 billion in revenues; like E.D.S., it is one of its parent's few bright spots.
"The issue for E.D.S. now is how aggressive I.B.M. will be," said Terence Quinn, an analyst with Furman Selz Inc. But I.S.S.C. also has some disadvantages. Not surprisingly, for example, it pushes I.B.M. hardware while E.D.S. can offer a wide range of hardware and software.
British Telecom and MCI also could become formidable competitors if they can acquire more information technology expertise and use their planned global telecommunications network to deliver services to corporations, Mr. Quinn said.
In contrast, the Perot Systems Corporation, the company started by Mr. Perot after he left E.D.S. following a high-profile squabble with G.M., has less than $450 million in annual sales, and has taken some, but not much, business away from E.D.S.
DURING the recession, E.D.S. capitalized on an outsourcing boom. More corporations turned over their data-processing operations to outside experts to save money and avoid technology obsolescence and incompatibility down the road. The American market for such services is expected to more than double to $61 billion by 1997, according to Dataquest Inc.
Corporate users last year awarded 18 big outsourcing contracts, half of them valued at more than $500 million. E.D.S. won five of the megacontracts and I.B.M. won three, including a $3 billion, 10-year deal with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.
E.D.S.'s non-G.M. work has soared in the past four years, growing at a compound annual rate of 25 percent from 1988 to 1992, compared with 4 percent for its G.M. accounts.
In the first half of 1993, however, E.D.S.'s revenues from outside customers slowed to single-digit growth. That worried some investors and dampened the price of class E shares, which have lagged competitors for more than a year and closed Friday at $30.75. But Merrill Lynch's Mr. McClellan believes the blip is temporary and that non-G.M. business will return to double-digit growth in the second half after some new contracts begin to produce revenues.
Still, he forecasts that the non-G.M. business will grow only 12 percent this year, while G.M.-related revenues will be flat. Because of the slower growth, E.D.S. has been reducing employment in areas that don't directly relate to servicing customers -- as much as 5 percent in some of its 37 strategic business units, according to analysts. E.D.S. employs about 71,000 worldwide.
"They're going through a major retightening," Mr. McClellan said, adding that he's glad to see it.
As it increases its non-G.M. business, E.D.S. also continues to ease its dependence on G.M., which accounted for 75 percent of its revenues immediately after the auto maker acquired the company. The share was down to 41 percent last year and is expected to fall to 38 percent this year.
"We don't want to have our revenue stream impacted by one company," Mr. Alberthal said, sounding another note of independence. "We don't want to be tied to one company or one industry or one country."
 
 
 
TO EUROPE, OR ANYWHERE
 Even without a telecommunications partner, the Electronic Data Systems Corporation is on the way to its goal of delivering any kind of information -- voice, data or video -- to anyone, anytime, anywhere.
The computer services company has won or is a finalist for several large contracts this year that expand its presence in Europe and cultivate a new customer -- consumers. E.D.S. has pushed into Europe mainly by acquisitions, buying SD-Scicon P.L.C., a British-based computer services company, for more than $250 million in 1991, for example.
That acquisition is already paying off. E.D.S., along with the Computer Sciences Corporation, is a finalist for a $2 billion contract to take over data processing operations for Inland Revenue, Britain's tax collection agency. A winner should be announced in October. Its largest contract so far in Europe is a $1 billion deal signed in April to take over data processing for a Swedish union of business cooperatives, the Kooperative Forbundet.
International business last year accounted for about 23 percent of E.D.S.'s total revenues of $8.2 billion and the company eventually wants to boost overseas sales to half its revenues. Revenues from customers in Europe, apart from General Motors, more than tripled in the last three years, to $828.3 million last year from $226.7 million in 1990. Total European revenues came to about $1.37 billion last year.
Consumers are also key to E.D.S.'s long-term global strategy. Typically a behind-the-scenes player, E.D.S. hopes to win more name recognition through deals like one announced in May to operate as many as 4,000 automated teller machines in 7-Eleven convenience stores. The E.D.S. logo will be on the machines for the first time.
Meanwhile, E.D.S. hopes to capitalize on the convergence of cable TV and phone companies to deliver video, which E.D.S. can store in computerized form and transmit over phone lines. Last month it signed a 10-year, $300 million contract with Spectradyne Inc., a leading provider of pay TV programming to the hotel industry, to deliver movies and other programs when guests want them instead of at a pre-set time.
"We want to expand beyond the business customer," said John R. Harris, an E.D.S. vice president and head of the Communications Industry Group. "We want to serve the individual at home or work or anywhere in between."

HEADLINE: Graduates Bring Their Ideals to a Battered World

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
AS Ricardo Horacio Roda prepared for graduation last week, he looked back on three years of struggling to learn a new language and make friends in a strange country. The 17-year-old from Argentina, the first Hispanic student in 60 years to become valedictorian of Roosevelt High School in Yonkers, said that for him graduation was "the American dream come true -- proof that in this country, if you want something and work hard for it, it can happen."
Throughout Westchester last week, high school students who were approaching graduation looked back at their struggles as teen-agers and ahead at the responsibilities they would shoulder as adults. Born in the 1970's, these graduates are statistically part of what some journalists are calling "Generation X" (from the 1991 book by Douglas Coupland, regarded by some as the manifesto of the under-30 set). This group has no formal name (titles like Boomlets and MTV Generation have at times been suggested by the media for the older, twentysomethings) and to date few distinguishing characteristics except that they follow a generation of baby boomers, school authorities say.
 
A Difficult Legacy
 It is what 17-year-old Jennifer Zobel, who graduated second in her class at Fox Lane High School in Bedford last week, described as "a generation of children of working parents, kids who had to learn early on to be independent." 
 But Jennifer, who plans to attend Columbia University, and other members of the class of 1993 rejected the notion that they were a nameless or faceless generation. They said that they had their work cut out for them in the world and vowed to distinguish themselves by addressing the issues of the day.
They chided the generation of their parents and teachers -- that of the 1960's and 70's -- for preaching love but bequeathing to succeeding generations a world where the legacy of racism and intolerance still prevails in many areas.
And they criticized the baby boomers, the high-earning and big-spending generation, for leaving behind a fragile economy and the worry that when the class of 1993 graduates from college in four years, there still may be too few jobs to go around.
Also, the students talked about AIDS, Bosnia, Somalia and domestic issues in the United States.
School principals, sending off the class of '93, characterized the graduating seniors as ethically and morally concerned about the world they were entering as adults, and more intent upon righting wrongs than making money.
"They're concerned about human issues," said Daniel A. Woodard, the principal of White Plains High School. "Our generation made a mess of things, and they want to turn that around."
At Mount Vernon High School, Vice Principal Brenda L. Smith said: "Many say they don't know what this generation is, but I cling to some hope that they will find themselves, given the problems that exist in society. I tell the students not to underestimate their ability to influence, for the better, the lives of others."
A 1992 national study of incoming freshmen, which was conducted by the University of California at Los Angeles, showed that the observations of school principals in Westchester and the graduating high school seniors in the county reflected concerns and attitudes of young adults throughout the country.
 
Social Values a Major Concern
 The university's 27th annual national survey of 213,630 incoming freshmen at 404 colleges and university showed that the percentage of students for whom "helping to promote racial understanding" was either an "essential" or "very important" goal rose to an all-time high of 42 percent in 1992, up from 33.7 percent the year before.
Also, 85.1 percent of the freshmen disagreed, compared with 79.7 percent the year before, with the statement that "racial discrimination was no longer a major problem in America."
The study also showed that influencing social values had become a major concern of students throughout the country, with two out of three saying they performed volunteer work -- similar to what school principals in Westchester reported. The study added that students today were less interested in majoring in business and more focused on the health professions and related fields like biology and medicine, which was borne out in interviews with graduating seniors in Westchester.
From black, white, Hispanic and Asian families -- and different religious backgrounds -- the graduating seniors agreed that the greatest challenge before them as a group was to create a world where more than lip service was paid to the Old Testament question, "Am I my brother's keeper?"
Solita Alexander, who graduated fifth in a class of 341 from White Plains High School and is to enter Harvard University as a pre-med student in the fall, said: "Our generation is very aware of the needs of people who have less than we do. We're not going on to college thinking that everything will be a big party."
 
Fulfillment Is Important
 Solita, who is black and the daughter of a single mother from Guyana, an executive secretary at International Business Machines in White Plains, said that she wants to work in a rural community, like Appalachia, where residents have limited access to medical care or other advantages.
In Mount Vernon last week, where Lindsey McCabe was preparing the speech she would deliver to 509 fellow graduates, the valedictorian said that she would preach tolerance for other races, for homosexuals and for those with AIDS and would tell the class of '93 that "success should not be measured in money or grades, but in the ability to lead a happy life and be fulfilled."
 
Appreciating Diversity
 The yearbook editor and staff member of her school's literary magazine, Lindsey is to enter the University of Virginia as an English major in the fall. She said that her experiences growing up as the daughter of an Irish Catholic father and a Jewish mother, and as a young white woman in a school district where 85 percent of the population is black and Hispanic, have taught her "the importance of learning to appreciate diversity."
In Tarrytown, at Sleepy Hollow High School, the valedictorian, Robert C. Hyman, 18, said he was worried about a world that "still has too much of a gap between the urban poor and the wealthy elite."
Robert, who plans to enter Harvard University in the fall and study either physics or history, criticized many universities, including Harvard, for "promoting diversity but still being too upper-crust," and took to task fellow classmates for "being concerned only with issues that affect them directly, like censorship, and not enough concerned with the big issues like the environment."
Robert's message to 99 fellow graduates last week was that no matter what a person's race, religion, line of work or income is, "each of us has to make a difference in the world, even in little ways, like how we raise our children or conduct our relationships."
 
Problem of Discrimination
 At Bronxville High School, Aileen Bramhall, 17, said that although she grew up in a small, affluent and predominantly white community, she is aware of "a lot of places in the world where there is despair."
She will enter the University of Rochester in the fall and hopes to become an opera singer. "Aileen in Gaelic means the bringer of light," she said. "That's what I want to do. It is very sad to think that there are other young people in places like Bosnia and Appalachia who have talents that we will never know about. For anything to be wasted is a great tragedy."
And at Briarcliff High School, one graduating senior, Nancy Lee, cited discrimination as a major problem facing high school graduates today. "People talk a good game about not discriminating, but they don't play it," she said.
 
'Hopeful for the Future
 The issue hits close to home for the first-generation daughter of Chinese immigrants, who said she rejected stereotyping of Asian students "by those who think of us only as smart and going into math or science."
Nancy, who graduated fifth in a class of 88 students and plans to study biology at Cornell University, also criticized fellow Asian students for "only staying with their own kind."
She added: "That's their part of discrimination. Both sides are at fault when they don't reach out."
In Yonkers, Ricardo observed that in many ways teen-agers have similar concerns wherever they live, whether it be in Argentina, in Westchester or in a third-world country. "The class of '93 throughout the world has to face a lot of problems," he said. "We worry about many serious issues, but we all still have to be hopeful about the future."

HEADLINE: A Therapeutic Program for Troubled Students

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG

DATELINE: VALHALLA

 BODY:
DURING the final weeks of the spring term, most high school teachers have to struggle to capture their students' interest. So it was to be expected that some of the teen-agers in Sam Hedrick's world-cultures history class were gazing into space recently instead of their textbooks. Still, Mr. Hedrick managed to steer a conversation about welfare abuse into a spirited discussion of World War II and the rise of Hitler.
Despite these trappings of a conventional high school classroom, which has such standard social studies features as world maps, globes and computers, this class actually took place inside the Psychiatric Institute of the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla. And the students, who have had problems with alcohol and drug abuse, as well as psychiatric disorders that include anxiety, depression, suicide attempts and severe mood swings, are enrolled in West-Prep.
 
Checking to Avoid Relapses
 The program, a joint effort of the Westchester County Medical Center, New York Medical College and the Board of Cooperative Educational Services of Southern Westchester, offers troubled adolescents a combination of school and therapeutic treatment on an outpatient basis. 
 "All the kids here have a psychiatric diagnosis and a substance abuse problem," said Meri Wieder-Sirkin, the health-services coordinator for West-Prep. Geared toward youngsters 14 through 18, this five-year-old program provides a full academic curriculum and a variety of therapy sessions during its 8:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. day.
Students have to be referred by other hospitals, private psychiatrists or therapists, home school districts or the court system. What distinguishes West-Prep from other programs designed to treat troubled adolescents is that the students live at home, yet have access to the medical services of the Psychiatric Institute.
"This is the only Boces program in this area that is focusing on this problem of substance abuse," said Neil Manis, supervisor of special education services for the Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services. "If school districts send these kids here, the school districts have made earlier efforts to intervene. They're here because they have a disease that's interfering with academics. And it has made enough of an impact so that the school district doesn't want to handle it internally."
In many respects, a typical day isn't so different from that of most high schoolers. Students take classes in English, math, social studies and science and have the opportunity to relax with such activities as gym and occupational therapy.
What is not part of most high school students' experience is having to give daily or weekly urine samples to check for relapses into alcohol or drug abuse, a routine that West-Prep's students perform matter-of-factly.
Atypical of many high school programs is the strict enforcement of a behavior code, with increased freedom and responsibility (as well as prizes) available to those students who follow the rules and have good attendance.
For those who are violent or return to drugs, consequences are increased restrictions and loss of such privileges as going on a field trip or watching a movie. "Reinforcement is the key," said Mr. Hedrick, a special education teacher who teachers social studies and English in the program.
 
Building Up Self-Esteem
 As part of the treatment, students are expected to participate in alcohol- and-drug-abuse, self-help and group therapy sessions with other youngsters in West-Prep. The program also offers group sessions for their parents and siblings.
Amanada Bevacqua, a drugs and alcohol abuse counselor, said: "I want to get them to have insights into what got them into trouble. Some common issues are low self-esteem, family dysfunction and negative peer pressure. In many cases, these kids have to work through needing to be on a prescribed medication for their problem."
One parent, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to protect her family's privacy, said: "I know that these people have done tremendous things with my son. He was a wreck when he came out of Stony Lodge, and he would have relapsed if it hadn't been for the teachers and counselors. They focus on what the kids can do and build up their self-esteem. He'd still be very vulnerable without their support system." Stony Lodge is a private psychiatric hospital in Ossining.
The 24 students who are currently enrolled in West-Prep reflect a diversity of backgrounds and abilities, with the alcohol and drug abuse and emotional disorder often the only common link. There are teen-agers with learning disabilities whose academic program focuses on remedial efforts, and there are those who can easily pursue college preparatory courses.
Some students come from affluent homes in the county's wealthier communities while others live in group homes.
 
Rain Forest as a Project
 Susan Taylor, who teaches math and science at West-Prep, said: "It's hard to get them motivated or focused if they've had a bad time at home. A lot of these kids have not had much success in school. Our main job is motivating them so they can get out of high school, so they don't lose their education and so they can be successful. We work with the school district in planning an academic program."
One of this year's more successful projects was the creation of a living rain forest as part of the environmental science course and horticulture program. In a light-filled room cluttered with hanging plants, a replica of the rain forest -- complete with appropriate plants and insects -- stands as testament to the students' interest and dedication.
Maxine Kaplan, a member of the expressive therapy department of the Psychiatric Institute, said: "We had done small-scale terrariums before. The kids built the entire rain forest."
 
A Success Story
 Added Mrs. Taylor: "The important thing was that the kids got to do something that was successful."
The combination of relentless reinforcement from teachers and therapists, small classes and positive peer pressure has apparently succeeded in keeping many of the students on a straighter path. "Before, I was not into school," said a 17-year-old girl from Pleasantville, Marie M., who agreed to be interviewed only if her last name was not used. "I really got into social studies here, especially economics. I also like math and accounting. Ever since I've been sober, everything's different. I can't wait for college next year." Marie, who attends Alcoholics Anonymous meetings regularly, plans to enroll in Westchester Community College next fall.
Michael Feldman, 18, of Yorktown Heights is one of the program's more accomplished graduates. While he was at West-Prep, Mr. Feldman took college classes at Westchester Community College. Since his high school graduation in January, six months early, he has been enrolled at Iona College, working toward an accounting degree.
"When I first started at West-Prep, I didn't want to work with the program," Mr. Feldman said. "Then I realized that I was not going to get anywhere until I made friends with the staff and my peers. The best thing is that the staff works with you as a person, not as a patient or student. When I had first come out of the hospital, I was ready to use drugs again. But I didn't want to when I went to West-Prep. I've been off substances for two and a half years now."
Still, those who work with the students at West-Prep acknowledge that it is a continuing struggle to insure that these youngsters stay off drugs and alcohol after they leave the program. "If an adolescent and his family are both engaged in treatment, the rate for success is much higher," Ms. Wieder-Sirkin said. "And we work hard on the transition by continuing to do treatment."
Added Joseph Starvaggi, a clinical supervisor for West-Prep:
"I feel I'm successful when we have a kid who has acknowledged his problem with drugs and has been sober for a long time. I can only guide them and give them a direction and tools to use. I want to establish them so they can contribute and be comfortable with themselves and their families. I don't expect to cure them."

HEADLINE: U.S. and Japan Discuss Trade Goals

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, June 28

 BODY:
As bilateral trade talks began here Sunday, Japan and the United States remained divided over the issue of numerical benchmarks for measuring progress in opening Japan's markets, officials said.
The discussion, which will continue through today, is intended to set up a framework for talks between the two nations on structural issues like Japan's distribution system, and on particular trade sectors like automobiles. The American side has said that being able to measure progress is a key requirement, a demand that Japan has rejected as "managed trade." 
 Japan on Sunday proposed to set up a high-level committee of American and Japanese officials to discuss trade matters during the next two years. The group would be called the Committee on Market-Oriented Economy and Trade, or Comet, according to American officials and Japanese press reports.
 
Elements of Open Trade

 
 Japan proposed that there be general areas of discussion, including loosening regulations, opening government procurement to foreign companies, strengthening each nation's competitiveness and harmonizing both countries' rules in areas like intellectual property.
The United States has also proposed that future discussions be grouped into "baskets" and there is some overlap between the two proposals. The Japanese proposal, however, does not have a basket for the specific issue of increasing Japan's purchases of American and other foreign autos and auto parts, which Japan argues is beyond the control of the Government.
Japan's proposal also emphasizes that American trade practices should be discussed as well as those of the Japanese. While Japan said the committee might discuss the Japanese Government's procurement of supercomputers and satellites, it said the "Buy American" programs by the United States should also be topics of discussion.
The United States and Japan have said they want to complete the framework in time for the visit here next month of President Clinton for the summit meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations. But the framework, if it is established by then, is likely to be only a roadmap for future discussions rather than including specific new market-opening measures.
 
Numerical Goals at Issue
 In a separate meeting here Sunday of representatives from the seven nations in preparing for the summit meeting, the United States proposed including numerical goals in the economic declaration to be made at the meeting, Japanese officials and news reports said.
The United States wanted the Group of Seven to agree that each country would strive to cut its current account trade surplus to within 2 percent of its gross domestic product, a demand that American officials have made separately to Japan as part of the bilateral talks. In addition, the United States wanted the seven countries to agree collectively on a target of 3 percent economic growth.
Japan and some European nations opposed including these goals in the summit meeting's declaration, so they will probably not appear, one Japanese official said.

HEADLINE: Jumpstarting the Electric Car's Future

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Almost everybody likes the idea of clean, quiet electric cars, but at today's relatively high prices -- from the mid-$20,000's for a small car to $100,000 for a mini-van -- almost nobody buys them. So they remain impossible to mass-produce, which means that prices stay high.
Now, a new analysis has concluded that the impasse could be broken if Federal and state governments would commit themselves to large-scale purchases of the vehicles, an idea that some Federal officials cautiously agree has merit. 
 The study, scheduled for release today by the Center for the Biology of Natural Systems at Queens College, calls on Federal, state and local governments to purchase 200,000 vehicles a year, or about 80 percent of the cars and light-duty trucks that they now order each year. An order of that size would lead to lower prices over all, according to the authors, who said that "this gridlock can be broken with no direct cost to taxpayers."
Dr. Barry Commoner, who directed the study, said that if the Government entered the vehicle market in a big way and caused the price to fall, "we're not talking about a subsidy, but simply an economic motivation."
While electric cars have far less range -- from 50 miles between charges to perhaps 800 -- than gasoline-powered vehicles, most cars in the Federal fleet do not travel more than 50 to 100 miles a day, Dr. Commoner said.
The main motivation for developing electric vehicles is air pollution control. Electric vehicles are pollution-free at the point of use. Electricity production creates some pollution, but power-plant smokestacks are more easily controlled than auto tailpipes, and can be located hundreds of miles from population centers.
President Clinton has been seeking to stimulate production of "alternative fuel vehicles," including those running on compressed natural gas, methanol and propane. In April, the President signed an executive order requiring the Federal Government to buy nearly 34,000 such vehicles during the next three years, or 11,000 more than the number specified in the Energy Policy Act of 1992.
But officials of the General Services Administration, which actually buys the vehicles, and of the Energy Department, which provides the difference in cost between traditional and alternative-fuel vehicles, say they prefer buying natural gas- and methanol-powered cars because their price premium is far smaller than for electric cars.
William T. Rivers, an official at the G.S.A.'s fleet management division who is responsible for buying alternative-fueled vehicles, said Congress had appropriated $18 million for the extra costs of buying 11,250 alternative-fueled vehicles next year. That comes to $1,600 a vehicle. The added cost of some alternative cars falls well within that margin. A Dodge Spirit that can run on methanol or gasoline costs $721 more than a gasoline-only model, Mr. Rivers said, while a Chevrolet Lumina or Ford Taurus that can run on methanol or ethanol carries no price premium.
In contrast, he said, electric mini-vans sold by Ford and Chrysler cost more than $100,000 each. For example, Mr. Rivers said one mini-van that sells for $15,000 in the gasoline-powered version costs $115,000 for the electric model.
Buying electric vehicles would require a substantial subsidy, Mr. Rivers said, one that must be shared with methanol and natural gas vehicles. "Right now the only mechanism we have to get the vehicles is that the Department of Energy receives an appropriation from Congress under the Energy Policy Act," he said, referring to a provision of the 1992 law that is supposed to reduce dependence on oil.
 
A State Issue, as Well
 California, however, is counting on the emergence of an electric car industry by 1998, when its air quality regulations call for 2 percent of each auto manufacturer's California sales to be electrics, rising to 10 percent in the early years of the next century. Other states are seeking to adopt California's rules. And Washington often adopts national rules after they have been tested in California.
Gary Mauro, the Texas Land Commissioner who was named by President Clinton as chairman of the Federal Fleet Conversion Task Force, said his group would try to work with state governments and private-sector fleet purchasers to stimulate demand for electric cars, with an eye to bringing down costs.
The problem, he said, was scale. For example, not counting postal vehicles, the Federal Government owns about 558,000 light-duty vehicles, too small a fleet to require 200,000 new vehicles a year.
In addition, Mr. Mauro said, it was wrong to think that electric vehicles would work in all situations; with the limited energy in their batteries, they could not perform adequately in areas where heat or air-conditioning requirements were high.
Other people are skeptical for different reasons. "The technology is not quite at the point where they're worth being mass-produced," said Kenneth F. Barber, director of the Electric and Hybrid Propulsion Division at the Energy Department.
The average passenger car in the G.S.A. fleet travels 13,000 miles a year, the agency said. That comes to 50 miles a weekday. Some, obviously, travel far more than 50 miles in a day, but proponents of electric cars say a motor pool could employ many vehicles with a 50-mile range.
Dr. Commoner and his co-author, Mark Cohen, a Queens College scientist, said they thought costs would drop sharply after the first few hundred thousand electric vehicles were ordered. They based their projections in part on studies of the gasoline auto industry's early years; the price of an average car fell by more than two-thirds between 1907 and 1915, the authors said, because of the "learning curve" inherent in mass production.
 
Demand's Effect on Supply
 Still, in the case of electric cars, mass production would not lower the price of batteries; it might even drive the price up, because demand could rise faster than production capacity, experts have said.
But mass production would lower the cost of assembling the components, Dr. Commoner argued. "Most of the value added that goes into the car is the assembly," he said.
At this point, the American auto industry has the ability to deliver electric vehicles only in limited numbers. But within three or four years, if demand mounted, auto makers could gear up to produce any number of electric vehicles. In the interim, electric vehicles are readily available from small assemblers, which buy cars from manufacturers, take out the engines and reconfigure them.
Electric car producers say that even modest increases in demand would lower the cost of some components. For example, the Solectria Corporation of Arlington, Mass., sells a converted Geo Metro with an electronic controller. This device converts alternating current from the recharging plug into direct current, the form in which it is stored in the battery. Then it changes the energy back into alternating current for use in the drive motor.
The controller, in a box the size of a videocassette recorder, costs about $5,000 because it must be hand built, Arvind Rajan, Solectria's vice president for marketing and planning, said. With automated production, he said, the price would drop rapidly.
Solectria's least expensive car model currently sells for $26,000; the company has sold 40 of them in the last two years. If it could sell 10,000 vehicles a year, Mr. Rajan said, the price would be about $10,000 each.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ed Trembly of the Solectria Corporation, right, working on a Geo Metro converted to run on electric power. (Michael Quan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Argentina's Oil Company Going Public

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, June 27

 BODY:
Argentina takes a step on Monday that no other Latin American country has done: It is selling control of its state oil company, YPF S.A., to local and international investors.
The planned sale of nearly $2.5 billion in YPF stock after the close of trading on Monday is perhaps the most graphic illustration of the change in political and economic orientation for Argentina under President Carlos Saul Menem and, by extension, for much of the continent as it emerges from almost two decades of high inflation, protected markets, weak growth and negative industrial investment. 
 Historically, state energy companies have been considered the crown jewel of any Latin American government -- the patrimony of its history and the ultimate financial refuge from the pressures of international bankers and other foreign interests that threaten national security.
 
A Sale is Cheered
 In the past, the hint of selling such energy companies would stir nationalistic outcry and predictions of economic ruin.
But Argentines have cheered the sale of YPF, formerly known as Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales, flooding banks here with four times the number of buy orders for the stock than had been expected. And under a plan devised by Economy Minister Domingo F. Cavallo to exchange YPF stock for Argentine bonds, the Government will be able to retire almost $2 billion of debt.
"This has to be one of the most important financial transactions in Latin American history," said Jose E. Rohm, executive director of Banco General de Negocios, adviser to the Argentine Government and the underwriting syndicate on the transaction. "In one big stroke, Menem and Cavallo will consolidate an extraordinary economic transformation. Other countries in the region have hardly begun to consider this. Chile still holds onto its state copper company, Venezuela and Mexico have yet to address the state monopoly of their oil industries."
Christopher Ecclestone, a stock market analyst in Buenos Aires, said, "This could accelerate the eventual sale of state-owned natural resource companies around Latin America, not only oil but mineral companies as well that have traditionally been considered sacred cows."
On Monday afternoon, underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation and Merrill Lynch & Company will announce the final offering price for the YPF shares and the number of shares sold to public investors.
Officials expect the shares to be priced between $19 and $20 each -- in the upper range of the $17-to-$20 a share previously estimated by the Government. They say almost 130 million shares, 37 percent of the company, will be bought by investors who have sent in orders to underwriters during the last month. YPF shares, in the form of American depositary shares, will begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Tuesday.
 
Exceeded Expectations
 Though analysts have been skeptical of the transaction because of the speed at which the First Boston-Merrill Lynch syndicate has marketed the deal, they admit the offering has exceeded expectations. If, as investment bankers predict, almost $2.5 billion in YPF stock is sold, it will be one of the largest initial public offerings on record as well as one of the largest privatizations.
But the value for the Argentine Government is expected to top $4 billion. The Government is offering to exchange certain bond issues held by pensioners and other investors for YPF stock at a 15 percent discount. Officials estimate that up to $1.6 billion in bonds will be exchanged, bringing the total value to the Government to $4.1 billion when the stock sale and debt retirement are combined. And the Government plans to apply the proceeds from the sale to pay part of the billions of dollars in bonds held by retirees.
 
An Oil Giant
 With a total market value of about $7 billion, YPF would be one of the 20 largest oil concerns in the world. The company controls 54 percent of Argentina's oil and gas industry and has reserves of 2.8 billion barrels of oil and oil equivalents.
Investment advisers note that at around $20 a share, the value of a barrel of YPF reserves would be about $2.50, much less than the current average among international oil companies of about $6 a barrel.
While the privatization of YPF represents Argentina's willingness to open its economy, the company's financial condition reflects a significant turnaround from three years ago, when it lost $576 million, and throughout the 1980's, when it lost more than $6 billion.
New management has cut employees from more than 50,000 in 1990 to fewer than 10,000 now. Though it earned just $259 million in 1992 on sales of $3.91 billion, earnings this year are expected to exceed $600 million and approach $1 billion in 1994.
One reason is that by next year a pipeline to Chile will be completed, opening a large new market for YPF and adding substantially to its projected earnings.
 
The Fears That Remain
 While some analysts see YPF as a pure play on oil and gas assets, there are those who see inherent risks in the country -- a possible disruption in its economic stability and the ever-present worry in Latin America that a future government might decide to renationalize the company.
Not only do most politicians feel that would be out of the question, but investment bankers say that the deal's structure would make nationalization nearly impossible.
"We estimate well over a million Argentines will own YPF stock," Mr. Rohm said. "Now you tell me which Argentine politician would come along and take those shares out of the hands of that many voters."
Officials project that the Argentine investing public will end up with 31 percent of the shares in the company. By law, the Government has to keep 20 percent. Ten percent of the shares go to YPF workers, and five Argentine provinces have decided to keep 11 percent of the company. Foreigners, therefore, would represent only about a 28 percent ownership.
Investors have also worried about the independence of the company's directors, because the Government and provinces will have 31 percent of the shares. Investment bankers structured the deal so that the Argentine Government and the provinces are entitled to elect a total of 3 of the company's 12 directors, far from management control.
But not everyone is convinced that the privatization will mean the release of control by the Argentine Government over YPF.
"No one really has the impression that the company is leaving the fold of the state, just by injecting outside shareholders," Mr. Ecclestone said. "The shareholders are going to be a very dispersed group and there will be no real dominant player among them to exert pressure on management."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Southwest Airlines Earns Praise for Its Profitable Ways.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell

 BODY:
SOUTHWEST AIRLINES, rare among the big carriers because it is the only one that has made money each of the last three years, has attracted a slew of imitators among start-up airlines intent on duplicating Southwest's emphasis on lean operations and a minimum of passenger amenities.
But analysts see little threat from the copycats.
"If the start-up airlines succeed in direct competition with Southwest, they would have some impact," said Paul P. Karos, the airline analyst for First Boston. "But that doesn't seem to be a likely possibility." First Boston recently raised its earnings estimate for Southwest's second quarter, which ends this week, as well as for the company's full-year 1993 and 1994 results. 
 Southwest, the only big carrier to turn a profit last year, is the only one of the big airlines that does not operate a hub-and-spoke system, will not transfer passengers' baggage to a connecting flight, does not serve meals, offers only economy class on all flights, and has only Boeing 737's in its fleet. Its policy of not reserving seats often sets off a mad scramble at boarding time.
While adopting some of these techniques, newcomers seem eager to avoid head-to-head combat with Southwest -- probably for the same reason its giant competitors are reluctant to take on the no-frills carrier. When Southwest recently started flying to San Jose, Calif., for example, American Airlines beat a hasty retreat from that market. According to a recent Transportation Department study, while Southwest is only fifth in total passengers and eighth in revenues -- $1.7 billion, compared with $14.4 billion for American, the industry leader -- it carries more traffic in the top 100 markets in the continental United States than any other United States airline.
"Five years ago people who flew Southwest loved it," Mr. Karos said. "But the general public had the perception it must have been a cattle-car operation. Not any more. Today there's a whole different attitude. It's considered the 'in' thing to fly Southwest."
It is also sometimes cited as a model for the Big Three carriers to emulate, although their unit operating costs average 50 to 70 percent more than Southwest's, according to the Transportation Department.
Southwest's growing popularity is largely the result of lower air fares. The average fares last year in markets served by Southwest were $56 for distances of less than 250 miles and $58 for routes of between 251 and 500 miles. Fares over those same distances, on routes not served by Southwest, averaged $110 and $130, respectively. Mr. Karos said the carrier would begin operating to "some new, lucky city" this summer, but the airline has not revealed which one.
First Boston raised its second-quarter estimate to 44 cents a share from a previous projection of 36 cents, either of which would be higher than the 25 cents a share that Southwest earned in the second quarter of 1992. For 1993, Mr. Karos raised his estimate to $1.65 a share, from $1.55, and raised his 1994 estimate to $2.30 a share, from $2.
"With earnings growth of 70 percent in 1993 and 40 percent in 1994, and with longer-term earnings growth potential in the 15-20 percent range," Mr. Karos wrote in a recent analysis, "we think this stock can trade at 20 to 25 times 1994 over the next 12 months.
"Valuing this company has proven very difficult the last several years since the growth keeps accelerating," he wrote. "We think the stock will continue to perform well as long as earnings expectations are met or exceeded. We think this will occur the next few quarters."
The big unknown, Mr. Karos said, is Southwest's load factors -- that is, the percentage of seats filled by passengers. While they may not equal the 68.6 percent load factor he expects for June, the highest for any quarter in Southwest's recent history, he said he thought they would continue at high levels.

HEADLINE: Voters Are Rejecting More School Budgets

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 27

 BODY:
Voters across New York State rejected school budgets this year at the second highest rate since 1980, baffling a monitoring group that said today that it did not expect so much discontent.
Frustration over expected increases in Federal taxes and New York's continued economic troubles may have contributed to the rejections, said the New York State School Boards Association. 
 Of the 637 votes this spring on individual school district budgets, there were 177 rejections, or just under 28 percent, the association said in its annual compilation of results. That is an increase from 1992, when about 20 percent, or one school budget in five, was defeated, and just under the level in 1991, when 181 budget plans were defeated.
"It's a big surprise to us," Louis Grumet, the association's executive director, said today. "Ordinarily, when state aid goes up beyond expectations, usually budget votes go very well. That's not the case this year."

HEADLINE: Machine Tool Orders Drop For First Time in 3 Months

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
Posting their first decline in three months, orders for machine tools fell in May by nearly 9 percent. But industry experts attributed little significance to the decline as an indicator of trouble ahead.
In its monthly report, the Association for Manufacturing Technology, a trade organization in McLean, Va., said yesterday that orders for May totaled $317.3 million, compared with $348.3 million for April, a decrease of 8.9 percent. 
 Since January, however, orders have increased 38 percent, to $1.6 billion, compared with the corresponding period last year, and orders last month almost doubled the orders of May 1992.
"I think it's just a blip on the screen," said Matthew B. Coffey, president of the National Tooling and Machining Association, a 3,200-member trade organization based in Fort Washington, Md. "I think everyone was a little uncertain at one point, with the chance of an investment tax credit. Everyone was waiting for that. But once that disappeared, everybody resumed their usual patterns. So maybe we're seeing the lag effect of that."
 
Orders by Auto Makers
 "I don't see anything like a trend," he added. "If this continues for a quarter, then I think we would be seeing a fundamental change."
Albert W. Moore, the president of the Association for Manufacturing Technology, attributed the growth earlier in the year to orders by the Big Three auto makers. He said he expected fewer orders from the auto makers through the rest of the year, but he predicted that year-end figures for 1993 would still reflect at least 10 percent growth over 1992.
Machine tools cut and mold metal for capital equipment in a variety of industries, including those that make aircraft engines, refrigerators and cars. Tool orders, for both domestic use and export, are watched closely for trends in investment and imports.
This year, nearly 90 percent of the orders have been for domestic use, though the figure vacillates each month. In January, 19.7 percent of the orders were foreign; in May, just 5.1 percent.
That, too, was a signal to some that the decline might not necessarily stir concern that a fundamental shift in the economy is brewing. More critical to the level of future orders, Mr. Coffey and others said, might be the final shape of the Clinton tax plan, now being debated in Congress.
"If orders are starting to fall off, some major companies are holding back," said Charles D. Yuska, executive director of the Packaging Machinery Manufacturers Institute in Washington, whose members buy capital equipment for packaging operations. "If they're a little more cautious, I think it's because of the uncertainty in Congress."
The monthly figures complied by the Association for Manufacturing Technology reflect shipments and backlogs, besides orders. Shipments have fluctuated this year, with the figure for May, $236.75 million, reflecting about a 5 percent drop since January. Backlogs increased for the third consecutive month, to nearly $1.5 billion in May, an increase of almost 6 percent for the month and 18.1 percent since January.

HEADLINE: Bankrupt Individuals Are Fewer

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 27

 BODY:
After rising inexorably for nearly a decade, the number of bankruptcies filed by individuals is suddenly declining.
In five of the last six months for which data are now available, filings were markedly lower than a year earlier. Bankruptcy experts say that the new data indicate that a significant shift has occurred. 
 Why this is happening and what it portends, nobody is quite sure. Although some skeptics see the data as a sign of greater caution by consumers who have been unwilling to overextend themselves, many experts believe the trend may presage an era of greater spending by consumers who feel less squeezed than in years past.
Lenders, accountants, economists and credit counselors who are still pondering the development might welcome it all the more -- if they could explain it. They offer many theories, however.
To the behaviorists, it suggests a new era of fiscal sobriety among consumers after a binge of borrowing. At the same time, they see more sophisticated management of credit risks by banks, which have become more careful about lending but also less aggressive about collecting debts from distressed customers.
 
A Recovery or Not?
 To some soothsayers, the reversal augurs a burgeoning recovery. Prosperity naturally fosters consumer confidence, they say, and a decline in bankruptcies goes hand in hand with a firmer job market and an increase in personal incomes. (Never mind that the upward march of bankruptcies coincided with the remarkable economic expansion of the 1980's.)
To number-crunchers, the reversal results inevitably from lower interest rates. These have allowed households to refinance debts on more favorable terms, improving cash flow and staving off financial collapse.
And maybe, like every statistical streak, the rise in bankruptcies contained the seeds of its own destruction: four million bankruptcies in the last six years just might mean that the nation's supply of deadbeats is starting to run low.
Whatever the reason, the change in the number of bankruptcy filings is distinct enough that Ed Flynn, the statistician of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts, which released figures last week for the first three months of the year, called the latest data "a dramatic turnaround."
Bankruptcy filings by individuals took off in the early 1980's. The number of filings doubled during the Reagan years and by 1992 had reached 900,000 a year, triple the number in 1984. Beginning in 1985, a new record was set every year.
But now the monthly tallies are shrinking, and the trend persisted through the first quarter of this year, with bankruptcies down 20 percent in January, 11 percent in February and 7 percent in March, compared with a year earlier.
Robert W. Johnson, senior research associate at the Credit Research Center at Purdue University, said the new data "would indicate that we are looking at a major shift in the trend in bankruptcies."
"I think it may reflect that we are coming out of difficult times, a sign of economic recovery," he said. "I don't think it is a change in people's basic habits and willingness to declare bankruptcy, or a change in ethical standards. But it is a sign that people believe they can handle their debts."
 
Is a Spending Boom Coming?
 He is among those who think this means the consumer is gearing up for another round of spending that could buoy the economy, although others think just the opposite.
Stephen Brobeck, executive director of the Consumer Federation of America, said the reversal resulted not from an economic revival, but from "a combination of lower interest rates and more prudent consumer expenditures."
"For tens of millions of American households the recession continues," he said. "Basically, it's the morning after the party. Most people have a slight headache. Some are even having difficulty getting out of bed."
Sam Gerdano of the American Bankruptcy Institute, which called a news conference to hail the statistical development, said that the shift in bankruptcy filings is probably largely a result of a marked decline in the percentage of earnings that the average consumer must spend on monthly debt payments, in light of lower interest rates. Encouraging the trend: Many homeowners in the last year have refinanced their mortgages and are using the monthly savings to reduce credit-card balances and other consumer debt.
The debt-service payment ratio, as this economic measure is called, is considered one of the best measures of financial stress on consumers. It started to rise just before bankruptcies began to climb, going from about 15 percent of income in 1983 to about 18 percent in 1990.
At such levels, Mr. Gerdano said, consumers "just cannot take on any more water." And finally, in 1991, the debt-service ratio turned the corner. It now stands at roughly 16 percent.
 
Change in Bankruptcy Laws
 It seems logical that fewer people would file for bankruptcy at a time when less of their income is consumed by paying monthly credit bills. But other analysts said this was probably not the only explanation for the new trend.
"I don't think the debt-service ratio explains it," said Philip S. Corwin, director of retail banking at the American Bankers Association. "It explains some increase, but it does not explain a tripling" in bankruptcies in the last decade.
The bankers say the long-running increase is mainly a result of passage of a new bankruptcy law that took effect in 1979, which made personal bankruptcy easier and more attractive economically, because it allowed the filers to retain more of their personal assets. And Mr. Corwin said that despite the latest numbers, the bankers fear that what is happening now is a leveling off at a lofty plateau, not a major decline.
Mr. Flynn, the statistician for the bankruptcy courts, said that in past cycles bankruptcy filings had fallen back just 10 percent or 20 percent from their cyclical peaks, which suggests that 700,000 or 800,000 new bankruptcies might occur each year.
But it is hard to say how many distressed debtors are still waiting in the wings.
"I think the overriding factor is that those people who have found it necessary to file, have already filed," said Jack Salomon, a partner at the accounting firm of Grant Thornton. "Now it is just the stragglers, the people who have tried to work it out and failed."
Both he and Mr. Corwin said that the banks might have become more flexible in helping people arrange to repay debts without going bankrupt.
"We are trying to put out the word that if you have a credit repayment problem, come talk to us; we will work with you," said Mr. Corwin of the bankers' group. "We can work things out outside the bankruptcy courts, which is better for everyone."
Not necessarily, said Mr. Johnson of Purdue's Credit Research Center. Consumers learned in the 1980's that declaring bankruptcy not only could make economic sense in the short term, but that it did not necessarily ruin one's credit.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
In a New Television Campaign, Perrier Tries to Ride a Wave of Tiny Bubbles to a Rebound in U.S. Sales.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
THE American marketer of Perrier hopes to put the fizz back into lagging sales with advertising that celebrates something much more basic than the brand's cachet: its bubbles.
A series of television commercials, which begin running this week, are silent but for the sounds of a bottle opening, the effervescence of the mineral water within and a glory-hallelujah wave of "Aaaahhhs" from an unseen choir. To give the carbonation added character, special effects make objects on screen -- city lights, golf balls, sunflowers -- rise to the sky, bubble-like, as each bottle is uncapped. 
 The commercials are the first for the Perrier Group of America since its French parent, Source Perrier S.A., was acquired last year by Nestle S.A., which subsequently consolidated the brand's worldwide advertising at Publicis-FCB Communications in Paris. The campaign, created by Publicis's New York office, replaces one by the Perrier Group's previous American agency, Waring & LaRosa, that portrayed the brand as omnipresent by deeming it "part of the local color" in bars and restaurants from the trendy Time Cafe in Manhattan to the prosaic Shake Shack in California.
"This campaign is a reaffirmation of Perrier, as opposed to the repositioning that some people might have expected," said Kim E. Jeffery, president and chief executive at the Perrier Group in Greenwich, Conn.
"Its tone is fun and light and somewhat magical," he added during an interview last week in which he provided a preview of the campaign. "It speaks to the exhilarating strengths of Perrier -- its bubbles, its simplicity, its naturalness."
Alan Platt, a vice president and group creative director at Publicis in New York, said that because the campaign was intended to "broaden what the perception of Perrier is, we're going back to what it is, a refreshing bottle of water that gives you a little lift."
"We want to get away from the 80's baggage," he added, referring to the sparkling water's lofty image during most of that decade, "and be more inclusive than exclusive." So the commercials feature people like a lithe young golfer in full grunge regalia (no shirt, baggy shorts, backwards cap and boots) and a trio of little girls.
Glen Jacobs, a vice president and group creative director who worked with Mr. Platt on the commercials, called them "our homage to the bubbles, which is where it all started; they're what set Perrier apart."
Mr. Jeffery is the first to admit that the Perrier Group is still struggling to regain the brand's momentum that was stopped dead by a recall in 1990 concerning benzene contamination. Sales in America, which reached $102 million in 1989, briefly fell to zero as 72 million bottles of Perrier were pulled off shelves.
Despite ambitious predictions that sales would rebound to pre-recall levels, they have yet to do so; while Perrier remains the nation's best-selling imported sparkling water, it lost its ranking as the No. 1 imported water of any type to Evian, the French nonsparkling brand. Perrier sales last year totaled just $60 milllion, though Mr. Jeffery said they were up about 10 percent so far this year.
"Very honestly, we thought it would take us less time" to recover from the "self-inflicted wound," he said, "but we had a recession intervene."
Jesse Meyers, publisher and editor of Beverage Digest, a newsletter in Old Greenwich, Conn., agreed that "Perrier has gone through some difficult times," adding, "It still has a way to go, and a way to grow, to make up for the recall."
Yet the Perrier Group "seems to be headed in the right direction," he continued, primarily because of "its new alliance with Nestle, which is worth a gazillion dollars," and the powerful bottlers who make up its distribution system.
The campaign is also the first to be completed by Publicis for any of the more than 100 countries where Perrier is sold. As a result, Mr. Jeffery said, "there's interest around the world to see what happens with this."
"The advertising may differ from country to country," he added, "but the core values will be similar."
The Perrier Group plans to spend $7 million on the campaign between now and the end of the year. By comparison, the company spent $6.1 million to advertise Perrier during all of 1992 and $4.9 million in 1991, according to Leading National Advertisers in New York, which tracks ad spending.
The commercials will run in 10 local markets that Mr. Jeffery estimated account for 50 percent to 60 percent of Perrier's sales volume: Baltimore, Boston, Los Angeles, Miami, New York, Philadelphia, San Diego, San Francisco, Washington and West Palm Beach, Fla.

HEADLINE: U.N. Talks Bring Haiti Leaders and Aristide Together in New York

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 27

 BODY:
United Nations diplomats began talks today in New York with senior Haitian political and military leaders and with Haiti's first elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, in an effort to restore him to power after 21 months of exile.
The negotiations, which came after continuing international pressure that brought tough new economic sanctions against Haiti's military leadership and its civilian allies last week, are being held on Governors Island, a tightly controlled military reservation in New York harbor. 
 Diplomats said the first stage of the talks did not involve any face-to-face meetings between Father Aristide and Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, the Haitian Army commander who led the coup in September 1991 in which the President was deposed and hundreds of his followers are believed to have been killed.
The conversations between the United Nations special envoy for Haiti, Dante Caputo, and the two adversaries were private, with few details passed on even to many of the diplomats gathered for the talks, which continued into the night.
 
Agenda Is Aim
 Instead, diplomats shuttled between the separate headquarters of Father Aristide and General Cedras and their large delegations on the island, seeking to establish an agenda centering on the basic goal of quickly restoring Father Aristide to office.
Mr. Caputo emerged from a three-hour meeting with General Cedras this afternoon to tell reporters, "If I may say so, I found on both sides a common ground, and this is not only to find a solution to the political crisis in Haiti, but to see that that solution will create a stable and durable democracy in that country."
Asked for an appraisal of the first day of talks, a member of Father's Aristide's delegation said: "Two inches forward, and then a freeze. I wouldn't even say three inches. We were hoping to see at least a foot of progress."
Diplomats said Father Aristide and General Cedras, enemies whose political stalemate has long had a bitter personal edge to it, would engage in direct talks only after significant progress had been made on terms for the passage of power.
Diplomats involved in the talks said they were cautiously optimistic about a breakthrough in the wake of the new United Nations sanctions, which are intended to block oil and arms supplies to the country and freeze the assets of supporters of the coup against Father Aristide.
A former Haitian official with close ties to the military said today that the armed forces had grown "extremely worried" about their ability to hold on to power in the face of the sanctions and had come to New York to "save their own skins."
The former official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that word had been spread among army officers in the Haitian capital, Port-au-Prince, that if General Cedras were arrested or not allowed to return to Haiti, as has been rumored, "everyone in the Lavalas movement should be rounded up" in retaliation. Lavalas, whose name comes from the Creole word for flood, is Father Aristide's political movement.
According to Haitian business executives with close ties to the Army, General Cedras, who has been offered an amnesty by Father Aristide, came to New York still hoping that he could preserve a place for himself in the Army. Failing that, they said, the general will seek some say over any shake-up or restructuring of the military. Diplomats and advisers to Father Aristide have said that they see no prospect of an arrangement that preserves a military role for General Cedras.
 
'Attempting a Dialogue'
 As he left Haiti for New York on Saturday, General Cedras said in a televised interview, "What we are attempting to do is to have a dialogue with him to see not only a proposal for his return, but to propose conditions by which he is to return, and in fact if that return can be possible."
Since his overthrow, Father Aristide has insisted on the removal of General Cedras from the armed forces. In recent months he has said the entire Haitian high command should be removed, along with the chief of police, as part of any settlement.
Diplomats said that two of the stickiest points of the negotiations, if the hurdle of General Cedras's resignation can be cleared, will be the restructuring of the armed forces and the naming of a new Government.
Haiti's Army-backed Prime Minister resigned this month, and some diplomats have expressed a concern that the sudden removal of all of the high command now would create a potentially unstable situation.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Worshipers Beaten in Haiti
 PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, June 27 (Reuters) -- Soldiers burst into a service at one of the city's largest churches today and began beating parishioners who held posters in support of Father Aristide, the state television reported.
The violence, at the church of Notre Dame, happened as the television was broadcasting a Mass in honor of Port-au-Prince's patron saint.
A few minutes after the beatings began, the television interrupted its transmission and rebroadcast a speech that General Cedras made on the eve of his departure for New York for talks with Father Aristide.
A priest at the church said at least 10 people had been arrested by soldiers in the incident.
Witnesses told the Haitian Press Agency that several elderly people were among those beaten by soldiers and armed civilians.
The incident began after some parishioners at the mass pulled out posters in support of Father Aristide and began shouting: "Long live Aristide! Down with the Army!"

HEADLINE: Deficit Taking Toll on Lawmakers' Dreams of Big-Science Projects

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 27

 BODY:
It took more than strutting astronauts and brilliant astrophysicists to spawn the miracles of moon walking, microchips and satellite communications. Congress wrote the checks.
But now the ink is running out. 
 The overwhelming House vote on Thursday to junk the Superconducting Supercollider proton-smasher was only the latest sign that the political consensus in favor of big science, wilting for years, has now virtually collapsed.
Only the day before, the House endorsed the remodeled smaller-scale Freedom Space Station by a single vote, and there is no assurance that the House will not reverse itself when it votes again on the program on Monday. The Senate is still a booster of space travel, but support is dwindling there, too.
 
Shift in Priorities
 Simply put, the very lawmakers who came of age marveling at "Star Trek" and "The Right Stuff" have scaled back their dreams of shaping the universe with space colonies across the galaxy. The Age of Tang has given way to the Age of Perot, and the budget deficit is the new target of choice.
Representative Jerrold Nadler, a freshman Democrat from Manhattan, noted the reluctance with which he voted against the space station by saying he had designed amateur rockets as a teen-ager. "But with a $4 trillion national debt, difficult choices must be made," he continued. "It simply does not rise to a high-enough priority level to compete with social service."
Actually, the shift in priorities has been long in the making. Twenty-five years ago, Congressional appropriations for scientific research made up 5.2 percent of the Federal budget, compared with 1.7 percent this year. In the meantime, programs like Medicaid, Medicare and Social Security that provide automatic benefits to everyone meeting certain criteria have ballooned to half of the budget.
"There is no lobby for the future," grumbled Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, the most prominent supporter in the Senate of the space station and the supercollider, which is being built in his state.
 
Jobs at Stake
 Tens of thousands of jobs are at stake in the two programs, which explains their bases of support in California, Florida, Louisiana and Texas, where the projects are being assembled. But while the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Energy Department have tried to spread out the contracts to as many states as possible -- often sacrificing efficiency for political expediency -- big science has only marginal economic importance to most states.
In the big-science heyday of the 1960's, jobs and other economic factors were not the primary incentives for exploration and development. Just as World War II gave a huge boost to nuclear research, the cold war set a national priority to beat the Soviets to the Moon and beyond. President John F. Kennedy blew the clarion call, and Republicans and Democrats followed as a matter of patriotism.
But with the collapse of the Soviet Union, and the defense applications of space and physics research now far less urgent, lawmakers are forced to grapple with the pure scientific pros and cons. Only a few members of Congress are scientists, and most come to Washington with only the faintest understanding of high-energy physics.
That makes the big, expensive projects hard to sell, especially when they are plagued by annual cost overruns.
 
Weighing Theoretical Benefits
 What is the supercollider, and what is it supposed to do?
Based 30 feet under the cotton fields and cattle pastures around Waxahachie, Tex., it was planned as a 54-mile oval tunnel with giant magnets designed to smash protons against each other. With any luck, it could discover new sub-atomic particles that could provide clues to the origins of the universe and lead to advances in superconductivity.
Many physicists hope that such advances could provide several spinoff benefits, from elevated, high-velocity trains to improved imaging for medical diagnostics. But, liberals ask, what about the homeless who crowd our cities? And conservatives wonder, how can a $11 billion ditch with annual budget overruns be justified when higher taxes are strangling small business and the middle class?
"We're expected to keep shoveling money into this project without even knowing how big a hole in the budget it represents," said Representative Sherwood Boehlert, the Republican from upstate New York who led the House forces against the project in the floor debate. "The benefits are distant, theoretical and limited."
Most House members agreed with Mr. Boehlert, and the project was defeated 280 to 150, a margin so resounding that it has already had repercussions in the Senate, where support for the project is wider but increasingly shaky. The Senate is expected to vote narrowly in favor of the supercollider in late summer, but it is highly doubtful that a House-Senate conference committee can resurrect it.
 
Backing for Humans in Space
 The $25 billion space station is easier to sell, not only because it provides more jobs in more states than the supercollider but also because space still captures lawmakers' imagination.
Representatives Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, and Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House minority whip, agree on little else but that the Government must continue to finance manned space travel.
"The space station will provide the opportunity for a permanent human presence in space," Mr. Gephardt said on the House floor before Wednesday's vote. "Investments in aeronautics and space programs are necessary to maintain our country's high-technology leadership and provide jobs."
Mr. Gingrich's imagery was downright cosmic. "The amount of money we are going to spend today is not decisive to the national debt, but it is decisive to our future in the universe," he said. "Fifteen years from now, when your children watch a Russian, or a Chinese, or a Japanese, or a European in space, and there is no American there, on this day you sealed our fate for a generation."
With all their combined fire power, the two leaders could manage only a single-vote victory, 216 to 215, authorizing the space station in Wednesday's vote. The House will reconsider the issue on Monday in a more critical appropriations vote, and a reversal is possible.
If so, the Senate is expected to save the project, at least for this year. But even proponents concede that prospects do not look bright for a project that is not due for completion until the turn of the century -- unless the budget deficit is brought under control.
