HEADLINE: Landscaper Admits to a Dozen Killings, Police Say

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
A 34-year-old unemployed Long Island landscaper, arrested after the New York State police discovered a body in the back of his pickup truck, has confessed to killing at least a dozen prostitutes and burying their bodies in remote parts of the New York City metropolitan region, the state police said yesterday.
They said the suspect, Joel Rifkin of East Meadow, L.I., described the string of killings after two state troopers found the decomposing body of a woman under a tarpaulin in his pickup truck when he was stopped for a traffic violation. 
 Maj. Anthony J. DiResta, commander of the state police on Long Island, said that "the degree of detail provided in the suspect's descriptions gives us reason to believe this may be the largest case of serial murder since the Arthur Shawcross killings" -- 11 murders in the Rochester area in the 1980's.
"All indications are that we have in custody a person who has committed multiple homicides," Major DiResta said. Other officials said Mr. Rifkin had given them a long list of approximately when he killed his victims and approximately where he left the bodies.
Law-enforcement officials from three states converged on the state police barracks in Farmingdale, L.I., hoping to establish connections between what Mr. Rifkin had said and unsolved cases in their files going back two years or more.
By last night, only one such connection had been made. John Gierasch, commander of the homicide unit in the Suffolk County police, said he had "reason to believe" that Mr. Rifkin was linked to a woman's body found on Route 59 in the Westhampton section of Southampton on May 9. He did not disclose what had led him to that conclusion.
The authorities began searching the ranch-style house where Mr. Rifkin lived with his 71-year-old mother and his sister, as well as locations on Long Island, in New York City and in Somers, N.Y. State police officials refused to give details of where they wanted to look in the three jurisdictions. But at the house, officers concentrated in the garage, where they clustered around a freezer. It was not clear what, if anything, they expected to find inside. Upstairs, other officers went through several bedrooms.
Investigators also took a flatbed truck to the Rifkin house last night. One official said it would be used to haul away Mr. Rifkin's other pickup truck, a twin of the one he was driving when he was caught, and two vans that he also owned. Early this morning officers were removing items from the house and garage and put a number of items, including a chain saw, into an evidence bag.
The horrifying discovery and the unexpected confession came after a wee-hours chase across Nassau County that began with a simple traffic violation: the troopers noticed that the suspect's tan Mazda was missing a license plate.
The chase that led to Mr. Rifkin's arrest began on the Southern State Parkway near the Wantagh Avenue exit at 3:15 A.M. yesterday and gained speed as he ignored orders to pull over that the troopers yelled through a loudspeaker. It ended 20 minutes later and about 10 miles away when Mr. Rifkin slammed into a light pole on Old Country Road at Washington Avenue in Mineola, L.I.
Capt. Walter Heesch of the state police said that as the troopers were handcuffing Mr. Rifkin for the license-plate violation, they realized that a foul odor was coming from the enclosed back end of the truck. One trooper pointed a flashlight in and reached under a tarpaulin that was covering the woman's body.
"He just put his hands up," said Trooper Sean Ruane, one of the officers who arrested him. "I said, 'Get out.' He got out of the car and just lay down on the ground. He never said a word."
Captain Heesch said Mr. Rifkin told investigators that he was on his way to bury the woman's body at Republic Airport in Farmingdale, L.I., when he was stopped. Captain Heesch said that the body appeared to have been "in a state of decomposition for three days." Major DiResta said that the woman had been strangled.
Captain Heesch said Mr. Rifkin told investigators that all of his victims were "New York City prostitutes, taken off the streets of New York City."
 
Sex and Murder
 Captain Heesch said Mr. Rifkin told investigators that the woman whose body was found in the back of truck was a prostitute he had patronized, apparently on Friday night in Manhattan.
Her identity was not immediately available. But the captain said her description was like that of the other women Mr. Rifkin said he had had sex with and then killed: they all were white and from New York City. The captain would not release the identities or ages of the women that the authorities believed matched the murders that Mr. Rifkin said he had committed, but said that investigators were reviewing cases from at least the last three years.
The New Jersey state police sent two detectives from its major crime unit to join the investigation. They had one case in particular in mind: the two-year-old unsolved murder of a woman whose badly decomposed body was found near an exit ramp on Interstate 80 in Sussex County, not far from an area truckers use as a rest stop.
The victim was known as "the tiger lady" because of a tattoo on her calf showing a leaping cat. "We were particularly interested in this one because the body was found along an interstate in close proximity to New York," a spokesman for the New Jersey state police said last night. But it was not clear last night whether there was any connection to the Long Island case.
New York City detectives were also sent to Long Island yesterday to listen to the suspect's confessions and to get as much detailed information on each killing he had described as they could, said a police spokeswoman, Sgt. Tina Mohrmann.
There is no list of murdered or missing prostitutes to match the information against, the police said.
A check with the Missing Persons squad would also allow a detective in a Bronx precinct seeking to identify a body discovered there to learn that a missing person from Brooklyn answers the same description. Investigators will compare the information with computerized categories like unsolved female homicides.
But if a victim's body has never been found, that murder will not come up on the computer.
"It will involve a great deal of work, but the computer will make the work a great deal easier," Sergeant Mohrmann said.
Last night in East Meadow, where a room of the public library was named for the Rifkin family and where Mr. Rifkin's late father was a library trustee, neighbors were shocked after the police had roped off the Rifkins' ranch-style house.
A neighbor, Harold Reiter, described the suspect as a "pleasant young man" who was a little reclusive. But Mr. Reiter added, "He was never any trouble."

HEADLINE: THE SUPREME COURT: Reapportionment;
COURT QUESTIONS DISTRICTS DRAWN TO AID MINORITIES

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 28

 BODY:
A sharply divided Supreme Court ruled today that designing legislative districts to increase black representation can violate the constitutional rights of white voters.
The decision casts doubt on the redistricting that brought North Carolina its first black members of Congress since Reconstruction, and possibly on districts in other regions that have been given bizarre shapes to insure the election of minority representatives. 
 The 5-to-4 ruling gave a group of white North Carolina voters the chance to prove that the state's new 12th District is an unconstitutional racial gerrymander that violates the white voters' right to equal protection of the laws. The district connects small black population centers in a 160-mile ribbon no wider in some places than the interstate highway that it follows.
 
O'Connor for the Majority
 The decision overturned a ruling last year by a special three-judge Federal District Court in North Carolina, which dismissed the challenge on the ground that Supreme Court precedents made it clear that white voters generally have no cause for complaint about districts drawn for the purpose of electing blacks.
In her majority opinion, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor drew a different lesson from the Court's precedents. Noting that the Court had struck down districting plans that excluded blacks, she said, "It is unsettling how closely the North Carolina plan resembles the most egregious racial gerrymanders of the past." [Excerpts, page A12.]
A reapportionment plan linking people who live far apart and who "may have little in common with one another but the color of their skin," Justice O'Connor said, "bears an uncomfortable resemblance to political apartheid."
 
White's Final Day
 The majority opinion was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and by Justices Antonin Scalia, Anthony M. Kennedy and Clarence Thomas. Justices Byron R. White, Harry A. Blackmun, John Paul Stevens and David H. Souter all wrote dissenting opinions.
On his final day after more than 31 years on the Court, Justice White, who began his public career handling civil rights issues as a Justice Department official in the Kennedy Administration, said it was "both a fiction and a departure from settled equal protection principles" to regard the white voters as having a case.
Justice White noted that even with the creation of two black-majority districts in North Carolina, whites were still a majority in 10 of 12 districts, or 83 percent of the districts, while constituting 76 percent of the state's people. "Surely they cannot complain of discriminatory treatment," he said.
In ordering the District Court to give the white plaintiffs their day in court, the Justices left unanswered many questions about the breadth of their ruling today.
Justice O'Connor said there may be "wholly legitimate purposes" for concentrating members of a racial group in one or more districts while excluding them from others. She said "traditional districting principles" like keeping districts compact, contiguous and within existing political subdivisions could provide such a "race-neutral" rationale.
 
'Compelling Interest' Needed
 But the opinion cast doubt on the extent to which explicitly racial considerations of the sort frequently invoked in reapportionment cases, like the desire to remedy discrimination or avoid dilution of black voting strength, can justify districts that do not fit the traditional descriptions.
Justice O'Connor said the North Carolina district would have to be judged by the legal standard of "strict scrutiny" that the Court applies to discrimination on the basis of race. Under this standard, which can almost never be satisfied in practice, the state must show that a "compelling interest" made it necessary to treat people differently on the basis of race.
In one of the most potentially significant parts of the opinion, Justice O'Connor said that the fact that the North Carolina Legislature drew the disputed district to comply with the Federal Voting Rights Act was not, by itself, a "compelling state interest."
 
A Familiar Divide
 The state came up with the 12th District after the Justice Department had rejected an initial plan that provided for only one majority-black district, saying the state's black population was big enough to support two districts. The Justice Department's refusal to approve the plan under Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act left the state with the option of going to court or complying; the Legislature's response was to draw the 12th District.
Justice O'Connor said today that while "the states certainly have a very strong interest in complying with Federal antidiscrimination laws that are constitutionally valid as interpreted and as applied," compliance with the Voting Rights Act does not provide immunity from constitutional challenge or give states "carte blanche to engage in racial gerrymandering."
The white plaintiffs in this case had argued that if the North Carolina plan was in fact required under the Voting Rights Act, then the law itself was unconstitutional. Justice O'Connor said that the District Court would be free to consider this argument when it reconsiders the case.
She also said that a district looking like North Carolina's 12th District could not be defended automatically as a remedy for past discrimination against black voters, a defense that the state put forward in this case. "Racial gerrymandering, even for remedial purposes, may balkanize us into competing racial factions," she said.
The philosophical and constitutional divide on the Court in today's decision, Shaw v. Reno, No. 92-357, was familiar from the Court's bitter debates over affirmative action and similar race-conscious policies: whether distinctions made on the basis of race can ever be benign.
The dissenters stressed that white voters as a whole in North Carolina had suffered no injury from a relatively modest, though historic, step in equalizing power in the state. "The duty to govern impartially is abused when a group with power over the electoral process defines electoral boundaries solely to enhance its own political strength at the expense of any weaker group," Justice Stevens said, adding:
"That duty, however, is not violated when the majority acts to facilitate the election of a member of a group that lacks such power because it remains underrepresented in the state legislature -- whether that group is defined by political affiliation, by common economic interests, or by religious, ethnic, or racial characteristics."
 
Risks Are Seen
 In the majority's view, however, "racial classifications of any sort pose the risk of lasting harm to our society," as Justice O'Connor said today. She said, "The very reason that the equal-protection clause demands strict scrutiny of all racial classifications is because without it, a court cannot determine whether or not the discrimination truly is benign."
Justice O'Connor said that one injury that districts of this type inflict is to perpetuate racial stereotypes and exacerbate patterns of racial-bloc voting. In addition, she said, representatives elected from such districts receive the "pernicious" message that their job is to represent only their racial group.
"This is altogether antithetical to our system of representative democracy," she said.

HEADLINE: Talks in Japan Fail to Fashion Trade Accord for Clinton Trip

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 28

 BODY:
Negotiations to define a new trade relationship between the United States and Japan broke off tonight in a deadlock, making it almost certain that no agreement will by forged by the time President Clinton arrives here next week for a summit meeting of industrial nations.
The failure is a blow to President Clinton, who has made a tougher stance with Japan a centerpiece of his efforts to revive the American economy. When they met in April, President Clinton and the Japanese Prime Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, set a goal of developing a new framework to guide future talks on economic relations by the time the two men met again at the Group of Seven summit meeting.
 
Background of Upheaval
 With today's development, it appears that the meeting, which begins July 7, will be missing the announcements of two major agreements. Only last week, negotiators from the United States, Japan, Canada and the European Community failed to agree on broad measures to cut tariffs and revive global trade talks, although negotiators said there was still a chance that an accord could be reached. 
 Japan is expected to come under pressure from all the industrial nations at the summit meeting to reduce its trade surplus and help stimulate world economic growth.
The Japanese-American negotiations took place at a time of political upheaval in Japan, with elections coming next month that will probably change the Government. This situation may have made it difficult for the Japanese to make concessions, but participants on both sides said they believed the political situation did not slow down the negotiations.
The big split between the two sides came over America's demand for Japan to agree to the principle of numerical targets for opening specific markets and for cutting its trade surplus in general. The deadlock could damage already tense trade relations between the world's two largest economies. It might lead to increased calls in Congress or from American companies for steps to punish Japan or protect American industries.
"The relationship as it stands is badly corroded," a senior Administration official warned here tonight. "It is up to Japan where it wishes to see the bilateral economic relationship go."
The deadlock is also a sign of a shift in Japan's trading stance. In the past, Japan has always seemed willing to accommodate American demands in the interest of keeping good relations with a nation that it reveres as an older brother and which serves as a huge market for its cars and VCR's.
Japan said targets violated the principle of free trade. It also argued that it was impossible for a nation single-handedly to control its trade balance because that depends on the policies of trading partners as well.
Behind these philosophical arguments are more practical considerations. Washington believes numerical targets work, as shown by a market share target it attained in a semiconductor trade agreement. And Tokyo wants to avoid more such agreements and is drawing a line in the sand.
 
Japan Stands Firm
 American negotiators appeared to think that Japan, despite its publicly stated opposition to numerical targets in the last two months, would also yield once it reached the negotiating table. But during two days of talks here, Japan firmly stood its ground.
"They will be incorrect if they assume that Japan will always behave in the manner in which it behaved in the past -- yielding to pressure and compromising at all costs," a Japanese Government official said tonight. "This is not the kind of behavior Japan will be assuming in the future."
American and Japanese officials said tonight that the talks would continue, although no date had been set.
"Sometimes games go into extra innings," W. Bowman Cutter, the chairman of the American delegation, said at a news conference tonight. "We don't have any reason to believe we will not reach an agreement."
But Mr. Cutter, who is deputy assistant to the President for economic policy, said, "It would be difficult, but not impossible, to reach an agreement by the summit."
For Prime Minister Miyazawa, who lost a no-confidence vote in Parliament earlier this month and is now effectively a lame duck, the lack of an agreement might not mean much other than loss of one more chance to be in the spotlight.
For President Clinton, however, failure to establish the new trading relationship with Japan in the next few months could be seen as another broken promise.
 
An Overall Proposal
 The proposed framework would not be a specific agreement on market-opening measures. Rather, it is intended to be an overall proposal governing which issues will be discussed in the future and how they will be negotiated.
The framework would cover general issues like Japan's antitrust law and distribution system, replacing the existing series of talks known as the Structural Impediments Initiative. It is also expected to deal with specific sectors like autos and supercomputers. American trade practices, including "Buy American" programs, are also expected to be discussed.
The United States wants Japan to reduce its current-account surplus in a few years to 1 to 2 percent of its economic output from more than 3 percent now. In return, the United States is promising to reduce its Federal budget deficit by an amount already contemplated in President Clinton's tax and budget policies.
The American side, which maintains that Japan is far from a free trader, argued that numerical targets for access to Japan's markets would reduce trade friction because they would provide objective ways of determining whether a trade agreement was being fulfilled.
The United States has gradually softened its language on numerical targets, saying they did not have to have specific market shares but could be a variety of other quantitative and qualitative measures, like how many foreigners are on standards-setting bodies. Washington also said there would be no automatic levying of sanctions on Japan if targets were not met, although sanctions were not ruled out entirely.
 
Some Progress Made
 The two sides did make progress toward agreement on some categories for future talks. These include government procurement, regulatory reform, harmonization of rules in areas like intellectual property, and the carrying out of existing trade agreements. But Japan objected to the American idea of establishing a separate category for autos and auto parts.
The Japanese official said Japan was being encouraged to hold its ground by other Asian nations, which fear the United States will take the same approach with them. In addition, he said, Japan knows that many people in the United States are also against "managed trade."
Analysts have pointed out other reasons that Japan might be less willing to yield to American demands than in the past. A smaller percentage of its exports and investments are going to the United States as its attention shifts to Asia. And a new generation of Japanese leaders is less beholden to America for help in rebuilding after World War II.
American officials said it was too early to reassess their approach to trade with Japan. They said they hoped that Japan would eventually agree to the benchmarks as pressure grows on Japan from its trading partners. Japan has acknowledged its trade surplus should be cut.
"There is no disagreement among the parties that tangible progress is required," one American official said. "So we do believe we will come to an agreement on this."

HEADLINE: RAID ON BAGHDAD;
Clinton Overstates Impact Of Raid, His Aides Warn

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 28

 BODY:
President Clinton maintained today that the United States missile attack on Iraq had crippled its intelligence capacity, but senior Administration and intelligence officials conceded that he had overstated the case.
Mr. Clinton told reporters this morning that he had received a report from the national security adviser, Anthony Lake, "confirming that we did in fact cripple the Iraqi intelligence capacity, which was the intent of the action." 
 But senior officials said that while the attack on Sunday had destroyed the crucial wing of the walled six-story headquarters of the intelligence complex in the heart of Baghdad, it had not destroyed other intelligence-gathering networks.
The Administration has also expressed concern that a new showdown is looming over Iraq's refusal to permit weapons inspections by the United Nations.
 
Warning From Gore
 On morning television news programs, Vice President Al Gore warned Mr. Hussein not to retaliate for the attack. "If he does something that is prohibited under the United Nations resolutions, there will be a response," Mr. Gore said.
The complex that was attacked is the headquarters of Mukhabarat, the security arm and the domestic and foreign intelligence operation of the governing Baath Party, senior United States intelligence officials said.
The attack destroyed the communications and computer centers in the operations wing of the intelligence building, but neither Gen. Sabir al-Duri, the head of Mukhabarat and a close associate of Mr. Hussein, nor his top aides were believed to have been in the building at the time.
Mr. Hussein uses overlapping intelligence and security services to keep order, and the Administration did not attack the three other services.
 
The Assets That Remain
 They are the Military Intelligence Agency, which is in the armed forces' general headquarters and is headed by a half-brother of Mr. Hussein, Sidawi Ibrahim; the State Internal Security, which deals primarily with internal security, and Special Security, Mr. Hussein's personal intelligence police, which is across from the Presidential Palace.
Senior Administration officials said the target of the operation was Mukhabarat because that agency had plotted to assassinate George Bush during his visit to Kuwait in April. Kuwait has arrested 16 Iraqis in connection with the reported plot.
While insisting that the President had not intended to mislead anyone with his remarks, intelligence officials conceded that the main impact of the attack had been the disruption of his domestic rather than foreign operations. And a senior Administration official said Mr. Lake's briefing for Mr. Clinton had focused narrowly on the extensive damage to Mukhabarat, not to the broader issue of Mr. Hussein's intelligence capacity.
 
What Clinton Meant
 "We have done a good deal of damage to that building, which contains a good deal of communications equipment and computers," said one senior Administration official involved in the operation. "Clearly Iraq has an elaborate intelligence capability and an elaborate network. I don't think the President intended to suggest that Iraq doesn't continue to maintain an intelligence capability."
That view was echoed by Amatzia Baram, an Israeli expert on Iraq, who said in a telephone interview from Haifa, "This is mainly important as a psychological blow because it says we can get you in the heart. To say it is crippling is to say too much."
The President also sent Congress a letter outlining his decision to attack Babhdad.
"Based on the Government of Iraq's pattern of disregard for international law, I concluded that there was no reasonable prospect that new diplomatic initiatives or economic measures could influence the current Government of Iraq to cease planning future attacks against the United States."
He said any Iraqi violence, aggression or state-sponsored terrorism against the United States would result in "necessary and appropriate" measures to protect American citizens.
 
An Admiral's View
 Mr. Clinton's remarks this morning appeared to go beyond what Rear Adm. Michael W. Cramer, the chief intelligence officer for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told reporters Sunday.
Asked in a briefing about the impact of the attack on Iraq's intelligence network, Admiral Cramer said much of the communications capability, records, computer support and operations in the intelligence building suffered "major damage by this strike."
But he added: "I won't stand here and say that there aren't alternate facilities and alternate means that even the Iraqi Intelligence Service can go to and employ. But this is their headquarters, by far their most important facility, and it has suffered a major setback."
Mr. Clinton's sweeping statement about the significance of the attack was reminiscent of the assertions by President Bush and Gen. Norman Schwartzkopf during the Persian Gulf war that later proved to be untrue.
 
What Bush Meant
 In January 1991 Mr. Bush announced that allied bombers had "put Saddam out of the nuclear bomb-building business for a long time to come." A few days later, General Schwartzkopf said Iraq's ability to manufacture nuclear weapons had been "neutralized."
A few months later, the Bush Administration had to acknowledge that United States bombers had failed to destroy many of the nuclear sites that had been their targets, and that United Nations inspectors had uncovered secret nuclear installations and equipment.
The following January, Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, told a Congressional committee that Mr. Hussein could rebuild Iraq's ballistic missiles and nuclear, chemical and biological weapons programs within a few years.
Administration policymakers say they do not believe Mr. Hussein will retaliate immediately, or directly, for the attack on Sunday.
They are concerned, though, about his refusal to cooperate with United Nations weapons inspectors.
Officials said the weapons dispute would be handled through the United Nations. The Security Council warned Iraq last week that there would be "serious consequences" if Baghdad continued to prevent inspectors from setting up cameras to monitor the destruction of Iraqi missiles and from inspecting certain suspected chemical-weapon sites.

HEADLINE: Mandela and de Klerk to Send Similar Signals on U.S. Visits

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, June 28

 BODY:
Nelson Mandela's itinerary looks like (and is) a campaign tour: New York to Los Angeles, David Brinkley and "Good Morning America," fund-raising dinners and photo ops galore.
F. W. de Klerk's resembles (and is) the state visit of a lame-duck foreign leader. He will spend low-profile time with policy makers. 
 Except for a couple of poses with President Clinton, one at the White House and one when they come together on July 4 in Philadelphia to accept their joint award of the Liberty Medal, the two men plan to keep their distance. When asked, they will speak of each other more as rivals than as partners.
 
A Quest for New Investment
 All the same, the two South Africans arrive in America this week on a common mission: to reopen the economic spigots rusted shut by years of sanctions.
In their separate ways, they will be trying to persuade American business and the United States Government that South Africa is more stable than it looks, that the course to democracy is inexorable and that it is O.K. for America to come back.
Aides to Mr. Mandela said that as recently as a week ago, he had hoped to use this trip to formally call for the lifting of remaining international sanctions against South Africa -- the most important encouragement that he could give to American investors -- but whether he will do so is now uncertain.
The congress has said it will call for the repeal of sanctions only when an election date is firm and when a multiparty transitional committee has been created, with powers to keep the campaign fair.
The election date, next April 27, is due to be ratified by constitutional negotiators on Friday. The transitional arrangements are not likely to be in place before August, although a senior congress official said it might be enough for Mr. Mandela to call off sanctions if "the process is in motion."
While he is in the United States, Mr. Mandela will also be soliciting millions of dollars in cash, volunteers and technology to help his African National Congress wage an election campaign against President de Klerk's National Party.
Relations between the Government and the congress were strained again last Friday when white separatists smashed their way into the constitutional talks and occupied the building for two hours.
Mr. de Klerk was as much a target of the right-wing hatred as Mr. Mandela, but the attack -- and especially the Government's decision not to risk arresting the armed invaders on the spot -- have churned up a new cloud of suspicion that could make it difficult for Mr. Mandela to call off sanctions.
"It is very clear to us that the Government either has lost control of the security forces or the security forces are doing what the Government wants them to do," Mr. Mandela told reporters Saturday night before flying to a meeting of African leaders in Cairo.
 
21 Arrests Reported
 By tonight the police said they had arrested 21 of the several hundred invaders, not including any of their leaders.
President Bush ended Federal sanctions against investment in South Africa, but many American states and cities still refuse contracts to companies that invest in South Africa. South Africa is still denied loans from the World Bank and International Monetary Fund.
Congress officials say Mr. Mandela desperately wants to welcome American business and world lenders back, knowing a surge of investment will make it easier for the next government to deliver on promises of jobs, housing and schools.
"Internationally we are losing opportunities," said Patrick "Terror" Lekota, a member of the congress's governing board. "We see capital flowing to Eastern Europe that could be coming to us."
 
Help for Campaign
 Mr. Mandela also knows that announcing the end of sanctions is one of the best ways to get the respectful attention of American business people, from who he hopes to extract pledges of cash and equipment for his election campaign.
Mr. Mandela is to arrive in New York on Tuesday from Cairo. Beginning with a Wednesday breakfast with Mayor David N. Dinkins, he is off and barnstorming for two weeks: Washington, Philadelphia, New York again, Chicago, Los Angeles, Indianapolis and Atlanta.
He will put the touch on New York financiers, Hollywood moguls, black business people, churches and labor unions.
Mr. Lekota, who oversees the congress's election campaign, said he hopes the trip will generate donations of car telephones, computers, fax machines, mobile video equipment and about $20 million in cash pledges, as well as advice on polling and fund-raising and possibly lists of eager university students interested in working as campaign volunteers.
"We are looking on the trip of the president as the last trip to the U.S. before the election," he said, referring to Mr. Mandela, who is president of the congress. "We are targeting all sectors of the American society."
Mr. de Klerk is to fly into Washington on Wednesday to spend a few days with members of Congress, Administration officials, World Bank officers and others on the fine points of reopening the financial pipeline.
"The United States has a role to play in this, just as it played a role in doing away with apartheid," said Harry H. Schwarz, the South African Ambassador to Washington.
The Ambassador said Mr. de Klerkwould urge President Clinton to support International Monetary Fund lending to South Africa and to plump for an aid package from the major industrialized nations. He will also try to speed an agreement making American enterprises here eligible for United States Government investment insurance, and will meet with members of Congress who are considering retaining a code of conduct for companies doing business in South Africa.
"Mandela will do the public things," said a South African official here. "De Klerk will be working on the mechanics. After all, if de Klerk calls for the lifting of sanctions, no one will listen."'
